TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to introduce legislation that will require the National Registration Authority to provide all available information on registered chemicals.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, made under subsection 4C(1) of the Child Care Act 1972, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement about the concerns of the committee with this instrument.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The guidelines confer important discretions on the minister which are not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The explanatory statement advises that such review will eventually be provided by act. In the meantime, however, the guidelines are scheduled to commence on 1 January 1994 without any review. The committee has written to the minister about this apparent defect. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of our concerns.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, made under s.4C(1) of the Child Care Act 1972

SPEECH.PARA: The Guidelines confer discretions on both the Minister and the Secretary or an authorised officer. The Ministerial discretions appear to affect personal and commercial rights to a significant degree. The Explanatory Statement, however, advises that new child care legislation presently being drafted by the Australian Law Reform Commission will provide for AAT review of ministerial decisions. This is an appropriate safeguard. Nevertheless, the Guidelines commence on 1 January 1994. The Committee considers that it would be appropriate to amend the Guidelines to provide for AAT review from 1 January 1994 and has written to the Minister accordingly.

In addition, the Explanatory Statement gives no such assurance about decisions of the Secretary or an authorised officer. The Committee accepts that these discretions appear to be less important than those exercisable by the Minister. Nevertheless, the Committee has sought advice on whether AAT review would also be suitable for these decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, made under subsection 4C(1) of the Child Care Act 1972 with respect to the Minister's powers under subsection 4B(2) of that Act, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion no. 481 standing in the name of Senator Patterson for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) concerning the Australian Artists' Creative Fellowship.

SPEECH.PARA: I have put forward a notice of motion requesting information about details of the awarding of an Australian Artists' Creative Fellowship and, in particular, an unprecedented awarding of a second fellowship, which is permissible under the guidelines but which has been questioned by a number of people. I believe that the material, if it were to be tabled, would provide us with the opportunity of examining the awarding of those fellowships in detail.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan yesterday brought up an unbelievable furphy when he said that these scholarships are less per annum than our salaries. Our salaries are determined by an independent tribunal. Sometimes we do not always agree with that tribunal and we change the decision, not always in our favour, but that tribunal is independent, it is open, it is public and it is available for all to see.

These scholarships were set up and initiated by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. As we have discovered, Mr Keating suggested the first advisory panel. Senator McMullan said yesterday, `It cannot happen by a process of osmosis'. It does not happen by a process of osmosis, but there are some question marks hanging over that first panel that was established in the late 1980s because every single one of the seven persons that Mr Keating suggested was amongst the seven that Mr Holding recommended to the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. One would question whether that is an open and appropriate process. The arts community may have come up with alternative suggestions as to how to determine a panel. That is not casting aspersions on the panel or the people who have been on the panels over time.

What I have been questioning is the process—the process by which the panels are appointed and the process by which these awards have been determined. There is some question mark over the accountability in terms of whether minutes have been kept and whether we can know about those scholarships in detail so that the parliament, the public and the arts community can be assured that these prestigious awards are awarded with all due processes being fulfilled.

Senator McMullan indicated some concerns the government had about providing information on principles of privacy. In redrafting our notice of motion, I have attempted to ensure, and I believe I have ensured, that an individual's privacy will be maintained. We respect that, but we also believe that the parliament has a right to examine those documents and to ensure that the concerns that have been expressed in large numbers to me by people in the arts community are given due process and due consideration.

I would ask honourable senators, the Greens, Senator Harradine and the Democrats to consider suspending business of the Senate so we can actually debate the reasons why we need those documents more fully.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reiterate briefly what I said yesterday before I go on to make some new points. This debate about whether certain documents should be tabled is not the orthodox conflict that we have over such matters, and Senator Patterson has made that clear in her remarks. In this instance, it is not a case of the executive defending its privileges in conflict with the legislature. That is not the issue here today. The issue here today is the rights of a citizen compared to the rights of the Senate. I am not arguing that the Senate does not have the power to seek these documents—I think it does—I am arguing that it should not exercise that power which it has because it would not be the appropriate thing to do. There have been other times when we have had debates of great principle about whether such documents can be tabled, but that is not in contention.

PARA.TAB: So let us go to it. Let us look at the four things that are being sought. There is the application from Mr Tozer. I welcome the fact that it is now qualified in the way Senator Patterson referred to. Were it to be carried, I acknowledge that this is a better version, from my point of view, than that which was previously sought. So I acknowledge that point. Nevertheless, what extra information are we seeking apart from that which I have already tabled? What we need to know is—and Senator Patterson has not said anything other than that this is what she is seeking—what were the purposes for which Mr Tozer sought this application?

That is really not the issue for the Senate. The issue for the Senate is: what were the reasons for which he was given the application? The accountability requires us to know why the grant was made to this person so we can check whether those conditions have been met. The reasons for which he was given the grant are explicitly stated in the documents which I tabled yesterday; both the reasons for the first grant and the second grant are given in detail. That is the decision that the Senate needs to know so it can check whether that has been properly done. So no argument has been put about what extra information is being sought under paragraph (i) other than it is some sort of fishing expedition in the hope there might be something smelly. The reasons for which the money has been given were explicitly stated in the documents tabled yesterday.

The second point concerns the minutes of the meeting. I have said that to the best of my knowledge there are no minutes, so I cannot table those. It is not that I resist tabling them; they do not exist. Did they exist, we would need to know what decisions that body made in regard to those matters about which we are concerned, and they are explicitly covered in the report of that committee in its recommendations to the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the minutes?
—There should be minutes, in my opinion. I am not justifying the fact that—
—Were they burnt?

—I do not know. That is another sleazy insinuation, which is exactly what I would expect. Senator Patterson discussed the matter in a good, tolerant, polite manner. Senator Kemp should not lower the standard. I do not agree with Senator Patterson but she put her case properly. Senator Kemp is just being sordid and sleazy and he should keep out of it. We have the circumstances here. There should be minutes but there are not. Every relevant fact of the committee's view is on the public record and tabled in this parliament. So I cannot do paragraph (ii).

PARA.TAB: Concerning paragraph (iii), the documents pertaining to the appointment of members have been tabled. I do not accept the point that Senator Patterson wishes to make. There is nothing wrong with a minister expressing a view about who should be on a committee: every committee is appointed by the cabinet. The Australia Council is appointed by the cabinet, on my recommendation. It might have been cleverer if the minister had rung up and said, `Clyde, why do you not do this?' and there would have been no record. But he did not do that, he did the proper thing: he sent a written proposal and we have tabled it. To the best of my knowledge there are no other documents, but certainly that which the honourable senator most wants is there.

With paragraph (iv), concerning the names and addresses of the people, the names are in the documents I tabled yesterday. The only thing we have not got is where they live. Do we have to go and knock on doors? Is that what the Senate wants? Why do we need the addresses? What a ridiculous question. However, if people want the addresses, they are all well-known citizens, why do they not ring them up and say, `Excuse me, where do you live?'. But why would the Senate want all of this tabled? Of course the Senate is entitled to know who the people are who made this decision, and I tabled that information yesterday. It is all on the public record. It is so much on the public record that the people about whom these question marks allegedly exist have been protesting to Senator Patterson, saying, `Why are you saying these things about us?'. So no-one is in any doubt about who they are. They are writing letters to—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been praising her.

—They have not. They have been writing letters to the Age saying what a terrible thing she is doing and they are writing letters to her complaining about the things she has said in the Senate. I do not intend to go into that because it was correspondence to her. But those people are writing and complaining, and I do not blame them. They have been slurred significantly, and the important arms-length process of the Australia Council is under threat.

PARA.TAB: Can honourable senators imagine what will happen next time the Community Cultural Development Board makes one of its controversial recommendations? We will be in here saying, `Who is the committee secretary who made the application? Who sat on the committee? What is the name and address of the secretary of the Arts Council of the ACT?'. We will have all this being pursued again and I think we have to make a stand about our rights, but not here. The Senate has the right to seek this information but it should not exercise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that we should suspend standing orders so that we can discuss Senator Patterson's motion. We would like to discuss it for a very short time, once standing orders have been suspended. I think it does need to come to a vote. Firstly, we support these fellowships. We believe these fellowships are very important. This is a very good thing that the government has done and the fellowships should continue. We also understand and agree with the privacy considerations that the minister has expressed. They are very legitimate concerns.

PARA.TAB: However, we also believe that we ought to have the right to have a look at these documents—not publish them or disclose them—to see whether there is a problem. We can get the information through freedom of information and, even if we cannot, it is the Senate's right to have it and nobody is disagreeing with that. We believe that the privacy considerations are so important that they should not be disclosed, but that they should be made available to honourable senators, and that is what Senator Patterson has asked for. The suggestion that all personal details be deleted from the applications being made available is a good one, and we agree with that. That should certainly happen.

Secondly, Senator McMullan says that the minutes of that meeting do not exist. If they do not exist, fine, we cannot have them. There is no question about that. Thirdly, there have been some documents tabled and that is excellent. We have seen those and they are very interesting. Fourthly, in relation to the addresses, we agree that they should not be disclosed, but that they should be made available in case there is a problem. Senator Patterson believes there may be a problem. If there is not a problem, she is not going to publish those addresses.

If any honourable senator goes around to the homes of these people to harass them about this, he or she should be severely dealt with by the Senate and by the parliament, but honourable senators are not going to do that. There should be no reason why these addresses cannot be made available but not disclosed. They should not be published. There is no reason to do that and they will not be. We believe that this should be dealt with now and that it should be dealt with extremely expeditiously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Patterson) agreed to:

That General Business notice of motion no. 481 standing in the name of Senator Patterson for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) concerning the Australian Artists' Creative Fellowship, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That—
(a)the Senate reaffirms the constitutional principle that expenditure of public money must always be accounted for to the Parliament;
(b)in accordance with this principle there be laid on the Table of the Senate, by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), on or before 8 p.m. on 25 November 1993:

TAB.TAB: (i)applications for Australian Artists' Creative Fellowships submitted by Mr Geoffrey Tozer, from which all personal information within the meaning of Information Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act 1988 is deleted,
(ii)the minutes of the meetings of the Advisory Panel of the Fellowship at which the awards to Mr Tozer were agreed,
(iii)all documents pertaining to the appointment of members to the original Advisory Panel, and
(iv)the names and addresses of the members of the original Advisory Panel at the time at which the first round of fellowships was awarded; and

PARA.TAB: (c)notwithstanding anything contained in standing orders particulars of the addresses of the members referred to in (b)(iv), and applications for Fellowships submitted by Mr Tozer referred to in (b)(i) not be published but may be disclosed to Senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to hold up the chamber for much longer because we have been debating this issue and I know that the Australian Democrats want to move along as well. I am not going on a witch-hunt in this exercise. Grave concerns have been expressed to me, which may or may not be right, and I want to allay the concerns of a number of people in the arts community about the way in which the scholarships have been awarded. I repeat that I am in no way casting aspersions on those who have made the decision and I am in no way casting aspersions on those who have received the awards, despite what has been said in newspapers in letters to the editor. None of us like to examine closely these sorts of things because people sometimes feel offended or feel as if aspersions are being cast on them. Let me say on the public record that I do not in any way cast aspersions on the people who have been involved.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying is that, in some people's minds, a cloud hangs over the awarding of these fellowships. Some people in the arts community in particular have expressed to me considerable surprise that the original committee was solely the suggestion of Mr Keating when he was Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —We already know that.

—Let me say to Senator McMullan that I know that. Those people have expressed concern and they were quite surprised when that was tabled. It did not appear to be open and clear-cut for many people in the arts community. Other concerns have been expressed. To have it cleared up in my mind and then to put it to rest, once those documents are available I can say to the community, `I do not believe your concerns are justifiable. I have examined the documents'. Because we have put some caveats on the information and on the way it can be used, I will not disclose that information. I have been privy to information before that Senator Tate gave me and I have not abused that privilege, nor would I ever abuse that privilege.

PARA.TAB: However, I believe that it will enable me, as the representative of many of those people who have rung me, to make a judgment about whether this issue should be pursued further or whether they ought to be told that people tend to get offended or upset if they do not get grants and that some people will make complaints that are not legitimate. Significant concerns have been expressed about the awarding of the second fellowship to Mr Tozer. In fact, the guidelines say:

SPEECH.PARA: In exceptional circumstances a new Fellowship may be granted at the end of the first. This could occur if a Fellowship proved to be especially rewarding for the artist and the community at large. No artist will be able to receive more than two Fellowships.

There is no doubt that Mr Tozer is an outstanding pianist and has a world reputation, but we believe, from the documents Senator McMullan tabled yesterday, that Mr Tozer was planning to open a music school. That was one of the objectives of using the $200,000 grant over a period of four years. We want to know whether that music school has been established. According to my advice, it has not. It is purported that Mr Tozer apparently bought a property in Queanbeyan for that purpose. That property is being sold on 27 November, this weekend. If that is what he said in his application that he was going to do, it would appear that he has not actually achieved it.

PARA.TAB: If there were exceptional circumstances for him then to be awarded a further sum of more than $300,000 over a five-year period, Mr Tozer will have had, over the two fellowships, more than half a million dollars. That is a considerable sum of money. Either we must be able to ensure that that money has been awarded on the basis that he set out to do a task and he achieved that task or we need to know the process by which that decision was made. Senator McMullan has admitted that there were no minutes for the first meeting, which is very peculiar and bizarre. That involved $1.4 million of taxpayers' money and we have no minutes to show how that money was allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right. The decision was made at the Australia Council, which is minuted, and you have got the minutes.

—And it does not give us indications about the process that was involved. The minutes of the second meeting really do not enlighten us much about the process of how the decisions are actually made, nor does the agenda for the first meeting. Senator McMullan says that he cannot provide that. Okay, he has got that on the public record and he can record that when he responds to the motion I am putting forward for the return to order. But I would hope that this is a lesson for all people when they set up grants like this—that at least we have appropriate minute taking and accountability for taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the issue about documents pertaining to the appointment of members to the original advisory panel. I am presuming that Senator McMullan is saying that they are the only documents that are available and that Mr Keating, when he was Treasurer, did not actually write to arts communities asking for suggestions of names. I do not know whether he did. I would like Senator McMullan to ask whether there are any more documents about whether Mr Keating sought advice from the arts communities about people they thought were appropriate to make a decision on for very prestigious awards.

We are not questioning the awards. We are not questioning whether artists of calibre ought to be awarded fellowships of this nature. What we are again saying is that we are questioning the process by which it has been done. I would like Senator McMullan to check and come back and say that there are no more documents. He said once that there were no more documents. Maybe he has checked that and he could give that answer in response to the return to order motion.

The request for the names and the addresses of the members of the original advisory panel at the time when the first round of fellowships was awarded, I think, is a reasonable request because, again, it is for my information only and it will clarify any concerns that people have expressed to me about the original advisory panel and put paid to any concerns that people have expressed on that issue. It may be a totally minor matter; it may in fact be of reasonable concern—again about the process.

I do not think these things I have requested are unreasonable. They are not all for public information. I hope, if the Democrats agree with me, that we can see those documents; that the concerns can be put to rest; that people can be assured that the process of the awarding of these scholarships is totally above board; and that we can be confident that those people that apply are treated equally and fairly, as, I am sure, people on the committee would want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, to be charitable, I take at face value that Senator Patterson wants this information for the reasons she says, in which case she is setting a dangerous precedent, by mistake rather than deliberately. Let us be charitable and say that, because I have no reason to suggest otherwise. First of all, I welcome the fact that Senator Bourne has given her support to these fellowships because I regard—
—So have I.

—I welcome that; I was not clear until the honourable senator made that interjection. I welcome it because this process is undermining the credibility of those grants. We have had people coming in here to try to dramatise their point by saying, `Shock, horror, this person has got, in the first grant, $180,000 over four years and, in the second grant, $325,000 over five years'. That is why I made the point yesterday that one can dramatise, inflate and give a shock-horror impression about these figures. I made the point, which some people did not like, that it is significantly less than, for example, everybody here gets paid. I am trying to make the point that what we are saying is that these are fellowships that give some proper recognition to outstanding Australian artists who have made an enormous contribution, and enable them to make a subsequent and continuing contribution.

PARA.TAB: I welcome and strongly support the initiative that the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), took in initiating it. It is no secret that he took the initiative. Everybody calls them, in the vernacular, `the Keatings'. Maybe the Prime Minister wishes they would not call them that, because they are supposed to be the Australian Artists' Creative Fellowships and I assume, in time, they will take their proper name. But there has never been a secret that he took a very strong proprietorial interest in this proposal, that he regards it as important. I do, but I do not claim any credit for initiating it. I was merely a supporter. The Prime Minister initiated it when he was the Treasurer. Why should we be surprised that he took a bit of interest in how it works and made sure that it worked well? I have to say to honourable senators that, when the extra people were appointed on this occasion, they will not find tonnes of documents. I did not write out to 100 people calling for nominations. I talked to a few people; formed a view about the balance of the committee and what areas of art form were needed; and made decisions and recommendations which were approved in the proper and normal process. So inadvertently, at best, we are putting in some jeopardy community support for these important fellowships. That was the first thing I wanted to say.

The second thing is that, in the debate about the original motion and now, we are creating the potential that the Senate is going to try to reassess the way in which these grants are made. Think about that, because what we are talking about is the same process that applies to every Australia Council grant. There are many controversial ones through this arms-length peer review process. I suppose that, if I were making the grants, there are some I would not make. But I do not have the capacity as minister to say, `I do not like that. Change that decision'. I do have the capacity to ensure, and the Senate is entitled to ensure, that the process was proper. But the arms-length principle is in jeopardy when the legislature says, `We want to take to ourselves the capacity to assess whether this committee should have made this grant to this person'. When people ask if all the people were treated fairly, what they are saying is, `Should it instead have gone to somebody else?'. That is the necessary implication, and it is very serious—more serious than we are, to date, giving consideration to.

I am very worried about the precedent we are setting here and I have to give some consideration to how I will react if the Senate carries this motion. But that is a problem for later today. What I am arguing now is whether or not we should carry the motion, and I am very strongly of the view that we should not. If we were going to put in jeopardy this great principle about arms-length and peer review—to which members of the opposition recently committed themselves, and I greatly welcome the fact; I am glad they did; but I am not sure if they understand what it means—there has got to be a pretty powerful reason.

What is the evidence that we need some extra information about Mr Tozer's application? The only thing that has been said—and it seems to blur—is that we will need to know whether some part of the reason he got the money related to the music centre. To the extent honourable senators need to know that is relevant, it is documented in what is already tabled, where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: A centre of music excellence is a long-term aim.
But above that, it makes quite clear the reasons for the grant in the following words:
to expand the musical horizons of the Australian community through additional recordings, the performance of works by lesser known composers and providing material for radio broadcasts.

In other words, it would enable musical activity to be undertaken that commercially could not be undertaken, because nobody could make a living by performing that music. But it was considered culturally important that he had the opportunity to do so.

PARA.TAB: Whether that is a better cultural reason than the reason that would have applied to the person who came eighth and missed out, I do not know. I think Geoffrey Tozer is an outstanding pianist, but I am sure some of the other applicants who did not succeed were outstanding, too. What I am saying is that we should not be inquiring. If we are going to have an arms-length process and say, `Politicians are not going to put their arm into this process—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the government.

—The honourable senator thinks it is all right for the opposition to put its arm in, but not the government. What I am saying is that the arms-length peer review process does not mean that the government cannot do it but the opposition can. The parliament should not. It is no better and probably significantly worse—but certainly no better—for the arms-length peer review process to be conducted by a parliamentary committee. I think we should make it very clear to the arts community that that is what is envisaged here—that we are now going to have a parliamentary process for deciding the relative merits of who should have got an arts grant. That is very dangerous. I do not dispute—
—So you could never question it?

—We should not question the artistic judgments as to whether this was the right thing. Of course, the honourable senator is entitled to ask, `Was there corruption?', but she has not just stuck to the process. She does not understand. I regret to say that she does not understand the implications of what she is doing. I am prepared to give her the benefit of the doubt that she does not understand and to say that, if she did understand, she would not do it.

PARA.TAB: It is a source of serious concern, and will be to the whole of the Australian arts community when they understand it, that every time the Australia Council makes grants and people are concerned about it, we are opening the possibility for the parliament to go in and look at the relative merits, under the guise of process. Did anybody on the committee know the secretary of the Turkish theatrical society that got a grant? At the end of the day we will find out that they did not, but we will have had a day investigating whether that society should have got the grant.

I often have to debate in public with media people the nature of grants made by the Australia Council. I have open to me always the option of saying, `I did not make it, it was at arms-length', but I am happy to go in to bat for these grants, even ones that I myself would not have made, to try to put the case for why we have to be tolerant and have diversity and recognise the right of the arts to be controversial and to do things with which even ministers for the arts are uncomfortable. I am happy to argue that. But how is it going to continue if the people making the decisions know that those decisions are going to come here, under the guise of review of process, and they are going to be attacked about that, and that the names and addresses—I accept that those opposite are trying to protect the addresses; I will come to addresses in a moment—of the people who made the committee are going to become the subject of debate? The names of people on those committees who made this decision are already public; they are not secret and were tabled in the parliament yesterday. So I am not quite sure why we are being asked to do it again. But their names are going to become the subject of debate and they are going to have to write letters to the Age defending themselves, saying, `I acted properly and how dare you imply that I did not', as John Bryson did yesterday, or write to senators complaining about how their reputation has been impugned, as one of the others did yesterday.

We do these things easily here and do not consider what it means to the people about whom we are doing it—what this means to Geoffrey Tozer, to Ross Gengos, to John Bryson, and to the other outstanding Australians on that committee. I am sure they are not ashamed of having their names on it, but there are question marks over this process. And then those opposite say, `We are not casting any aspersions on the people'. How can they say that the Prime Minister had undue influence on the decision but that the decision makers did not do anything wrong, when their brief is to act at arms-length? Either they are saying that they did something wrong or they might have done something wrong—or why are those opposite asking?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the process.

—But the honourable senator's implication is that the Prime Minister had undue influence or that there was something else wrong. There cannot be something wrong with the process if every individual within it behaved properly. Those opposite cannot say, `These citizens, these distinguished Australian artists, all behaved with propriety and in accordance with the arms-length peer review process', because, if they acted properly in terms of arms-length and peer review, those imputations that those opposite are making cannot be true. They can be true only if they did not act in accordance with arms-length and peer review. That is why they are offended and that is what those opposite do not understand, and it is why we should not proceed any further down this track.

PARA.TAB: I now want to go to the detail of the information. I will reiterate it only briefly because I said it in substance in my comments about why we should not suspend standing orders in the first place. I accept that people say that suspending standing orders to debate the motion is legitimate. I wish it were otherwise, but I understand that. However, it is different from actually carrying the motion. What possible public policy concern is served by making available the addresses of these people? Nobody has said that there is anything we are chasing about this. Were all these people shacked up together? Is that what we are trying to say? It is absurd. They are all on the electoral roll, if we need to know. I do not understand this. Why are we having a debate here about where Betty Churchill is? It seems bizarre. Why are we doing it? Not one reason has been put forward.

We are chasing four documents. In regard to the first one, all the relevant information has been tabled, that is: why did he seek this money, why was he granted this money and did it relate to this music centre? To the extent that there is any information that is of proper public purpose—and I accept that the reason why he got the money is a proper public purpose for the Senate to know about—it is on the table. We have said that. The official reason and the form of the letter that went with it are on the public record. Nobody has said what extra information is being sought. That extra information is not denied.

The second document we are seeking does not exist. The honourable senator is welcome to ask for it if she wishes. I will write back to her and say that it does not exist. If she wants to carry paragraph (ii), I do not mind. I do not know why she wants to do it, but if she wants to carry it, I cannot pretend that there is any offence in that. The third thing sought is all documents pertaining to the appointment. To the best of my knowledge, they have all been tabled. Certainly to the extent that there is any imputation of wrongdoing—I think there is none—to the extent that the honourable senator wants to make that point, that which she alleges is on the record. I do not understand why she is excited about it, but if she is, she already knows it. As for paragraph (iv), the names are public, and asking for the addresses is ridiculous. So I say to Senator Patterson: having reaffirmed her right to do this, please do not do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this motion. We understand that if the minutes of that meeting do not exist, we cannot expect to see them. If those other documents have been tabled—and I believe they have—that is fine. In regard to the application, privacy considerations have been considered; they are in there. We are not asking for personal details. That has been taken out. Impugning of reputations can happen and does happen without the tabling of any documents. Documents have been tabled already. I hope nobody's reputation has been impugned because there is absolutely no reason so far for anybody's reputation to be impugned. If anybody deserves to have his or her reputation impugned, it will happen later. It has not happened now, it should not have happened now and I certainly hope it has not happened now.

PARA.TAB: We are merely asking if these documents will be put on the table. They are not being disclosed to the general public, they are not being given to the newspapers. They are being put on the table merely so that other senators can have a look at them. That is the only thing we are asking to be done. The same goes for the addresses. I do not know what Senator Patterson's reason is. One would have to ask her what her reason is for doing it, but if she has a reason to do it and she does not want to publish these addresses further than on that table, that is fine—put them up, put them on the table. If she or any other senator goes out of this place and uses them inappropriately, if she or any other senator goes out of here and harasses people in their homes, rings them up—does any of this stuff—then they should be dealt with, I should be dealt with, we all should be dealt with by the Senate for doing that. That would be an outrageous use of those addresses. Senator Patterson has a concern. We merely want these documents put on the table, so that she can have that concern allayed.

I support these fellowships. I have no problem, we have no problem, with the current Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, having recommended them. That is a good idea. I have no problem with any senator or member recommending this sort of thing. In fact, I am considering recommending a couple myself. I do not know how far they will go, but I think it is a very good idea. This is the sort of stuff we should have. People should be innovative; people should be able to recommend people. If something as good as this gets as far as cabinet, if it gets as far as being instituted, great. We have no problem with that and we support these grants as far as they can go. We also support the motion that these documents, with the privacy considerations taken into account, be laid on the table.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (ISOLATED AREA ZONE EXTENSION) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Panizza) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide for an extension of the definition of isolated areas to include the seas situated in certain adjacent areas.
Motion (by Senator Panizza) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill seeks to amend an anomaly in the Income Tax Assessment Act in the implementation of the rebates allowed in disadvantaged remote areas as designated by Zone A and Zone B.

The rebate available through Zone A and Zone B, as defined in the present legislation, ceases at Australia's shore line or the shore line of an off-shore island. This means that any man-made construction such as an oil rig or oil and gas platform in those seas off the shore of either Zone is not regarded as being part of that Zone.
The legislation was drafted before such expansion of engineering and technology to erect ocean installations.

By this bill the problem areas will be covered by extending the land areas in Zone A and Zone B by an imaginary line from the shore point parallel to either the Equator or lines of longitude out to Australia's territorial limit.

It is interesting to note that the government has amended the Income Tax Assessment Act to include these very situations that I am addressing in the provisions for fringe benefits tax. So this is an opportune time to address this point for Zone A and Zone B, so that claims for rebate can be made by those living and working in those areas for the specified time in each year.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Faulkner) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the business of the Senate notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Newman, relating to the disallowance of guidelines concerning child-care accreditation, moved forthwith.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, do I now seek leave to make a statement or do I just proceed to?
—Why do you want leave?

—I have been given to understand that I could now make a statement, and I am pleased to accept your advice, Mr President, so as to explain why the understanding we had that this notice of motion be brought on today should proceed.
—Senator Crowley, you can seek leave to make a statement.
—We would welcome a statement as to why the government thinks it is necessary to bring this matter forward.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President, and I thank Senator Hill. There are a number of reasons why I think this motion should be put today. First of all, it was set for debate within this period of time, on a motion by Senator Newman. It was only when Senator Newman became ill, as I understood it, that the motion was deferred to 8 December. I have since discovered—
—No, she moved it in October.

—And Senator Herron moved an extension of it. I have to say that there is a confusion in my mind about this motion, and I am happy to accept what the opposition senators say on this matter. But Senator Hill asks why, and I will be happy to tell him.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, there was what was described as a march—I did not see it; I read about it today—on this place by a number of people from a certain section of the private child-care industry. I know that some of those people came into Parliament House. I know that, because they physically abused one of my staff—a matter I find totally unparliamentary and quite unacceptable. But that is just the evidence I have that many of those people were here. Some people here would know that I was caught up in other things yesterday. I did not get to know that march was on or have the opportunity to meet those people.

Properly they were here because they understood the debate was on today. Indeed, until this morning, the debate was expected to come on today. On all the advice I had from the whips' meeting, I understood there had been an acceptance that this debate would happen today. If I have got that wrong, I will accept that I have got a wrong understanding of it. Certainly, there was a campaign that was whipped up focusing on today: a march to this place yesterday, and with a certain number of honourable senators, other than me, very busy in the last few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Weren't you busy?

—Yes, I was very busy, but I do not wish to say that I was busy on the same business, Senator Macdonald. Why I think it is important, and why I would ask the Senate's support for bringing this debate on today, is because of the huge level of anxiety and fear out in the community that has been created as a result of serious misunderstanding about what this accreditation process is.

PARA.TAB: I would not mind if there was just some confusion. I could perhaps accept just some confusion. It is the business of the government to explain what the accreditation process is about and it is the business of government to counter any campaign to oppose the matter or spread misunderstanding. But I find it very unacceptable to deal with the threats and the viciousness of this campaign. That is one of the things that shock me. I was appalled to be advised that some parents have been rung up and told, `We know which child-care centre your children go to'. That is totally unacceptable. I am not talking about one person; many have been told by people who purport to care for our children, `We know which child care-centre your children go to'. I say to honourable senators: it took my breath away. It took my breath away that that is the level of this campaign. That is the sort of thing that I would want to lay to rest, Senator Hill. If we go back to debating this issue on its merits, I have no dispute about it. But to have people, in the name of some kind of campaign, running threats and vicious campaigns like that is unacceptable.

The misinformation is all the way from sublime to ridiculous. I have to say—I hope I have already made it clear—that it is my business, in this case, and that of government to make sure that people have the facts. It is my responsibility to iron out the confusion. It is my business to counter the nonsense that Senator McGauran is running around with. I am assisted by senators who say that I am the minister for cancelling Christmas. Most people would know that that is a nonsense. Most people who understand that are quite right. We are not cancelling Christmas. We are not cancelling Christmas carols. We are not stopping little boys playing with trains and trucks. It is a measure of the opposition senators, the National Party senators, that they would sink to that level of nonsense, but it is not without precedent in their ranks.

I do not mind dealing with that nonsense. I am prepared to talk to the community at any time about the facts, but I find it absolutely unacceptable that riding just underneath this so-called legitimate campaign is this appalling attack by people who purport to care for children: they are threatening parents, threatening people working in the child-care industry, with lines like, `I know where your child goes to child care'. I cannot think how much lower they can go than that. That is one of the most important reasons, I believe, that this debate should be brought on now.

I think it is also very important to help people in the community know that they can proceed with their child-care just as they are doing now. These guidelines are a description from the child-care industry itself of what is good practice in child care—what most child-care institutions are providing now, but some are not. That is what we are talking about, not the madness and nonsense that have been whipped up. Most importantly, because of that anxiety, we have people now very confused about what is the case.

I think a very good case can be made for why we should bring the motion on soon. I would have to say, just as another matter, that one of my colleagues in South Australia had his office extensively covered with what is known elegantly as graffiti; it was smear painted with anti-child-care accreditation slogans. We are getting a bit carried away in the community if this is the level the debate has gone to. For these sorts of reasons, I suggest that there is a very good case for bringing on this disallowance motion forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Crowley, with respect, is confused. The government two days ago said that it was going to bring on this motion today. There was no consultation with the opposition in this matter—none whatsoever. The government said that it was going to bring it on. I was out at the front of the parliament yesterday when those parents arrived. Senator Crowley has just said that it is the business of government to counter confusion—not to consult with the parents, which it should be doing. The government should be meeting those people. There were 21,000 signatories on petitions from parents, and it needs only a few more thousand to actually have a referendum on this matter in the country. If that is what the government wants, that will occur, because the parents are so outraged with the guidelines that have been put forward—and I do not wish to debate the guidelines at this moment. I will leave that for an appropriate time.

PARA.TAB: There is confusion out there—I agree with Senator Crowley—and it is of the government's making. And there is fear in the community. The parents are only just becoming aware of it. For example, this is in the government's guidelines:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unsatisfactory that there is a constant repetition of Christmas songs as background at the end of the year.

Can the government understand that two busloads of parents came up yesterday when they became aware of this through the media? Can it blame them for coming up? I was appalled when I read that, but I had no idea that this reaction from the community would exist. Senator Crowley saw them on the media. It is not confusion. It is there in black and white. I can interpret that as easily as anybody else, but the parents are only just becoming aware of the social engineering that is presented in these guidelines; and we will leave that to another time.

PARA.TAB: I think there should be further time—not to counteract the confusion but to have further community consultation. That is all that is intended by the postponing of this debate until 8 December. There is no reason why it should occur today. Senator Crowley has not advanced any argument why it should be today, except an argument about due process when the motion was given—but no reason to do with community consultation. The only reason she gave was that one of her staff apparently was abused. I am not sure whether that was verbal or physical, but surely that is completely extraneous to this matter. I would put in a report to the security officers of this place, if that were so. That is a complete diversion in relation to this matter.

Certainly there is confusion, and there is no reason why this should be brought on today except, as the honourable senator mentioned, for some sort of procedural matter. My understanding, as I said, is that we were told two days ago that it would be brought on today. There is no reason why it cannot be brought on on 8 December, as was foreshadowed in the original notice of motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I listened very closely to Senator Crowley's explanation of why the disallowance motion should be brought on now and not on 8 December, as was the sitting date prescribed by the notice of motion. Her explanation seemed to me to be that the community was confused and that the answer to that confusion would be to race this disallowance motion through in the midst of that confusion, not giving the people some explanation of what is in these accreditation principles. She is saying, `People can remain confused, but we are going to get this off the agenda because it is hurting us'. That is the real reason the government is trying to get this up and off the political agenda.

PARA.TAB: The thousands of parents and grandparents who are generally concerned about their grandchildren's childhood and their children's childhood remain confused, and the government just wants to block it—not give them any chance of an explanation, but just get it through, make it law and force these accreditation principles onto the community.

Ros Kelly and Senator Crowley have become the Calamity Jane sisters of the government, and they are causing the government terrible embarrassment. They are carrying on like the wreckers that they are. They have no political balance in this whatsoever.

I can read black and white, and it is very clear to me when something says `unsatisfactory'. It says that it is unsatisfactory for staff to provide stereotype toys such as trains, tip-trucks and bulldozers for boys, and dolls and tea sets for girls. One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar or even have a secondary education to understand that to do those things is unsatisfactory and, therefore, if they are done, there will not be accreditation.

I turn to Christmas carols. Senator Herron is a professional, a doctor, and he has got a very high reputation in Queensland as a surgeon. He is a man of immense integrity and he has a large family. He says that these principles and these guidelines remove the right to play Christmas carols continually, or whatever it is, in child-care centres, and his integrity can never be impugned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will note he has not said that.

—Senator Crowley will know that; she is a fellow doctor. She knows the reputation of this man and she cannot ever undermine that reputation. It is okay for Senator Crowley to have a go at the National Party. We do not mind. We are the defenders—with the Liberal Party—of the families of this nation. It is the Labor Party that wants to bring in some social engineering structure. And, if people are confused, it is the Labor Party's fault that they are confused. I am not confused because I can read. I can read black and white. The guidelines say that it is unsatisfactory to give little boys' types of toys to little boys and little girls' types of toys to little girls.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party has got to the very heart of this nation and it is no wonder there is an eruption. The childhood of our children is sacrosanct. All parents, be they Liberal, Labor, National or Democrat, would agree with that. It goes right over the whole political spectrum. They do not want their children to be socially stereotyped. Senator Crowley has not come up with an excuse. She just wants to get this off the agenda so that she can save the government some embarrassment. It is about time that she let the people out there circulate these things and understand them. They will not be confused; they will be outraged.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It goes very much to what Senator Herron said and it also goes to what I understood to be the intention conveyed to me about this matter by the opposition. If I have misunderstood that, make it clear. I am here to do what I thought was agreed to. My office has been in constant contact with Senator Newman's office. I would like to make it clear here that I am not doing this because Senator Newman is ill, as was imputed to me yesterday.
—Who said that?

—Somebody did, and it is disgraceful. I was very sorry to hear of Senator Newman's illness. Senator Newman's office has been in constant contact with me about this. Her office informed me on Tuesday of this week that the debate would be on Thursday this week—that is, today. Senator Newman's motion said, `In seven sitting days'. Subsequent to that, we had a phone call from Senator Newman's office advising us that Senator Herron had written to one of the clerks, Mr O'Keefe, moving for an extension to 8 December. We were advised by Senator Newman's office that, despite Senator Herron's letter, the debate for disallowance would be coming on today.

PARA.TAB: It is in the light of that constant contact with Senator Newman's office, and from what I understood from speaking to the opposition whip that I have proceeded to seek leave to move that this motion be brought forward today. I have not made all of this up. From all of the advice, and on following closely with Senator Newman's office, I was given to understand that the debate was on for today. I believe it was after the phone call from Senator Newman's office on Tuesday that Senator Herron wrote to the clerk moving a further extension of that disallowance. Subsequent to Senator Herron writing that, we heard from Senator Newman's office that, notwithstanding that, the debate would go ahead today. Senator Newman's office informed us of that letter. There is no other way we could have known about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been on the Notice Paper.

—Subsequent to that we did see it on the Notice Paper. However, we knew to look for it on the Notice Paper because Senator Newman's office told us that it would be there. This is not some plot by us. We understood, through constant contact with Senator Newman's office, that it was the opposition's intention to bring on this debate.
—Why weren't you dealing with Senator Herron? He is the responsible person. You are dealing with the wrong person.

—To that point, we had been told by Senator Newman—I am not sure when we were last in contact, but I am advised that it was on Tuesday—who was the responsible person at that time, that Senator Herron had written for an extension and that despite that the debate—
—You weren't told by Senator Newman; you were told by her office.
—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. Senator Vanstone is quite right: it was by staff in Senator Newman's office.
—She is not responsible; Senator Herron is responsible.

—Senator Newman's staff advised me, firstly, that Senator Herron had written to the clerk and, secondly, that it was their understanding—that is, Senator Newman's staff and Senator Herron's staff—which gave my staff to understand, that it would proceed. My staff have been talking to the opposition whip, and it was our understanding that the debate would proceed today. I have not made it up. There are very good reasons for bringing it on, but the principal reason is that that is what I understood to be the intention of the opposition.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been obvious confusion between what Senator Newman's staff said and what the Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) has been led to believe. I accept completely the statement made by Senator Crowley. I have been in control of this bill since the shadow minister, Senator Newman, went off on leave. I was not contacted by Senator Crowley's office, and that should have been apparent. I am unaware of any conversations that have occurred between Senator Newman's office and the minister's own office, and that should be perfectly clear.

PARA.TAB: I moved to defer the motion until 8 December for further consultation. Whatever occurred between Senator Newman's office and Senator Crowley's office is no business of mine. Quite rightly, Senator Newman's office notified the minister of that. So I think that should be clarified. I was not aware of anything to do with it, and Senator Reid as whip may speak from the point of view of the whip's office. But surely the answer to it is to put it off, as my motion requested, until 8 December so that further consultations can occur.

The premise in my original statement this morning still holds. I can see no difficulty with extending it and allowing parents further time for consultation. If Senator Crowley is correct and there has been widespread consultation, why has this confusion occurred among the parents of Australia? They are coming out of the woodwork. The radios, the papers and the television are running mad on it today. The minister can argue that it has been whipped up, but 21,000 people did not get whipped up to put their names to petitions and 12,500 did not get whipped up to write letters. I have seen nothing like it in my life.

I spoke to two bus loads of parents yesterday. They did not know who I was. I went around the back. I was intrigued, and I asked, `Why have you come today?'. They said, `We heard this on the radio and we got together'. Parents got together and came up here because, they said, they thought it was imminent. But apparently those parents were not aware of it until they heard Senator Crowley on the radio with John Laws. They said they were appalled by what came out on the radio. That was the stimulus. Senator Crowley was responsible for those bus loads that came up yesterday. She was responsible because of what was said on the John Laws programs. So she should not blame us for whipping up this matter. It is coming from the parents themselves. So what has the minister got against my original motion to bring it on on 8 December?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Firstly, I would like to answer Senator Herron. We have had something like two years of consultation on this matter. It came up initially with a draft document, which was then put out for further discussion and consultation across the child-care industry in the private sector as well as in the public sector. So I do not know how another 12 days are going to do anything but give those people who are opposed to it greater opportunity to whip up more hysteria. I think we really do need to deal with this matter today. I would like to turn to some of the misleading and mischievous work that has been done in this place over the last two days, particularly by members of the National Party of Australia, and put into context something that Senator Herron mentioned about Christmas carols. The Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Senator Crowley) has said that apparently she is now known as the minister who cancelled Christmas.

PARA.TAB: I turn here to principle 21. I emphasise again that these principles were drawn up by the industry, not by somebody in a backroom somewhere off in the department who thought of all these wonderful ideas for little children. They were drawn up over a long period of consultation with people in the industry and that included parents. All right, private child-care centres do not want to abide by these principles but managed to make their parents sign. In some cases I stress the word `make' because we have had complaints from people who said, `I was told I was expected to sign that or this centre would close'. That is the sort of misinformation that has been put around to get that many signatures on a petition.
Let us go to principle 21. This basic principle is, `The program fosters creative development and aesthetic awareness'. What on earth is wrong with that? It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for children to have the opportunity to produce their own creative product as well as to begin to appreciate the creativity of others.
How terrible. I will read everything under `Unsatisfactory' for a change.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole 50?
—I am referring only to music. If Senator Herron has not read it all, he should listen. Under the heading `Unsatisfactory', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The program includes very little or no music, art, drama, movement or other creative experiences.
The only music children hear is taped music that meets staff preferences. This is on for a large part of the day.
In other words, they listen to nothing but Triple J. It is on in the background and the kids get nothing else. I have no problems with Triple J; I just used it as an example. It continues:
There are no musical instruments for the children to play and they learn no songs.
That is what is unsatisfactory. Let us look at what are the basic requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else does it say?
—This is the only mention, in case the honourable senator has not read it, of anything to do with Christmas carols. The basic requirements are:

SPEECH.PARA: The program provides some music specifically for children, but it is usually in the background.
Children learn songs but the repertoire is not large, or songs are only for special occasions such as Christmas and are culturally irrelevant for many children.

We are not banning Christmas carols; we are saying, if the only songs the children ever get to learn are at Christmas time, they get only a basic requirement. It is not unsatisfactory, but it is only a basic requirement.

PARA.TAB: Let us go on and look at good quality requirements. Under `Good quality' it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Children learn finger plays and songs with simple rhythms and melodies.
Staff provide opportunities for children to move freely to music, and these activities are at an appropriate level.
There are appropriate musical instruments to enable children to experiment with sound and with rhythm, e.g. home-made shakers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody disagrees with that.

—I am reading this out because this is what has been misrepresented as being some sort of stop on Christmas carols. Let us now look at high quality requirements when it comes to music. Under `High quality' it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The program emphasises a wide variety of areas for creative expression, and children are brought into contact with the creativity of others through—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Leave has been given to a number of speakers, including Senator Lee, to discuss the question of when this matter should be debated. It seems to me that Senator Lee is now debating the matter. Rather, she is not debating; she is reading out large passages from a piece of paper about things that we are all very familiar with. If we are going to have the debate at some time, this is when Senator Lees will get her opportunity to do that. My point of order is that leave has been given to discuss the matter of when this is to be debated and why the confusion arose, not actually to debate the substance of the matter. Senator Lees is under leave and I am not suggesting we are going to withdraw that but I would ask, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you might ask her to be relevant to the subject that we are discussing.
—Firstly, I ask that the honourable senator at least get my name right. Secondly, if I could explain—
—Are you speaking to the point of order now, Senator?
—I am speaking to the point of order to show the level of misrepresentation and garbage that has been promoted on this issue.
—That is not what we are discussing now.
—That is why we need to bring this on today, because if we give honourable senators another day this level of misrepresentation will continue. I am referring to the specific material you have used.

—Order! I uphold the point raised by Senator Ian Macdonald. I would ask Senator Lees to be mindful that she is at the moment speaking with leave to the motion for the issue to be brought on for debate and not to the substantive motion. I would ask her to confine her remarks to the reasons why the debate should be brought on.

—I shall conclude my remarks by saying honourable senators obviously do not want to listen to the truth as to what is actually in this document. Finally, the only possible reason to delay this any further is so that the scurrilous campaign can continue for another 12 days.
—Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Are you seeking leave, Senator Kemp?
—Yes.
—I am a bit inclined to say to Senator Kemp that I am disinclined to give leave, so that we can actually conclude this preparatory stage—
—You have had leave twice.
—I do not care if I have had leave 10 times. I want to proceed again to ask for leave to actually proceed to the debate.
—We are not going to give it to you if you are not going to give me leave.

—In that case, Mr Acting Deputy President, I oppose leave for Senator Kemp, and I ask for leave of the Senate, once again, to have the business of the Senate notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Newman relating to disallowance of Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance) moved forthwith.

—On a point of order, I seek your guidance, Mr Acting Deputy President. There are certain courtesies in this chamber, and Senator Crowley sought leave to bring on a matter which is a highly contentious public issue. Senator Crowley decided to put this on the agenda today, not us. As a courtesy of the chamber, we gave her the chance to put her views. Then when she was upset with someone else's views, we extended the courtesies of the chamber to give her another chance to put her views. This is how this parliament operates. It operates on a reasonable exchange of courtesies on this matter.

PARA.TAB: I wish to speak for four to five minutes on this matter. It is an important matter, and if Senator Crowley and her colleagues are going to seek for us to give them leave to apply one set of rules to them, and they refuse to give us the same courtesies, I think she has set a rather unpleasant precedent for this chamber. I would ask Senator Crowley to reconsider her decision. Again, I seek leave to make a limited contribution on this important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: I just say that my understanding is that leave will not be given. It is my understanding that it would be better to proceed back to the business of the day as proposed. I would just like to say, on the point of order, while I am here, that I did ring Senator Herron's office. My staff rang his office and asked who to speak to about this matter and were told to deal with Senator Newman's office—
—Order! Senator, that is not relevant to the point of order being discussed.
—We could actually trawl across a lot of other things, Mr Acting Deputy President—
—No, not when you are raising a point of order. Speak to the point of order.

—Under your instructions, I am speaking to the point of order, which was that somehow I would like to know what the point of order was; I never got it clear from Senator Kemp. His point of order was apparently that—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all right, Senator, you are not on your feet; I am.
—Sit down and I can assist you.
—Order! Senator Kemp.

—What was this about orderliness and procedures that Senator Kemp was referring to? He flouts them all he likes. Mr Acting Deputy President, if there was a point of order that we should behave graciously in this Senate, then I would like to say that, of course, we would support that; we always behave graciously. My understanding was leave would be given. I am now advised leave will not be given. So I thought it would expedite matters in this chamber if I moved the motion having sought leave, which I have done. I believe we should get a ruling on whether leave will be granted to proceed and, if not, get on with it.

—I wish to speak on the point of order that Senator Kemp raised, and point out that Senator Crowley has made a number of references to our whips and our whips' meeting. Senator Reid is trying to get the call to obtain leave to explain her position, and Senator Crowley is stopping the by leave debate. I am sure Senator Kemp also had a very good point.
—No, I am not. I will not be misrepresented like that.
—You just did.
—You moved the motion.
—I did not move the motion. I sought to. You denied it. I have not moved any motion.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I draw your attention and Senator Crowley's attention to the fact that Senator Reid is trying to get the call as well as Senator Kemp. I am sure that Senator Kemp's contribution would—
—That is not a point of order, Senator Macdonald.
—I seek leave to make a brief statement in contribution to this debate.
—No, we cannot have any further leave until we resolve the matter as to whether Senator Kemp is going to be given leave to speak.
—I am sorry, I thought you had resolved that.
—With respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have sought leave once again to have the business of the Senate disallowance motion come on.
—The issue we are discussing at the moment is whether Senator Kemp is to be—
—Very well. I make it clear leave is not granted for Senator Kemp.
—Leave is not granted.
—In that case, I seek leave to bring this debate on again.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was next on the list to seek leave to make a contribution.
—Senator Crowley has sought leave to—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I stood up and sought leave and you said that what we first have to deal with is Senator Kemp.
—I am sorry, Senator Vanstone, but Senator Crowley was the next to rise. Is leave granted to Senator Crowley?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, if leave were to be granted, I should like briefly to make a comment on some of the things that have been said this morning.
—Senator Reid, leave is granted to you.

—Thank you, Senator Crowley. I think what has occurred this morning indicates that there has been some confusion about this matter and perhaps it is because of the unfortunate absence of Senator Newman that that has occurred. As I understood the situation, today was the day that it was to have come on but it was deferred by Senator Herron to 8 December. This occurred also at a time when the government was pressuring us considerably to get the industrial relations legislation on and we were conscious that industrial relations was the centrepiece of this week. It is beginning to look as though we will not get to it at all, but we were under the pressure of trying to assist the government to meet that objective of getting industrial relations done.

PARA.TAB: It was two days ago when I first heard—I think at the whips' meeting, or shortly before it—that the government was bringing on this matter on Thursday. That took me somewhat by surprise. I knew that we would not want that to occur, but I interpreted it to mean that, if the government was bringing it on, it had the numbers to do so, which clearly it does because Senator Lees has indicated that she would wish the matter to come on today.

Because of that, I then, of course, advised all of those in my party who wished to speak on the matter that, although it was not our wish that the matter come on today, the government wanted it on today and they had better be ready to speak today; and that is the position. But it is not our view that it should be brought forward to come on today. Unless the government has some mechanism whereby it can bring it on today, we should proceed with the program. There is still a big program ahead and we have wasted a considerable amount of time this morning. Industrial relations has obviously slipped down the list a bit and I do not know why. It is to be started today, when we get around to the government's program, and there are a number of bills still to be dealt with in addition to that.
Motion (by Senator Sherry, on behalf of Senator Faulkner) proposed:

(1)That the order of the Senate of 18 August 1993, relating to the introduction of bills into the Senate after 29 October 1993, not apply to the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993.

(2)That the resumption of the debate on the motion for the second reading of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 and the Industrial Relations Court (Judges' Remuneration) Bill 1993 be an order of the day for Thursday, 25 November 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I was just a little surprised. I thought the government would try to make a case for its motion, but apparently it does not think that argument is necessary. But now that the matter has been clarified, this motion relates to the incredible situation whereby the government is seeking to override the time constraints that were imposed by the Senate on the introduction of bills, and it is intending to do it in relation to a bill of major consequence, that is, the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. We on this side of the chamber will oppose that. No case has been made out for the need for urgency. As I said a moment ago, I think it is incredible that, in moving the motion, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) did not think it was necessary to put an argument at all.
—Not by choice.

—No, the Senate had imposed a restraint upon the government and the parliamentary secretary has come in here and expected the Senate to lift that restraint without putting any argument at all. The onus is not upon us; the onus is upon the government. But I will take the opportunity to remind the honourable senator of the history of the matter that led to the imposition of these constraints on the introduction of bills.

PARA.TAB: We have had a problem over the years of an incompetent government basically failing to manage its business in an orderly way, with the consequence that a large number of bills get stacked up towards the end of session and are therefore not dealt with properly by this chamber. The Senate, reacting to the frustration of not being able to do its job properly, therefore, some years ago introduced a time constraint limiting consideration of bills that were not introduced within reasonable time; in other words, bills that were not going to be allowed full and adequate debate in this place. That was referred to commonly as the Macklin motion, because it was introduced by our former colleague Senator Macklin.

It worked reasonably well for some time, until the government at the other end of this building started to abuse it.
