It did that by stacking the bills up against the time constraint in the House of Representatives so that we were being blamed for the government guillotining large numbers of bills through against the introductory date in the House of Representatives. Again it was simply a case of the government not being able to plan its program properly. That extra frustration after a year's debate caused this chamber to introduce the current constraint, which is a two-level constraint. It means that bills have to be introduced into the House of Representatives to allow reasonable debate in that chamber and then into this place to allow reasonable debate. At the beginning of this session the Senate imposed that obligation. It was done for very sensible reasons. If we are to act properly as a chamber of scrutiny, we have to receive legislation within a reasonable time, otherwise we are simply not going to be able to do the job properly.

What the government has done here has been to bring down a major piece of legislation, its industrial relations package, which is highly controversial and severely damaging to small business in Australia. My friend and colleague Senator Crane might give the Senate a little more detail on that in a moment and you might as well, I suspect, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you can find somebody else to sit in that chair. We have this piece of legislation of major consequence to the Australian business community, and therefore of consequence to all Australians, which the government is seeking to bring in in the twilight of this parliamentary session and to ram through this place. I stand to be corrected if I am wrong, but I think the government guillotined it through the House of Representatives anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —They guillotined through 177 amendments.

—It demonstrates the incompetence of the government when it introduces 177 of its own amendments to a piece of legislation that it brings in, and then guillotines it through the House of Representatives. In other words, the government would not even allow that chamber full debate, even though the House is continuing to sit today and will be coming back for another week. It really is unforgivable if the government abuses its numbers in that way in the House and fails to allow that chamber full scrutiny of the bill. Be that as it may, all we can really do is make the point that that is intolerable parliamentary practice.

PARA.TAB: The issue now before us is whether, in the light of that abuse, this chamber is going to lift the time constraint and allow the government to introduce this bill several weeks after the cut-off time and in a way in which, clearly, it is not going to receive the full attention it deserves in this chamber. The bill did go to a parliamentary committee for a very short inquiry. In many ways, it was an inadequate inquiry, although excellent work was done by coalition members on that committee to at least bring out some of the shortcomings in the legislation. But legislation, being part of a properly planned program, does not have to be processed in this way. What is to be lost if this bill lies on the table here and is debated when the parliament returns in the beginning of February? What is to be lost by that, other than that the public will have an opportunity to give perusal to what the government is intending to pass and the parliament can have a reasonable time for its debate. There is no substantive reason for not dealing with this legislation in accordance with the motion that has already been passed by this chamber.

I do not want to reflect to any great extent on the substance of the IR bill but this is the bill that removes sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act. It removes the protections that have been in place for small business for years—that guarantee against union abuse, which is recognised and appreciated by small business throughout Australia. This is the bill by which the government intends to remove that safeguard. So, with that example alone, it is clear that this is a piece of legislation of major consequence and major detriment to the Australian people. It is obviously demanding of very careful scrutiny in this place.
As I understand it, this is also the bill that the government says frees up the potential of enterprise bargaining for the non-unionised

SPEECH.PARA: labour force. But I also understand that it in fact fails to do that. That is an issue that—if the government is going to hold out a hope for non-union labour—simply is not warranted from the detail of this bill. That is something that has clearly got to be considered in great depth and with great care. The history of this chamber is that, when we are given the opportunity to do so, we do exercise that care and, in scrutinising legislation, we do our best to improve it.

PARA.TAB: However, we have to be given a fair opportunity to do that. This government is not prepared to give us that. It is not prepared to act in accordance with the resolution of the Senate that is in place. The government comes in here today and wants to remove that legislation and remove the benefits that were written into it of adequate time for proper scrutiny. The government says, `Deal with this now, because we want it'. I think the bottom line to all of this is that the government recognises that this is unpopular legislation and that the longer it takes in the process the more difficult it becomes for the government politically.

That is an unfortunate consequence of bad legislation, but it in no way justifies a failure to allow this chamber the opportunity for proper scrutiny. So we will oppose this. No case has been made by the government for its actions. As I said, incredibly, the parliamentary secretary did not even put an argument. I trust that the Senate, which only a few months ago put this safeguard into place, will stand by and uphold that safeguard, and tell this government that it can bring this bill back at the beginning of the next parliamentary session when it can have full and proper debate in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely amazed that Senator Hill managed to give that contribution and keep a straight face. I congratulate him for that. It was, of course, nothing but cant and hypocrisy. Frankly, every honourable senator in this chamber has known from day one that the cut-off motion, relating to the introduction of legislation in this chamber and the House of Representatives, could not be met on this bill. That has never been a secret. The government has always admitted that that would be the case. The government has always said the same is true of the Mabo legislation. The same is true of the native title bill. We have admitted it; we have been honest about it.

PARA.TAB: We made it clear at the time that Senator Chamarette moved her ludicrous cut-off motion, supported by the opposition for no other reason than to try to frustrate and filibuster the processes of this chamber, that urgent and unforeseen legislation had to be given special priority and special consideration by this chamber. We all knew this. I pointed this out, and so did many other speakers in the debate, when the preposterous cut-off motion was first mooted and first debated in this chamber.

Does Senator Hill really suggest that we went through a hearing with the Senate standing committee just to see the bill deferred to next year? Of course he does not. He, like every other honourable senator in this chamber, has known that the Senate would be dealing with this matter prior to the end of the year. He is right, of course. This is an important bill, and it is an urgent bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it urgent?

—I will tell Senator Vanstone why. Unlike the mob over there, who are interested only in disruption, who are interested only in delay, who because of all their problems with uncertainty over their leadership in the House of Representatives cannot focus on the major issues of the day, we are about bringing stability and certainty into Australian industrial relations. This very major industrial relations reform, this very important industrial relations reform—certainly this is one of the most important industrial relations bills we have seen come before this parliament in literally decades—will do that.

PARA.TAB: I stress to the chamber that warnings about legislation of the urgency and importance of this industrial relations legislation and the native title bill were given at the time the opposition decided to line up with Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts and support this cut-off motion. All honourable senators knew at that time that we were going to face this situation. A lot of credit ought to be given to the government for being able to work very successfully within the ludicrous constraints the cut-off motion has applied to the procedures and the business of this chamber.

It is nothing short of miraculous that only three individual bills and two packages of legislation, that is, Mabo and industrial relations, will be subject to a request to lift the provisions of that cut-off motion. It is nothing short of amazing that the government has been able to mobilise resources to that extent and fulfil those impossible constraints, those impossible requirements, that were placed upon it by Senator Chamarette's cut-off motion.

Until today, until the pathetic contribution we have heard this morning from Senator Hill, there has never been a suggestion from the Liberals or the National Party—if they are able to make any suggestions at all; given their state of disunity, it is a bit of a difficulty for them—that this piece of legislation should not be dealt with by the Australian parliament this year. We have gone through hours of debate in the House of Representatives on this bill. Did one opposition member of the House of Representatives stand up and say, `We don't think we should deal with this bill today'? Did Senator Crane in the committee ever suggest that, or did any other member of the standing committee? The answer is no, they did not, nor has the shadow minister for industrial relations, Mr Howard. It is not and never has been a position the opposition has adopted.

This is a preposterous, time-wasting filibuster from the opposition. I think all honourable senators know that this is just an attempt by Senator Hill to put something on the record. He knows as well as every other honourable senator that this is an appropriate course of action for the government and has always been timetabled to be dealt with by the Senate on this day and subsequent sitting days. There is no secret in this. It is all very straightforward. It is everything we expected. Commitments and predictions were made when the cut-off motion was originally debated about what would occur in relation to urgent legislation coming before the parliament, and the government has done a fantastic job, an incredible job, in fulfilling the absurd requirements of that motion. We have said all along that it was not possible on industrial relations or on the native title bill. There were no secrets in that, no scams, no tricks, which is just what every honourable senator and every Australian in the broader community who has followed this debate has always understood.

Let us put this sham to rest and get on with the substantive debate on the bill. We have had enough posturing from Senator Hill. He has made his pathetic political point. No-one agrees with him—not even the opposition senators on the other side of the chamber. If I were them, I would worry about more important issues, like the leadership of their party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortunately, you are not me.

—I know it does not worry Senator Vanstone. She is desperate for Dr Hewson to stay there because she is part of his very inadequate team here in the Senate. Senator Vanstone is gone when he goes. It will not be very long, we all know that. Let us just get rid of this matter and get on to the substantive business before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! I have been advised by the clerks that, under the terms of the original cut-off motion, debate on this motion should have been limited to 30 minutes and each speaker limited to five minutes. We have had two speakers to whom it was indicated that they were allowed 30 minutes, so I rule that we will have a further 20 minutes of debate, with each speaker limited to five minutes, which will mean that this debate should conclude at 12.18 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not want to speak in this debate. I have been sitting in this place since 11 o'clock hoping to deal with the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, and everyone else wanting to have a say on a whole variety of other things has held me up. I was here yesterday for a couple of hours hoping to deal with the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. But such is the nature of this place that other things do intervene. Other things come up that have to be dealt with, and so be it. I will just have to wait a little longer.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of Senator Faulkner's contribution, if one can call it that, I feel obliged to make a couple of points. Any senators, members and, indeed, members of the public who want to look at the second report of the cost of justice inquiry entitled Checks and Balances will see very clearly the concern expressed by the committee that, to put it in my own language, we are not doing our job properly. From these taxpayers here in the gallery and from your taxes and my taxes, Mr Acting Deputy President, comes money that funds the operation of this place. The notion is, and sometimes I think it is just a notion, that we will do the job properly, that we will properly scrutinise legislation and come to the right decision.
In an attempt to ensure that proper scrutiny, some suggestions were made. I believe that they actually started with the Democrats. Is that right, Senator Bell?

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know yet.

—I think they did. Some suggestions were made that there be a cut-off time whereby this chamber would not accept bills from the other place after a certain time because we would not have time to consider them properly. Then we decided to add a second cut-off point because the other place was jamming up 40 or 50 or 60 bills on one day and dropping them in this place the next. We were not achieving our aim of giving ourselves the time to consider things properly.

PARA.TAB: It was always accepted—Senator Faulkner is right—that urgent and unforeseen legislation should be able to break those time barriers. I make no bones about that, but I do not know that this legislation comes into the category of what was thought of as being urgent. Senator Faulkner made no case for there being any real harm done by allowing this place and members of the public to consider properly the government's legislation, and it certainly was not unforeseen.

I would just like to raise a couple of examples of what happens when we, at taxpayers' expense, do not do our job properly. We have to come back and redo the job, as we did recently with the bankruptcy bill. We passed the bill here. There was a little bit of a guillotine downstairs and I think it was under a guillotine here and it was unconstitutional. The whole thing had to be done again. That was not difficult to do again but there was a court case, the costs associated with that in the meantime, and the consequences of that bill not having been effective.

Some years ago, we had a problem—which I think the Democrats and the coalition had different views on—with old oil and new oil in relation to the taxation measure. The bill was not drafted properly and was shoved through this place. People did not spot the ambiguity or the problem that might arise because the bill was not given sufficient time to be properly read. There was more litigation and more bills were put through this place because in the first instance we had not done our job properly. There is a bill, taxation laws No. 3, which is either on the agenda or was dealt with yesterday though I do not recall it going through yesterday. It is the one dealing with—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still on the Notice Paper.

—It is still on the paper. It is dealing with a bill that was passed in 1990 which inadvertently allows deductions against non-taxable income overseas. It was never intended to do that. I understand from the second reading speech and from the explanatory memorandum to that bill that it was never intended to do that. Because we did not do our job properly, the plain written law indicates that people can do it. So now we have to fix that up because we did not do that job properly at the time.

PARA.TAB: As for the government saying that this is a fantastic bill and it understands what it is all about: why would it have 117 amendments to a bill that Senator Sherry describes as `being everything we expect'? Clearly there are 117 things at least the government did not expect. All I am saying is that we should have sufficient time for this legislation to be read. This place should not run on the basis of a good idea one day, legislation the next. It is the wrong way to do it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, like Senator Faulkner who spoke before, I have serious reservations about the cut-off resolution overall. I do not want to take any time discussing that. That has been carried by the Senate; that is our practice. It was clear on day one that not just urgent and unforeseen legislation but major pieces of legislation which could not be dealt with in accordance with that timetable would be considered by the Senate for exemption from that. On day one there were two exemptions referred to explicitly and, as I recall it, acknowledged by at least Senator Chamarette in her speech. Perhaps it was not here; I cannot recall it in that much detail but it was in her public discussion at the time. The exemptions were the Native Title Bill and the industrial relations package.

PARA.TAB: What we are doing here is what was indicated at the time. Nobody can say that this bill is not important. It may well be that people say, `We want to vote against it'. That is a perfectly valid thing for them to do in a democracy, but for them to say, ` We don't want to talk about it', is a very different question. People are saying that this bill could mean horrific consequences, the end of Western civilisation, great problems for the economy, but we will leave it hanging about for a few months. We will leave that uncertainty hanging about for a few months.

If people were saying that this bill does not have any important consequences; it does not matter whether it is carried or not; there is no particular significance; we probably would not be proposing it but certainly there would be a rational case for arguing against it. Honourable senators cannot come in here and say, `It is important but we shouldn't deal with it'. That is not a logical and consistent position.

Nobody has proposed how the public interest will be served by leaving the passage of this legislation uncertain. I know that people in the opposition have strong views about the contents of the legislation. We do not share those views, but I acknowledge them as sincerely held. That is a case for debating the legislation, not for not debating it. There is one particular reason why I think it needs to be dealt with now before I go on to why the process has been adequate. Until this legislation is dealt with and I hope passed, the working conditions of Australian workers, particularly in Western Australia but also in Victoria—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why Western Australia?

—Because of the outrageous government in Western Australia; that is why. The workers are under threat—they do not have the security that they should have—and it is very important that we put in place this federal legislation, which gives security to the basic industrial rights of Western Australian workers. They will be under threat from the legislation rammed through—not in any way consistent with the highfalutin words of Senator Hill—by the Western Australian government; and we will not stand idly by and allow that to happen.

PARA.TAB: There is plenty of time for this. This is not a motion to gag or guillotine this bill. There are eight or nine sitting days left. There has already been a committee hearing. I know Senator Hill tried to disparage it because it did not suit his argument, but every major industrial player on both sides of the debate about this bill was heard. The states were heard. The Department of Industrial Relations came before the committee, ably represented by me. And what happened? Did we have to cut off the questions because we did not have time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your modesty is astounding.

—The honourable senator agreed so enthusiastically when I was self-deprecating the other day that I did not think I would try it again. Did we run out of time for those questions? No, we did not. We exhausted it; we stayed until the committee finished asking all the questions. The committee did not run out of time.
—That is not correct. You are forgetting we had to get home.

—I was still there and we dealt with it comprehensively in the committee—as comprehensively as almost any bill that comes before us is dealt with by the proper legislation committees of this place. What we have before us is just an old stalling tactic. It is a pretty tired old nag. It is stalling tactic by filibuster, out of obstruction, and it should be put out of its misery.

—Apparently, what we should be discussing is a decision as to whether this subject is sufficiently important to be dealt with now. Right from the beginning, I think, Senator Hill made a perfectly adequate case for that. He claimed that the government had not made the case for its importance. But I think in Senator Hill's very first few sentences he actually made that case, because he described this bill as a bill with major consequence to the business community. I would suggest that it is also of some considerable consequence to every person in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The other matter of the discussion centred upon the appropriateness of the cut-off date. I do not think I need to add our feelings to that. We voted against that cut-off date at the time. Senator Vanstone rightly observed that the notion of a cut-off date was initially a Democrat proposition, known as the Macklin amendment, the Macklin provision, which we think had worked quite well for some years. But it is the constriction of that approach, brought about by the changing of the date to an earlier date, which has dealt us this problem. It would not necessarily be a problem if what Senator Hill said was acknowledged—that this is a bill of major consequence to the community—because it is those bills of major consequence which, it was indicated, would get some exemption from what has been described as the ludicrously short cut-off date.

In fact, this bill of major consequence has been well discussed and well canvassed over a number of months, if not years. The issues were well canvassed during the election campaign. They were well and truly canvassed during the previous inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into sections 45D and 45E. That inquiry was initiated on my motion. As has previously been described by Senator McMullan, all the major players, all the major theorists, all the major opinion holders, all the major stakeholders in a discussion about industrial relations in Australia's future who appeared as witnesses and who made submissions to that previous inquiry did so over the course of a full year. That committee's inquiry took place over a year.

In participating in the next inquiry, which the same committee conducted into this bill, it was of some amusement to me that those same players, opinion holders and stakeholders, however one likes to describe them, the participants in the industrial relations debate, rehearsed the same arguments. We learnt nothing knew from the subsequent inquiry, which took place just last week.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that?

—I can say it because it is true and it stands within the proceedings and the report of that committee. The fact is that anybody can read the report of that committee and anybody can compare and contrast the evidence that was given and find nothing new in terms of initiatives, theories or any contribution to that debate. The arguments have been well rehearsed. In fact, much of the substance has been in constant discussion since December 1992. I mean December 1991. I put the wrong emphasis there. I apologise for that. I was getting very excited about that. It has not only been in 1993 and it has not only been in 1992; it was in December 1991 that we had a major piece of legislation about to come before this chamber, and since then we have been rehearsing and re-rehearsing these arguments.

PARA.TAB: The notion that we need to do our job properly, as advanced by Senator Vanstone, is a notion that I share, but I suggest that we will not do it properly if we continue to waste time debating whether this thing is important. It obviously is. Let us get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the motion before us—
—You have spoken.
—I have sought advice, and apparently I can.
—You are going to close the debate. You moved the motion.
—May I make a point on this matter?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as you are not using up the time for the debate.

—I certainly moved the motion. I did not speak at that time. There was a ruling from the chair part way through the debate. The debate was restricted to five minutes per speaker, to a maximum of 20 minutes, with the motion to be put at 18 minutes past. I am not closing the debate by virtue of the fact that I have the right of reply. I am closing the debate because of the ruling of the chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, may I ask a question of you about what is happening in this debate? The rules were changed halfway through, or there was a misunderstanding. If honourable senators want to debate that, I will debate it as well. I have two questions. Firstly, is Senator Sherry closing the debate? Secondly, is he using up the time that was allocated for the rest of the debate following that misunderstanding?

—I take a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to standing order 188, which indicates that an honourable senator may speak only once on a question before the Senate. Senator Sherry, having moved the motion, has of course spoken and therefore he is speaking a second time. The standing orders on a suspension, I understand, do not necessarily allow Senator Sherry to close the debate. Accordingly, under standing order 188, it appears to us that Senator Sherry does not have the right to speak at this point. We would be willing, however, if the debate is allowed to proceed with Senator Crane having the call for five minutes, to allow Senator Sherry some brief time by leave at the end of that.

—I think that might be a satisfactory way of resolving the matter because I believe that the point of order could well be upheld, that Senator Sherry would be speaking twice. So if we can have that understanding that Senator Crane and Senator Sherry both have the opportunity of speaking, that might be the best way out of something that was just as a result of accident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, I just want to pick up one point out of Senator Faulkner's irrational tirade. That is when he said there was no misunderstanding in this place that this legislation would be brought forward after the cut-off date. I absolutely and totally refute that. If we look at the evidence and the information from the public statements of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, it was his intention to take this legislation to cabinet in early August and have it in the chambers soon thereafter. That is on the public record. The reason why that has not happened is purely and simply that, when he went along to his mates at the ACTU conference, they hissed and booed him and virtually kicked him out of the place. He had to go away and reconsider it. That is why this legislation was not here when it was destined to be and that is why it is not in conformance with how it was initially intended, as outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others.

PARA.TAB: I have just one other comment before I go to the substance of what I want to say, and that is in response to Senator Bell. To try to say that we canvassed virtually exactly the same ground in the second inquiry as we did in the first is absolutely, totally misleading and wrong—and what is more, he knows it. Moreover, I doubt whether he spent 20 per cent of the time listening to the witnesses and hearing what was said, because he just was not there; it is as simple as that. Certainly, it did cover some of the things we canvassed in the first inquiry, but there was proposed legislation before us, although it is quite different now—it has been amended 177 times. There were lots of other arguments canvassed.
In using this cut-off motion, I just want to remind people of some of the things that were said at that particular time. Senator Chamarette said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . within the House of Representatives which then came through to the Senate without proper notice and the chance of proper debate.
That was reiterated by the Australian Democrats and also by Senator Harradine, when he said:
But I would have thought that one of the greatest impertinences has been the way the government has treated this chamber over a period in respect of its duties to review this legislation.
Now I say to the government and to the other parties here that this is indeed important legislation. But the government has not yet got it right. It needs the time—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just come to that in a minute. Honourable senators will hear why they have not got it right. We have had very recent discussions. Government people are out there now writing more amendments, as a result of questions we asked them. They will be writing more amendments; they have not got it right. That is why this legislation should not proceed at this particular time.

PARA.TAB: My other point is that it is a misuse of this procedure, a total misuse. The cut-off debate should only be negated when it is a matter of national emergency and the government stepped outside that. This legislation is certainly not of national emergency. The award system will continue; the certified agreement system will continue; what is happening out in the marketplace now with voluntary agreements will continue; the government does not need it to proceed. In fact, what the government proposes will inhibit that particular process and it is far better left alone. The evidence was consistently given to us in that inquiry that, in fact, this was a tightening up of the market; it would be more rigid, not freer.

I just want to highlight the particular point of why I believe it would be in the interests of the government. It is purely and simply that, when I asked this morning whether or not the no disadvantage clause would apply as far as preferences to unions were concerned, with an enterprise flexibility agreement—I hope honourable senators understand what I am saying; the preference to unions with enterprise flexibility agreement—when there were no union people in the workplace, the answer we got was, `We do not know, we will have to go away and check that'. I understand they are now looking at writing an amendment with regard to that.

There are a number of very good reasons why this legislation should not proceed at this particular time. One is that the government has not finished putting the whole thing together. The government is still out there writing amendments to it now. It would be in the interests of the people of Australia—business people, employees and the economy—for the government to take this back, reword it, and get it right.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I first want to thank the opposition for facilitating the time allocation in this debate between Senator Crane and me. Senator Crane, and I think he is reflecting the general arguments advanced by the opposition, put forward two reasons for opposing the motion that I moved to negate the cut-off date so that we could get on and discuss the Industrial Relations Reform Bill. His first reason for opposing it was that we should be negating the cut-off date only because of a national emergency, and they were the words he used.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we heard a lot of argument from Senator Chamarette and others when the cut-off date was introduced, I do not recall any argument that we should be negating that cut-off point only in the event of a national emergency. National emergency brings to mind a fire, a flood—

TALK.START.PARA: —War.

—That is right, warfare. I certainly do not believe that they are the only circumstances in which we should be reversing that motion. The argument that Senator Crane is advancing is ridiculous. As was pointed out by Senator McMullan, there are another eight or nine sitting days of the Senate, we hope. I note that Senator Crane heads the list of speakers on this debate. Some 15 people have put their names down to speak on industrial relations and that is as lengthy a contribution as we get on most pieces of legislation.

PARA.TAB: The second reason that Senator Crane advanced for opposing the negation was that this matter should be dealt with next year—I think that was his basic thrust—because there are so many amendments to the legislation. That is not an unusual situation. The superannuation supervision legislation that I dealt with earlier this week in the Senate had some hundreds of amendments to it. I think there were 18 pages of amendments to the superannuation legislation. The superannuation legislation was a very substantial package of legislation, as is the industrial relations package. But the truth is that this debate on industrial relations reform has been raging for at least 10 to 15 years in the political arena.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still haven't got it right.

—Senator Chapman interjects and says that we still have not got it right. We are just going to have to agree to disagree on that. The opposition, and I accept this, has a fundamentally philosophically different approach to industrial relations from the Labor Party. Those opposite will continue to argue that we have not got it right. This is an important piece of legislation and it is urgent because it brings to a head many of the legislative requirements that need to be made. It also brings to a head the industrial relations debate, particularly on the issue of enterprise agreements.

PARA.TAB: It is quite critical for there to be some surety out in the industries of this country so that they can plan and know the framework in which they are going to be able to conduct these enterprise agreements. There has been a lot of debate. An election was fought partly on this issue, which the opposition lost. This was a critical issue in the last election. It was one of three issues before the people. They made a judgment between the opposition's approach—the so-called unfettered, free market, remove the shackles and chains of the Industrial Commission approach—and the government's approach. We have all heard the same jargon for goodness knows how many years. We heard it in the election and basically the opposition's approach was unacceptable to the people of Australia.

We have had many years of debate, public and political, about this package and the central themes contained within it. We have had a committee hearing, as Senator Bell referred, that has looked quite exhaustively at the provisions of this legislation. It is a major package of legislation. It was foreshadowed by the minister some months ago. The fact that it was not introduced before the cut-off date has, in fact, given us additional time to make the necessary refinements and to listen to industry and all parties who have concerns. We should now get on and debate this legislation and pass it before the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: under standing order 191 I wish to make an explanation. I believe I have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to two aspects of Senator Crane's speech, I believe I have been misquoted. Senator Crane said that I had said that the arguments in both inquiries were exactly the same. That is not so. I just said that there were no new arguments. But the most important misrepresentation of my position was with regard to my absence from the committee of inquiry. Senator Crane said that I was not present for more than 20 per cent of the time. That is perhaps a true indication of the situation. I was very critical of my own absence at that time, which was necessary because there was an industrial relations bill before this chamber at that time. I was critical of that and I have taken this opportunity to again emphasise my abhorrence of the situation that we were placed in—that there was an industrial relations bill here in this chamber at the same time as we had an inquiry. I just wanted to clarify that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Sherry's) be agreed to:
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill has been waiting to come on in this place for some time, so when I say, `Thank you, Mr President', I really do mean it as more than a courtesy.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to allow intercepting of certain telecommunications which are currently not necessarily disallowed, but in respect of which the legality of the police procedures is questionable. What the government has sought to do is to identify the circumstances under which an intercept can be made without a warrant. I think that is probably the best way to put it. The bill is, in its primary purpose, seeking to ensure that in certain limited circumstances the police can intercept telecommunications without a warrant, but they are limited circumstances and they are spelt out in the bill. They are emergency situations where there is a threat to property, loss of life, et cetera; and anyone who is interested obviously will see that in the bill.

The problem, of course, is that there is a traditional reluctance in the Australian community, quite rightly, to allow the police to have any extension of their powers to intercept. That is why in this particular bill the government sought in the first place to, relatively speaking, strictly limit the circumstances under which the police would be able to do it. By amendment moved in the other place, the coalition has not further restricted those circumstances but has at least made sure that there is some sort of check on the circumstances under which this tap can take place.

Basically, the circumstances are where one party agrees and, secondly, where an officer, or another officer, of the agency is a party to the communication; that is, if it is the AFP, there has to be an AFP person as a party to the communication. What that means in practical terms is that we are not talking about telecommunications interceptions or tappings where there are two parties and neither of those parties is aware that the phone is tapped—the sort of tapping that you might find in a drug inquiry, for example, where neither party is aware of what is happening.

In the circumstances being proposed by the government here, either one party will have agreed—and that may be the person who has a telephone in the house and it is believed that someone in that house has been kidnapped and the person agrees that the tap can be put on—or, in this second circumstance, where one party to the communications happens to be a member of the relevant agency seeking to put the tap on.

We are not talking about unknown secret taps that might be used in drug offences or in pursuing drug offences and other similar criminal activities. We are talking about a situation strictly limited to where at least one party agrees. That party might be a private citizen who, for one reason or another, has his own life, the life of someone else, or property at risk and he is a party to the communication, or, on the other hand, where an officer of the agency is so placed. So that limits it in the first place.

Then, of course, there are additional limits. They are these: there have to be reasonable grounds for suspecting that another party to the communication has done an act that has resulted or may result in loss of life or the infliction of serious personal injury; or, secondly, has threatened to kill or seriously injure another person or to cause serious damage to property; or, thirdly, has threatened to take his or her own life or to do an act that would endanger his or her own life or create a serious threat to his or her health or safety. And—this is a further limitation—there has to be a consenting party at least on one end of the line; there must be reasonable grounds for suspecting that the list of things that I have just outlined have happened; and there must also be such an urgent situation for this intercept or tap to be done that it is not reasonably practicable for an application for a part VI warrant to be made.

That is where we have got to as a consequence of amendments moved by my colleague Mr Daryl Williams QC in the other place. In other words, originally all that was required was one party to be consenting and there be these reasonable grounds for suspecting that these dreadful things were going to happen. We have sought, because we are concerned about any extension of the power of agencies to intercept phones, to add to that that it must be a sufficiently urgent act that `it is not reasonably practicable for an application for a Part VI warrant to be made'.

So this is not a case where the police can just say, `Let us do this. We can now intercept without a warrant'. That intercept would be unlawful unless they could make out the case, if they were challenged, that it was not reasonably practicable for an application for a part VI warrant to be made at that time. We are pleased that the government accepted that amendment. We think it is a sensible amendment and a sensible limitation on the amendments that the government is seeking to make to the whole bill.

There are, of course, further amendments that we moved, that we believe go further in protecting the community from the misuse of powers by agents who might be entitled to use this technology. One amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: As soon as practicable after the doing of an act in relation to a communication under the provisions of subsection (4) or (5), an officer of the agency which is concerned with the communication shall cause an application—

to be made for one of these warrants. In other words, we are saying that, if these circumstances arise and if one of the parties, a private citizen, consents or there is an agency officer on one end of the line, and if it is so urgent that it is not practicable to apply for a warrant at the time, then yes, they can go ahead with the intercept. But we have added the extra requirement that, as soon as practicable after having put the intercept on, an application has to be made for a warrant.

PARA.TAB: When an application is made for a warrant to authorise the police to so intercept a communication, it may be that a judge could say, `I do not think that in this circumstance you can justify the warrant continuing'. In other words, it does not fit into these categories. If he says, `I do not think that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is a threat to kill or seriously injure another person', or whatever, then the judicial officer will obviously refuse to issue a warrant. What that will mean is the tap will then have to come off. But that will not make illegal the tap up to that point. So what this does is allow the agencies concerned to function in a fairly practical way, to tap a communication when there is not time, when there is some matter of urgency. Then as soon as practicable afterwards they have to go to a judicial officer to see if they can get a warrant—in other words, get judicial approval for what they are doing.

I understand the sorts of circumstances that are envisaged might include a kidnapping, for example, where a child might disappear and be thought at the time to be playing truant, off at a neighbour's place or whatever. Then, very suddenly, it becomes apparent that it is a kidnap. I do not think that there is anyone in this place who would want to put the police in a situation where they were not entitled at that time, with the consent of the parents of the child, to tap their phone, to have a proper recording of whatever information might come down the line at that particular time. I cannot see that anybody could think that was unreasonable.

But I can see that it would be unreasonable to say, `We will let the police decide when those circumstances are and there will be no check on it'. That would be unreasonable and we are very pleased that the government accepted our amendments to so curtail this right. Yes, in order to protect the community—in some instances from themselves, such as in the case of suicide—we will allow the police to make a decision that intercept has to take place. But it must be not practical to get a warrant at the time and they must, as soon as practicable—that is a well understood terminology in the courts, well litigated—seek a warrant.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest for discussion.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions

TALK.START.PARA: —A few weeks ago I attended a reunion at my old school of the class of 1953. The school I was proud to attend was a Christian Brothers boarding school, Nudgee College. In recent times, we have seen allegations of sexual and physical assault by certain Christian Brothers, going back over 40 or 50 years. I wish to speak on this matter as I have viewed with concern and dismay in this chamber calls for a judicial or, failing that, a Senate inquiry into the Christian Brothers. I take a very strong contrary view to those proposals.

PARA.TAB: Let me say from the outset that, if any individual has been responsible for sexual abuse, that person would be subject to the full force of law and would face criminal charges. This applies to every one of us, not just Christian Brothers. To push for some sort of judicial or Senate inquiry into the Christian Brothers organisation itself is to smear and taint by implication all Christian Brothers, something I sincerely hope no-one seeks to do.

Australia owes much to the Christian Brothers and their role in bringing education to the poor and less privileged in our society. There is no doubt that all of us who were educated by the Christian Brothers readily acknowledge that they are strict disciplinarians. As such, they are an outstanding support group for family values and family principles. They are tough but fair, which guarantees them profound respect. With the benefit of age and experience and the luxury of retrospectivity, there is no doubt that this discipline did us all a lot more good than harm.

Many of us today reflect the aims of the brothers. We have the capacity to face each day with self-discipline and confidence, thanks to their teachings. The Christian Brothers set standards that many of us continue to try to emulate, and we will do so for the rest of our lives, including long hours of dedication to the task in hand.

Their day started at 5.30 a.m. Then followed rostered responsibilities. Paramount was the teaching program, based on hours of instruction, discipline, encouragement and guidance for the many-faceted personalities that shape a Christian class; followed by playground supervision and sporting coaching; and, finally, ending the day with supervision of controlled study periods and dormitory duty—all to start again at 5.30 a.m. the following day. They set the example, and that was the example they passed onto their charges going through their formative stages of life. The thoroughness of their programs was such that everyone slept soundly, the sleep of honest and utter exhaustion.

It was on the sporting field, particularly the football field, that the personal strength of the brothers had to be acknowledged. It was here that the students, smarting from what they felt was unduly harsh treatment from a brother during school hours, took the opportunity to exact retribution. It was always to the brothers' credit that, although they knew what was happening, few sought reprisal, and the student concerned ended his day repentant. It showed a great understanding of human nature, to say nothing of substantial self-control.

As far as I am concerned, all the brothers with whom I came in contact were real men, genuine Australians who played a major role in shaping this country. There would not be a city or a town in this country that does not have someone educated by the Christian Brothers, and probably a great number.

At the recent reunion, we were privileged to have at the gathering the surviving Christian Brothers who taught us in 1953. All students had nicknames for their brother teachers, some of them not very complimentary and all of them great secrets as far as the students were concerned. Of course, that belief was a myth, as every Christian Brother knew what his nickname was. There was Brother `Moose' Gallagher, who taught science and sport, who is now semi-retired and living in the Australian Capital Territory. He is still teaching young people in hospital. Brother `Speed' Miller taught mathematics par excellence and was the swimming and football coach. He is now semi-retired in Ballarat. Brother `Foxy' Keenan, was a teacher and sports coach, and is now in retirement in Brisbane because of failing eyesight. Those who have died but are with us in spirit are Brother `Bromm' O'Connor, headmaster; Brother `Crock' Fogarty; Brother `Lefty' Wright, which is not a very original nickname; and Brother `Crom' Davey. They were all fine men, every one of them.

Those of us who were taught by them owe them a great and unrepayable debt. They had to cope with a bunch of adolescent boys who, given half a chance, would have been up to every trick in the book. I might say that many tried but few succeeded. I and the vast majority of students taught by the brothers are not prepared to sit back now and watch these great men smeared by association, or see the great religious order they served besmirched and denigrated. Any organisation as vast as the Christian Brothers must have a few bad apples, but that does not mean that all are tainted because of the actions of a few. A judicial or Senate inquiry would do just that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—I thank Senator Collins. It is not the intent of anyone to see that happen, but such is the nature of these procedures that justice is swept aside and the judgment is made before the jury has retired. I therefore call on those honourable senators who want to take this course to give some thought to the great injustice they propose for a very fine order and to think again and weigh the inevitable adverse repercussions of the action they propose.

PARA.TAB: If followed to its logical conclusion, an inquiry into the Christian Brothers should be followed by an inquiry into the Labor Party because of the actions of Keith Wright, a Labor leader who came close to being Premier of Queensland and who was the member for Capricornia. As far as I am aware, no-one has called for such an inquiry, nor should they.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now six years since the Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, was formed. Much has changed on the political landscape over those six years. We are in a different parliament house, for starters. The original patrons of the association were Mr Hawke, Mr Howard, Mr Sinclair and Senator Janine Haines, the party leaders at the time. Yet the association has not only survived, it has also grown.

PARA.TAB: We said at the time that we were the first group of parliamentarians in the world in support of UNICEF, and we hoped the group would be the start of many others. I can now say that similar groups have been formed in countries such as Italy, the United Kingdom and Japan. At the recent Inter-Parliamentary Union conference held in this building the association, together with UNICEF Australia, promoted our work to visiting parliamentarians from throughout the world.

A number of former senators with whom many of us have served in this place over the years were involved in the formation of the parliamentary UNICEF group. They include people such as Michael Macklin, the original treasurer of the association, Jo Vallentine and Peter Baume.

Today the office bearers of the association are as follows: I am president; Kathy Sullivan MP is vice-president; Senator David Brownhill is secretary; and Senator Robert Bell is treasurer. The genuine multiparty nature of the association has been maintained from the beginning. The association's charter is simple but covers the key issues relating to the work of UNICEF. The charter states that the Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF will do the following things:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Support and promote the Declaration of the Rights of the Child as adopted by the United Nations in 1959 and support the adoption of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

2. Promote in the parliament and throughout the Australian government and the Australian community the work of UNICEF for children and their mothers. 3. Encourage Australian governments to give priority support to children and their mothers in Australia's overseas assistance program.

Our most important role, I think, is as a consciousness-raising group in this place. The success of UNICEF's work is dependent upon political cooperation and goodwill. We should not run away from the role we can play as decision makers. As I have said before, priorities must be moved towards the poor, which places a responsibility on the major industrialised nations to review trade, aid and financial policies in relation to the developing world.

PARA.TAB: UNICEF talks of a grand alliance for children, including teachers and religious leaders, mass media and government agencies, voluntary organisations and people's movements, trade unions and business leaders, women's groups and health workers. The Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF is a small but proud part of that alliance.

UNICEF has worked since 1946 to improve the lives of the world's needy children. It is almost 50 years since UNICEF went to work in Europe under a mandate to aid children suffering the aftermath of the Second World War. Today, UNICEF is at work in 128 developing countries where governments have requested UNICEF cooperation in programs providing basic health care, clean water supply and sanitation services, education, nutrition and training. UNICEF concentrates its efforts on fighting silent emergencies—the insidious combination of disease, malnutrition and poverty that kills 35,000 children in the world every day. Two-thirds of these children die from causes that are easily preventable at low costs.

Much of UNICEF's efforts now focus on generating the political will to make these simple, low cost remedies and preventive strategies available throughout the developing world. The grand alliance for children helped achieve, in 1990, the World Health Organisation-UNICEF goal of immunising 80 per cent of the world's children against six preventable diseases that take so many young lives—measles, tuberculosis, tetanus, diphtheria, whooping cough and polio. This program saves 3 million lives each year.

In 1991 the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, became the 104th national leader to sign the World Summit for Children declaration on the survival, protection and development of children, thus committing the Australian government to a series of goals for children. The goals for this decade include eliminating neonatal tetanus by 1995; reducing deaths caused by measles by 95 per cent; eliminating polio by 2000; promoting oral rehydration salts and home remedies for diarrhoea in order to help prevent deaths due to diarrhoeal dehydration; and the provision of universal access to basic education.

The parliamentary association has a great deal of material that I would urge all parliamentarians to look at. Each year UNICEF publishes a report on the state of the world's children. In the latest report there is a proposition which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the principle of `first call for children'—meaning that protection for the growing bodies and minds of the young ought to have a first call on societies' resources—should become an accepted ethic of a new world order.

Let us not forget that 90 per cent of the growth of a human brain, and much of the growth of the human body, is completed in the first five years of life. There is no second chance. The association also has copies of the 1993 edition of the Facts for life. This is the most authoritative expression in plain language of what we now know about practical low cost ways of protecting children's lives and health.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I received from UNICEF copies of the latest edition of their quarterly publication, First call for children. Every politician should have a look at The progress of nations, which records each year national achievements in child survival, health, nutrition, education, family planning and progress for women. The inside cover sums up the philosophy behind UNICEF:

SPEECH.PARA: The day will come when the progress of nations will be judged not by their military or economic strength, nor by the splendour of their capital cities and public buildings, but by the well being of their peoples: by their levels of health, nutrition and education; by their opportunities to earn a fair reward for their labours; by their ability to participate in the decisions that affect their lives; by the respect that is shown for their civil and political liberties; by the provision that is made for those who are vulnerable and disadvantaged; and by the protection that is afforded to the growing minds and bodies of their children.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is important that all of us, as decision makers, familiarise ourselves with the material in these publications. I am happy to provide any of my colleagues in the federal parliament with this material. Since 1991, the association has hosted an annual dinner here in Parliament House. In 1991, our guest was renowned soccer player Craig Johnston, UNICEF Australia's special representative for sport. The role played by prominent community figures such as Craig Johnston in support of UNICEF deserves recognition. The parliamentary UNICEF group has also hosted well-known Australian artist Ken Done. Ken is UNICEF Australia's goodwill ambassador, a role he has performed with distinction. Recently he designed the cover of the Weekend Australian for the Sydney 2000 Olympic decision. He donated his fee to UNICEF Australia.

Last year we hosted Scholastica Kimaryo, UNICEF's representative designate in South Africa. This year we welcomed Ian Macleod, UNICEF Australia's man in Somalia and a former officer of UNICEF, back to the country on a short trip and had him inform parliamentarians of the situation in Somalia and UNICEF's work there. Last year the association donated the sum of $1,878 to UNICEF's Somalia campaign. We propose to continue these dinners each year. Whilst all of us are overworked and often cannot fit in everything we would like to when the parliament is sitting, by hosting a dinner annually we give parliamentarians the chance to catch up with the important work of UNICEF through our special guests and the contingent from UNICEF Australia whom we meet with in the parliamentary dining room.

Finally I would like to pay tribute to the dedicated workers of UNICEF Australia. As president of the association over the last six years, I have always been impressed by their dedication and their professionalism. Their work in stimulating interest among the people and governments of Australia in the welfare of the world's children and achieving greater financial support to enable UNICEF to expand its programs, which bring life and hope to children at risk, deserves recognition. The Australian Parliamentary Association for UNICEF will continue to recognise, promote and support UNICEF's work.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Physical and Sexual Abuse in Catholic Institutions

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Parer in his submission that there should not be a judicial inquiry into the Christian Brothers in Australia, nor a Senate inquiry for that matter. At the outset let me declare an interest. I was educated at Trinity College by the Christian Brothers. My father as well was educated by the Christian Brothers. I can say to the Senate that, from my own experience, I never saw any evidence at all of abuse of young boys, as has been alleged. That does not mean that I dismiss such allegations. In fact, the allegations that have been made are extremely serious. Not for one minute would I suggest that they should be swept under the carpet.

PARA.TAB: The Christian Brothers were established in Ireland in 1802 by Edmund Rice. They came to Australia in 1868. They have a commendable record for the education of young boys. In fact, the congregation was set up for the education of poor boys in Ireland, and that theme was carried through in Australia. Perhaps a brief summary of the matter so far might assist in placing this matter in perspective.

Earlier this year, I think it was, an ABC television series brought this matter to a head when it suggested that there was an abuse by Christian Brothers of young boys who had been brought to this country from England. Following that, various articles appeared in the press and there was a good deal of response. More recently, allegations have been made concerning the abuse of children at Bathurst Island in the Northern Territory. In New South Wales, 240 writs have been issued recently in relation to civil proceedings against the Christian Brothers.

My point is a somewhat legal one in that I think it is entirely inappropriate for a judicial inquiry to be conducted at this stage. Litigation is pending in New South Wales, there is a police investigation pending in the Northern Territory, and there is a police investigation pending in Western Australia. Such an inquiry could well frustrate all three of the matters I have mentioned.

Recently the Crown Prosecutor in Western Australia, Mr McKechnie, announced that prosecutions would not be commenced in relation to 16 cases. But that is not the end of the matter, of course, because there are still other matters being investigated by the police, and quite properly so. The Attorney-General for Western Australia, Cheryl Edwardes, announced that that state would not be conducting an inquiry, and, again, that decision was made on quite proper grounds. One of the points made by the Attorney-General was that the Catholic Church had acknowledged that there had been cases of abuse and had taken action in relation to that. In fact, in Western Australia an independent panel has been set up under the chairmanship of Jane Brazier, who is a senior public servant, who is not a Catholic, and who comes from the Bureau of Disability Services. I understand that the response to that panel has been good. What is being looked at is how victims can be assisted and also whether any evidence is being put forward which can be acted upon. I understand that that independent panel has a consulting psychologist who is assisting in the investigation.

When you consider what is being done and the admissions that are being made, it is really quite inappropriate for a judicial or Senate inquiry to be called for at this stage. When one looks at what such an inquiry could result in, one is left with the question: what could an inquiry do? Not much more than is being done at the moment. The police are investigating the matter, there is this independent inquiry, and people are exercising their rights at law in New South Wales by issuing writs. I would say to those people who insist on an inquiry that there is no benefit to be had from such an inquiry and that only harm could result because of the frustration it might cause to these other matters I have mentioned, which are, after all, an exercise in the due process of the law.

There is one other matter Senator Parer mentioned with which I entirely agree. An inquiry of this nature could also result in the unfair denigration of the Christian Brothers congregation as a whole, which I think would be most unfortunate. We have seen many inquiries over recent years that have resulted in the destruction of reputations of individuals. We have seen inquiries where unsubstantiated evidence has been called under privilege, and that has resulted in a very unfair situation for citizens of this country. One always has to be very careful, when one calls for an inquiry, to make sure that it is the measure of last resort.
I can only say, from my own experience, that the Christian Brothers did a very good job with me—although that might be open to some query.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be better phrased, I think.
—I can say this with objectivity: if it had not been for their persistence and patience with me I certainly would not find myself in the position I am in today.
—You went downhill to the Senate.

—No, I think not. I do think the brothers have contributed greatly to the education of young boys in this country. One thing they taught us was fairness. They were the epitome of social justice. I can recall one occasion when Brother Kelly brought to the front of the class a fellow who thought he was very smart at mathematics. He said, `You take over the lesson and you teach the boys'. That inspired those boys who were not so good at mathematics because they saw that this fellow they thought was so smart really was not so smart after all. I can tell the Senate that at the end of the year 110 boys passed both mathematics A and mathematics B; there was not one failure. I think that speaks volumes.

PARA.TAB: I say to the Senate that we should think very carefully before we call for this inquiry, and I say that from personal experience and also from a legal perspective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an issue that is of significance not only in my state of Tasmania but nationally. I refer to the question of drug law reform. Why is it that we can be acutely aware of social problems associated with substance dependency and yet continue to fail in our attempts to provide appropriate legislation or strategic responses to address the issues? Today I wish to discuss some of the apparent difficulties legislators face with respect to adopting reformist policy initiatives and to suggest that, if we are serious in our intention and desire to deal effectively with substance dependency, we must adopt a program of law reform and we must dedicate adequate resources to appropriate service delivery agents.

PARA.TAB: It is imperative that we begin to widen our view and direct our funds to alternative approaches in dealing with substance abuse. For instance, in Tasmania there are no services offered to drug users where they can receive medium- or long-term residential treatment. Clients are often referred necessarily to interstate facilities. This cannot be interpreted, by even the most residualist approach to welfare, as an acceptable level of service by government. The need for more support services and an increased level of integration between existing services is essential if we are to achieve a level of change and adaptability of our services to meet the needs of drug users in our community.

As those who control the allocation of public moneys attempt to rationalise their welfare budget, the service providers working in the field of substance dependency must protect their funding. It appears that often the manner by which agencies receive recurrent funding is more likely to be determined by historical factors than on the grounds of evaluation, input and outcomes. I would argue that we can no longer justify continued financial support of large government agencies and units if it cannot be shown that they provide the standard of service we desire. On the other hand, the funding of community-based organisations with high client numbers has remained low, thus marginalising many of those workers and clients. I know of a community-based counselling service for young people in Hobart that has a budget of $60,000 for 1992-93, yet services over 600 clients. The operators of the counselling service have told me of the difficulties they experience in ensuring continuity of service delivery because of the intense competition for resources.

Bearing in mind that differences exist between states and territories with respect to drug dependency patterns, I draw upon issues from my own state of Tasmania to exemplify some of the areas to which we must turn our attention. Tasmania experiences a dearth of treatment options for our drug dependent population. NCADA funding to the state is disproportionately allocated to the government-run detoxification facilities and the government-run services without there being any clear evidence of significant outcomes.

To paraphrase Grant Wardlaw in his discussion in 1992 on Australia's drug strategy, the pattern of much of the debate over drug policy in recent years has pitted demand reduction against supply reduction. There has been considerable criticism of law enforcement for its perceived failure to contain drug use. However, most observers now realise that the failure was not of law enforcement but of society, with unrealistic achievements placed upon it. It is time for us to accept that the path we have followed has not provided us with a satisfactory result in our efforts to maximise the harm from drug use. This can come about only if policy is aimed to achieve integration and cooperation.

Another important aspect of Tasmania's situation is the provision of drug and alcohol services in prisons. NCADA parameters clearly identify that prevention and treatment services in prisons should be developed and that these should be coordinated with services outside the prisons, together with general health, welfare and education services within the prisons.

The program which operates in Tasmania is provided by a community-based organisation on a budget of $24,000 in 1992-93. With an average population of 300 inmates in five separate locations, I am deeply concerned as to the rationale behind such a meagre level of funding for a program which is explicitly targeted to address a focus of the NCADA guidelines. Once again, this highlights the difficulty in ensuring that what is enunciated in policy through NCADA must find a way of being implemented at the ground level in a manner which reflects our emphasis.

In relation to drug law reform, I can only emphasise the facts that have been produced by many others before me. Treatment of substance-dependent individuals as criminals has not effectively reduced the incidence of drug-related problems. In fact, the negative impact of incarceration, particularly among young people, cannot be refuted. We must find alternatives to legal sanctions and then we must implement them. It is absurd that we continue to explore approaches from other countries and other states and yet hesitate to implement anything that resembles radical reform.

I do not believe we can continue to adopt this tortoise-like pace in relation to drug issues. While we procrastinate and debate the possible pros and cons of particular policies without making the necessary changes to our existing position, more of our population is being devastated by the way in which we manage and attempt to help substance-dependent individuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to raise a concern about some confusion surrounding the tax-exempt status of business enterprise centres. These business enterprise centres are well established around Australia. In fact, their activities are coordinated by an organisation called Business in the Community Ltd, and a network is in place which in New South Wales is made up of 47 units.

PARA.TAB: The organisation of business enterprise centres is by no means an amateurish affair. They are largely operated by active and retired businessmen who provide their services voluntarily for the purpose of advising prospective and established business people in the small business area to assist them to survive. In fact, they are one of the most effective ways of assisting small business. They were granted public benevolent institution status similar to that given to, for example, the RSPCA, in February 1992. The effect of this was that they were exempt from sales tax and, at the same time, were entitled to certain income tax concessions.

The Parramatta branch of the tax office advised by letter dated 7 October 1993 that tax deductions to business enterprise centres will no longer be available from the date of that letter. The Parramatta branch has taken the view that business enterprise centres play more of a counselling, advising and referral role than actually providing relief in a direct sense. We feel that their activities can be distinguished from those conducted, for example, by Skillshare. That particular branch of the tax office goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we consider that the Enterprise Centres do not provide direct and immediate relief to a class of persons in need of benevolent relief.

However, the Newcastle office, after consultation with its national office, ruled in favour of business enterprise centres. I put it to the Senate that it is difficult to understand how one branch of the tax office can directly contradict the advice of another, especially when we are told by the national office that it has a computer network that provides the mechanism for uniform advice to all offices right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: The point I wish to make is that business enterprise centres clearly do assist the unemployed and the small business sector on an increasingly day-to-day basis. In the current economic climate, with massive retrenchments and voluntary redundancy from the Public Service, more and more people are turning their skills towards small business. They invest their savings and time into small business, and the business enterprise centres provide invaluable assistance in achieving that particular objective. In fact, business enterprise centres are not financed by the federal government, and the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) might like to take that issue on board. Their operating costs are actually funded by state governments and the community—for example, service clubs and Rotary clubs—on an equal basis. The greatest resource advice is provided absolutely free by the volunteers, who are active and retired business people.

The tax revenue to be recovered by the tax office, as a result of the reversal of its position on the exemption status of business enterprise centres, will not be significant in any particular way. Generally, the only staff member of a business enterprise centre who is remunerated is the executive officer—the coordinator. So the exempt status allowed to a business enterprise centre, for example, to purchase a car for the executive officer would normally be free of sales tax. Under the ruling from Parramatta, that will not be so, but under the ruling from Newcastle, people in that centre can be sales tax free.

To require business enterprise centres to pay sales tax but to deny them the other income tax concessions does seem to be unfair. It is essential that they have a public benevolent institution classification so that they can obtain the benefits of sales tax and the other income tax concessions. I call on the Australian Taxation Office to review its position and to ensure, at least, that they get uniform advice and, more particularly, to make sure that they maintain the concessions that are available by means of being public benevolent institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I raise a matter in relation to the administration of the Bankruptcy Act. It is a matter I first raised upon the presentation of the annual report by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy. However, in the time since the presentation of the report last week, I have been contacted by a number of trustees who are active in the administration of bankruptcy who have raised further matters with me. I have worked through those matters and I come to the chamber with much more detail and with very grave concerns about our commitment to enforcing the Bankruptcy Act.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators should understand that the Bankruptcy Act has obligations placed on trustees both to protect the interests of creditors and also, in certain cases, to safeguard the rights of the debtor. Of course, the whole thrust of the Bankruptcy Act is that a person can be relieved of his debts—he is also relieved of his property—and he gets an opportunity after the expiry of the bankruptcy to start his life afresh. Most trustees work assiduously at attempting to do this.

The difficulty comes, however, when a bankrupt or, in some cases, a debtor under part X of the Bankruptcy Act seeks to alienate his assets so that there is absolutely no money available for the trustee to fund an investigation of the bankrupt's business affairs. Honourable senators have to understand that the trustees can only conduct investigations where there is money available in the estate to pay the costs. In other words, there have to be assets available for realisation. We are not talking just about payment of their own costs and expenses but also necessary legal costs, for example, if a trustee chooses to have a bankrupt publicly examined.

I well remember, when I was working in the insolvency profession, a number of cases in which people originally had very substantial assets but, over a period of time, they were alienated, put into discretionary trusts and companies, the shares of which were owned by other companies which owned shares in other companies and so on, so that there were no assets available for distribution to creditors. That is of great concern. That is a fraud on the creditors.
