In many cases, it is a fraud on the Commonwealth because, frequently, it is a Commonwealth instrumentality that is on the receiving end of some of this fraudulent activity.

The Bankruptcy Act contains a provision in section 305 that allows trustees to make application to the minister, the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy or the Assistant Secretary of the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia for Commonwealth funding of actions in relation to the estate. Frequently, they are public examinations. In some cases, they can be actions to recover assets, for example, that have been alienated within what is called the relation-back period. In other cases, they are more substantial actions to recover assets, sometimes overseas assets.

It is interesting, when one turns to page 118 of the 1993 annual report, to see a dwindling in the number of cases approved for funding under section 305 of the act. In 1986-87, there were 237 cases which received approval for government funding under section 305. The next year it was 168; the next year it was 51; then 58, 87, and now 68 cases in the 1992-93 financial year. The government was coming before us last financial year and saying, `We must become tough with bankruptcy administration, we must streamline the simple bankruptcies, but we must give extra powers for trustees to investigate the particularly heinous or objectionable bankruptcies'. Reference was made to Mr Skase, and I do not disagree with that at all. At the same time as the government was talking tough on bankruptcy administration, it was restricting the funds available to trustees under this section.

The interesting thing is that it has always been the case that the 305 funding, as it is called—that is, the guarantees or the underwriting of legal expenses given under section 305—has been paid out of fees on the realisation of assets. Honourable senators will not be aware of it if they merely read the act, but if they read the rules in bankruptcy, which do not accompany the act in the form in which it is available from the Australian Government Publishing Service but which are available separately, they will find that in rule 179(4) there is a fee which is prescribed as payable by a trustee on the lodgment of his accounts in the estate of the bankrupt. The trustee has to lodge these accounts every year.

On the first $50,000 of the prescribed amount, the fee is three per cent. If the prescribed amount exceeds $50,000 but does not exceed $100,000, it is a fee equal to $1,500 plus an amount of 2 1/2 per cent on everything over $50,000. Above that, it is a fee equal to the sum of $2,750 and an amount equal to 1 1/4 per cent of the amount that exceeds $100,000.

Paragraph 5 of the rules goes on to say what is a prescribed amount. Basically the prescribed amount is the total receipts less any amounts paid to secured creditors in respect of their securities, any amounts paid by the trustee in the carrying on of the business of the bankrupt and any amount of the surplus. In many cases, of course, when we are dealing with a bankrupt estate there is a secured creditor, but it is not that common that they are going to have a cost in trading order business because most bankruptcies are not of that nature. That is a cost which is more ordinarily incurred in the winding-up or receivership of the company.

I went through the annual report and looked at the total receipts by trustees, both official trustees and also private trustees. Under part IV of the Bankruptcy Act, which is bankruptcy, and under part X of the act, which is debtor arrangements under the act, something in the vicinity of $27,441,039 was received into the common investment fund of the official trustees; funds totalling $18,478,373 were received by trustees in respect of bankrupt estates and $38,358,393 was received by trustees in relation to part X estates. The total receipts by trustees under the Bankruptcy Act last year were $84,277,805.

Roughly speaking, that should mean that fees payable will not exceed $2.5 million. Three per cent of that is a bit over $2.5 million but it is unlikely to be that different from the $2.5 million. The exact figure, which is probably in the vicinity of $2 million, was received by the registrars in bankruptcy in each of the jurisdictions. So we have $2 million which has been received in fees; yet in the last financial year total approvals for funding under section 305 amounted to $413,200. That is something in the vicinity of one-fifth of the total amount of fees received.

It gets worse, of course, because we all know that in many cases the actions succeed in recovering assets. The report of the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy makes it perfectly clear that the Commonwealth is never required to pay out all the money which is approved for funding. In fact, it says that over the last few years the average annual amount paid out is $104,000, which is a very small sum. It is something like one-twentieth of the total amount received in fees.

That sounds bad enough, but it gets worse. Guidelines were issued under section 305 of the Bankruptcy Act to trustees this year on 21 July. They were also accompanied by a letter from the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, Mr R. G. Moss, which is dated 3 August 1993. I do intend to speak on them very briefly, but at this point I seek leave of the chamber to have those documents tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the documents and I thank the Senate. Section 305 funding is governed by these guidelines and it is quite interesting to see what it says. For example, in the scope of the funding, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.3 Funding may be available:
—where there is a significant public interest to be protected

—where there is not a significant public interest, and no creditors are able or willing to indemnify the trustee, but where the Inspector-General considers that there are good prospects for recovery of assets or property if the proposed action is pursued and there are creditors deserving of assistance.
That makes it sound as though the Inspector-General is going to be reasonably generous in allocating the section 305 funding. But his explanatory letter says:

This section is streamlined, to emphasise there are two clear funding categories: those where there is `a significant public interest to be protected', and those where there is not. In the latter case, funding will not ordinarily be provided.

The problem is, if the creditors have looked at it and have decided that they are incapable of funding it for commercial reasons, people are unlikely to get the section 305 underwriting. The problem with that is that in many cases the creditors are not able to fund it because they are carrying so many debts that are owed by the bankrupt estate anyway and their own business is being squeezed.

PARA.TAB: The other difficulty with these guidelines is that they require trustees to get lawyers to do the work for 80 per cent of the scale fee. The trustees themselves do not get remunerated unless they can recover sufficient funds to pay the costs of the lawyers, pay their own costs and then make a distribution to creditors. In the very peculiar case that trustees get their costs covered, they are only covered at 80 per cent. Those would be the cases where it is in the public interests for a trustee to pursue a bankrupt—for example, Mr Skase. Yet we expect this trustee to do this work at 80 per cent of the scale fee. In those cases, the work involved is quite substantial and trustees do not operate on large profit margins. The consequence of that is that the work will not be done.

The program portfolio estimates of this department were slightly misleading. They set out quite clearly the expenditure, which is in fact declining this financial year. The expenditure of Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia will decline from a 1992-93 estimate of $27,635,000 to a 1993-94 estimate of $22,252,000. When we look at the revenue aspect of the program, on page 74 of the program portfolio estimates, we see that it talks about the revenue received by the Commonwealth. It also talks about dividends paid to Commonwealth instrumentalities, usually the Australian Taxation Office; about official trustee fees, which are taken on a scaled fee basis on realisations; and about interest on the common investment fund which does not get credited to bankrupt estates. In 1991-92 that totalled $7.9 million. In 1992-93 it totalled $8.98 million.

We are seeing Commonwealth funding going down and revenues going up, but nowhere in the program portfolio estimates is there an outline of the amount of fees that are also received by the Commonwealth through the registrars in bankruptcy from the estates of bankrupts and paid by the trustees. We see that that may well be in the vicinity of $2 million. So what we are seeing is a government beating its chest a lot about getting tough on bankruptcy administration, but not matching that with resources. It is also not matching that with funding. In fact, it is taking very large amounts out of the coffers of the trustees, and out of the hands of the creditors, and it is not even displaying those figures in the annual reports.

I hope this will receive some action by the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy or by the Attorney-General. Bankruptcy is a very serious matter. We do have to have compassion for those who are bankrupted but we also have to have an enforcement of the legislation where it is appropriate. I think the government should match its words with deeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the film Cenotaph. Senator Faulkner was kind enough to draw to my attention the fact that the film was being shown in Parliament House. I had the chance to view the film and, given the importance of this particular project, I would like to make a few comments about it. I think that most Australians who see the film will think of it as a very moving film. Many people will find the historical footage of the First World War and the first Anzac day parades to be a very emotional experience.

PARA.TAB: I think many families will be able to effectively identify with some of the individual stories which are mentioned in the film of the young men who went to the First World War. The film also records the visit of the old diggers to France. I think that was in August. Part of the film focuses on the school that was built in Villers-Bretonneux after the war, through the contributions of Victorian school children. This is a story which I think deserves to be told and retold.

The film told the story of the Great War from the perspective of the township of Hay, from which township a very high proportion of the young men decided to volunteer in the First World War and left our shores. I think that was a particularly original approach. It gave the backgrounds to all those weathering memorials which appear in virtually every township throughout the nation. I always feel it is particularly moving to drive into an Australian country town and to see, often in the main street, a memorial to the men who left that township some 75 years ago.

This film is part of a series of films. It is the first of seven films on Australia's forces. The aim was to show to viewers the impact on our culture, our heritage and our character of the participation of our forces in the various campaigns in which Australians have fought. Senator Faulkner expressed the hope that it will boost community awareness of the participation and contribution made by Australians to notable events and the campaigns within these conflicts as well as of the overall outcomes.

There are five matters that I would like to raise in, I hope, a constructive way. I think the film is a worthwhile film. It is a film that I certainly hope a lot of Australians will have the opportunity to see. I think it was a pity that the film did not mention the great strategic significance of the First World War for Australia. Without mentioning this at least in a brief manner, the viewer of the film may be left wondering why this magnificent army ever left our shores.

As the great war historian Bean points out in his book Anzac to Amiens, had the Great War resulted in a German victory, `the first term in the peace treaty would have been the abolition of the British Navy; and for the Australian nation this meant either subservience to Germany or extinction at the hands of the Japanese'. Honourable senators will recall that around that period there were a number of areas in the Pacific region where Germany had control. Of course, one of those areas was the neighbouring country of Papua New Guinea. So there was a significant strategic reason why Australia had a great interest in a successful outcome to this war.

Unless we say that, it is a bit hard to explain why so many Australians were prepared to leave our shores and fight for so long. It seems to me that, to a certain extent, we undervalue the sacrifice made by these Australians if we do not mention the overall outcome. Despite the dreadful loss of young men and despite the blunders that were made, at the end of the day the war was won, and that was of great strategic significance for Australia.

The second point I would like to make is that, while the film appropriately highlighted the dreadful loss of life and the great agony of war, to my mind, it largely ignored the brilliant victories in which Australians played a significant role. It is interesting that some dramatic events occurred on 8 August 1918, just 75 years ago. This was the occasion when the five Australian divisions broke through the German lines. General Ludendorff, who was in charge of the Germany army, described this as `the black day of the German Army in the history of the War'.

If, as Senator Faulkner said, we are to consider the contributions Australians made to notable events, to my mind, it would have been appropriate to mention again, albeit briefly, the battles in the months leading up to the armistice on 11 November 1918. Monash says in his book on the battles of 1918:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the claim may fairly be made for the Australian Army corps, that in each of the stages of operations which led to the military overthrow—
of the German Army—
the corps played an important and, in some of them, a predominating part. No better testimony for such a conclusion can be adduced than the admissions of Ludendorff himself.

PARA.TAB: The third point I would like to make in relation to our national character is that Bean further observes that Australians achieved more than national security. He points out that the experience brought `a new confidence into Australian national undertakings . . . the return of the AIF, its leaders covered with distinction, its ranks acclaimed overseas as one of the notable fighting forces in history, deeply, if insensibly, affected that outlook'. There is no question that the First World War and the experiences, both negative and otherwise, did have a major effect on the Australian character.

The fourth point I make, and it is a related point, is that we should not be shy of acknowledging the great fighting qualities of these men. It is often expressed that we do not want to glorify war, and I agree with that. On the other hand, it is appropriate to pay tribute to men who show great skill in the military arts and show the great characteristics of courage and sacrifice. This was touched on in the film when it referred to the magnificent army. I think that Patsy Adam-Smith expressed this point particularly powerfully in her book on the ANZACs.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great Australian writer.

—Correct, a great Australian writer, and I do not think anyone would describe Patsy Adam-Smith as a conservative. In her book on the ANZACs she wrote about the Australian armies in the First World War and she addressed them directly. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: You had the greatest number of casualties per men in the field of all the Allied armies; you travelled furtherest, were away the longest. You were the only volunteers. You came from a newer land, were a younger race than any who entered that awful arena. When time has removed this age to a distance, our descendants will speak of you now as we speak of the three hundred at Thermopylae . . .

As I said, we should not be shy of acknowledging the great fighting skills of these men and of the armies which they formed. I think it is a pity that the impression was left at the end of the film—and I make the qualification `if my memory serves me correctly' as I do not have the text before me—when in the final comments it was suggested that soldiers were court-martialled and shot if they refused to fight.

PARA.TAB: One of the features of the Australian army, which is very well known in military circles—and, I hope, in the wider community—is that desertion was not punishable by death. I think this actually marked the Australian army as being quite different from virtually all other major armies. As a footnote to history, it is worth noting that the British House of Commons, 12 years after the war, voted to abolish the death penalty for desertion from their own armies. I understand it was said in that debate:

SPEECH.PARA: If it can be demonstrated that the Australians could fight as gallantly as they did without the death penalty, then it is a libel of the courage of other British troops to say they cannot fight without it.

The point I am making there is that we undervalue the heroism of these troops by including what, I think, was an historical inaccuracy. As I said, I think the old footage in Cenotaph of the vast columns of returned servicemen marching in the early Anzac Day parades shows just how proud these men were of their achievements and, indeed, rightly so. To a certain extent, the film will explain to the current generation of Australians aspects of this pride that these men felt. My comments today should be read in the light that the film could have given some emphasis to some areas which were mentioned only briefly, or ignored.
