PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation, which the opposition will not be opposing, amends five acts. The amendments proposed to the acts concerned are fairly innocuous. There is no real theme to the amendments. There are essentially no great policy changes involved. While the bill lacks any theme, the focus of the amendments is to improve rights and conditions of service.

PARA.TAB: Very briefly, the effect of the amendments is to modify section 52 of the Defence Act to reflect the fact that certain productivity superannuation determinations are no longer interim; to limit the right of appeal from conscientious objection tribunals and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the Federal Court to appeals on questions of law; to streamline overseas command procedures where forces of Australia and other nations serve together and to provide a more precise delegation provision, which means they have got some authority; to allow a minister, rather than the Governor-General, to appoint certain trustees to welfare trust funds; to provide a special loan benefit to Australian Defence Force members for warlike service; to amend section 117A dealing with salvage claims by crews of naval ships; and finally to amend the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act to remove the liability for double benefit for members who have transferred from DFRDB to MSBS and who have since retired.

I will deal briefly with those changes. In relation to the conscientious objection tribunals, these amendments raise a couple of minor questions that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) might care to address. Firstly, considering that the legislation to validate the conscientious objection tribunals was passed only last year, following a gestation period which goes back to the mid-1980s, why is this being changed now? Why was it not foreseen and done at the time? I am curious to know why it has now been decided to restrict the right of appeal merely to questions of law.

In relation to the home loans provisions, according to the Department of Defence annual report, the objectives of the scheme include encouragement of home ownership during service as a cost-effective alternative to rental assistance. Further, it is to assist in the reintegration of defence force personnel into the community on return to civilian employment. Basically, the scheme entitles members to an interest subsidy on a loan funded by the National Australia Bank. Interest on the loan is subsidised to the extent of 40 per cent of the average interest payable over the term of the loan. The maximum loan to which a subsidised interest rate can be paid is $40,000. Various rules apply as to eligibility and so on. The amendment seeks a waiver to the qualifying period, as defined in clause 13 of the principal act. Additionally, it extends the years of loan subsidy, depending on the length of warlike service, and allows for future extension, dependent upon subsequent service.

This amendment represents another method for compensating members of the ADF and recognising their overseas service. Recent examples of this were the Gulf War, which attracted slightly different rules, and service in Cambodia, Somalia and the former Yugoslavia. This loan will count in the assessment of income for the purpose of estimating family payment and additional payment. Under a recent amendment to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, this loan now becomes a fringe benefit if the recipient is in that income area which is considered low enough to attract additional assistance for the family. This group, therefore, will be financially penalised, depending on the formula as contained in the act, for taking up this loan which Defence claims is a cost-effective alternative to rental assistance. However, if the recipients in the services are above the AFP cut-off point, then this loan will be of benefit to them. In practice, what the government has done has been to create two different classes of recipients within the Australian Defence Force—those who gain home loan assistance as a condition of service and those who acquire a home loan as a fringe benefit. The great irony here is that fringe benefits are normally something acquired by people on high incomes, not on low incomes.

Under the legislation that passed through this chamber a few months back, legislation that was enthusiastically supported by the minister at the time, those in the Australian defence forces who are on higher incomes currently do not receive any so-called fringe benefits, but it is those on the lower salary scales who are going to be classed as receiving a fringe benefit. Not only do they receive this so-called fringe benefit as a basis of their conditions of service but the sad consequence of it is that, since it will now be classified as a fringe benefit for low income earners, they will not get the family support that they needed to maintain their standard of living and consequently they will go backwards. They are, of course, the group in the defence forces which can least sustain this attack on their family budget.

I raised this matter with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Senator Faulkner, during the estimates hearings, and he started off by comparing members of the ADF with the Public Service in terms of remuneration. I have always argued in this place, as all honourable senators would know, that the members of the Australian Defence Force are not members of the civilian community; they are a unique force and they are paid certain allowances as a reward for the conditions of service that are different from all civilian occupations. He also made this admission at the start of the Senate estimates hearing, when I was questioning him on the effect of the legislation on these low income groups:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot say to you directly what specific impact there will be on any individual defence family.
The minister also stated:

As you would be aware, the Minister for Social Security or the minister who represents him in the Senate would obviously have more direct knowledge of this than you would expect the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to have.

I certainly do expect the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to have a very detailed knowledge of the impact of legislation on his own people, the people in the Australian Defence Force. Later on in the Senate estimates hearing he did say:
I am aware of the impact on defence families and other Australian families of the bill that saw passage through the Senate. . .

He realised that there was going to be an impact but he could not quantify it. He did not know what effect it is going to have, and I do not think that is good enough. It is nowhere good enough for a minister, particularly in the defence field, to not defend to the limit the interests of his constituency, the people he is responsible for in the Australian defence forces. It would be one thing if we are talking about a minister for the Treasury or for social security or something like that where there is a great aggregation of people in the Public Service under comparable conditions. But for the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel not to have fought for the interests of the members of the ADF and won the case, as they could well have—because there is no way anyone would describe Senator Ray in a political forum as a lightweight or an easy push-over—is I think quite reprehensible.

PARA.TAB: The next item I want to talk about is superannuation. This legislation also deals with defence superannuation. It cleans up a problem the government itself created through a badly framed disallowable instrument last year. Additionally, an amendment is made to reflect the fact that productivity superannuation determinations are no longer interim. These measures are acceptable to the opposition. However, again it is odd that the government is involved in an exercise to clean up the defence superannuation area on the one hand yet on the other is apparently using superannuation as an instrument in its attempt to achieve increased separations to preserve government budget targets with respect to the Department of Defence budget.

For example, if ADF members separate voluntarily but before the completion of their term, they attract a superannuation penalty, but, should they accept a redundancy package prior to the completion of their term, the penalty is waived. While it is not directly related, I should comment that, as far as I can ascertain, the return of service obligation is also being waived on a selective basis. But, to return to superannuation, reports are now circulating that superannuation is also being used as a convenient way to ensure—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., I call on questions without notice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, is attending the national trade and investment outlook conference in Melbourne and will be absent from question time today. During his absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolios of trade and primary industries and energy.
—Again, the parliament is second best. It is typical. Any conference is good enough—other than the parliament. It is typical of the attitude of your Prime Minister.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the efforts by Australian business over recent years to improve trade and commercial links with Malaysia, and to the background of ongoing problems, self-generated by the Prime Minister. Will the minister explain to the Senate how the attack on Dr Mahathir by Mr Keating helps the private sector to develop industry links and capitalise on trading opportunities with Malaysia?

—I have very little to add to what I have already said on the public record in relation to this matter. It is very important that this issue be kept in proportion, and we certainly propose to do our best to keep it that way.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that the deputy head of UMNO youth has sent a letter to Australia's High Commissioner in Malaysia, Mr John Dauth. That letter is not a communication from the Malaysian government. The High Commissioner, in fact, is currently accompanying a senior Malaysian business delegation to the national trade and investment outlook conference in Melbourne, which is where Senator Cook is at the moment. It is the biggest such conference in the history of this country and one of the most important contributions that could be made to the business environment of this country, I say by way of interpolation in response to Senator Hill's original, opening, very churlish remarks. Mr Dauth, as the High Commissioner, will respond appropriately to the letter in question when he returns to Malaysia.

The government's position remains exactly as I described it in this place a couple of days ago, on 23 November. I add just this: our relationship with Malaysia is a very substantial and very balanced one which I think is unlikely to be blown off course by cross-winds of this kind. It is an important relationship which produces major benefits, not just for Australia but for both sides. Both our leaders have a habit of expressing themselves from time to time in rather forthright terms, but I believe that our bilateral relationship is capable of withstanding such exchanges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. More specifically, did the Prime Minister take into account the business and industrial links between Australia and Malaysia when he chose to make the derogatory comments about Dr Mahathir? In particular, did he take into account the years of hard, solid effort, without personal abuse, put in by Australian businessmen to build such relationships?
—I expect he did so to the same extent as Dr Hewson, Mr Fischer and Mr Peacock, each of whom has expressed some understanding for the context in which the Prime Minister made the remarks that he did.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and it refers to the recent unanimous United Nations General Assembly resolution in support of a comprehensive test ban treaty. What impact will that have on the achievement of a complete international ban on nuclear testing in all environments for all time?

—It has been rather under-noticed in this country and in this parliament that last week, for the first time ever, the international community gave its unanimous support for a UN resolution calling for a comprehensive test ban treaty. That resolution, of which Australia was the chief sponsor, had a record number of 156 co-sponsors. Such an outcome is a very significant breakthrough in Australia's and a lot of other countries' endeavours to achieve a total prohibition of all nuclear tests in all environments for all time.
—Like the Cold War.

—The Cold War has been over for five years; Senator Hill might not have noticed that. This is the first time that this has been able to be achieved in all the efforts since that period. I would not expect him to understand or appreciate these matters. He is again demonstrating that he is absolutely true to form.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly significant that this year the resolution was able to secure the support of the five nuclear weapon states. It is now vital that the international community turn this expression of political will into practical action in the form of a negotiated convention at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva. The resolution calls on the CD in Geneva and all UN members to undertake cooperative and intensive negotiations towards the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had a talk to China?

—I have had a number of talks to China about the comprehensive test ban treaty. Senator Hill will be pleased to know that China says that it supports such a treaty. But he would not know, because he has to be told these things.

PARA.TAB: This resolution also reaffirms the need for a continuation of the moratorium on nuclear testing that is currently in place for four of the five nuclear weapons states. I take this opportunity to call again, as we have in the past, on all nuclear weapons states to build on that spirit of the resolution and to now maintain a genuine moratorium on testing while the CTBT—the comprehensive test ban treaty—is negotiated. We have always very strongly supported the CTBT as it would greatly advance nuclear non-proliferation and disarmament goals, including the prospects for an indefinite extension of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty—the NPT—at the 1995 review and extension conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has the Minister for Family Services, in her child-care guidelines, chosen to ignore the attitudes and values of parents and families and given priority to the ideology of a few trendy child-care professionals?
—Have you read them?
—Yes.
—Shame! The way you've distorted them and beat them up is a disgrace. I have three young kids and I reckon they're great.
—Order, Senator Collins! The question was asked of Senator Crowley.

—I said it yesterday, I have said it many times before, including on the radio, and I am happy to say it again: they are not my guidelines. I am ignoring nothing. Those guidelines were written by the child-care industry, which is represented by private and public child-care centres and parents. I can only say again and again that those child-care guidelines were written by the industry.

PARA.TAB: It was also suggested today that there has been no consultation with the child-care industry. This program has formally been in consultation with the child-care industry, which involves centres and parents, since the beginning of 1992. But the process was proceeding well before that. The representatives of the child-care industry defined these guidelines, wrote those words, made these conclusions, and they are extensively understood by the child-care centres.

I have also told the Senate—I am happy to tell it again—that the guidelines accreditation process was pilot tested in a large number of centres, which reported only very high acceptance and appreciation of the process. Those centres, parents and staff were involved in it.

The campaign of misinformation by the opposition is making people fearful and anxious about this process. As I have said again and again, those guidelines were designed and written by the industry and accepted by government. Where they have been tested in the community and with parents, they have acknowledged their appreciation of them. It is just drawing a spurious red herring to suggest that I have ignored parents' wishes. They are the parents' and the child-care providers' words; they are not the government's words.

It is also important to understand that centres will be provided with these guidelines; indeed, most of them now have them. They can sit down and work through them. No-one—no police force or bureaucrats—will investigate them. The centres will assess themselves.
Unless the opposition is determined to be thick about this issue then it should understand the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not thick; they are just malicious.

—The guidelines are designed by the industry and they will be assessed and evaluated by the centres themselves. How much more clearly can I put it? The centres will have the guidelines which they will evaluate themselves. The difficulty the opposition is having with this issue may be because, as my colleagues say, they are not thick but they are determined to misunderstand it. The centres wrote the guidelines. The centres will assess them themselves. I believe the opposition would do much better in this debate if it waited for the judgment of the parents and centres themselves.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In my question I referred to the parents and the family. I ask the minister how she defines `the family'?

—That question was asked to distract entirely from the discussion about child care. As Senator Herron properly knows, that is also a matter which is being debated in the legislation which is currently before the Senate. It would be inappropriate for me to comment on the legislation which is currently in committee.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Herron knows, the commonly understood meaning of child care and the family is,—

TALK.START.PARA: —Define it.

—This is an amazing response from the opposition. It does not want to know what is in the guidelines. It does not want to know that the purpose of the guidelines is to assure parents of the quality of child care and to know that parents will be happy—
—Mr President, I am trying to raise a point of order.
—Maybe I did not hear the point of order because of the constant interjections from both sides. I ask that they cease.
—Mr President, I seek your help. Would you explain the question to Senator Crowley because she does not seem to understand it.
—This is another spurious point of order that should not and will not be allowed.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the minister inform the Senate whether there has been an improvement in investment in Australian industry and, if so, where such improvements are occurring?

—I thank Senator Murphy for his question. I am sorry that people do not think investment in Australia is as important as distorting the child-care guidelines. Most Australians do consider investment to be important. It is actually a particularly timely question. The Australian Bureau of Statistics yesterday released its September quarter survey of private new capital expenditure. The survey shows that in the June quarter, private new capital expenditure grew by 2 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms. Those commentators who have expressed some scepticism as to the importance of these numbers have failed to look behind the aggregate figures and analyse their composition. It is important to note—and if the commentators had assessed the figures they would have noted—that investment in plant and equipment increased by a very solid 5 per cent. Expected new capital expenditure for 1993-94—that is, business expectations—has risen by 6 per cent since its already revised June quarter estimate.

PARA.TAB: This follows a significant upward revision to the actual level of private investment in 1992-93. The rate of growth in the volume of plant and equipment investment has been revised upwards from 1.6 per cent to 5.4 per cent. People on the other side of the chamber are happy to make negative comments, but I have not heard them commenting on the upward revisions. This substantially improves the base on which this latest evidence of improving expectations is now building.

The Treasurer has publicly noted on a number of occasions in recent days that it is now clear that the economy is on the move, even though the opposition would love to find ways of talking it down. This morning the Australian Bureau of Statistics released manufacturers' sales figures showing that these are estimated to have grown by 2 per cent in real seasonally adjusted terms in the September quarter. Expected sales for 1993-94 have been revised upwards by 4 per cent since the June survey. A pick-up in investment in new productive capacity is crucial to ensuring that the recovery, which is unequivocally under way, is sustained and that unemployment is reduced.

I am pleased to see that at least one shadow minister is acknowledging that the business situation is improving. Opposition members do not want to hear about the fact that the economy is improving because they are very disappointed when it happens. They would love the situation where they could continue to say how bad it was but, unfortunately for them, things are improving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment went up last month, didn't it?

—No, it did not. These figures are therefore particularly encouraging, as are anecdotal reports that the opposition wants to interject about. The opposition wants to disguise the fact that, as well as employment growing, there are important positive announcements such as yesterday's press report—that the opposition would hate to recognise—that the electronics giant Siemens is planning to invest more than $100 million in new research and development in Australia. I have been waiting to hear the opposition welcome that, but I have not heard a word.

PARA.TAB: Business is beginning to respond—this is just another sign of the positive response. Company profits figures released today for the September quarter show a further increase of five per cent—the ninth consecutive quarterly increase which has taken this series to its highest level since the series was commenced in 1985. So I think there is a broad range of statistics that builds on the welcome growth in employment which is being shown in the Australian economy. The significant trend in increased employment, which the opposition always fails to recognise; the increase in private new capital expenditure; the upward revision in the level of private investment; and the release of improvements in manufacture sales figures continue to confirm the improvement. These are not figures I am making up; these are all figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which is recognised internationally as amongst the best one or two statistical organisations in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the minister: would any delay in this parliament's considering and passing the Native Title Bill 1993 diminish the rights of Aboriginal people in Western Australia, particularly in the light of the actions the Western Australian state government will be able to take once it passes its own legislation, which I understand is being guillotined through its parliament today. Secondly, what is the extent to which the Native Title (Status Quo) Bill 1993, which I understand is to be introduced here tomorrow, can be realistically expected to avert any diminution of the rights of Aboriginal people in Western Australia?

—With every respect to our Green colleagues, to describe the legislative adventure on which they embarked yesterday as half baked would, I am afraid, be too much of a compliment. Even the most cursory scrutiny of that Native Title (Status Quo) Bill shows it to be full of legal, constitutional and administrative flaws. Quite apart from the question of whether there is a sufficiently strong Commonwealth head of power to sustain legislation of this kind, and quite apart from the question of the possible implied immunity of states from legislative exercises of Commonwealth power which dramatically impact on the performance through legislation of essential state functions, the bill simply does not address the just terms question which always arises whenever any inhibition on state property dealing is involved.

PARA.TAB: Quite apart from that consideration, the bill does not affect—or even purport to affect, or prevent in any way at all—any grant or extinguishment made under any existing law or, for that matter, by any exercise of executive power. The bill purports only to apply to inhibitions on native title as a result of legislative action undertaken by someone after 1 July. So it is really full of flaws, quite apart from the other problems associated with delaying the passage of this legislation at this stage.

Far from having the practical impact of inhibiting the passage of the Western Australian government's legislation, the presentation of this little number by Senator Chamarette last night provoked precisely the opposite—an obscene flurry of activity throughout the night in the Western Australian parliament when, among other things, for the first time in the history of the Legislative Council in that state and against every stated belief of the parliamentary leaders of that state, the guillotine was used.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hypocrite!

—For a party whose big brother nationally not only carries on like this whenever the use of the guillotine is proposed by us, but which also has been making a major national issue of the need for extended debate, consultation and parliamentary analysis and discussion of complex legislation of this kind, it has been a delightful spectacle to see Mr Richard Court running as fast as his spindly little legs could carry him to fall over the line before this non-existent—and if it did exist, thoroughly impotent—piece of Commonwealth legislation caught up with him.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian legislation itself, about which Senator Kernot also asked me, is—and we will have an opportunity to further debate it in this place before long—something of acute distress to the Aboriginal people in that particular state and, indeed, to Aboriginal people nationally. Far from protecting any aspect of rights of native title, it is, as Carmen Lawrence so aptly described it, in this respect, just a big bagful of nothing. It is a piece of legislation in which the rights of traditional usage which purport to be conveyed by this legislation depend not on decisions of the court, not on any legislative entitlement but, effectively, on the exercise of ministerial discretion.

I hope that the Greens start now on a rather comprehensive rethink of the legislative strategy on which they embarked last night, which so far has been nothing less than a debacle and is destined to remain so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Each year many elderly people are admitted to hospital because of adverse drug reactions. What is the minister able to do to reduce this incidence of adverse drug reactions in veterans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Veterans' Affairs has commenced a repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme project, to be known as the RPBS prescribing awareness program, aimed at improving veterans' health by providing doctors with information about the drug regimes of their patients who are veterans. The Department of Veterans' Affairs recently analysed prescribing patterns and has identified several issues. For example, a patient may attend two medical practitioners who each prescribe different drugs. When used in combination they may lead to serious and adverse drug reactions. Often, neither practitioner is aware of what drugs the other is prescribing. Over a recent four-month period there were several thousand instances where dangerous combinations of drugs were prescribed, many of these involving more than one prescriber.

PARA.TAB: The project will help the medical profession to maintain high quality health care by identifying those drugs or drug combinations that have the potential to cause adverse reactions. When my department becomes aware that a veteran is being prescribed drugs that have the potential to cause adverse drug reactions the prescribers will be contacted and informed of the potential problem as well as being provided with educational material on those drugs in question.

The aim of the program is to improve communication. I can assure the Senate that the department will not be restricting doctors from prescribing necessary medication but will be taking the approach of informing and educating doctors. During the term of the project, the department will look at some specific areas of concern to both the medical profession and veterans' groups. Some of these are the fact that drugs prescribed may not be appropriate for older people; the fact that drugs should not be used for long periods of time; the fact that drugs can cause adverse reactions when taken together; and also the use of asthma medication.

The project has the support of the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia. It also has support of the Returned and Services League and other ex-service organisations which have been consulted about the program.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs leads the way in the area of drug prescribing education. I think data from this project will be of great interest, both nationally and internationally. The project will be trialled late this month. I believe that yet again it is fair to say that this project is an example of this government's commitment to improving the health and the quality of life of Australian veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. Can the minister indicate the status and the outcome of the Australian Electoral Commission inquiry into the Electoral Act breaches by Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins when they threatened various organisations which aggressively campaigned in the March 1993 federal election and were subsequently dropped from various government bodies?

—It is not possible for me to make the political comments about this accusation that I would like to. It is still a matter of inquiry by the AEC, as would be expected, because a complaint has been lodged, so I should not express my views about the query.

PARA.TAB: It is public knowledge that the State Director of the Liberal Party, in a letter submitted with his party's annual return, has referred to some comments he alleges were made by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and has made some allegations about their relationship to section 327 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I am advised that the AEC is considering this matter. It has not yet given me any advice as to the outcome of its consideration, if there has been any outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Will the minister indicate whether Mr Howe and Senator Crowley are also to be the subject of inquiry or prosecution in light of the evidence to Estimates Committee C in which they acknowledged and supported the vindictive banning of the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry?

—There is absolutely no law that can require anybody to waste their time. People are entitled to make a judgment about those to whom they speak and those to whom they do not speak. It remains a free country. We are entitled to choose to speak or not to speak to whomever we wish. That is not the slightest problem, and I am happy to make that generalised comment.

PARA.TAB: Of course, as a matter of proper process, if somebody makes a complaint to the Electoral Commission that anybody has breached the act, the commission will properly inquire into it. But nobody has ever passed a law to say that we have to waste our time talking to people when we think it is a waste of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to my question yesterday to the Minister for Foreign Affairs regarding the intervention of the United States which has resulted in the interruption of the flow of money from the Fred Hollows Foundation to aid projects in Vietnam. Is the minister in a position to advise the Senate whether or not the government has made progress in reversing that action by the United States Department of Treasury to freeze those moneys belonging to the Hollows Foundation?

—The Australian Embassy in Washington has been very actively following up this matter with the relevant US agencies. I pay tribute to the support we have had in this respect from the new US Ambassador to Australia, Mr Ed Perkins, who found this problem on his plate as the very first item of business after he presented his credentials yesterday morning.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to be able to report back to the Senate, as I said I would when I had something to say, that US officials have now found a basis for reversing the original decision and releasing the money in question. On closer examination, it appears that the initial request by the manufacturer of the lenses, which I understand to be a company based in India, for the appropriate licence to carry out this transaction in New York was incomplete in that, among other things, no mention was made of the involvement of a humanitarian NGO—that is, the Hollows Foundation—in the transfer of these lenses to Vietnam.

Now that the US authorities are aware of the humanitarian nature of the transaction and the very good work of the Hollows Foundation, they have advised our embassy that a licence will be issued, probably immediately after the Thanksgiving break.

There was a second issue relating to a fine levied on Westpac. As to that, US officials have advised us that this was levied on a `US person', that is to say the New York branch of Westpac, for not blocking the funds involved as no licence had at that stage been issued. The fine has in fact been paid by Westpac New York. In light of the history of this case and the surrounding circumstances, I do believe that it would be very appropriate for this fine to be rescinded, if there is a discretion open to US authorities to do so, and Australian officials will be pursuing this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Under self-assessment, the government's intention is to ensure that tax returns remain open for amendment for four years; whereby, the tax office can issue an amending assessment during that four-year period. Can a taxpayer, having obtained by objection an amendment to an assessment, seek a second or further amendment, particularly in circumstances where amendments are raised subsequently by the Australian Taxation Office?
—I have not the faintest idea, but I will inquire and find out.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given that the government has been consulting with Australia's indigenous people for more than two years on the ratification of ILO convention 169 on tribal peoples, what is the government's position on ratification of the convention? Will the government ratify before the end of the Year of the World's Indigenous People? If not, why not?

—The government has not yet formed a final view on ratification of ILO convention 169 because the process of consultation in this instance with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and with the state and territory governments, something we are always being commended to do by senators opposite, is still proceeding. The Department of Industrial Relations is the coordinating agency in this process and of course ATSIC is also closely involved.

PARA.TAB: The question of ratification of this particular convention is quite complicated as it represents a comprehensive effort by the international community to set out the rights of indigenous people in a legally binding way. ATSIC is currently coordinating responses received from regional councils and other Aboriginal organisations on both the contents of the convention and the question of its ratification.

Given the nature of the issues involved, it is understandable that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are being quite careful in their approach to the convention. While some elements of those communities do support ratification as a useful step in establishing international instruments for protecting indigenous rights, there are equally other elements in those communities urging a more cautious approach.

In parallel, a thorough analysis of the degree to which Australia already complies with the provisions of the convention is currently being made by relevant departments, in conformity with normal Australian practice before ratification of international treaties is concluded.

The progress of the government's native title legislation through this parliament is, of course, relevant to this issue and the faster that can be passed, the happier we will be in terms of what we can say about its implications for this convention.

For all of these reasons I am not in a position to put any very firm time frame on when this consultative process will be completed. It is, however, clear that the government will not be in a position to ratify the convention before the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. What has taken the process so long? Why is the government waiting when, to refer to a speech of Gough Whitlam, the 1967 referendum on Aborigines gave the federal parliament complete jurisdiction to ratify such a convention, and when the Prime Minister is entitled to claim electoral mandate to pass it this year, having made his Redfern speech on 10 December 1992 at the launch of the International Year of the World's Indigenous People?

—I am afraid that is very much a pre-programmed supplementary. The reason it has taken so long is the complexity of the convention, the range of issues that have to be addressed in it, all of which I spelt out in loving and elaborate detail in the long reply I just gave the honourable senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to a report in the Weekend Australian of 20/21 November—that is, last weekend—that a national intelligence assessment has warned about the dangers to Australia of serious organised Asian crime, including the importing of narcotics into Australia, extortion and illegal immigration; that it had found that Chinese migration provided the liaison and cover to allow the flow of narcotics, without any need for large-scale worldwide organisations; and that Asian women are entering Australia on three- to six-month visas for the sole purpose of prostitution. Can the minister advise the Senate as to whether this report is accurate? If so, what action, if any, has he or his department taken to ensure that the integrity of Australia's migration program is not being breached?

—I have seen that report. In fact, I have had follow-up to that with my own department in respect of the mechanisms we have in place to either respond to this report or, of course, to keep monitoring and keep surveillance of our borders in prevention of some of the activities that were reported in the Weekend Australian.

PARA.TAB: I tell Senator Short and the Senate that the department cooperates with all state and national law enforcement agencies in relation to assessments, and we have a very healthy interaction with those agencies when a specific case is brought to either their attention or our attention. We do have the capacity to respond in certain circumstances, and we do so. Senator Short asked questions of the department during estimates hearings recently in respect of this matter, and I think they satisfied him, the committee and me as to the degree of cooperation on a state and federal level.

Essentially, we have an ongoing responsibility to ensure not only that the sorts of activities that were warned about and reported in the paper are monitored—and I understand the paper that is being talked about is one that has been prepared on a state level—but also that we have effective mechanisms to ensure that those activities do not filter into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I further ask him: can he assure the Senate that he is totally satisfied that fully adequate provisions exist to ensure that all persons either seeking to enter Australia or, if already in Australia on a temporary basis, seeking to remain permanently are subject to thorough, comprehensive character checks? Will he advise the Senate as to the nature of the character checks?

—I think we can approach the response to this particular question on two levels. First of all, I can give an assurance that the mechanisms are in place and that the department takes its responsibilities very seriously to ensure that, both in a generic sense and in specific circumstances and instances, we are at the ready to ensure that the sorts of activities that Senator Short is concerned about and that I am also concerned about, as is the whole government, do not filter through to Australia.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the particular mechanisms and arrangements we have in place, already this week I think Senator Short has requested a briefing on that. Given the sensitivity of some of the arrangements in place, I am prepared publicly to ensure that that briefing goes ahead in its totality so that Senator Short can, on behalf of the opposition, get his own appreciation of the level of the cooperation that we have in place, both on a state and federal level and also internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Will the minister invoke the national forests policy, in particular the old growth and wilderness protection strategy, with respect to his imminent decision to renew woodchip export licences? Is the minister prepared to attach conditions to these renewals which reflect the old growth and wilderness protection strategy? Is the minister aware that his New South Wales Labor colleagues have supported the private member's South-east Forests Protection Bill under which logging of old-growth forests in south-east New South Wales would cease? Finally, is it crude party politicking that the federal Minister for Resources is taking such a different line from his New South Wales state colleagues? Why does he not support them?

—The Minister for Resources is currently in the process of considering applications for renewal of annual hardwood woodchip export licences for 1994. All major hardwood woodchip exporters have long-term export approvals, which in most cases have been given after the completion of environmental impact statements. All woodchip export approvals are subject to the issue of annual export licences.

PARA.TAB: In considering the issue of export licences, the minister will fully consider, consistent with his legal obligations under a range of legislation, the potential environmental impacts of proposed operations, including for operations proposed in old-growth forests. This will include any implications for endangered species and potential impacts on National Estate areas. With regard to National Estate areas, there are specific obligations to identify any feasible and prudent alternatives to the proposed operations, to consult the Australian Heritage Commission, and to identify any actions necessary to minimise adverse impacts.

Consistent with the government's policy, the minister will also ensure that woodchips are exported only where there are no viable domestic processing alternatives and that the prices received provide a reasonable return on the use of our natural resources. Likewise, due regard will also be given to ensuring that all export operations are consistent with the national forest policy statement and other state agreements. In this regard, it should be noted that the national forest policy statement is based on the principles of ecologically sustainable development and that that policy does not preclude logging in old-growth forests.

Senator Coulter should also be aware that the statement in question was developed as a partnership between the Commonwealth, states and territories for the future management of Australia's public and private forests on a sustainable basis. It is the Commonwealth's intention to cooperate with the states to ensure the protection of old-growth forests as outlined in the policy, rather than to act unilaterally as Senator Coulter has suggested. There are associated Commonwealth-state consultative mechanisms for implementing that policy. In this respect, the minister will also consider the views of the states in his consideration of woodchip export licences.

Much more briefly as to the last two parts of Senator Coulter's question, he should be aware that Labor policy supports development of Australia's forestry resources on an ecologically sustainable basis. That is firmly supported throughout the Labor Party, including in New South Wales. Labor's support for ESD of our forest industries is clearly illustrated through the development of, and support for, the national forest policy statement. Ecologically sustainable development is the basis on which woodchip export approvals are considered and underlies all Commonwealth forest initiatives such as the farm forestry program and the establishment of the Forests and Wood Products Research and Development Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Yesterday the minister estimated the cost of the review process for the child-care accreditation scheme at 80c per child per week. The Association of Child Care Centres of New South Wales has written to the minister expressing its concern that costs will be increased, making child care less affordable for parents. The association cited increases in fees for parents from $33 to $69 per child per week. The Australian Federation of Child Care Associations has said that the implementation of accreditation guidelines would also increase costs by $30 per week. Was the minister yesterday referring only to the costs of the external review process and other documentation costs required under principle 17 for the centres? How can the minister justify such a large new financial burden on working parents?

—What I said yesterday is the answer, Senator Boswell. Senator Boswell referred to the Association of Child Care Centres, and also I think he said the federation of child care, which are putting around stories of figures of $33 to $69 a week—
—They were wrong too?

—Yes, they are wrong. On all the evidence that we have from a private consultant who examined the cost of review, which was especially done by a private consultant so that senators like Senator Alston could be assured that it was not a government plot, the costs were estimated at 80c to 88c per child per week.

PARA.TAB: Included in the figure of a $4 million cost to industry that was circulated with the Interim National Accreditation Council was the cost of assisting staff and providing relief staff for the training process. The government recognises the importance of that training process and has actually set aside a separate vote of $1.6 million to cover that training. That needs to come out of the cost assessment on which some of the child-care associations are making their claims about figures. On all the sensible, thoughtful evidence provided to me, the costs are minimal. It is kept that way precisely so that there will not be a large cost against child-care centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —You lied your way through it.
—Mr President, I would ask you to ask Senator McGauran to withdraw that.
—Order! I did not hear the comments that were made.
—He said, `You lied your way through it'.

—All I can do, if Senator McGauran did make that statement, is to ask him to withdraw it. Unfortunately, it is very hard to hear comments at that end of the chamber. Senator McGauran, did you make an unparliamentary remark?
—I did call Senator Crowley a liar, Mr President, and I do withdraw.

—The costs of this process take into account the whole thrust of this program, designed by the child-care industry to be assessed by the child-care industry and costs kept to a minimum precisely because we do not want the child-care fees becoming high and making child care unaffordable. The whole aim of this program is to make sure that we can assure parents that there is quality care in the child-care centres. I am sure that the honourable senator will find that most parents are very happy with the child-care centres they have at the moment. I can assure the Senate that any centre where parents are happy will continue its services in that way, and that parents will assess themselves as satisfied with the quality and will note that the costs will be very modest indeed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Crowley holds to her line that the new accreditation scheme will cost 80c per week per child, whereas both the New South Wales and Australian associations are saying that it will cost around an extra $33 a week. Would Senator Crowley be prepared to table the documentation which she has quoted from to show that the costs will be 80c a week per child rather than the $30 that the child-care associations are mentioning, to alleviate their fears and the fears of the people who have children in care?

—I will assure myself that that is okay, but as much as I understand that that will be all right I will seek to get that document for the honourable senator. All the members of the interim council that formulated these guidelines—and that included representations of the organisations Senator Boswell cites—had access to that documentation about costs. I am certainly happy to make sure that once again they are given a copy of it. They do not accept the figures from that private consultant, or seem to be devoted not to taking note of them. But as far as possible I will provide that for the honourable senator.
—Can the Minister for Health comment on recent criticism that the government has not made the drug interferon alpha-2B available through the PBS for the treatment of hepatitis C?

—I always think there is a difficulty with the application of new drugs. When some patients who have serious illnesses are told that a new drug might help them, there is always considerable agitation for that drug to be made freely available. I think Australia has got it basically right in the way we assess those drugs and the kinds of processes through which the manufacturers must go before they get full approval and before drugs eventually go on to the pharmaceutical benefits list. Interferon alpha-2B is a drug that is currently subsidised for the treatment of hairy-cell leukaemia and hepatitis B.

PARA.TAB: At its most recent meeting, the pharmaceutical benefits advisory committee also recommended that this drug be made available for the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukaemia. I was actually quite pleased that that occurred because I had a meeting with a number of prominent haematologists from around Australia who were pleading for that. Prior to that moment the pharmaceutical benefits advisory committee had not agreed with myelogenous leukaemia being one of those problems for which this drug could be used on the pharmaceutical benefits list.

When we have a conflict between experts who are advising us, as a minister it is always difficult to sort it out. We have never sought to disagree with the pharmaceutical benefits advisory committee and it would need to be a pretty special occasion on which we would ever seek to do so. At the same meeting that the advisory committee extended interferon 2B to chronic myelogenous leukaemia, it also decided against recommending subsidising interferon for the treatment of hepatitis C. It did so primarily due to a lack of what it considered to be sufficient information. The committee was not convinced of the efficacy of the drug for hepatitis C without more evidence. The long term benefits of treatment of hepatitis C with interferon still remain unclear.

It ought to be made clear here that that decision was not based on cost. I have seen some suggestions that it was. A recent report from the NHMRC task force and the health ministers advisory committee stated that the evaluation of more clinical data is needed before precise recommendations can be made about the circumstances in which interferon alfa-2B can be considered in the overall management of chronic hepatitis C infection. With hepatitis C infection becoming a bigger problem in Australia, we will have to monitor this very carefully, but we cannot and should not adopt new drugs simply on the basis of hope. We will need to make sure that proper assessments of the efficacy are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that the regional manager, south-west region, flight operations, of the CAA refused to take advice given by the relevant assigned flying operations inspector that the air operators certificate for Monarch Airlines be withdrawn?

—Even if I knew the answer to that question—and I do not—it would be totally improper for me to provide it to the Senate. The matter has been canvassed at length. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is in the process of conducting an investigation into that entire incident.
—The question has nothing to do with the incident.

—In response to the idiot interjection from Senator Macdonald, it is an absolutely central issue in the investigation. The investigation is about two months off being completed. When it is completed and the evidence collected, a public report will be provided. An interim report has already been released publicly by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which Senator Macdonald was given a copy of. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has also released four interim recommendations for the Civil Aviation Authority as well, prior to the completion of its final report. When the final report is completed, it will be a public document and it will then be followed by a coronial inquiry at which the evidence will be collected.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, the entire issue, as the Clerk has rightly indicated to the Senate in his advice, is sub judice and it would be irresponsible of me as the responsible minister to act in any other way. Individual senators can speculate and run on unsubstantiated assumptions as much as they like but as the minister, I cannot. I am sorry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. What is the Australian Electoral Commission doing to maximise the participation of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in the forthcoming ATSIC regional council election on 4 December?

—This is an important question because an important election is being held on 4 December for ATSIC. This is building on the important step of establishing ATSIC and, in that way, increasing the empowerment of the most disadvantaged in our society. It is important to use every opportunity to encourage a high rate of participation in these elections because, for very good and obvious reasons, information on racial origin is not recorded on the Commonwealth electoral roll and, therefore, we need to take steps to encourage people to seek to participate in these elections.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to report that preparations for the second round of elections for the ATSIC regional councils is progressing smoothly. The signs are that there is increased support for these elections. The Australian Electoral Commission, as everybody knows, is the agency responsible for the conduct of these elections and it is working very closely with ATSIC in making available to those eligible to vote information about enrolment, nomination and voting procedures.

An additional 40 staff have been recruited for the duration of the election to work closely with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in urban, rural and remote areas. Information is being distributed in video, print, radio and poster form to a very large number of groups, communities and individuals throughout Australia.

I have been advised by the Electoral Commission that there appears to have been a considerable increase in enrolment activity by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the lead-up to the close of the rolls. Those involved in preparing for the ATSIC elections are confident of a larger turnout across Australia than in the 1990 election.

The strong interest in these elections is evidenced too by the over 2,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are standing as candidates for the 573 vacancies. This is a considerable increase on the number of candidates for the 1990 election, and I think something that everybody who takes a genuine interest in the success of this democratic process within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community would welcome.

These elections provide all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with a very valuable opportunity to have their say in electing people to represent them at the local level. The people whom they so elect will have the power to make important decisions in a number of areas of great importance to their communities. I welcome the opportunity to raise this matter here; I would urge all honourable senators to do what they can during the next week to further encourage a high participation level at these elections.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer the minister to his statements supporting the use of Gillman as the multifunction polis's core site and to his threat to withdraw federal funding if a future South Australian government does not utilise the Gillman site. I also refer to a report by the Director of Capital Works in the South Australian Treasury, Mr Neil Nosworthy, dated 31 May 1993 which warns against spending $150 million at Gillman. The report states:

QUESTION.PARA: The key point which needs to be made is that the benefits derived from the additional employment associated with the MFP are not justification for spending $150 million on urban development at Gillman.
Does the minister still support using $40 million of federal government funds in and around the Gillman site?

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing is certain, and it is that we will not be building a dog kennel at the Gillman site. What we do build may be airconditioned and it may have central heating. I am aware of this issue only because I have seen today's Adelaide Advertiser report on it. I also note that the Premier of South Australia pointed out that the report was not an official report of either the government or the treasury of South Australia. I have not seen the report.
—That does not surprise us.

—If it has not been supplied to me, I would not have seen it. I will check whether the MFP unit in my department has a copy of the report. But I emphasise the statement by the Premier of South Australia that it is not the official position of either the treasury or his government.

PARA.TAB: As for Senator Chapman's other point about my threats on federal funding, I want to re-emphasise that the policy document of the Liberal Party for this election vis-a-vis the MFP is rather confused. At one stage it states that the MFP project will no longer have Gillman as a core site, but that the Liberal Party will continue to environmentally upgrade the Gillman site and go ahead with the expenditure of money under the better cities program. I do not quite know whether the Liberal Party in South Australia is trying to have it both ways or is just confused, as is usual.

I emphasise that all the advice I have had from the international advisory board of the MFP, which is made up of the advice of a range of people, including a former deputy Liberal premier of Queensland, Sir Llew Edwards, and a range of Australian business people who in no way can be called supporters or stooges of the Labor Party, makes it clear that the Gillman site and its development over a long time is part of the theme of the MFP. They also point out that turning the MFP project into just another version of a tech park, which is what it appears Mr Brown in South Australia wants to do, will mean the loss of all its international credibility and support.

Probably 20 to 30 different tech parks are being developed around Australia, and none of them get federal funding. They are all developed by state governments as tech parks. If we turn the MFP from an international project into a state tech park project, every other tech park will say, `If you are going to continue the funding on that basis, we want our cut of the cake'. I do not think the federal government will be in a position to say that we will start funding the development of every tech park in Australia.

We are supporting the MFP because it is a long-term international project with an international commitment to the principle of the MFP. We all understand that it will take a long time to develop. It is unfortunate that Mr Brown and the other confused members of the Liberal Party in South Australia just cannot understand that point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November Senator Reid asked me a question about international airports in Australia. I gave an undertaking that would I get that advice for her. I have categorised it, as I said I would. It is a very long answer and I seek the leave of the Senate to have it incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Reid asked Senator Collins without notice on 17 November 1993 "How many airports are there in Australia which received international passenger flights."
I now provide the following answer:

There are currently 13 mainland airports in Australia which have been designated as international airports allowing them to receive international passenger flights. These airports are classified below according to one of the two following categories:

PARA.TAB: "Major International Airports"—which means airports of entry and departure for international air traffic where all formalities incident to Customs, Immigration, Health, and similar procedures are carried out (these airports receive scheduled international flights); and

"Restricted Use International Airports"—which means airports of entry and departure at which the formalities incident to Customs, Immigration, Health and similar procedures are made available on a restricted basis, to flights with prior approval only (these airports are able to receive ad hoc international charter flights).

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the above mainland airports, there are also three Australian external territory international airports; Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Island, at which all formalities incident to Customs, Immigration and Health, and similar procedures are available. Both Norfolk Island and Christmas Island receive a small number of scheduled international services. Cocos (Keeling) Island does not receive any scheduled international services.

There are also a further two airports, Avalon (Victoria) and Learmonth (W.A.) which have been designated as Restricted Use International Airports. However, Avalon Airport's designation was granted on the basis that the airport would be used for the purposes of aircraft maintenance, pilot training and international airfreight operations. Learmonth's designation was granted on the basis that it would be used for outbound technical stops by aircraft en route to Christmas and Cocos Islands.

"Which other countries do not have an international airport at their national capital?"
I now provide the following answer:

There is no international airport at Monaco's capital of Monaco-ville but there is a heliport at Fontvieille, Monaco.
Lusaka airport in Zambia is designated for international traffic but has the following restriction: "Alternate aerodrome (only) for international traffic."
