QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, Senator Gibson asked me a question regarding the criteria for approving grants under the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. The grants under this program are decided on the basis of published selection criteria. The grants are aimed at the most needy areas as defined in the application form in section 3.5.

PARA.TAB: The selection criteria include a demonstrated community need for the proposed facility. The application form states that priority will be given to the needs of residents in new suburban areas; residents in inner urban areas; youth in the community; communities in rural areas; Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities; communities with high unemployment; and communities with large migrant populations.

I am advised by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) that the decisions on funding under this program are based on needs as demonstrated by the published criteria. I will also provide to Senator Gibson the circular prepared by the department about the program which outlines the selection criteria program guidelines and so forth.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, Senator Ferguson asked me a question relating to the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program approval for applications from category 4. First, it must be stated that applications in all categories are eligible for funding, including category 3. Ineligible applications are eliminated before the categorisation process commences. The audit office was under some confusion about this. When it first raised this question, it was using as its guide out-of-date criteria. It has since rectified its mistake and now acknowledges that these applications are eligible for funding.

PARA.TAB: The figures quoted by the ANAO do not tell the whole story. Obviously, when one looks at selectively published groups of figures it is easy to misinterpret the situation. The opposition's finance spokesman fell for that this morning when he stated that a project was more likely to be funded if it were in category three. The truth is that he got it wrong.

The categorisation program used by Mrs Kelly's department forms the basis for decisions in this program. In the last round of grants, 55 per cent of category one applications were funded compared with 26 per cent of category two and 15 per cent of category three. Clearly that shows that a high quality grant in category one is far more likely to be approved.

However, in the assessment of the categories it became clear that a number of very high quality applications had been ranked in category three because of a minor mistake in their applications. Under the guidelines, any project with a total value of over $50,000 can receive a maximum of 50 per cent funding from this program.

For example, if an applicant with an otherwise excellent application requested $31,000 out of a total cost of $60,000, the department would place it in category three. The minister believed that the categorisation was unduly harsh and considered the application on its other merits. If funding were approved for these projects, it was approved only on the basis that the organisations applied a revised budget in accordance with the guidelines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chapman this day, relating to the proposed Multifunction Polis.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take a minute of the Senate's time to respond to the answer that Senator Schacht gave. I want to respond to his unprecedented threat to the people of South Australia—what one might call electoral blackmail. The minister said that if the incoming government in South Australia decided to put the MFP money where it should be—that is into the scientific research and the industrial application of that research—instead of wasting it in the swamp at Gillman, then he would perhaps withdraw Commonwealth funding for the project.

PARA.TAB: That is an appalling threat that is certainly not in the best interests of South Australia. He ought to be ashamed to come in here and use electoral blackmail in that way. As a federal member, as a minister and as a South Australian senator, he should be saying, `I want to see that research money go into South Australia so that it can benefit South Australian scientific research and the industrial advancement that can come from that research'.

The minister knows as well as I do that the Gillman site will simply absorb hundreds of millions of dollars. It is an unsuitable site and everybody knows that. The minister and the present Premier of South Australia are not prepared to face up to the reality. Instead the minister is choosing to threaten South Australia in the way he did today.

Senator Schacht ought to be ashamed of himself. He has failed in his responsibility as a South Australian senator. Senator Schacht should do something to help South Australia develop and help it get out of the rut that it is in at the moment. He should do something to provide jobs for South Australia instead of constantly bagging it in this place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an extraordinary performance. This matter is obviously stinging the opposition. The opposition has realised that it is turning a project which has international support into a limited state technology park. It has realised that by doing so, it will lose international support. Of course the Australian government has to assess its contributions to programs such as these. We do not fund state technology parks around Australia per se.

PARA.TAB: The comments made by Senator Hill indicate that the opposition will say that it will add a bit of money to the Adelaide University, the Waite Institute and the South Australian University in order to make them centres of excellence. All of those programs are already operating in Australia, including the program in the cooperative research centres. In Australia, we already have funding for those programs but it is under a different guise and a different name.

It is extraordinary that the Liberal Party would want to destroy the only major international project that South Australia has had in the last couple of decades. The opposition wants to turn South Australia's only such project into a limited minor vision for a state technology development park. There is no future in that. The international partners will be off. They are only in it because they see the MFP as part of an international project.

As I say, those opposite want to turn the project into a narrow-minded, petty, parochial state development. Well, they can do so. But they cannot expect the federal government to automatically front up with money for such a project when it is being replicated all round Australia in every state and territory—or all of those bodies could also demand money for those sorts of developments.

I point out to Senator Hill that the federal government not only provides moneys under the better cities program, which is specifically for urban upgrading, to help the development of the Gillman site but also provides funds separately to the MFP for administration, the corporation and consultancy work. That money is a specialised allocation to the MFP in the annual budget of my department.

As I say, it will be very hard to justify making that sort of continuing allocation if the project is only a replica of every other state technology park around Australia. That is what I am warning the people of South Australia about. The vandals in the Liberal Party, by destroying an international project, are putting the federal funding at risk, because the federal government is in this project only because of its international and national dimensions, not on the basis of its being a purely state run, state technology park.

I have said this on four or five occasions now. I know that it is hard for Senator Hill and his ilk to understand the point. I only do so to warn him and the others that, if they go down this path of wrecking the international aspects of the MFP, it will be on their heads. The consequences for South Australia would be very severe indeed because we would lose a major international project—a project the likes of which has not been developed in South Australia or any other area for many years. That is why it is so disappointing to see the narrow focus and the parochialism of the Liberal Party of South Australia and its supporters in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely delighted that the opposition has at long last caught up with the duplicity of both the federal and South Australian Labor governments with respect to the MFP. Honourable senators will recall that for years I have been asking questions in relation to this nonsense development—this waste of money. Former Senator Button used to criticise me regularly, with the support of the opposition, over my position on this wastage of money.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht, in response to a question from Senator Chapman, said that Senator Chapman was confused about the nature of the MFP. To give just one example of how confused this government was, the original proposal for the MFP put forward by the South Australian government talked about the recreation capabilities of the Gillman site. It talked about people recreating on the beaches in the mangroves. People who know anything at all about mangrove areas know that they do not have beaches; they are full of sticky mud and one does not lie on them and recreate.

Honourable senators will recall that repeatedly in answers to questions about the financial support for the MFP Senator Button said that no government money was to into it; this was going to be privately driven. I think Senator Chapman is confused because my estimate of the amount of money which the federal and state governments have already committed to the MFP is $167 million. When we look at the original proposal we see incredible and amazing maps of the Gillman site showing axes named `Water', `Humanity' and `Environment', which quite miraculously happen to cross at the Gillman site. Of course, anybody with any sense could see that those lines could be drawn on any map anywhere and could be made to intersect.

When we look at the environmental assessment of the Gillman site, we find that the Department of Environment and Planning in South Australia advised the South Australian government that the Gillman site should not be touched. The government went back to the Department of Environment and Planning in South Australia and said, `We don't like your report. We want you to report differently'. The Department of Environment and Planning went back to the South Australian government and said, `The Gillman site should definitely not be touched'. So there is clear evidence that the Gillman site is totally unsuitable for the sort of development which the South Australian and federal governments are trying to foist onto it—with very inappropriate planning and thinking.

I turn to the other matter that Senator Schacht has just raised in his comments. In the federal area, since 1983 this Labor government has consistently cut down the money which goes into research institutes and universities around Australia. Then it turns around and says, `We need to spend money on an MFP'. What it should be doing is precisely what the Liberal opposition in South Australia is now, belatedly, recognising: the money should be going back to the starved research institutes and universities around this country.

There are many excellent projects which should be supported. With respect to this aspect, I think that at long last the Liberal opposition in South Australia has got it right. It is unfortunate that it has taken it so many years to recognise that, but it does have it right. That is precisely where the money should be going. Senator Schacht spoke about this project having international support. We have repeatedly invited Senator Schacht to tell us exactly how much international money has come into the MFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not much.

—None whatsoever. This project has been going for years and years. It has been attempting to attract international money. As yet there has been no international money attracted into it. It appears to be just another one of those projects in which governments—both federal and state—having committed themselves, will be dragged down this road of having to throw more and more good money after bad. It is about time it pulled out, cut its losses and recognised that whatever money is available should go back to the existing research institutes. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling this day, relating to an Electoral Commission inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, in answer to a question, Senator McMullan acknowledged that the government was guilty of both retribution and vindictiveness with regard to various community associations and organisations. We have seen the sensitivity of a Labor government that is not prepared to talk to anyone who takes a contrary or different, and perhaps controversial, view from its own.

PARA.TAB: This saga goes back to just following the March election when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) raised the possibility of retribution against business groups which in his opinion had exerted or exhibited an election bias. It was, of course, the right of groups such as the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to take a principled position on views which differed from those of the government. But not according to Mr Keating.

At about the same time, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, also engaged in a degree of criticism and implied that the government would take very strong action against the business community and, in his words, would treat them accordingly. In that respect, very early in the piece we saw those sorts of actions from both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. During the Senate estimates committees in September, I again raised this issue, particularly and specifically with regard to the Housing Industry Association. I was informed on 3 September by Mr Howe's departmental secretary, Mr Cole, that:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has made a decision that it is not going to deal with the Housing Industry Association. I have been instructed that the department should not deal with the Housing Industry Association. Accordingly, where the Housing Industry Association as such was represented on the various consultative committees that we have with the industry, its representatives have stood down from those positions.
That, of course, brought out the ire of the Housing Industry Association, which, in a letter to me, responded as follows:

One issue we found bemusing was Mr Cole's observation during the hearings that the Association had "stood down" from representation of various committees. In fact, this was not a choice the Association made. The HIA was notified officially by the Department that it had been "suspended" from the housing committees.

Again, right through the estimates of 3 September and 25 October, it was very clearly established that Minister Howe very vindictively had wiped the Housing Industry Association out from any contact with the Labor caucus or, for that matter, the government.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, Senator Crowley at the estimates committee very clearly established her own bias. In a letter that was incorporated at the estimates committee hearing she made some very strong and similar statements. It stated:
The Government considered that in taking this action—

SPEECH.PARA: that is the electoral action it took—
the HIA had moved from the conventional role of a non-party-political peak association lobbying on behalf of its members over particular issues, to a partisan political position.

PARA.TAB: Taking this changed role into account, the Government questioned the extent to which the HIA could continue to represent the view of organisations in the housing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an incredible position for a government to reach. It certainly would appear that it has countered the views—and certainly the spirit—intended in the electoral act. Whilst I am aware, as Minister McMullan mentioned earlier today, that complaints had been made against the Prime Minister and Mr Dawkins, I believe the actions very clearly indicated and taken by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, who is the portfolio minister relating to housing, and Senator Crowley should also be subjected to inquiry now by the Electoral Commission.

PARA.TAB: It again reveals the arrogance of this government in dealing with anybody that is representative. Anyone who takes a contrary view to that which the Prime Minister wants to espouse or the Labor Party believes it has a divine right to hold, will be wiped from the face of the earth. The fact that such people might represent most of the industry organisations, as does the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry or the Housing Industry Association, reveals the government's arrogance and shows very clearly where the Labor government is heading.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding, as I said in answer to Senator Tambling's question, that unlike him I feel constrained from wandering in and commenting on matters that are under inquiry, nevertheless I do want to say some things in response to his remarks. First of all, I absolutely repudiate the deliberately misleading remark he made that I had in some way endorsed an outrageous proposition which he put. I reject that entirely.

PARA.TAB: It is true that before the election campaign I, as parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer, came to the conclusion that it was a waste of time talking to the Housing Industry Association and stopped bothering. That cannot be said to have been a result of the association's activities in the election campaign because I did that before the election campaign started. I just thought its people gave such continually biased advice that it was an absolute waste of time talking to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you removed them from all the advisory bodies?

—They were not any advisory bodies to me. They are not, were not, and I can not see how on earth they could ever be on any advisory bodies to me. My point is simply that it was an absolute waste of time talking to them and I stopped bothering.

PARA.TAB: It is inevitable that everybody who is busy, I think even people who are not, make assessments about the usefulness of dialogue that they have to have. When there are more people wanting to talk to you than you have time to talk to—and that is inevitably the case for all ministers, and I suspect for opposition members as well—then you have to choose. We cannot talk to everybody, so we liaise with those with whom we think there is some possibility of having a useful discussion.

I do not know the detail of what is being alleged was done by Mr Howe and Senator Crowley. But what I said in the answer stands: if someone wishes to make a complaint, it is a matter for that individual to make that inquiry, and the Electoral Commission will independently assess it. But nobody can say that the law requires us to sit and talk to someone just because we used to. If after talking to them for a while, we find it an absolute waste of time, why would we bother to continue? That certainly was the view I took in dealing with the Housing Industry Association in my areas of responsibility. It was not on any formal committees and it was well before the election, so it was not as a result of its election campaign activity. I just found it an absolute waste of time and stopped doing it.

I did not try to interfere with that association's right. I am simply saying that people are entitled to form their views about with whom they seek to conduct dialogue. I can only indicate the decisions I make. But the situation is simply this: that, in the circumstances of any minister's conduct of operation, as I have said and as Senator Tambling would know, he or she has to make choices. That is not the same as saying that we seek to interfere with the right of that organisation to discharge its obligations on behalf of its members—that is the business of the organisation and its members.

Nothing has been done that seeks in any way to interfere with the right of either of those organisations to liaise with its members, to represent its members or to participate in democratic dialogue. But that is not the same as saying that we feel obliged to continue to consult with them. I have no particular brief for or against the participation of these bodies in particular advisory roles. That is a matter for the judgment of the individual ministers, and they will make it on the merits of the case.

But we cannot come in here pretending that, in some way, a law which says that we should not discriminate against people requires us to continue to participate in useless dialogue with people who have spent an enormous amount of time trying to distort the position and create unreasonable and unfair propositions—at least in our minds. It is a free country and they are entitled to say that; but it is also a free country and we are entitled, as citizens, to choose with whom we conduct these sorts of conversations.
This is a wonderful diversion. I realise that the opposition is still trying to come to grips with the fact that it lost the election; I have to say, it did.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator McMullan has just said is typical of the Australian Labor Party's very un-Australian approach to government. If one disagrees with the government, one is finished.

PARA.TAB: The Housing Industry Association is one of the most respected and influential bodies in the housing industry—a body that should well be giving advice to the government. It is an association which the government should listen to. This government simply cuts it off because it had the temerity to point out just how wrong the government was at the election. For example, look at Henry Bosch. He dared to disagree with the government and got the flick immediately—and the list goes on and on. This particular party in government at the moment is an absolute disgrace, completely un-Australian and undemocratic in the way it runs this government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to child-care accreditation guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue that Senator Herron raised with Senator Crowley related to the very contentious issue of the child-care guidelines which have been brought before this chamber. It is correct to say that there has been a great upwelling of fury on this particular issue from the wider community. Those who listen to talkback radio and read the popular press will see the very widespread concern that exists in the community about the government's actions in this regard.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to reflect why this has occurred. When one reads through the guidelines, many are unexceptionable and indeed some would be regarded as quite normal by a lot of families. When one takes the whole package together, one finds that it is bureaucracy in the extreme, and often the guidelines are contradictory within themselves. A number of guidelines reflect an astonishingly trendy view of how children should be brought up. It is interesting that the guidelines speak about being sensitive to multiculturalism, which I think is appropriate, but at the same time the guidelines are astonishingly insensitive about Australian culture.

Every year in this country for some 200 years we have had the occasion of Christmas in which Australians join together to sing Christmas carols. It is one great part of our cultural experience as children. I would suggest that this would be the first time that any document has ever been put out in this country which somehow says that on the Christmas occasion carols are not culturally relevant to many people. It is interesting that at the same time as the document so constantly speaks about being sensitive to different views and attitudes in the area of multiculturalism, it tramples so shamelessly on the sensitivities of most Australians. That is the first point I wish to make before the chamber.

The second point is that, whereas the guidelines pretend to be sensitive to multiculturalism and use that as a way to attack what has been regarded for some 200 years as a traditional Australian custom, they also trample on many of the values of multiculturalism. Many migrant groups have particularly traditional and conservative views on the role of the family. I find myself sharing many of those views in common with those groups. I do not know how they would react to the very strange views that these guidelines have about giving boys trucks and trains and giving girls dolls. A lot of these groups would feel exactly like me that this is a perfectly normal thing to do.

When we read these guidelines, I find it astonishing that such customs and attitudes should come under attack and be treated in such a disapproving manner. Any government that puts these guidelines down has totally lost touch with mainstream Australian values. Any minister who could sign off documents which seem to suggest that Christmas carols are culturally irrelevant shows no pride or sensitivity in basic Australian customs and traditions.

The Australian Labor Party need go no further to explain the upsurge of fury in the nation that these few guidelines have created. As they enjoin us often to be sensitive about multicultural aspects—and I think that is appropriate—I believe that equally they should be very careful about treading on Australian cultural traditions. This is what these guidelines do. They stamp all over many of the cultural traditions of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we have this beat-up by the opposition, reflected in its lack of understanding about the necessity within child-care areas for some form of accreditation. It is the desire of those who provide a child-care service and who actually feel the need to have professional standards within this industry.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken to a number of people within the industry and a number of students who are doing the two-year associate diploma. They are astounded that anybody would not realise the need for a standard, the need for accreditation. What is within the accreditation is absolutely commonsense and essential in providing care to children. The industry was involved for a long time in this process. The private sector of the industry was also involved in the process. The only complaint I have had was from one group within the private sector who were complaining because their two representatives were not doing what the group thought they should have been doing.

As for trucks and trains for boys and dolls for girls, when will the opposition realise that what is important for children is that they have access to choose what they play with, that there not be stereotyping whereby the boys will play with one thing and the girls will play with something else? It is essential that people realise that children have a vivid imagination and that they be allowed to fulfil and explore that imagination. That is all part of their growing up to be whole, good, complete, happy, well adjusted human beings. That is why we need to make sure that standards are involved and are upheld. These are the standards that the profession feels proud to uphold.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
