I understand that it would accord with the wishes of the Senate if motions of condolence for the deceased were debated when the Senate resumes its sittings in December. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation reports Nos 3,4,5,6 and 8 and seek leave to incorporate the responses in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The responses read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE THIRD REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON
SUPERANNUATION
Recommendation

1. The Committee recommends that the prime regulator of superannuation, the ISC, monitor, report and regularly publish comprehensive aggregate statistics on superannuation, including details of fund earnings.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The ISC already publishes aggregate statistics on superannuation and provides data to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) for publication. The ISC has procedures in place to improve the quality, quantity and timeliness of statistics. Many `public offer' funds already provide information on their fund earnings and these are regularly published in 'performance tables' compiled by the private sector.
Recommendation

2. The Committee recommends that the ISC ensures that details relating to costs and fund returns of Approved Deposit Funds and Deferred Annuity investments be published in a succinct summary using a standard format and be made available to investors and prospective investors of these products.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Government has already required a significant improvement in the information that superannuation funds must provide to members and prospective members. Considerable improvements with respect to superannuation funds were made with effect from 1 July 1992 with the insertion of "Division 2—Information on fund management" (Regulations 18C to 18S inclusive) into Part II of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations (OSSR). These broadly require that the trustees of superannuation funds disclose certain information to members, prospective members and former members of funds. The amount and determination of members' benefit must be provided by means of regular reports. Information with respect to the management and financial affairs of the fund must also be supplied regularly to members of funds which have more than four members. Additional information must be disclosed to fund members on request.Existing regulation 22 prescribes the disclosure of information standards pertaining to approved deposit funds (ADFs). The regulation requires, broadly, that the trustees shall give to each depositor a written statement setting out the opening and closing balances, deposits, withdrawals and earnings for each year of income. A similar report is required upon a person ceasing to be a depositor. Upon request, a copy of the ADF's returns, certificates and notices must be provided.The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) legislation (SIS) empowers the making of regulations with respect to the information to be disclosed to members. It is the Government's intention that the intent of the current regulations be broadly transferred to the SIS regulations. However, the development of the SIS regulations will also provide an opportunity to improve the current regulations, particularly with respect to the relevance of the information provided to members and the public, and to limit funds' compliance costs.The Government does not consider that publication of details on fund costs and returns by the ISC is warranted because it is already being provided by the private sector. For example, there are comprehensive comparisons published of the entry, exit and annual fees and earnings rates of superannuation entities.The Government, industry bodies and professional organisations are currently examining the possibility of adopting standards of both measurement and presentation of performance indicators.
Recommendation

3. The Committee recommends that the Government monitor trends in changes in the investment portfolios of superannuation funds to enable appropriate judgements and decisions to be made about the extent of diversification.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Government will continue to monitor the general investment practice of the superannuation industry. However, the Government notes that the optimal degree of diversification will vary from fund to fund depending upon a number of fund specific factors. For this reason the Government believes that trustees of superannuation funds are best placed to determine what is an appropriate investment profile for a particular fund. The SIS legislation contains covenants which are to be included in the governing rules of superannuation funds.One of these covenants is the 'prudent person rule' which is designed to ensure that trustees adopt a suitably diverse investment portfolio consistent with maximising retirement income. This covenant (under paragraph 50(2)(f) of the SIS legislation) requires the trustees of a superannuation entity 'to formulate and give effect to an investment strategy that has regard to the whole of the circumstances of the entity including, but not limited to, the following:(i) the risk involved in making, holding and realising, and the likely return from, the entity's investments having regard to its objectives and its expected cash flow requirements;(ii) the composition of the entity's investments as a whole including the extent to which the investments are diverse or involve the entity being exposed to risks from inadequate diversification;(iii) the liquidity of the entity's investments having regard to its expected cash flow requirements;(iv) the ability of the entity to discharge its existing and prospective liabilities.'The Government will, of course, continue to monitor changes in investment portfolios as evidenced by data published by the ABS, information collected by the ISC as part of returns provided by superannuation funds and life companies, other information published by the private sector, and from industry contacts.
Recommendation
4. The Committee recommends that the Government consult with the States to explore the possibility of the ISC becoming the prime regulator of superannuation products offered by friendly societies.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

At the Special Premiers Conference in October 1990, the States and the Commonwealth reaffirmed the long standing view that responsibility for non-bank financial institutions lies primarily with the States. The life insurance business of friendly societies is excluded from the Life Insurance Act 1945 and is not supervised by the ISC. There are a number of complying superannuation funds run by friendly societies that do report to the ISC.
Recommendation

5. The Committee believes that the initiative of the ABCI in conducting a strategic assessment of superannuation is a forward looking one which warrants the full support of both the superannuation industry and relevant government regulatory and enforcement agencies. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the Treasurer and the Attorney-General take steps to ensure that a thorough and systematic assessment is made. Further, the Committee recommends that, upon the completion of the assessment, an appropriate strategy to combat the entry of organised crime into superannuation be developed by the end of 1993.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The ISC's audit procedures are designed to form an opinion on the validity of the trustee's claim that the fund is complying with all relevant operational standards. These procedures also facilitate the monitoring of key prudential concerns, in particular, minimising the risk of fraudulent misappropriation of members' funds. The procedures seek to identify weaknesses in internal control systems and to identify situations or events that increase the risk of fraud to enable appropriate and timely remedial action. The Government will be giving consideration to what further assessment and analysis needs to be undertaken in this area.
Recommendation

6. As the Committee has not received sufficient evidence on the matter of unfunded public sector superannuation liabilities, and as it does not have the resources or time to carry out a far reaching investigation of the problem, it recommends that as a matter of urgency the Commonwealth Government convene a meeting of State Finance Ministers/Treasurers to develop a plan of action for addressing the problems posed by unfunded public sector superannuation liabilities.Not acceptedThe Government considers that decisions on the funding of public sector superannuation liabilities are matters for each individual government.The Government is fully aware of its responsibilities in administering its superannuation schemes, particularly the need to contain the costs of these schemes at manageable levels. The long term costs of the schemes are reported regularly by the Australian Government Actuary and monitored by the Government. This and other costing processes also ensure that superannuation costs are fully factored into management and employment decisions.The Government has implemented significant reforms over recent years to lower the long term employer costs of Commonwealth superannuation. Several States have also implemented major reforms to their principal superannuation schemes and others are considering such reforms.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE FOURTH REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE
ON SUPERANNUATION
SOCIAL SECURITY MATTERS
RecommendationResponseComments
Recommendation

3.1 The Committee recommends that, as a matter of urgency, the Commonwealth should initiate discussions with the States with a view to facilitating portability between them and that these objectives be achieved by the end of 1993.Accepted in partFollowing the December 1992 meeting of the Council of Australian Governments a working party was set up to investigate barriers to mobility between State, Territory and Commonwealth sector employment and to recommend solutions to overcome those barriers. Superannuation has been identified as one of the barriers and an examination is being made as to the options and preferred solution. It is expected that this matter will be addressed by a future Council of Australian Governments meeting.
Recommendation

3.2 The Committee recommends that the Government take steps to provide for the mandatory vesting, as from a date to be determined, of a significant part of the employer-financed benefits in occupational superannuation funds accrued to that date but not otherwise vested. An example of a possible scheme is:Accepted in partThe Government is reviewing the need for minimum vesting standards for voluntary employer-financed benefits in the light of the introduction of the Superannuation Guarantee.(i) The amount to be vested shall be not less than each member's contributions, plus fund earnings, to that date.(ii) The amount should be vested over a ten year period. (iii) Where existing rules would, if applied, result in a greater sum being vested in any member, those rules should apply.
Recommendation

3.3 The Committee recommends that, in relation to Recommendation 3.2 regarding increased vesting requirements, the base date should be the date on which the Government announces the adoption of the policy in order to protect the interests of then-existing members. Employees retrenched or dismissed after the announcement, but before the base date, should be entitled to whatever vesting they would have been entitled to if the base date had been the date of their termination.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments
See response to 3.2
Recommendation
3.4 The Committee recommends that immediate vesting of all employer contributions subsequent to the vesting base date be compulsory.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments
See response to 3.2.
Recommendation

3.5 The Committee recommends that the commencement date of the new rules to substantially increase the amount of benefits to be compulsorily preserved, as announced in Security in Retirement, should be reconsidered by the Government with a view to earlier commencement.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Government will, over the coming months, be consulting on and reviewing superannuation matters raised by Dr FitzGerald in the report on National Saving, with a view to announcing its response by early 1994. This issue will also be reviewed in that context.
Recommendation
3.6 The Committee recommends by majority that the preservation age be raised to 60 years in accordance with the phasing in proposals outlined in Security in Retirement.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

This issue was raised in the report by Dr FitzGerald on National Saving. The Government will, over the coming months, be consulting on and reviewing superannuation matters raised by Dr FitzGerald with a view to announcing its response by early 1994.
Recommendation

3.7 The Committee further recommends that the Government should, as a matter of urgency, initiate research into all aspects of appropriate retirement ages and the extent of double dipping in Australia.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Government has commissioned from relevant departments and Government agencies a comprehensive review of the manner in which the Government's policies toward superannuation interact with its provision of the age pension. DSS has undertaken some limited research into the incidence of double dipping in Australia, both through commissioned survey work (Later Life Provision Survey, DSS 1992) and review and analysis of existing information (Kalisch 1992, Patterson and Kalisch 1993).The incidence of double-dipping is to a large extent dependent on the size of the superannuation benefit received. Double dipping is not an issue where superannuation payments are small and the pensioner has little or no income or assets from other sources because, regardless of the uses to which it is put, the payment would have little, if any, impact on the level of the age pension entitlement under the DSS income and assets test.Results from the Later Life Provision Survey suggest that the extent of double dipping in Australia has been exaggerated. The survey showed that only about 3 per cent of pensioners received a lump sum of over $100,000 and most pensioners who had received a lump sum, regardless of its size, either re-invested it to provide income or used it to pay off their mortgage or other debts. Similarly, 19 per cent of non-pensioners had received a lump sum in excess of $100,000, and most non-pensioners also re-invested it or used it to pay off debts. Kalisch (1992) in a paper prepared for an Economic Planning and Advisory Council (EPAC) seminar on the interaction between superannuation and age pensions also found that double-dipping was not as prevalent as had been thought. The paper used the results of a number of other Australian surveys previously published on the double-dipping issue and data from recent Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys to demonstrate that lump sum superannuation payments are largely directed towards income-generating investments or housing. While some limited expenditure on holidays was also relatively common it accounted for a small amount of the total lump sum received.There was some indication that pensioners diverted more of their superannuation lump sums than non-pensioners towards housing investment but on the whole pensioners appeared to be still very prudent in their disbursement of any lump sums they received. Evidence showed that larger lump sums were more likely than smaller amounts to be used to generate retirement income (rather than for immediate consumption) and there was no indication of former high income earners restructuring financial arrangements to draw the pension.
Recommendation

3.8 The Committee recommends that the ISC, the organisation which it believes is best placed to administer this policy, work towards the achievement of the Committee's long term goal to eliminate early access to retirement benefits. The Committee also recommends that the ISC promulgate a policy to ensure consistency of treatment of applications and further recommends that the ISC develop a more limited set of rules setting out clearly the circumstances for hardship assistance.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Government acknowledges that in principle early release of retirement benefits should be discouraged. In current economic circumstances, however, the Government is prepared to agree to early release if the fund member is in severe financial difficulties or for other compassionate reasons. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) has guidelines for assessing case-by-case whether preservable benefits should be released having regard to the applicant's circumstances. The administration of the guideline was reviewed recently and revised procedures were implemented from 1 July 1993. The new guidelines aim to improve consistency in the treatment of applications, minimise delays, increase uniformity across different categories of applicants and to make some refinements to account for advice from the Privacy Commissioner and the Ombudsman. The ISC has received a large number of applications in recent times which include evidence of severe financial difficulties and which are consistent with the guidelines.
Recommendation

4.1 The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the possible expansion of long term debt instruments with a view to affording annuity providers greater opportunities to provide lower-cost indexed products.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Commonwealth's debt portfolio is managed with the objective of minimising long-term cost while limiting exposure to risk. Managing the maturity profile of the portfolio is integral to achieving an appropriate balancing of cost and risk objectives, and the issue of longer-term debt is, and will continue to be, considered in this context. The Commonwealth's conventional (nominal) Treasury Bond portfolio now includes maturities in each year out to the year 2005.In February 1993, the Government resumed the issue of Treasury Indexed Bonds as part of its issue program with the introduction of a new 2010 maturity. There have been four issues to date into the 2010 stock, with total volume outstanding approximately $1.45 billion. At present it is expected that around a further $0.8 billion of Indexed Bonds will be issued over the remainder of 1993-94 with precise decisions as to volume, maturity and price to be made in the light of market conditions and related factors at the time of issue.

The Government intends to issue indexed bonds on a continuing basis over the longer term. The availability of CPI indexed bonds should assist the development of superannuation and other retirement savings products.
Recommendation
4.2 The Committee recommends that the Government proceed with its announced intention to rebate all income tax otherwise payable by age pensioners.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The Government decided not to proceed with this measure because it is not necessarily the best way of responding to its continuing concerns regarding pensioners. The Government is concerned to assist those who rely on the pension as their sole source of income. At the same time, the Government is concerned that the interaction of the pension income test and income tax relief directed towards full-rate and lower-income part-rate pensioners results in high effective marginal tax rates for many part-rate pensioners.The Government will examine other policy options to better integrate the tax and the social security systems and to address problems caused by high effective marginal tax rates.
Recommendation
4.3 The Committee recommends the assets test be aligned with the income test via the application of realistic, market-related interest equivalents, subject to:
(a) a reasonable allowance, for example $50,000, for personal and household possessions; and
(b) inclusion of actual income on bona fide income-earning assets.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The recommendation diverges from the Government position that people with very substantial assets should use some of these assets to support themselves before calling on the taxpayer for assistance. Hardship provisions and the separate pensioner loans scheme are available for people who either cannot liquidate certain assets, or who choose not to.In addition, the assets test thresholds are generous and are also indexed in July each year to protect assets-tested pensioners. Currently, if assessed under the assets test, a single homeowner with assets of less than $112 750 (excluding the family home) would receive maximum rate pension. Assets over this level would reduce the pension payable by $1.50 a week for every $1000 above the threshold until the pension cut-out point (currently $220 000 for a single homeowner) is reached. Married non-homeowners can have up to $419 000 in assessable assets before they lose all the pension.The assets test withdrawal rate was reduced in September of this year from $2 a week for every $1000 in assessable assets above the threshold, in recognition that the decline in interest rates has meant a reduction in income for some retirees with relatively high asset levels. This meant that retirees with assets over the threshold received a pension increase or, in some cases, qualified for a part-payment for the first time. The initiative is expected to help over 40 000 retirees in a year.
Recommendation

4.4 The Committee recommends that the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security form a working party to examine income tax and social security legislation with a view to maximising the consistency of definitions and treatment of matters of common concern to the two systems and that the report be tabled in Parliament by the end of 1993.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The Committee advocates the smooth transition from dependence on the age pension to fully self-funded retirement, through the establishment of consistent definitions, concepts and practices between the taxation and social security legislation.Specifically, it cites tax law which treats each individual separately: the incomes of husband and wife are taxed independently, although a rebate is allowed for dependent spouses and any unused pension rebate is transferable. By contrast, all income is allocated equally to husband and wife for age pension income test purposes because social security assistance is based on the concept of the `income unit'; not the individual.In addition, the social security system assesses both income and assets, unlike the tax system in order to ensure that all resources are taken into account in determining pension entitlement.Also, social security eligibility requirements, including the income and assets tests, are based on the provision of income support when and as it is needed. If, as occurs in the tax system, the income test was based around annual reconciliation on a financial year basis the assistance is likely to be unrelated to the needs of the individual at a particular point in time.The differences in taxation and social security assessment of superannuation are particularly marked. The tax treatment is based on a lifecycle approach extending from accumulation to receipt. In contrast, the age pension is intended to provide income to those most in need at particular points in time.While it is recognised that client understanding would be enhanced by consistent treatment across social security and taxation, these considerations mean that the tax and social security systems do not operate in the same way because of the divergent purposes of the two systems. It is not proposed to alter this.The Minister for Social Security has announced an independent review of the pension income and assets tests to report initially in July 1994 with a final report due in September 1994. The objectives of the review require it to examine the relationship between the income and assets tests and the tax system. The terms of reference for the review were tabled in the Senate on 22 November 1993. A copy is attached to this response.
Recommendation
TAXATION MATTERS

5.1 The Committee recommends that a specialist unit, known in the Australian Taxation Office as a `cell', be established within the ATO to clarify taxation law and practice for the superannuation industry.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The ATO is currently examining whether to establish a Superannuation Cell or some other mechanism to enable the ATO to focus on clarification of taxation law and practice for the superannuation industry.
Recommendation

6.1 The Committee recommends that the Government monitor and examine the use of salary sacrifice arrangements with a view to ensuring that their use does not undermine the equity aims of the Government's retirement incomes policy.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The impact of salary sacrifice arrangements on retirement incomes policy will be monitored as part of the ongoing review of the superannuation system. However, the 1 July 1994 changes that limit the amount of deductible employer contributions will constrain salary sacrifice arrangements.
Recommendation
7.1 The Committee by majority believes that the contributions tax should be retained for `deductible' contributions and the exemption for `rebatable' contributions should also be maintained.
Response
Accepted
Comments
This is consistent with the existing law.
Recommendation

7.2 The Committee believes that the contributions tax, with respect to employer contributions, should be withheld by the employer instead of the fund trustee. This would substantially reduce the administrative complexity of the current arrangements and lead to less loss of benefits through inadvertence. In other words, employer and self-employed contributions (which have been subject to the 15 per cent tax) should be excluded from the assessable income of the fund.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The problems highlighted by the Committee have been largely overcome by the amendments to the notice requirements for member contributions introduced in Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Act 1993.
Recommendation

7.3 The Committee by majority recommends that the fund earning tax should be maintained at its current concessional rate and that it should retain its concessional character by being reduced in line with other reductions in personal income tax rates.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments
The Government considers that the current level of budgetary assistance for superannuation savings is appropriate.
Recommendation

7.4 The Committee recommends that the Commissioner of Taxation should clarify, by way of Taxation Rulings and Determinations, the allowable deductions available to superannuation fund trustees. Further, where appropriate, the position of superannuation funds should be aligned with normal businesses.
Response
Accepted
Comments

The Commissioner has issued Taxation Ruling TR93/17 dealing with the deductibility of expenses incurred by superannuation fund trustees. The Ruling puts superannuation funds in essentially the same position as normal businesses for the purposes of claiming deductions.
Recommendation

7.5 The Committee recommends that any expenses incurred by trustees in complying with legislative and regulatory changes, some of which will flow from its series of reports, be completely tax deductible for fund trustees.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

Taxation Rulings IT2672 and TR93/17 indicate that expenses incurred by superannuation fund trustees in complying with legislative and regulatory changes are deductible if they are made solely to enable a fund to maintain its complying status. Other expenses of this type may not satisfy the existing requirements to be deductible under the tax law. It would be inequitable to amend the tax law to allow deductions for expenses incurred by trustees where similar expenses incurred by other taxpayers are not deductible.
Recommendation

7.6 The Committee recommends that the Treasury consider whether there is scope to correct any anomalies that may exist in the application of Capital Gains Tax (CGT) to fund trustees. The Treasury should specifically consider the application of CGT to units in unit trusts, the application of CGT to pre-September 1985 assets and the application of CGT in fund amalgamations.
Response
Not accepted
Comments
It is not considered that CGT applies inappropriately.
Recommendation

7.7 The Committee recommends that the Treasury examine the arrangements applying to current pension liabilities to find a less complex regime. Regard should also be had to the complexity of the taxpayer rebates.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments

The complexity of the provisions allowing a rebate on superannuation pensions and annuities has been largely removed with effect from 1 July 1994 by the amendments in Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Act 1992.
Recommendation
7.8 The Committee recommends that the Treasury examine whether there is scope to overcome the confusion surrounding the transfer of tax liability provisions.
Response
Accepted in part
Comments
As it may be possible to alleviate concerns in this area administratively, this issue will be examined through industry consultation with the ATO.
Recommendation

7.9 The committee recommends that the Government review section 290A to determine whether there are impediments to ADFs claiming the exemption, and, if so, to remove such impediments to ensure that the exemption is enjoyed by those who are entitled to it.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

Section 290A was amended by Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Act 1993 to overcome some minor technical deficiencies and to ensure that the exemption available to continuously complying fixed approved deposit funds is not jeopardised. Because the exemption available under Section 290A is targeted to a particular group of members of certain ADFs, it is not unexpected that an ADF would need to devote some administrative effort to obtain the exemption. Whether this effort is appropriate in the circumstances of a particular ADF is a matter for that ADF. STRATEGIC REVIEW OF THE PENSION INCOME AND ASSETS TESTS TERMS OF REFERENCE
THE OBJECTIVES OF THE REVIEW

PARA.TAB: The consultant is to examine the current income and assets tests applied to social security pensioners, service pensioners and other retirees, to assess these provisions against a set of principles and to provide options for reform to these arrangements where the above suggests that changes are required. Specifically, the consultant should:

SPEECH.PARA: Examine the rationale for income and assets testing in the context of the Government's retirement income objectives;

Examine the conceptual framework, design principles and the actual operation of the pensions income and assets tests to, inter alia, minimise perceptions of intrusiveness and complexity on the part of social security and service pensioners;
Examine the relationship between the income and assets tests and the tax system;
Assess current provisions including the treatment of investments against the design principles; and
Identify options for improvement or change to the existing income and assets tests.
THE SCOPE OF THE REVIEW

PARA.TAB: In undertaking the consultancy, the consultant is to have regard to:

SPEECH.PARA: The key objectives of the income and assets test within the context of the Government's retirement incomes policy, including
targeting expenditures to those most in need;
ensuring that appropriate incentives exist for self-provision; and
ensuring an adequate level of retirement income.
recognising that tensions may exist between these objectives.
The interrelationship between income tests, assets test and relevant taxation provisions including the use of lump sums to produce adequate retirement incomes;
The Government's commitment to consultations regarding the income taxation treatment of penslons.
Sub-objectives of maximising equity (including the treatment of different types of incomes and assets), simplicity, and efficient, accountable administration;
The Government's need to contain pension outlays in line with the Government's overall fiscal strategy, the need to increase national saving and the ageing of the population;
Other related work being carried out for the Government (eg, Retirement Incomes Modelling Task Force); and
Relevant experiences of overseas Governments with targeting pension payments.
THE FINDINGS OF THE REVIEW

PARA.TAB: The consultant is to prepare a draft and final report, to include findings and recommendations on:

SPEECH.PARA: A set of benchmarks or design principles against which possible means testing provision can be measured;
Any inequities, inconsistencies and inefficiencies in the current methods of means testing pensioners and veterans;
The strengths and weaknesses of the current income and assets tests as well as any possible future means testing arrangements; and
Options for addressing identified inequities, inconsistencies and inefficiencies.

PARA.TAB: The Consultant will seek Submissions from a wide range of individuals and organisations across Australia. The consultant should submit his or her first report by July 1994.
Following the finalisation of the report, the consultant will be required to assist with consultations on the report involving pensioner, community and investment industry representatives.
The consultant should submit his or her final report by September 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: SPECIALIST REFERENCE GROUP

PARA.TAB: The consultant in undertaking the consultancy will be provided with technical and other specialist advice from a "Reference Group" made up of experts from:

SPEECH.PARA: Peak retiree and veterans' organisations;
The finance/superannuation industry;
The Commonwealth Public Service—the Department of Social Security;
the Department of Veterans' Affairs;
the Department of Finance;
Treasury.

PARA.TAB: The consultant will also have the services of a small project/research team located in DSS, including representatives from DSS and DVA.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE FIFTH REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON
SUPERANNUATION
General Points
The Report and its recommendations are broadly consistent with the Government's approach and the ISC practices in calculating the levy.
The Government accepts the report and a majority of the recommendations.
The Government and the Commission are extremely conscious of the need to minimise the supervisory costs.
For the 1993-94 income year, the levy remains unchanged.
The Commission will continue to consult closely with industry on the preparation of the annual levy.
Recommendation

4.1 The Committee appreciates the move by the ISC to include the Chairman of the Joint Superannuation Committee of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants and the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Australia in its consultations on the supervisory levy. The Committee recognises that the interests of small fund members will be best served by this initiative. The Committee recommends that section 7(2) of the Superannuation Supervisory Levy Act 1991 be amended accordingly.
Response
Accepted
Comments
The Government accepts the Recommendation to amend Section 7(2) of the Act at an appropriate opportunity and undertakes that meanwhile the consultative process will continue.
The ISC does in practice consult with ASCPA and ICAA through their Joint Superannuation Committee.
Recommendation
4.2 The Committee is concerned that parties to the consultation process of the supervisory levy have differing expectations as to what that process involves. The Committee recommends the following:
that the ISC consult with industry representatives throughout the year rather than after the resource needs of the ISC have been decided with the Department of Finance;
that the ISC consult with the industry on the way it will spend money rather than just the way it is raised;
that the ISC provide the industry with budgets which clearly indicate the expenditure priorities for the year in question; and
that the ISC publish, as part of its annual report, a description of the consultative process it followed in determining the supervisory levy.
However, the Committee recognises that ultimately the ISC is the industry regulator and, as such, the opinions of the industry should not be binding on it.
Response
Accepted
Comments
Arrangements have been made for ISC-industry consultations, at appropriate junctures of the financial year, about ISC expenditures and their implications for future setting of the levy.
Consultations with industry associations are substantive and include estimates and consultations on the way in which levy monies will be spent.
The ISC does, and will continue, to provide the industry with expenditure estimates.
The ISC will publish in its 1992-93 and subsequent annual reports a description of the consultative process.
Recommendation

4.3 The Committee recommends that the costs associated with administering the Reasonable Benefit Limit regime not be recouped through the supervisory levy. This cost should be borne by the Government, as it will be when it is transferred to the Australian Tax Office.
Response
Accepted
Comments
RBL costs were not included in 1992/93 calculations and will not be included in estimating the levy in future.
Recommendation

4.4 The Committee recommends that an averaging approach be adopted when setting the supervisory levy. This would prevent any large fluctuations in the levy from year to year and provide certainty in planning both in the ISC and the industry.
Response
Accepted
Comments
The Government believes that trends in super fund numbers and in ISC supervision costs should be taken into account in setting the levy annually, as they have been in 1992/93.
The Government also seeks to smooth the levy as much as possible.
1991/92 required an unusual increase in revenue from the industry. This was because of a significant increase in supervisory costs, associated with increased responsibilities of the ISC-
while at the same time the number of funds was contracting.

Lower than budgeted expenditures as a result of deferred legislation, resulted in a surplus from 1991/92 which, when applied to funding the costs for the 1992/93 income year of super funds, has resulted in the levy remaining unchanged.

The Government agrees with a smoothing approach but not necessarily the application of a strict arithmetic averaging approach which may work to the disadvantage of funds, especially if supervision costs fall, when for a period levy collections could exceed requirements. The Government believes a 3 to 5 year rolling average may best meet the desire to avoid large fluctuations.
Recommendation

4.5 The Committee believes that it is not in a position to recommend the precise model which could be used to set future ISC supervisory levies. However, the Committee does have recommendations on the broad parameters which should underlie the levy setting process. In summary these are:
the current formula based on a flat fee and a variable fee dependent on asset size should be retained;
Response
Accepted
Comments
The present levy formula can be seen as a flat fee plus a variable fee on funds with assets in excess of $0.5 million.
Recommendation
the costs of administering the RBL arrangements should not be recouped
through the supervisory levy;
Response
Accepted
Comments
Current and future costs of administering RBL arrangements have already been removed from the levy charge.
Recommendation
the costs associated with the processing of annual returns should be recouped through a flat fee per fund;
Response
Not accepted
Comments
It is not practical to separate the annual returns processing charge from prudential supervision costs.
Recommendation
an attempt be made to identify the proportion of corporate overhead costs attributable to other functions which are required for prudential supervision;
Response
Accepted
Recommendation
As far as possible these costs are identified to facilitate consultations about, and calculations of, the levy.
Recommendation
and the costs associated with the development of policy and legislation should not be recovered through the supervisory levy.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The Government does not agree with the exclusion of certain superannuation supervisory costs from the cost calculations, as development of policy and legislation is an integral part of prudential supervision for the protection of members' interests.
Recommendation
4.6 The Committee recommends that the current formula based on a flat fee and a variable fee dependant on asset size be retained.
Response
Accepted
Comments
See response to 4.5 above.
Recommendation
5.1 The Committee recommends that cross-subsidisation between different sized funds should be kept to a minimum.
Response
Accepted
Comments
The Government agrees that cross-subsidisation between different sized funds be kept to a minimum.

The approach to setting the levy does help to minimise cross subsidisation. Considerable effort is made to achieve this minimisation and, broadly, revenue for the levy on small funds is relatively close to the estimated ISC costs relating to small funds.
Recommendation

5.2 The Committee recommends that cognisance be had of the likely service categories of funds would receive for the payment of the levy noting, however, that the levy is a tax and not a fee-for-service.
Response
Accepted
Comments
Cognisance will continue to be made of the service which funds receive for the payment of the levy.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SIXTH REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT
COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION

PARA.TAB: The recommendations apply only to personal superannuation plans which are sold by life insurance companies supervised by the Life Insurance Act 1945. A number of the recommendations have already been addressed in the Government's response to the Trade Practices Commission report on consumer experience with superannuation and life insurance (these are marked with an *).

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation

3.1 The Committee recommends that information provided to potential policy holders be presented in a brief and standardised format which will allow consumers to compare different products. (This information would be in addition to the more detailed contractual information.)
Response
Accepted*
Comments

Legislative amendments to the Life Insurance Act 1945 will set out the broad principles on the timing and content of disclosure to consumers. The amendments will impose a general legal duty on life companies and their directors to provide in a timely, accurate and comprehensible way all the information consumers need to make an informed choice.
Recommendation
The Committee further recommends that the brief and standardised information include:
a written description of each investment option facing the consumer and an outline of the general policy and strategy of the fund;
a written description of all fees and charges, (including any initial, ongoing and/or termination fees/charges) and, where these are variable, the minimum and maximum charges:
details of any penalties which may be imposed on early termination of the policy and the method of calculating these charges; and
details of the dispute resolution process which can be accessed if the consumer believes the advice or information provided may be inaccurate.
Response
Accepted in part*
Comments

The Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) will prescribe the structure and content of documentation to be provided at each stage of the policy life cycle (promotional documents, policy information statements and annual statements). It is envisaged that policy information statements will include a disclosure statement in brief and standardised format.

The level of detail which can be practicably disclosed at the point-of-sale, and whether it is appropriate to exempt any particular distribution methods, companies or intermediaries, from these requirements will be a consideration in the final form of disclosure.
Recommendation

3.2 The Committee recommends that, in conjunction with investment information, a 'needs analysis' based on the consumer's individual circumstances and preferences should be carried out and retained by both the life office and the consumer as verification of advice to the consumer.
Response
Accepted*
Comments
Legislative amendments to the Life Insurance Act will subject intermediaries to a `know your client' rule identical to the rule applying to investment advisers under the Corporations Law.

Intermediaries will be required to prepare a written `needs profile', recommend products appropriate to the client's financial circumstances and clearly describe their relationship with each life company they represent.

The ISC is developing a compulsory Code of Practice for life companies with the assistance of the Trade Practices Commission (TPC), the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs (FBCA), industry and consumer groups. The Code of Practice will prescribe minimum standards for the `needs profile' which must be appropriately documented, explained and provided to the consumer.

A `compliance committee' of the board of each life company will be required to monitor agent compliance with these rules, and the ISC will undertake random audits of life office compliance mechanisms.
Recommendation

3.3 The Committee recommends that the ISC encourage the adoption by the industry of standard clauses within promotional material and contract documentation and the adoption of plain English documentation.
Response
Accepted*
Comments

The ISC will prescribe the structure and content of documentation to be provided at each stage of the policy life cycle (promotional documents, policy information statements and annual statements). The disclosure rules will not prescribe the structure or content of the policy contract between life company and policyholder as this might inhibit product innovation to the detriment of consumers.
Recommendation
In implementing this policy, appropriate material for consumers from a non-English speaking background should also be developed.
Comments

Details of the disclosure requirement will be worked out in consultation with the industry. The extent to which Government intervention is required to meet the needs of consumers from a non-English speaking background will be considered in that context.
Recommendation

3.4 The Committee recommends that life insurance agents disclose both orally and in writing the amounts of commission, as well as other benefits that accrue to them, as a consequence of the sale of personal and group superannuation products.
Response
Accepted*
Comments

Commission disclosure is currently required on single premium products. Commission disclosure for other life company products will be required in promotional statements and in Policy Information Statements. Consultation with interested parties will establish the precise form of commission disclosure, the level of detail which can be practicably disclosed at point-of-sale, and whether it is appropriate to exempt any particular distribution methods, companies or intermediaries, from these requirements.
Recommendation
3.5 The Committee recommends that any new commission disclosure scheme applying to life insurance agents be reviewed by an appropriate Senate Committee within three years.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

It is noted that three years after the implementation of the above mentioned Code of Practice the ISC, TPC and FBCA will conduct a Government review of the consumer protection measures. A Senate review of the new commission disclosure scheme within three years might therefore prove unnecessary and a decision should be delayed to that time.
Recommendation
3.6 The Committee recommends that, to distinguish the role of the different types of agents and life brokers, agents should be required to disclose:
the organisations with which the agent holds agency agreements;
whether the agent is acting for the life office(s) with which the agent holds agency agreements and the nature of the fiduciary relationship with the life office;
whether the agent is remunerated in whole or in part by commission on behalf of the life offices for selling the companies' life products;
whether the commission will be paid from charges imposed by the policy; andthe manner in which early surrender charges will be calculated.
Response
Accepted*
Comments
Legislative amendments will require that agents clearly describe in a written document their relationship with each life company they represent.
The form of the document will be set out in the Code of Practice
Legislative amendments will prohibit certain intermediaries from describing themselves as independent.
See also comments on Recommendations 3.1 and 3.3.
Recommendation

3.7 The Committee recommends that the Prices Surveillance Authority closely monitor the level of fees, charges and commissions applying to superannuation products and report on its activities in this area in its Annual Report to Parliament.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) does not have a formal monitoring function under the Prices Surveillance Authority Act 1983. The number of superannuation funds would also present difficulties and the Authority may feel that to adequately monitor prices it would need to monitor a range of other indicators such as company profits and costs.

Moreover, it would be inappropriate to have the PSA monitoring superannuation charges on an on-going basis so soon after major public inquiries into the industry and proposed major changes to the regulation of the industry. Requirements under the Life Insurance Act for full disclosure of all fees and charges, (including commissions), will put pressure on the industry to ensure competitive pricing. Already some life companies have reduced fees and charges on their products.
Recommendation

3.8 The Committee recommends that the Insurance Contracts Act be amended such that the term `free look period' is replaced by `cooling off period' and made to apply to all personal superannuation plans.
Response
Accepted.
Recommendation
3.9 The Committee reiterates its recommendation in Safeguarding Super that an external review body be established to adjudicate on superannuation disputes.
Response
Accepted*
Comments
The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints)Bill 1993, introduced into Parliament on 27 May 1993, provides for the establishment of a Superannuation Complaints Tribunal to operate from 1 July 1994.

The Tribunal will be able to deal with any complaint which relates to a decision made by a trustee in relation to a particular individual. The Tribunal will provide mechanisms for the conciliation of complaints and, where the complaint cannot be resolved by conciliation, review the decision of the trustee(s) to which the complaint relates. The Tribunal is not precluded from dealing with complaints arising from personal superannuation products sold by life companies.
Recommendation

The Committee further recommends that Government's proposed dispute resolution tribunal adjudicate on consumer complaints arising out of personal superannuation contracts entered into after 1 July 1992 where these have not been satisfactorily resolved at the company or industry level.
Response
Accepted in part*
Comments

The Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 does not expressly limit the kinds of complaints the Tribunal can deal with, in terms of the time at which the decision to which the related complaint was made. However, the Bill confers discretionary power on the Tribunal to effectively withdraw a complaint if more than 12 months have elapsed since the trustee has made the decision to which the complaint relates. This will ensure that the Tribunal is able to operate efficiently and effectively in its handling of complaints, without precluding it from handling valid complaints arising from any trustee decision, no matter how old.
Recommendation

3.10 The Committee recommends that the ISC and key superannuation industry groups representing the interests of consumers and providers, combine to develop and implement a five year superannuation consumer education strategy for implementation in early 1994.
Response
Accepted
Comments

The ISC together with other key entities is developing a community education strategy about superannuation. It is expected that consumer groups will be consulted in the process as appropriate. This strategy will identify the main aims of an education program and the best methods of achieving those aims. It will undertake certain educational activities to promote community understanding about superannuation and be catalytic in encouraging other superannuation educational activities such as inclusion of instruction about superannuation in high school curricula.
Recommendation
3.11 The Committee recommends that consumer counselling services be provided by the ISC in each of the capital cities and major regional centres.
Response
Not accepted
Comments

The ISC provides information and education to consumers on the superannuation and insurance legislation it administers. It would not be appropriate for the ISC as a prudential supervisor of the insurance and superannuation industries to provide counselling on matters that are mainly of a private financial nature. Consumer counselling which requires detailed analysis of a person's financial needs and circumstances, and a knowledge of the financial products suited to those particular needs and circumstances, would most effectively be carried out in the financial services marketplace. The cost of such a counselling service could be high, if offered by a public sector organisation in competition with the private sector. Levies on superannuation funds and life offices, which ultimately fall upon the retirement savings of fund members and policyholders, have already had to be significantly raised to fund ISC supervision.
Recommendation
3.12 The Committee recommends that the industry establish and maintain an agent registration system, together with a code of conduct to be approved by the ISC.
Response
Accepted in part*
Comments

Existing legislation imposes obligations on life companies to be responsible for the conduct of their agents. The ISC is developing a Code of Practice for life companies which will, inter alia, address agent regulation. It is envisaged that the Code will impose minimum obligations and standards on each life office with regard to supervising agent selection, training, competence and conduct. A Compliance Committee of each life office will be required to monitor the company's compliance with the rules and the ISC will undertake random audits of life office compliance mechanisms.

There will be a mechanism to ban agents who have failed to comply with the legislation or the Code from working in the industry.The consultation process will establish detailed requirements for agent regulation to be incorporated in the Code.
Recommendation

3.13 The Committee recommends that the ISC report annually on developments in the area of agent registration and that in three years an appropriate Senate committee inquire into and report on this matter.
Response
Accepted in part*
Comments

The ISC will report annually on the operations of the Code of Practice for life companies which will continue to be responsible for agents. Agents will not be registered. However, given that the ISC, TPC and FBCA will be reviewing the implementation of the Code of Practice in three years, a Senate inquiry and report on this matter at that time may be unnecessary.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE EIGHTH REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT
COMMITTEE ON SUPERANNUATION
General Points
The Government accepts the Report and the recommendation of the Committee which is related to the Government's retirement income policy.
The Government is conscious of the need for the early implementation of legislation to increase the prudential control and supervision of superannuation funds.

The Superannuation Industry Supervisory Bills which the Government introduced into the Parliament on 27 May 1993 give effect to increasing the prudential and consumer protection arrangements for superannuation.
Recommendation

The Committee in carrying out a close study of the Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund observed the consequences when the principles of trust law are neglected and abused. It remarked on the important role government had in educating both trustees and members as to their respective rights and responsibilities as a means of preventing a Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund situation. The Committee recommends the early implementation of legislation to increase the prudential control and supervision of superannuation funds.
Response
Accepted
Comments

The Government welcomes the Committee's Recommendation that the Superannuation Industry Supervisory legislation be put into effect quickly. That package of legislation gives effect to the prudential and consumer protection arrangements for superannuation announced by the Government on 21 October 1992. The legislative framework includes a comprehensive system of prudential supervision. The legislation is designed to support honest and diligent trustees and give members a greater say in the management of funds. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) will be monitoring and auditing compliance.

The Government has also recognised the importance of education trustees and members about occupational superannuation. This will improve the effectiveness of trustees and their understanding of their responsibilities and so improve the security of retirement savings. Better informed fund members will also contribute to improved fund operation. The Government also recognises a need to increase community understanding of the critical role superannuation plays in retirement income.

The ISC is working with other government agencies, representatives of the superannuation industry and consumer groups to develop an effective education strategy. A range of education and information initiatives will be developed and implemented to ensure trustees, their professional advisers and members understand superannuation as a retirement income strategy and their obligations and rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report 327, containing the finance minute on report 325, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to report No. 327, which deals with the response to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Midford Paramount case and related matters, several important areas need to be drawn to the attention of the Senate. I would like particularly to single out the comments that have been made by the Director of Public Prosecutions in response to the report of the public accounts committee. To say that they are disappointing and that the DPP seems to have learned little, whereas in evidence it said it had learned something, is to put it mildly.

PARA.TAB: The committee has taken the almost unprecedented course of answering the responses by the DPP so that, on the record, they can be seen as the facile comments that they are. Time permits me to deal with only a selected number of them, but I would like to point out some of the more salient points. The first area I wish to address deals with the failed prosecution which the DPP mounted. To understand the context of this prosecution, it is necessary to set the scene of just what transpired.

The Midford Paramount company had been in business making shirts and other garments for 40 years. It was a company owned by the Macdessi family, who came to this country as migrants, established a successful business, were well respected in the community, provided employment for 400 people in Wollongong, enjoyed the confidence of many members of parliament and enjoyed the confidence of the citizenry generally who came to know them. They conducted their business in a highly professional way, they used the services of reputable and known consultants and they were regarded as one of the great success stories in Australia. Their reputation, health and businesses were destroyed by the actions of the Australian Customs Service, involving at least two officers of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and by the failure of the Director of Public Prosecutions to properly prepare the case which finally came to court and was thrown out in no uncertain terms and in a scathing way by the magistrate.

The DPP says that the collapse of the prosecution did not mean that the DPP was at fault. The DPP concluded that the net result of the approach taken by the committee in assessing the evidence before it was that findings of fact made by it must be treated with considerable caution at the very least. The DPP has sought to try to cover up its own ineptitude by attacking the committee.
Let me go to the statement that the DPP was a fault. The committee comments on the assertion that the DPP says that it was not at fault for preparing a poor case in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: If the `committal proceedings foundered at an early stage' it is hard to see why the competence of those running the case would not be called into question.
This is a perfectly reasonable comment, I would think. The committee goes on to say:

At the committal hearing it become apparent during cross-examination that the two `expert' witnesses for the prosecution were far from expert. If, as asserted at paragraph 28 dot point 3, `copies of all relevant Cabinet documents were in material originally provided to the DPP by ACS—
the Australian Customs Service—
and were given to the prosecuting counsel', why were the `expert' witnesses apparently unaware of them, or of their significance?
In short, the Committee concluded in Report 325 that officers of the DPP failed to properly perform their duties and this led to a debacle.

Further, the DPP said in paragraphs 7 to 12 that the case was a very difficult one and that the committee set unrealistic standards and `failed to recognise it was reviewing the case with the benefit of hindsight'. A very simple answer to that point is the fact that if the case was so complex, why did it choose to run the case under the Crimes Act and not the Customs Act, and why was it then allocated to an inexperienced and relatively junior DPP case officer?

PARA.TAB: Let me refer to the evidence given at hearings by one Mrs Hannam, the relatively young and inexperienced officer of the DPP. When I asked Mrs Hannam why the source documents were not part of the evidence, she replied that they were not relevant. Of course, the magistrate held that they were and that was in fact the reason that he threw the case out. Mrs Hannam said:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence that we relied on to set out government policy was not through tendering those documents themselves; it was through Dr Fitzpatrick. His evidence gave the history of the schemes and how they were set out. He was who we were relying on. He was our witness.
I went on to ask her:
So you simply accepted what Dr Fitzpatrick said as the basis of your case?
Mrs Hannam replied:
No. I had seen the documents—

I then said that Dr Fitzpatrick had told me in estimates hearings that he did not see the documents. Another officer of the DPP replied that that was a matter of regret. Regret? This destroyed the lives and reputation and health of Australians who had worked hard and contributed to the economy of this country. It has resulted in the government having to accede to the request of the public accounts committee that compensation be paid. We the taxpayers are accordingly having to fund $25 million in compensation to people whose lives were destroyed by actions of incompetence.

PARA.TAB: Yet the DPP has the audacity to come back and say, `You can't blame us because we got it wrong'. The point is that, on the DPP's very own admission, if it was such a complex case, why was it not given to a senior person and why was there no checking of the way in which the case was conducted? In the further examination of Mrs Hannam, I said that she knew what was in those documents and she knew that they were never dealt with in evidence.

The management of the case in fact resulted in people being prosecuted in a way that would have resulted in permanent injustice. These people had nowhere else to go except to this parliament. Senator Ray, who sits on the other side of the chamber, comments that the committee—I being one member of the committee—chose to have close cross-examination of the person who was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Arrogant, rude, abusive interrogation.
—This was the person who was in charge of prosecuting these Australians and destroying their lives.
—Bully boy magistrates court tactics. That is what it was.

—Indeed, the failure of the DPP to properly conduct its case meant that distinguished Australians who had contributed to the economy of Australia were facing the prospect of 20 years in gaol. And Senator Ray would criticise questions being asked about that?
—No. The manner and the rudeness in which they were directed and the sexist manner of them; that is what I criticise.

—The question was: why did the DPP assign this case—the first under the Crimes Act—to a person who was inexperienced and why was the work not checked? That is where the DPP is culpable in this matter.

PARA.TAB: I wish to raise a further point—that is, the action the DPP took to prevent the committee from beginning its hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: We were ready to commence our hearings when the DPP asked to see us to tell us that he did not want the hearings to begin because he would be relying on the evidence of two witnesses who would appear before our inquiry and he did not want the credibility of those witnesses to be tested other than in the court case that he was presenting. We, the committee, acquiesced in that request. To my dying day, I will regret having done that, because I do not know whether or not it was in fact that evidence given by those two people that convicted the people who were prosecuted and about whom the DPP was concerned.

PARA.TAB: The reason that I have a personal concern is that those two witnesses—Mr Robinson and Mr O'Shannassy—were found to be highly discredited witnesses. In a way, the committee was placed in a position where its acquiescing in the request of the DPP not to proceed with its hearings let those witnesses be seen in a light other than that in which we found them in our inquiry.

The DPP states in paragraphs 14 and 15 that much of the criticism against him was based on the conclusion that the case was flawed. The DPP states that it was not possible to do this because the issues were not tested in law. The committee very properly comments:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee made no findings on matters of law. Plain English definitions and common sense were applied to the interpretations of the Cabinet documents and quota instruments referred to in paragraph 15 and the interpretations sought by the ACS and DPP were not sustainable.

During public hearings the interpretation of the quota instruments was discussed at length. The DPP witnesses were unable to produce authoritative documents, either during or after the hearings, to support their contention that the phrase `sourced from' was equivalent to `manufactured'.
The Committee concludes that the DPP appears to be covering up for its failure to prepare adequately for the case.

There were further examples of poor preparation and, indeed, misleading evidence and missing evidence. I refer again to Mr O'Shannassy and Mr Robinson, the two officers who went to Malaysia to try to find proof in order to prove the case which they were determined to prosecute. They obtained documentary evidence and statements from people in Malaysia in defiance of a court order of the court of Malaysia. When the pressure was stepped up and an injunction was obtained, those two officers did what could only be described as a moonlight flit: they left their dirty washing behind in the hotel; they did not use their proper airline tickets; there were Telecom records of telephone conversations with Australia; they took stand-by tickets and got out of the jurisdiction, taking the documentation with them. This caused a diplomatic incident. There was grave concern about the continuing effectiveness of the five power defence treaty. The Australian Customs Service tried to bolster a case which was flawed from the beginning.

PARA.TAB: In paragraphs 19 and 20, the DPP accuses the committee of subjecting witnesses `to personal abuse bordering on harassment', that questions often took the form of lengthy diatribes and that the proceedings were sometimes `conducted more as an inquisition than an inquiry'. The DPP adds that this treatment contravenes section 19(1) of the Public Accounts Committee Act which affords witnesses the same protection and privileges as before the High Court. The committee very properly responds:

SPEECH.PARA: As the Inquiry progressed, the Committee found itself faced with hostile Government agencies. Massive quantities of evidence were given to the Committee but they were unindexed, often duplicated other evidence and in numerous instances were irrelevant. Witnesses were often evasive, giving evidence which was subsequently found to be incorrect. Occasionally, they altered their story whilst giving evidence. This is commented on in Report 325.

The Committee was faced with the task of examining ACS officers who had lost their notebooks, had a diary page reporting events on a crucial day only affixed to the document by sticky tape, had mislaid notes of crucial conversations, had altered evidence pertaining to the case, and had lost the original of a brief sent to the DPP.
This is discussed at length in the report of the public accounts committee into the whole sad, sorry, saga of the Midford Paramount affair.
The committee further responded as follows:

.In the face of continued obfuscation the only way the Committee could extract anything resembling the truth from some witnesses was to engage in close questioning. The Chairman told the Comptroller-General of Customs that the Committee did not resile from this task.

Here is the most bobby-dazzler statement of the lot! This, I remind the Senate, comes from the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is truly one of the more amazing statements I have ever read. In paragraphs 22 and 23, the DPP accuses the committee of giving undue status to the legal presumption of innocence. The Director of Public Prosecutions says we gave undue influence to the legal presumption of innocence! This is the man charged with ensuring justice. We heard evidence that the DPP was desperate to get a conviction, and yet we gave undue evidence to the presumption of innocence. How can we possibly continue to have confidence in an office which says it has forgotten that the presumption of innocence is prima facie and fundamental to our concept of justice under the criminal law?

PARA.TAB: We asked very early in this inquiry why the Director of Public Prosecutions chose the Crimes Act and not the Customs Act. It was because the Crimes Act meant that people faced up to 20 years in jail and meant that the DPP could invoke the use of the Proceeds of Crime Act and freeze all the people's goods and bank accounts. The DPP destroyed the business altogether. The significance of the Director of Public Prosecutions's downgrading of the presumption of innocence should not be lost, or left as a statement with which anyone in this parliament could live. The committee's answer to the Director of Public Prosecutions's accusations is this:

SPEECH.PARA: .The major flaw in the conduct of the investigation by the ACS was that it presumed Midford was guilty, and that all it had to do was find the right evidence.
.It should be noted that the Committee received huge volumes of conflicting evidence, and made no assumptions that the ACS, DITAC DPP, Midford or anyone else's material was entirely accurate.
.In fact, the comment in paragraph 23 displays an ignorance of the parliamentary committee inquiry process . . .

There is one other matter that is equally of grave concern, and it concerned us at the time of the hearing. The DPP complained that, in its words, we placed considerable weight on self-serving affidavits filed in Malaysian proceedings and that we made positive findings on the basis of those affidavits. There was a continuing undercurrent, which I and others found totally unacceptable, that somehow evidence of Australian customs officers was preferable and better than evidence given by Malaysian people. The fact of the matter is that those affidavits were sworn in the way that affidavits by Australians were sworn. The innuendo that somehow, because they were Malaysians, one would place less reliance on their evidence than on Australian evidence is totally and utterly unacceptable. Those affidavits were given due weight, but we relied on extraneous evidence to those affidavits to come finally to the conclusions that we reached.

PARA.TAB: The whole story of the Midford Paramount saga is one that has to set a standard that says that individual Australians must not be subjected to the brute force of bureaucracy and the open-ended purse of the public sector. It says that this parliament will provide justice for individual Australians who are persecuted in the manner in which these people were.

This matter began in the estimates committees where I began asking questions. It then came into this chamber where, with the concurrence of the Australian Democrats, the matter was referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Two years of inquiry passed and a mammoth report was produced. It then took the government 11 months to compensate those people, because we saw the bureaucracy attempt to retry the issues. It was only after I and other senators brought pressure to bear that we finally saw the interdepartmental committee make a report and the announcement of the $25 million compensation.

Look at the personal lives of those who were affected. A director of the company of Midford Paramount was hospitalised. One adviser is a former shadow of his physical self. Another has lost his business and is being sustained only by his church. One former senior person in the company has died. The compensation can never restore what these people had, but it does recognise that justice can be brought about by actions within this parliament.

The matter began in an adversarial way. The minister, former Senator Button, fought off an attempt to have this matter fully inquired into. But when we finally came to the business of the inquiry, a bipartisan effort transcended party political differences and we worked together to find the truth and vindication for people who had been oppressed.

The second thing that we all wanted, again in a bipartisan way, was a fundamental change in attitude on the part of the bureaucracy which perpetrated this horrendous case upon a group of Australians. There has been a total change in the culture of the Australian Customs Service. It does not continue with the attitude that it has got it right and that everybody else is wrong. I can only say of the DPP that when Mr Coghlan said in evidence that they had learned something from the failure of their prosecution, the rest of the DPP's operatives learned the same things.

I never again want to see or hear from the person charged with prosecuting ordinary Australians that there is undue influence put upon the presumption of innocence. That is the essence of our criminal system. We must all stand fast in this parliament and say that those in whom we put the confidence of upholding the law and seeking justice—and, indeed, punishment for those who breach it—must pay attention to the principles that bind us, of which the presumption of innocence remains fundamental.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to a misunderstanding, report No. 327 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was tabled by Senator Panizza before it was scheduled to be dealt with according to the Order of Business. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the remarks that I intended to make on behalf of the committee on the tabling of the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The remarks read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Report 327 contains the Finance Minute (or formal response) on Report 325, The Midford Paramount Case and Related Matters, together with Committee comment on the Finance Minute and in particular, comments made by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) in an appendix to the Finance Minute.

The Inquiry into the Midford Paramount Case and Related Matters investigated the failed prosecution of a Wollongong-based shirt manufacturer, Midford Paramount and revealed significant failings in Commonwealth administration. This of necessity resulted in a report to the Parliament which was critical of both the Australian Customs Service and to a lesser extent the DPP. While the Committee may have anticipated that these agencies would not agree with all of its recommendations, it did not at any time foresee the gratuitous comments that would be offered by the DPP in the Finance Minute.

The DPP's comments, if read in isolation, would present a reader with a false view of the Committee's Inquiry and Report 325. Therefore to ensure that the Parliament and other interested parties are presented with a balanced view, the Committee has prepared this report.

The DPP's criticisms appear to be based on selective quoting, a failure to read the entire Report, and contain simple errors of comprehension and demonstrate a lack of understanding of basic fundamentals such as public accountability, the role and functions of parliamentary committees, and the presumption of innocence.

The Committee is disappointed at the comments made by the DPP, for they indicate that the Director has learnt little from the Midford case or the Committee's Inquiry. Given the breadth of the Committee's Inquiry it is significant that the DPP chose to make no comment on the vast majority of the Report even though he did not confine himself to findings relating to the DPP.
Needless to say, the Committee is firmly of the view that Report 325 stands on its own merits as a thorough and balanced document.
I commend this Report to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to report No. 318 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on public sector research and development. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC SECTOR RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT

14. Appropriation funding for research organisations be responsive to shifts in the level of industry demand for short term research support from these organisations, but continue to maintain sufficient resources to support core research programs at all times. (paragraph 5.68)
