Not agreed The 30% external earnings target has been effective in making research agencies responsive to industry demand. When the target was introduced, the Government also announced that external earnings would be retained by the research agencies. The recommended changes to appropriation funding would result in significant instability in funding core research programs, and this should be avoided.

The Government has put in place a review to examine the external funding targets for Government research agencies including CSIRO, ANSTO (the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation) and AIMS (the Australian Institute of Marine Science). The review will be conducted by ASTEC (the Australian Science and Technology Council), with a report to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science due by February 1994.

16. The Government provide sufficient funds to research agencies through Appropriation Acts No. 1 and No. 3 to cover the cost of smaller equipment and maintenance purchases and the direct cost of core research programs. (paragraph 6.21)

20. The Government ensure that funding levels and mechanisms do not compromise the capacity of Commonwealth research agencies to conduct the core research which is necessary to the achievement of their respective missions. (paragraph 7.34)

Agreed in principle The Government provides funds to agencies in the budgetary process sufficient to realise the objectives set. Funding is based on the explicit objectives of programs, and it is the responsibility of management to ensure that the full cost of their various programs and activities are assessed and provided for within the allocated funds.
The Government is aware, however, that costs of imported scientific equipment have risen substantially in the face of the falling dollar, and is encouraging agencies to seek other forms of income.

A number of new measures have been introduced in recent years, and the government is monitoring the effects of these. One of the most significant mechanisms is the 30% target for external earnings by research agencies such as CSIRO.

The Government notes that the 30% external earnings target is only one of several indicators of the agencies' interactions with clients—a wider range of indicators for the agencies' effectiveness and efficiency are appropriate and attention is being given in each of the agencies to improving these. The benefits of the targets have been to:
make the research agencies more outward looking in their interaction with industry and other government agencies;
provide a long-term target for those research agencies less focused toward industrial development;
motivate agencies to develop sources of income other than direct appropriations; and
initiate consideration of the costing and pricing of research services, and increasingly, the value of the environment, health and other non-commercial objectives.

35. The Government urgently review the effects of the 30% external funding requirement on the capacity of those organisations affected to best serve the needs of Australian industry and to maintain relevant basic research expertise (paragraph 8.83)

Already established process The Government currently monitors the funding and efficacy of all its operations, and the agencies that have 30% external funding requirements are monitoring the impact on their operations. The Minister for Science and Small Business has put in place a review of the external earnings targets the Government has set for the research agencies.
See also the response to Recommendations 16 and 20.

9. The Government review on an ongoing basis the salaries paid to public sector researchers, teaching academics and school teachers working in science and science-related areas, with a view to establishing more appropriate relativities for the salaries paid to these professionals vis-a-vis those paid in the wider community (paragraph 5.33)
Not agreed The salaries of academics and science teachers are set through the normal industrial relations processes.

Salaries for teachers are a State responsibility. There has been considerable effort in recent years to implement pay structures for teachers based on national benchmarks which treat teachers as a single professional group. Implementation of new structures involving improved career paths and substantial pay increases began in 1991 with Tasmania the only State yet to implement the new structure (a decision by the Tasmanian Industrial Commission to adopt the new structure is being appealed by the State Government).

Recent changes to the wages system increase the flexibility for agencies to reward staff within the limits of their overall budgetary resources. In its October 1991 National Wage Case decision, the AIRC adopted the Enterprise Bargaining Principle to enable wage increases based on productivity increases at the enterprise level. In July 1992 the Government amended the Industrial Relations Act to encourage the use of certified agreements as a vehicle for workplace bargaining.

On 4 December 1992 an agreement between the Government and public service unions entitled Improving Productivity, Jobs and Pay in the Australian Public Service 1992-94 was certified by the AIRC. This provides for a total of 4.9% for all classifications, including APS research scientists and academics, over the life of the Agreement. In addition it provides for:
the introduction of performance-based pay for the Senior Executive Service, Senior Officers, and related groups such as Research Scientists and Academics; and
the possibility of productivity pay, based on negotiations at the agency level;
In the case of teachers, the Australian Teachers' Union has discussed a similar approach with the Government.

Base salaries are only one component of the total benefits available to public sector academics and researchers. These include superannuation, tenure, and in the case of research scientists, the availability of merit advancement and accelerated advancement. The CSIRO has provision for performance-based pay and this is also being introduced in ANSTO. The CSIRO also has the power to pay bonuses to persons or teams in respect of discoveries or inventions made by them. Academics often have rights to engage in consultancy up to a certain percentage of salary.
In addition, other rewards such as undertaking work of public value and the intrinsic interest of the work have always been factors in public sector pay fixation.
10. The Government regularly monitor the universities' needs for capital funding and, using a formalised priority-setting process, plan to meet these needs. (para 5.40)

Agreed in part The Government regularly monitors needs and has decided that, from 1994, capital funds for higher education institutions will be provided as part of their operating grants. This will enable institutions to make their own funding decisions regarding the expenditure of capital funds.

11. The Government monitor the level of funding per Effective Full Time Student Unit such that the increase in the number of university places is matched by appropriate improvements to university infrastructure, bearing in mind the greater funding needs of science and science-related university places. (para 5.40)

Already in place The Government does this. The funding provided per EFTSU to institutions takes into account the different funding needs of the various disciplines and covers the full teaching costs including infrastructure. The Australian Research Council (ARC) provides Research Infrastructure Funds through Mechanisms A, B and C. Mechanism A is block funding and the use of the block funding is at the discretion of the receiving institution.

12. The number of science research fellowships and postgraduate research awards be progressively increased to a level where supply equates more closely with evolving demand in Australia and overseas (para 5.44)

Agreed in principle In the 1992 Budget the Government announced that it would provide 200 additional Australian Postgraduate Research Awards (APRAs), bringing the total number of new awards made annually to 1500. The Postgraduate Awards Scheme has recently been reviewed by an ARC working party whose recommendations included:
an increase in the numbers of APRAs to 1900 new awards annually (including 200 industry-linked awards);
an increase in APRA stipends by $2000 pa, with the stipend in future maintaining its parity with academic salaries; and
changes to the formula used to allocate awards to institutions.

The ARC has considered the working party report and is preparing advice for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, which is required to be tabled in Parliament. The Government has responded to this report in the Budget context.

The Research Fellowships Scheme supports researchers from the postdoctoral level through to professorial level. A total of 105 new research fellowships are available each year. The scheme was last reviewed in 1989 following a reference from the Minister. The review resulted in the National Research Fellowships being replaced by a scheme which provided three levels of fellowships:
The Australian Postdoctoral Fellowships (for researchers with less than two years postdoctoral experience);
The Australian Research Fellowships (for researchers with more than two years postdoctoral experience); and
The Australian Senior Research Fellowships (for researchers at Senior Lecturer level or above).
13. The Government evaluate the contribution of the 1% training levy to improving the skills needed by Australian firms for the successful performance of R&D and its commercialisation (para 5.52 )

Agreed The Department of Employment Education and Training is evaluating the training guarantee levy (now at 1.5%) and will have completed it by December 1994. One of the areas to be covered by this evaluation is the interaction between training practices and innovation in industry.

21. Research agencies be required to continually monitor private sector capabilities in relevant research areas, and actively explore the possibilities of subcontracting work to private sector agencies. (paragraph 7.39)
22. Research agencies be provided with sufficient resources to enable them to carry out these functions. (paragraph 7.39)
25. Sufficient appropriation funding be provided to government departments and agencies to enable them to meet the cost of contracting good quality research. (paragraph 7.47)

Agreed in principle Expanding the performance of research and development by the private sector is one of the major goals of Government policy for science and technology. This goal is being pursued in a variety of ways, including the strengthening of linkages between public sector research organisations and the users of research. This requires that research agencies understand the capabilities of the private sector and strive to ensure that companies are involved in research programs to the fullest extent possible. The Government sees `contracting out' as a useful means of developing researcher-user interaction and as a valuable mechanism to facilitate commercialisation and technology transfer.

The current practice in the research agencies is that consultants are recruited on the basis of their capacity to add value in a cost-effective way. In much research, environmental research for example, the quality and credibility of the work done in the agencies cannot be matched in the private sector. Whilst the Government is keen to ensure that the public sector does not crowd out new players in commercial research, it considers that allowing Government research agencies to compete on level terms with the private sector is the best way to ensure quality in Australian research.

Research projects are contracted out by Departments whenever there is a requirement for the research for Government policy purposes and the necessary skills are unavailable, or otherwise engaged, within an organisation.

80. Funds be provided to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to enable it to make grants to government organisations, which have responsibilities for environmental management and wish to commission research from the Australian Institute of Marine Science. (paragraph 14.43)
Not agreed It is inappropriate to specify the commissioning of research from AIMS as a condition of funding.

23. The Australian Bureau of Statistics collect and regularly publish sufficient information on research contracts let to private industries by Government agencies to allow regular monitoring of the extent of this practice.
Agreed As part of its regular R&D surveys program, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) collects data on:
payments made by Commonwealth, State and Local Government authorities to other organisations for the conduct of R&D; and
funds obtained by private businesses from Government authorities for the conduct of R&D.

These statistics are published every two years in ABS catalogues Nos. 8109.0 and 8104.0 respectively. These statistics should provide sufficient information to measure trends in research work contracted out to the private sector.
15. As a general principle, the full cost of carrying out research should be recovered from the user or from research grants obtained from funding bodies. (paragraph 6.17)
24. The Government review the effects of commercial pricing by research agencies on the capacity of users to access and apply that research. (paragraph 7.47)
56. Budget-funded research agencies obtain some contribution to overhead costs when performing research financed by other government organisations. (paragraph 11.54)
Agreed in principle This issue was addressed by the Government in the 1992 White Paper Developing Australian Ideas, from which the following response is taken:

"The Coordination Committee of Science and Technology has recently produced a paper on the costing and pricing of public sector research, as a guide to researchers and funders on the principles to be applied. The Government has endorsed the following principles for the costing and pricing of public sector research:

.all research performers should develop and maintain accurate accounting systems, recording all the costs associated with any research project/program, with the best balance of accuracy, transparency and cost-effectiveness in doing so.

.pricing decisions should be based on knowledge of all relevant cost components, to ensure the long-term viability of the research enterprise and to meet the need for accountability for publicly-provided resources.

.decisions on price should be based on an understanding of the respective objectives and responsibilities of the research performer and funder, and the extent to which the benefits from the conduct and results of the research can be captured by each party."

In general, the Government considers that the user-pays principle should be applied but also accepts that details of implementation are a matter for individual agencies with negotiations carried out on a case-by-case basis.

41. The Bureau of Industry Economics, the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics receive increased funding for any additional research work required of them by the Government. (paragraph 9.36)

Already established process The Bureau of Industry Economics has its own work program, approved by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. It has established pricing procedures for work beyond this program which are based on costs incurred, the nature of the work and the user of research.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy carries out a rigorous forward planning program which sets priorities and reflects the appropriation provided for its three research bureaux (including the now Bureau of Resource Sciences and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics). Independent evaluation of the cost effectiveness of different kinds of research are currently conducted by the bureaux, and the bulk of this work is carried out on a contract basis.
51. The research costs of Government funded R&D organisations such as CSIRO be exempt from the application of the efficiency dividend. (paragraph 11.40)

Agreed in principle The Government has announced that further consideration of funding levels in the next triennium (1994-5 to 1996-7), including the efficiency dividend issue, will be determined by the end of this year. The review of triennium funding recommended that the efficiency dividend should apply only to the administrative element of the science agencies and that research activities be exempt. This issue will be further considered by the Government following the McKinnon review into marine and fisheries science research and the interdepartmental committee's report on nuclear science and technology arrangements.
94. The research costs of the Bureau of Mineral Resources' programs be exempt from the application of the efficiency dividend. (paragraph 16.34)

Implemented in part All AGSO running costs including research costs are subject to the efficiency dividend. This issue was considered in the Richard's Review and the Government has agreed that the lease costs of the vessel Rig Seismic will now be exempt from the efficiency dividend on the grounds that this represents a substantial fixed cost to AGSO against which it would be difficult to accrue annual efficiencies.
2.1 Mechanisms for Setting Priorities
1. The Government review on a regular basis the effectiveness of the mechanisms for establishing national research directions for Science and Technology White Papers. (paragraph 4.34)
18. The Australian Science and Technology Council continue to use and refine its approach to prioritising national needs for large scale research facilities. (paragraph 6.35)
19. A regular review of such facilities be undertaken, as proposed by the Australian Science and Technology Council (paragraph 6.35).
27. The Government consider extending the use of the attractiveness/feasibility model developed by CSIRO in the development of national research priorities. (paragraph 7.61)

28. Other Commonwealth research agencies evaluate the appropriateness of the attractiveness/feasibility model for use in the internal assessment of priorities for the expenditure of untied research funds. (paragraph 7.61)

Agreed in part The importance of ensuring that Australia's substantial investment in research and development produces appropriate benefits for the nation has meant that considerable attention has been given to priority setting in the Government's policies for science and technology.

The 1992 White Paper Developing Australian Ideas articulates the Government's role of identifying overall national goals and the responsibilities of individual agencies for establishing their own priorities within that overall framework.

The Government's strategy is to allocate decision making to the appropriate level, so that decisions can be taken by informed people and in the context of factors such as industry or other end-user interest and support, or an understanding of social or economic needs. This strategy has been developed and strengthened over recent years and most, if not all, Departments and agencies now have priority-setting procedures closely matched to the characteristics and strategic plans of the industry or area of social or economic activity for which they are responsible. The White Paper required the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology (CCST) to report on these procedures and address their adequacy and the Committee is now undertaking this task.

As noted in the White Paper, the Government considers that one of the most effective and direct mechanisms of priority setting is to have users pay directly for the research they intend to use. This has been implemented through the setting of earnings targets for some research agencies.

The need to prioritise proposals for national research facilities is accepted. As noted in the White Paper, the CCST will keep a watching brief on the development of specific proposals for national research facilities, particularly those that cross departmental boundaries. As far as possible, the Government intends to ensure that Australian industry will be involved in major facilities, both in Australian content and as a user of the operating facility.

Some other Commonwealth research organisations have taken the CSIRO attractiveness/feasibility model for use in the internal assessment of priorities for the expenditure of untied research funds. However, research agencies may choose to develop other forms of priority-setting mechanisms, and are best positioned to determine their own priorities based on interactions with relevant users of their research.

A number of research agencies, including DSTO and agencies within the Primary Industries and Energy and the Health portfolios have already considered the suitability of the CSIRO model for priority setting. They have found that, while the model contains features such as consideration of cost-benefit, economic returns, attractiveness, potential benefit, feasibility and commercialisation potential, their own rigorous priority setting mechanisms better match their particular needs.

54. In conjunction with other research institutions, the universities, the private sector and the Cooperative Research Centres, CSIRO develop a 10-year master plan to identify high priority strategic research which is essential to the national interest. (paragraph 11.46)

Not agreed The Government has implemented policies and programs to encourage business and the research sector to take a longer term view when determining their research priorities. CSIRO already has a well established intensive planning process which involves external consultations and includes the preparation of five-year strategic plans, which are published. It is the Government's role to identify overall national goals and objectives. The Coordination Committee on Science and technology was tasked with examining national priorities for research in the 1992 White Paper on Science and Technology (see response to Recommendation 28 above).

26. The Government carefully monitor the level of economic, commercial and scientific representation within research funding agencies to ensure that an appropriate balance between these different forms of expertise is maintained. (paragraph 7.57)

Already established process The Government recognises the advantages of strong involvement of business and other end-users as well as the scientific community in public research decision-making. For example:
membership of the ARC and its Committees include appropriate representation from industry, Government agencies and universities;

the IR&D Board funds industrial research and will be considered more closely in the second JCPA report on Commonwealth Support for Private Sector Investment in R&D. Of the fourteen members, nine have an academic background in science or engineering, two work in manufacturing industries, seven in services industries (health, finance, law, information, engineering), two are public servants and one works in a medical research institution;

a key feature of the Primary Industries & Energy R&D Corporation model is that the Boards comprise persons with a broad range of management skills, production and scientific expertise. Under legislation the Boards are selected by independent selection committees with appropriate balance of expertise in as many of the following fields: production, processing and marketing; conservation and management of natural resources; science, technology and technology transfer; environmental and ecological matters; economics; R&D administration; finance and business management.;

the Cooperative Research Centres Committee includes members of the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council, senior representatives of industry and the Chairs of other Commonwealth grant giving bodies.
47. In the context of establishing national research priorities, the Government:

define the appropriate balance between the support provided for R & D by the private sector and that given by the Government for the applied, strategic and basic research necessary to advance the knowledge base of the nation and its long term economic welfare; and
ensure that this balance is reached and maintained. (paragraph 10.42)

Not agreed The Government recognises the need to advance the knowledge base of the nation and its long-term economic welfare through applied, strategic and basic research. By such decisions as determining the level of appropriation for research agencies and providing funding for higher education research, it seeks to ensure an appropriate level of public sector research for these purposes. The Government does not accept that there is an appropriate definable ratio between private and public sector R&D, and also notes that R&D balance differs on a sector by sector basis. The international experience is that levels of private sector R&D have generally increased at a faster rate than public sector R&D. The level of private sector R&D in Australia is still low by international standards and the Government has a range of measures in place to encourage its increase.

2. The Commonwealth and State Governments take action to implement the options for improving intergovernmental coordination suggested by the Australian Science & Technology Council in its report, Research and Technology: Future Directions. (paragraph 4.40)

Not agreed The ASTEC report concluded that `. . . insufficient cooperation and policy coordination between the Commonwealth Government and the State Governments is leading to national policies and programs which commonly do not adequately reflect important regional dimensions.' Options suggested by ASTEC and supported by the Committee as a means of rectifying the situation were for a Special Premiers' Conference to assist in the development of improved coordination; and for States to develop and provide adequate resources for State coordination arrangements.

Relevant research and technology issues of mutual concern to State/Territory and Federal Governments are coordinated by Ministerial Councils where appropriate. Internal State coordination arrangements are the responsibility of the relevant State Governments. Some established consultative mechanisms are noted in Table 1 below.
3. The Government give consideration to extending the membership of the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology to include high level state and territory representation. (paragraph 4.40)

Not agreed The Coordination Committee on Science & Technology (CCST) deals primarily with issues of concern to the Commonwealth. To the extent that it does address issues of interest to the States, the CCST consults fully with relevant State Departments and agencies. This was the case when the CCST prepared a report on research and development related to ecologically sustainable development.

Existing mechanisms to coordinate S&T policy matters between the Commonwealth and the States were raised in the Finance Minute (paragraphs 12-19). The most appropriate forum to coordinate general S&T matters between tiers of government is the Standing Committee of the AITC.

The Australian Industry and Technology Council (AITC) and other Ministerial Councils are the vehicle through which the different responsibilities and policy instruments of the Commonwealth and the States can be harmonised. The AITC includes all Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers directly responsible for industry and/or technology policy. Other relevant Councils include the Australian Education Council; the Environment, Transport, Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand; the Australia and New Zealand Fisheries and Aquaculture Council; the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council; and the Australia and New Zealand Minerals and Energy Council. The Council of Australian Governments announced its decision to halve the existing 45 Ministerial Councils to 21 in a Communique of June 1993. The reduction is to be carried out and the support structures reviewed by January 1994. At that time the AITC will be included in the new Industry, Technology and Regional Development Council; and some of the other relevant Councils noted above will combine functions.
ASTEC meets State counterparts twice yearly.
DITRD State offices maintain close links with State Departments on matters relating to industrial research and technology.
CSIRO consults extensively with relevant State Departments at an organisational level.

ANSTO has Memoranda of Understanding with the Western Australian and Queensland governments which provide for scientific and technological cooperation, and maintains close contacts with authorities in other states.

AIMS maintains close contact with the Queensland, and Western Australian State Government Departments, and liaises with the Northern Territory Department, Universities and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to keep its knowledge at the organisational level up to date.
2.2.1 Environment research

33. The Australian Bureau of Statistics regularly collect data on the nature and extent of private sector environmental research, and publish detailed breakdowns of publicly and privately performed environmental research. (paragraph 8.59)

Agreed The ABS currently produces statistics for public sector R&D classified by socio-economic objective (SEO) which separately identifies environmental R&D. The ABS trialled the use of SEO for classifying R&D in its 1991-92 Business Enterprise Survey. The trial was successful, and ABS has now incorporated the collection of this type of data in its regular R&D survey program.
30. The Government take action to redress the reduction in funding for long term basic research in taxonomy, entomology and soil science. (paragraph 8.27)

Alternate approach already in place In science agencies, including the CSIRO, the allocation of resources to particular fields is a management responsibility determined in accordance with the agency's priority setting plan taking account of the agency's objectives and its individual perception of the national interest.

Taxonomic, entomological and soil science research at higher education institutions is supported by research programs funded through the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the ARC, for which normal competitive evaluation procedures apply.

The Prime Minister announced an additional $3 million allocated to the Australian Biological Resources Study in his environment statement of December 1992, primarily for the identification of aquatic plants and animals.
29. Further steps be taken by the Government to finance and coordinate sufficient long term baseline research and monitoring to enable the assessment of environmental change. (paragraph 8.23)

Agreed in principle The Government recognises the need for strengthened and coordinated long-term baseline environmental research and monitoring of the kind represented by the Baseline Air Pollution Station at Cape Grim in Tasmania and the long-term sea level monitoring network. It has addressed some of these needs in the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development and the Prime Minister's Statement on the Environment.

The Cooperative Research Centre for the Antarctic and Southern Ocean is conducting research to characterise the oceanic and atmospheric circulations of the region, their relation to global environmental change and their relation to biological productivity. The Cooperative Research Centre for Southern Hemisphere Meteorology will investigate the mechanisms that control stratospheric ozone, especially in the Australian region, develop an improved model for long-term ozone modelling and assessment of the impact of stratospheric pollution, and investigate the effects of ozone depletion on climate change and vice-versa. As well, it will develop a new global transport model to study global atmospheric pollution and investigate Southern Hemisphere Climate Dynamics.

In adopting the National ESD Strategy the Government has undertaken to assess the need for additional scientific knowledge relevant to Australian conditions for environment protection policy development, implementation and monitoring. It will also consider ways to facilitate the collection and handling of data, public access to relevant scientific data, and evaluate user needs in relation to the many data acquisition activities in order to make data more accessible.

The Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency is establishing a system for data collection and national state of the environment reporting. Most States have developed, or are developing, the latter capacity and a working group of State and Commonwealth officials has met to coordinate activities relating to state of the environment reports. The need for a consistent and systematic approach is being addressed through the development of protocols by State and Commonwealth environment and natural resource agencies, such as ANZECC under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

However, establishment of such long-term networks suitable for assessment of environmental change is expensive and scientifically complex and will require substantial coordination between the disciplines, between Commonwealth agencies and between the Commonwealth and the States. A range of scientific institutions are collaborating in the development of baseline monitoring of climate, oceans and terrestrial ecosystems and their linkage into the Global Climate Observing System, the Global Ocean Observing System and the Global Terrestrial Observing System. These will be considered in due course in the context of overall government responses to the challenge of climate and environmental change.

A considerable amount of work is already undertaken on the long-term monitoring of climate change and its effects on the environment. For example, the work of CSIRO, the Bureau of Meteorology and the National Tidal Facility. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the CSIRO have developed a proposal to establish ALTERM, the Australian long-term research and monitoring network. Further action is dependent on funding availability.
31. The Government provide further support for the development and coordination of Commonwealth and national environmental research priorities. (paragraph 8.40)

Already established process Substantial resources have already been allocated to environmental research and to the ESD process. In adopting the National ESD Strategy, the Government's objectives are to establish communication channels between R&D advisers, funders, performers and users concerning ESD-related R&D activities; and to encourage existing public sector funders and performers to cooperate in the type of multi-disciplinary and inter-institutional R&D needed to address intersectoral ESD issues. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is facilitating this process.

The Government recognises the importance of achieving a coordinated national approach to environmental research but is also aware of the wide range of interests, disciplines and agencies involved as well as the difficulties in delineating the boundaries of environmental research. At the Commonwealth level, coordination of research occurs through a range of mechanisms, including liaison and advisory committees of CSIRO, the Primary Industries & Energy R&D corporations, the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology (CCST) and specialist bodies such as the Heads of Marine Agencies (HOMA).

The Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment, and the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development provide a partial foundation for addressing overall Commonwealth-State coordination, while sector-specific coordination is assisted by the various Ministerial Councils. The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories (DEST) will be further addressing the overall issue of the development and coordination of Commonwealth and national environmental research drawing on expertise in the CSIRO, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Australian Geological Survey Organisation, the Bureau of Meteorology and other major Commonwealth scientific organisations engaged in various aspects of environment research.

In the 1992-93 Budget, the Government announced a range of ESD/Greenhouse measures including funding for climate change research, work on energy efficiency, tax deductions for environmental protection measures, feral animal control, the establishment of the Forest and Wood Products R&D Corporation, funding to facilitate drought R&D, the development of the Environmental Resource Information Network, improvement in scientific knowledge to assist the maintenance of biological diversity, marine and coastal research, and a survey of old growth and wilderness values.

32. The Government support a research training program to ensure an adequate supply of highly qualified environmental researchers, in accordance with Recommendation 2 of ASTEC's report, Environmental Research in Australia: the Issues. (paragraph 8.44)

Not agreed Government funds institutions to provide higher education services. However, institutions offer training programs and courses in accordance with their perception of need and demand from their client groups, including potential students and employers.

34. The Government address the potential of user pays mechanisms in the area of environmental management in order to achieve a better allocation of public and private resources in the field of environmental research. (paragraph 8.62)

Under consideration The BIE and the Industry Commission have done work in this field. The difficulties in identifying and quantifying externalities should not be underestimated. Environment management charges to be met by commercial operators have been introduced in relation to the Great Barrier Reef, and this will provide a significant source of funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, inter-alia for environmental research through the Cooperative Research Centre for Ecologically Sustainable Development of the Great Barrier Reef. Commercial operators using a community asset will, on a user pays basis, contribute to research necessary to sustain this unique resource.
36. The Government review:
which particular rural industries should receive public R&D funding support on the basis of public good grounds; and
whether or not the levy mechanism is the most rational means of providing support where support is deemed necessary. (paragraph 8.91)
37. The efficiency and effectiveness of the organisational, administrative and funding arrangements of the R&D Corporations be reviewed on a regular basis. (paragraph 8.100)

Already established process All Government programs are reviewed on a regular basis and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy R&D Corporation model is subject to constant review and enhancement. Following a review of the industry levy arrangements in 1985, the objective was established of encouraging rural industries to increase their contribution to funding of R&D to 0.5% of the Gross Value of Production.

A comprehensive review of the arrangements in 1989 led to the Primary Industries & Energy R&D Corporation model being established to allow users to better direct the research. This model was reviewed in 1991-92 to determine the impact of corporatisation on the effectiveness and accountability of R&D. In the last Budget, the levies and matching arrangements were again reviewed and the existing arrangements continued.

The Australian National Audit Office is currently undertaking an examination of the administrative effectiveness of the Primary Industries R&D Corporations, their success in promoting industry participation in R&D activities, and the benefits to industry of the research they have funded. Terms of reference for an extensive inquiry into R&D by the Industry Commission have recently been finalised.

38. The Government take action: to identify the national needs for social science research, including the humanities research and research into the social impact of technology; to improve the coordination of social research; and to ensure the adequacy of funding for social research. (paragraph 8.111)

Established process in place Social science at higher education institutions is primarily funded through the Department of Employment, Education and Training's (DEET) research funding programs, including research grants, fellowships, postgraduate awards, research infrastructure grants and research centres. These programs are allocated on the advice of the Australian Research Council. In 1993, over $6 million will be provided in large research grants to higher education institutions to support projects in the social sciences. In addition, social sciences research is also supported through institutions' operating grants and through the Research Schools of Social Sciences and Pacific Studies at the Australian National University.

The Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services (HHLGCS) has also taken a number of actions relevant to this recommendation. These include identifying national needs for social science research, improving coordination of social research and ensuring the adequacy of such funding. These issues have been addressed in several ways:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services Research Development Grants.

SPEECH.PARA: The program aims to encourage applied research which is likely to make a practical contribution to the utilisation and development of community, housing and health services in Australia. In an attempt to identify national needs for research RADGAC conducts workshops to provide community participation in the establishment of research priorities.

In 1991 Health, Housing and Community Services reviewed non-biomedical research, and recommendations were made which included the need for a rationalisation and refocussing of research activities in the Department. Implementation of the recommendations is underway to improve research coordination and place the Department's research program onto a sounder strategic footing. Issues realised by the Report and the Implementation committee will be considered by the Departmental Research Advisory Committee in the first quarter of 1993.

HHLGCS has made considerable efforts to forge closer relationships with research centres such as the Australian Institution of Health and Welfare (AIHW) and the Social Policy Research Centre (SPRC). An example of the closer links is the provision of block funding to the SPRC at the University of NSW. The RADGAC program provides core funding to support social policy research of relevance to the portfolio. HHLGCS also expects that its direction will lead to the development of better relationships in the social policy research field.

ASTEC recently published a major study of the contribution of social sciences and humanities to national economic and social welfare including their contribution to science and technology. The Coordination Committee on Science and Technology (CCST) has undertaken to prepare a Government response to this study.
42. The Government foster the acceptance of an agreed definition of commercialisation. (paragraph 10.12)

43. The goals and objectives of major research organisations, which have received a government directive to generate a portion of their funding from non appropriation sources, include reference to commercialisation within their goals and objectives. (paragraph 10.26)
44. The commercialisation objectives of research organisations performing R&D be included in their management plans. (paragraph 10.28)

49. Research organisations assess the full costs of commercialisation and, when commercialising their research, ensure that a reasonable rate of return is obtained on the Government's investment. (paragraph 10.62)

50. Research organisations regularly review the systems and practices used to commercialise their research and give priority to introducing any improvements suggested by these reviews. (paragraph 10.66)
Agreed in principle The term `commercialisation' has a number of different meanings depending on the context in which it is used. Two common uses are:
Commercialisation as the appropriation of some of the value of the research results by licensing or sale of patent rights, or trading for equity, as in the case of Gene Shears Pty Ltd; and
Commercialisation in the wider industrial sense describes the processes involved in getting a new or improved product or process to the market, and generating economic benefits from the process.

More important is the clarification of the intended meaning in context where it is used—in legislation, guidelines, statistical surveys and other Government documents. As far as possible use of the term (in statistical collections particularly) should be in accordance with standard international definitions, but such definitions have yet to be adopted.

A definition for commercialisation may be developed as part of the continuing work of international experts in OECD countries to implement standard guidelines for collecting technological innovation data. Research results are considered to be `commercialised' when they diffuse into (Australian) industry and new products are manufactured or new processes employed. It may be more appropriate for agencies such as the CSIRO and DSTO to use a broader definition for commercialisation than that chosen by the Committee, to include advice provided by agency consultants and research under contract to external organisations.
If a common definition of commercialisation is needed for national and international R&D reporting purposes, this could be a sub-set of a broader definition better suited to research agency needs.

The Government intends to continue to encourage innovation and competitiveness on all fronts. To encourage commercialisation, the Government has focused on stimulating market demand. The different technologies, companies and industries interact in different ways and no universal optimum strategy for commercialisation exists. Government officials, researchers and companies are being encouraged to understand the process of innovation and the peculiarities of the particular companies and technologies involved. The Government has established the Australian Technology Group Pty Ltd (ATG), Pooled Development Funds, and changed the "prudent man" rule to catalyse private sector finance for research and technology.

The CSIRO corporate planning process assesses the ability of Australia to capture the benefits of research as commercial or other gains, aims to maximise involvement with the business community in Australia and internationally in identifying long-term strategic options, and to increase the investment by Australia's local and multinational companies in innovation.

There is a new position at CSIRO Head Office of Director of Corporate Business, responsible with other Directors for linking research planning to long-term industrial development and for designing and negotiating larger commercial contracts for CSIRO. CSIRO's preferred commercialisation approach is for industrial partners to become involved as early as possible in research projects, perhaps even before specific research has begun. Examples of major collaborative research agreements are those made with Boeing, BHP, CRA, Queensland Metals Corporation involving MIM and Ube of Japan.

AIMS's Act was amended in 1992 to enable it to pursue commercialisation objectives. A draft Business Plan and commercial capability statement has been prepared and AIMS is going ahead with proposals and is receiving some attention from industry. A recent scientific collaboration with scientists at the University of Rhode Island has resulted in a marketing and distribution arrangement for Australia and SE Asia for simulation software for the trajectory and fate of oil spills.

DSTO has identified commercialisation as an objective in its Corporate Planning Statement 1992-96. This objective is fulfilled by DSTO undertaking, on a commercial basis, the provision of consulting services, contract R&D, training, the hire of unique facilities, and the medium to long-term exploitation of DSTO's intellectual property through licensing of technologies to industry, collaborative research and development, and joint venture arrangements. Currently DSTO holds numerous patents, has arranged many manufacturing licences with industry and is involved in three incorporated joint ventures.

The Primary Industries and Energy R&D Corporations were established with the view to encourage increased funding towards the commercialisation end of the R&D spectrum, where this is shown to be a productive means of providing returns to their levy payers. The Corporations are able to borrow money, form corporations, enter into agreements and participate in joint ventures, take out patents, generate income from royalties and licences for successful R&D, and determine their own internal structures and processes.

A key objective of the Cooperative Research Centres Program is to capture the benefits of research and to strengthen the links between research and its commercialisation by the active involvement of research users in the work of the Centres. It is expected that all Centres with industrial applications will have strong participation by appropriate business enterprises. It is mandatory for all Centres to put in place firm strategies to manage the intellectual property they produce and to commercialise the results of their research to the benefit of Australia. The proportion of the forward commitment by CRC partners provided by industry has increased from 17% to 28% as the Program has developed.
45. Research organisations involved in commercialising their research:
consider the optimum profile of skill sets required in carrying the results of research from the laboratory to the market place; and
recruit and retain such skill sets. (paragraph 10.31)

Agreed in part The Government does not consider that the research agencies should necessarily commercialise research themselves. Rather, they should have the skills needed to tap into and/or initiate the commercialisation process which includes excellent links with companies and other users who have the necessary skills. Agencies should have access to such skills and a good understanding of the commercialisation process, but not necessarily `own' the skills. ATG, ATICCA companies, or private sector companies may provide these skills.

Departments and the research agencies regularly review their systems and practices. The Government notes that different technologies, companies and industries interact in different ways and that no universal optimal strategy for commercialisation exists. Government officials, researchers and companies are being encouraged to understand the process of innovation and the intricacies of the particular companies and technologies involved. A case in point is the CSIRO which is already training staff in-house on the processes of commercialisation of science and technology.
46. Research organisations involve commercial partners with resources to successfully commercialise the results of R&D at an early stage of the R&D. (paragraph 10.39)

Agreed A number of Government measures are aimed at facilitating this involvement. Major examples at CSIRO include the recent Memoranda of Understanding with BHP, Boeing and the Sydney Water Board. The 30% external funding requirement is also aimed at this.

The Cooperative Research Centres Program has as one of its four major objectives "to capture the benefits of research, and to strengthen the links between research and its commercial and other applications, by the active involvement of the users of the research (industry) in the work of the Centres".
48. The performance of the Australian Technology Group be monitored and consideration be given to utilising more effectively the expertise of the Industrial Research & Development Board.
(paragraph 10.59)

Agreed The Australian technology Group (ATG) has been established as a technology commercialisation corporation to contribute to the translation of Australian research into products and services which can be delivered to the Australian and international markets on a totally commercial basis. The Government will be receiving regular reports from the ATG on the company's activities and operations. This is addition to the statutory financial reports the ATG is required to provide under corporations law.

With regard to utilising the expertise of the IR&D Board, the ATG Board and management have been establishing links with interested expert groups and various Australian sources of technology. In developing its business strategy it will be open to the ATG Board to decide on a commercial basis the extent to which it accesses the client base of the IR&D Board to grant recipients or utilises external experts, such as members of the IR&D Board, to evaluate research and technology for commercialisation.
39. The recent organisational and funding changes to Commonwealth research agencies be allowed to stabilise before any further major changes are considered by Government. (paragraph 9.13)
Established principle It is Government policy to introduce all major changes at an achievable pace.

40. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training urgently consult with the Australian Education Council, the Centre for Research Policy and other relevant bodies as to the most appropriate means of increasing the supply of dedicated research management training in Australia. (paragraph 9.21)

Not agreed Decisions regarding the courses offered by higher education institutions are made by the institutions themselves. The government does however recognise the need for improved research management capability at higher education institutions, and institutions are now required to provide research management plans as part of the annual profiles process.
Recent initiatives include:

the UTS and University of Sydney are establishing the Australian Graduate School of Engineering Innovation (AGSEI) in April. It aims to bring technology closer to management and marketing with an overall focus on wealth creation; and
the Macquarie University Bachelor of Technology and Postgraduate Diploma in Technology Management which started in 1990.
5.1 CSIRO
52. The Government give high priority to increasing the funding for CSIRO's longer term strategic research. (paragraph 11.46)

Considered as part of the Budget process The Government provides CSIRO with a high degree of autonomy in meeting broad community objectives. Decisions on the most appropriate balance between long and short-term research are made by CSIRO in the context of the needs of particular industries and the opportunities the research presents.
53. The funding period for decision making be extended beyond the present three-year funding mechanism. (paragraph 11.46)

Under review The Forward Estimates process adds to the certainty of planning for all agencies by providing a four year timeframe—Budget plus three outyears. This funding, while not guaranteed, nevertheless gives a reasonable indication of likely allocations over that period in respect of current policy. The triennium arrangement for the science agencies provides additional security.

The Government has agreed to defer consideration of triennium funding for the science agencies, pending decisions on nuclear science and technology arrangements and marine science research. The Government anticipates making a decision on triennium funding not later than the end of 1993.

Under the CRC Program applicants may identify the most appropriate length of the funding period for their proposals and, in practice, the great majority of Centres are operating under a seven year funding regime, subject to appropriate reporting and review mechanisms.
55. The Auditor-General follow up the audit of CSIRO's generation of funds from external sources. (paragraph 11.50)
Agreed in principle The Auditor-General is responding directly to the Chair of the JCPA.
57. CSIRO assess the need to rationalise its location at 108 sites and 150 laboratories in terms of the economical, efficient and effective utilisation of its resources (paragraph 11.65)

Agreed CSIRO is acting in accord with this recommendation. Following an extensive workshop in July 1992 in which it reviewed the progress of CSIRO, the CSIRO Board suggested that the Organisation should continue to be active in "seeking opportunities both to reduce costs and to improve flexibility, such as through further site rationalisations (not necessarily centralisation) and from streamlining provision of site services". CSIRO is strongly committed to further developing its major sites in Canberra, at Clayton and North Ryde and to rationalise elsewhere to the extent that is compatible with research and collaboration needs. In doing so, it has to respond to very strong pressures upon it to open new sites, a recent example being the recommendation by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works to locate the CSIRO Division of Food Processing at Wagga Wagga.
58. CSIRO develop a longer term capital replacement program in the light of the assessment (paragraph 11.65)

Agreed CSIRO is committed to maintaining its capital infrastructure, has developed a long term capital replacement program and is acting to link this more closely with forecasts of the demands of its evolving research priorities.
59. Future annual reports of CSIRO provide information regarding rationalisation studies and the implementation of the 10 to 20 year building and refurbishment program (paragraph 11.65)
Agreed CSIRO is acting on this recommendation.

60. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation review and update the policies and procedures which define the strategic and corporate planning process and the fit between its own planning and the Defence Five Year Plan (paragraph 12.17)
Agreed This is already being put into effect.
61. The plans be updated on a yearly basis in the light of both performance against timed targets within those plans and factors external and internal to the organisation (paragraph 12.17)
Agreed Revised procedures will be implemented in the 1993-94 financial year. The essential features of the revised process are:
the provision, on an annual basis, of a Defence Science and Technology Strategy, providing essential top down guidance to DSTO for long-term planning of its research program;
the introduction of a Client Program structure (for planning, reporting, reviewing and evaluating the program) with four Defence client segments, and a fifth commercial segment; and
the introduction of a planning cycle, which involves face-to-face interaction with the senior clients in an Annual Planning Meeting to shape the future R&D program.
62. Adequate capital funding be provided for the accommodation and equipment needs of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (paragraph 12.28)

Agreed in principle DSTO's operating efficiency is being hampered by existing facilities and equipment needs. DSTO Salisbury has developed costed options to consolidate its activities into new, refurbished and recently built accommodation on part of its present site. Such consolidation would achieve a very substantial reduction in site operating costs and would also provide gains in research output.
However, funding must be considered in the light of overall Defence priorities and Government expenditure priorities.
63. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation establish a mechanism whereby it can effectively establish its funding needs and attach priorities to these needs (paragraph 12.33)

64. The Department of Defence monitor the adequacy of the funds allocated to the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in relation to its capacity to maintain its technological base and provide additional funds when they are needed (paragraph 12.33)

Agreed in principle Implementation of these recommendations is closely allied to the current restructuring of DSTO's planning procedures mentioned above. See responses to Recommendations 61 and 62 above.
65. The level of funding provided for the commercialisation of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation's research be monitored (paragraph 12.46)

Agreed However, the JCPA report identifies only two strands to DSTO's approach to commercialisation—transfer of technology to the private sector so that Australian firms can supply goods required by the Defence Forces, and making DSTO research available for the commercial production of non-defence related products. This is too narrow a view. A significant amount of the interest shown by commercial enterprises in DSTO research is in research which has the potential to result in products for world defence and commercial markets. To a large degree this is the factor which can make manufacture in Australia cost-effective, by providing for manufacturing sustainability and economies of scale. Overseas sales are often critical to the success of commercialisation as local volumes are too small.

With regard to technology transfer from DSTO, the mechanisms referred to (Defence funded contracts for the early stages of R&D, and support or adaptation of locally manufactured equipment throughout its life cycle) are only two of many successful mechanisms used by DSTO. Other mechanisms are: staff training and programs, industry contracted R&D expertise, facilitation of outside development of DSTO technologies through Technical Support Service contracts, the Defence Industry Development program, direct provision of technical data, licensing, joint venture development and scientific presentations. DSTO is trialing an Industry Support Office to increase industry awareness of commercialisation opportunities arising from DSTO research and development.
DSTO's commercial activities are not concerned solely with "commercialising" existing inventions, but with exploiting its overall R&D capability for the national benefit.

The JCPA noted that the 1% limit reflected the level of effort Defence is prepared to divert to supporting the commercial exploitation of DSTO's R&D capability. However, as a result of the November 1992 review of industry policy conducted for the Parliamentary Secretary, the 1% limit on net diversion of appropriated resources to commercial activity will be removed, and DSTO will increase its formation and use of strategic alliances with Australian industry. These changes are supported by the findings of the Australian National Audit Office's review of DSTO's commercial activity. It is intended that DSTO will manage these changes without detriment to its ability to meet Defence R&D requirements.

As a result of their commercial activities, Business Development Units have developed considerable expertise in managing and protecting intellectual property, which is of significant value to DSTO's mainstream activities for the Department.
66. This funding be adjusted, in the light of cost-benefit analyses, to maximise the income from the Defence Science and Technology Organisation's commercial activities (paragraph 12.46)

Not agreed The Government does not accept this recommendation. Maximising the income from DSTO's commercial activities may not provide the best results in terms of national benefit. National benefit, rather than income maximisation, should be the key criterion in determining priorities for commercial activity. The programs must respond to strategic and national goals. For example, maximum income from a licence might be achieved by selling it to a foreign company, but the national interest might be better achieved by selling at a lower price to an Australian company, thus providing employment, export income and industry infrastructure growth.

67. The Department of Defence, the Department of Finance and any other organisations, that are identified as delaying the commercialisation of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation's research, review their procedures with a view to streamlining them (paragraph 12.50)

Agreed The Government accepts this recommendation. However, it notes that the current arrangements for the commercialisation of DSTO research are conducted within existing guidelines and legislative requirements. Specifically, the Government, in determining its response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements (1989), decided that the Minister for Finance and the Attorney-General be consulted in advance on any proposals to establish or vary a direct Commonwealth interest in a company. Nonetheless, Finance is willing to review any proposal to streamline administrative procedures that may assist in the satisfactory resolution of DSTO commercialisation proposals

68. An independent review be carried out of the adequacy of the funds available to employ individuals with the best available skills for negotiating, establishing and managing the commercialisation arrangements of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (paragraph 12.54)

Not agreed This recommendation is not accepted as the situation has to be balanced against DSTO's prime customer requirements. It is not clear that an independent review (assuming this means external to Defence) would be able to comprehend all the issues. With regard to employing individuals "with the best available skills", DSTO recognises the importance of this but believes that such skills are best obtained externally by contracts or consultancies.
DSTO routinely assesses the industrial capability of its innovations.

69. The Defence Science and Technology Organisation identify those areas where its expertise coincides with Australian industrial capability and defence requirements, and concentrate on these areas by:
setting up an industry advisory group to devise industry development strategies for the Organisation's expertise; and
forming long term alliances with companies (paragraph 12.57)
Agreed The Government agrees with the recommendation and announced the establishment of a DSTO Industry Support Office in the 1992 White Paper on Science and Technology.
70. Priority be given to making funds available for the establishment of the Industry Support Office at the Aeronautic Research Laboratory (para 12.64)

Agreed DSTO's Aeronautical Research Laboratory's Business Development Unit is now being trialled as an Industry Support Office (ISO), which is a distinct, commercially oriented entity designated to manage all of ARL's business activities. The ISO concept will be trialled until October 1993 with funding of $1.5m derived from the DSTO Commercial Activities Account and, if successful, consideration will be given to extending the ISO structure to other DSTO laboratories.
71. Publicly available reports of the work of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation be produced annually (paragraph 12.67)
Agreed The Department of Defence will act upon this recommendation.

72. Increased funding be provided to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation to enable it to upgrade its facilities and purchase new equipment, particularly a new reactor. (paragraph 13.27)

Under review In 1992, the Government established the Research Reactor Review to examine and report on the need for a new research reactor. The Review has produced its first report and has recommended that no decision need be taken on a new reactor for at least five years. The Government is considering this and the other recommendations of the Review.

73. The nuclear reactors and associated plant belonging to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation be reviewed regularly by an appropriate, independent, overseas organisation. (paragraph 13.36)

Not agreed The safety of ANSTO's nuclear plant is monitored and reviewed continually and closely by the Nuclear Safety Bureau (NSB), whose operations are monitored by the Safety Review Committee, which has found that the NSB carries out its responsibilities thoroughly and professionally. The recent amendments to the ANSTO Act have provided increased independence from the NSB. ANSTO commissioned a review of its Nuclear Technology Program in 1990 by Atomic Energy of Canada Limited. This review considered operational procedures and objectives of the program, and was not focused on nuclear safety. The review recommended many improvements in practices and procedures, which have been acted on by ANSTO.
74. The Government ensure that sufficient resources are provided for R&D on radioactive waste management and its commercialisation. (paragraph 13.44)

Already done The Commonwealth Government has spent over $25 million on the development of Synroc by ANSTO. Synroc is a highly stable wasteform for the immobilisation of high level radioactive wastes produced by the nuclear fuel cycle overseas. Further development of the technology now requires a country generating high level radioactive wastes to adopt Synroc as its preferred technology for high level radioactive waste disposal on a commercial basis. ANSTO would then be well placed as Australia's expert on Synroc technology to contribute to the international application of Synroc.
75. The Commonwealth take urgent action to select a site for and construct a safe and secure nuclear waste repository. (paragraph 13.48)

Agreed ANSTO is playing a significant role in assisting the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to identify the most appropriate site for a national repository for low level radioactive waste and is expected to be involved in a safety assessment of a prospective site. The technology for the disposal of Australia's low level radioactive wastes at a national radioactive waste repository has been developed and ANSTO operates facilities for the conditioning of radioactive waste prior to its transport to, and disposal in, a national radioactive waste repository.

In paragraph 13.45 of the report the Committee states that the "potential threat to the community from having radioactive waste stored in built up areas needs to be urgently addressed and prompt action taken". While some current temporary storage in urban areas is not ideal, the wastes remain under control of Commonwealth or State Government authorities and do not present an appreciable hazard to local communities. The only way of dealing effectively with these concerns is by removal of wastes for disposal at a national repository located well away from major population centres.

The Safety Review Committee (SRC) has recommended each year that action be taken as a matter of priority to identify a site for, and construct, a national radioactive waste management repository. The SRC reviewed ANSTO's waste management practices in detail (1991) and found that they are sound, and safe for members of the public. Nonetheless, there is still considerable public concern. The National Resource Information Centre (NRIC) is assisting in the process of identifying a suitable site for a national low-level radioactive waste repository.
76. The Government coordinate arrangements with State and Territory Governments for improved annual reporting of radioactive waste holdings to a central authority. (paragraph 13.53)

Existing arrangements are adequate State and Territory Governments already provide details of the radioactive waste holdings on a voluntary basis to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy which has portfolio responsibility within the Commonwealth Government for radioactive waste management. This information is given to assist the Commonwealth in its coordinating role to establish a national radioactive waste repository by providing information on the likely capacity requirements for the repository. The Commonwealth will provide approximately 90% of the radioactive waste for the repository, and Commonwealth waste holdings are well documented. Existing reporting arrangements for State/Territory holdings are considered adequate. However this is a matter that could be considered by the Nuclear Regulation and Monitoring Inter-Departmental Committee in its report to Government.
77. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce scrutinise the effectiveness of the existing mechanisms for providing advice on funding and research priorities for marine R&D (para 14.26)

78. Bearing in mind the recommendation of the McKinnon Review that an Australian Maritime Industries and Sciences Council be established, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce consider whether new mechanisms are required to provide advice on funding and research priorities (para 14.25)

Under review In the Government's response to the McKinnon Review it decided not to proceed with the formation of the Australian Marine Industries and Science Council (AMSIC) but rather to make more effective use of existing mechanisms. As such, the Heads of Marine Agencies group (HOMA) was asked by Government to provide appropriate advice to ensure that important areas of marine R&D of national benefits and/or commercial opportunity are funded, directly or in liaison with NBEET, ARC, FIRDC, the IR&D Board, ERDC, CSIRO or other appropriate bodies.

At the request of the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology (CCST), HOMA has undertaken a major review of the state of publicly funded marine research in Australia. The study examined current funding levels and the extent and effectiveness of existing coordination mechanisms. The study was presented to the CCST in July 1993.

Since the report was prepared the Government has considered a proposal by the Minister for Science and Small Business to establish a new National Institute for Marine Science, to be formed by the amalgamation of the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the CSIRO Divisions of Fisheries and Oceanography. The proposal has been referred to Professor Ken McKinnon who has been asked to conduct a process of consultation and independent review.

79. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Heads of Marine Agencies develop effective processes to identify ways in which Australia's research capability in marine sciences and technology can be used, disseminated and marketed overseas, especially among semi-tropical nations (para 14.30)

Already in place A number of mechanisms for marketing Australian expertise in marine sciences and technology are already in place. In 1989 the Australian Marine Science and Technology Project Office was established with the aim of marketing the expertise of the Commonwealth marine research agencies to these areas. The Government allocated $250,000 seed money in the 1989 Science and Technology Statement and INTROMARC (International Tropical Marine Resources Centre) based in Townsville, was established in 1991 with the role of promoting the use of Australian expertise in tropical marine ecosystems and in training in this area.
Other action the Government is taking includes work done by the Office of Northern Development and the ASTEC Review into research in tropical Australia.

81. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce consider other ways, such as levies on the tourist industry, to finance research relating to environmental management and protection (paragraph 14.43)

Already in place Where opportunities arise, levies or fees are regarded as options to raise funds for management, of which research may be an aspect. For example, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service collects park use fees for all of its mainland national parks ie Kakadu, Uluru and Jervis Bay. Under a formula determined by the Department of Finance, funds collected are used for a variety of park management related activities or returned to consolidated revenue. Further, in June 1992 the Government announced that tourist operators using the Great Barrier Reef are required to pay a fee from 1 July 1993 as a contribution to management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. A major proportion of this levy will be directed to funding relevant environmental research within the Cooperative Research Centre for Ecologically Sustainable Development of the Great Barrier Reef.

82. Additional funds be provided to the Australian Institute of Marine Science for research staff salaries and the purchase and maintenance of equipment to ensure that it remains a research centre of world class. (paragraph 14.49)

Not agreed Budget allocations for AIMS have increased on a regular basis from $5.2 million in 1981-82 to $16.9 million in 1993-94. In addition, further funds have been provided by Government for special uses. These include: $1.32 million, over three years, for the reef monitoring program in the 1991-92 Budget and, in the 1992-93 Budget, funding of $4.73 million over three years for the establishment of an AIMS facility in north-west Australia and $1.5 million as part of the Government's science agencies infrastructure program.

Furthermore, recent changes to the Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972 will allow AIMS to become involved in more commercially oriented activities based on the exploitation of the results of its research into marine science & technology. This will enhance AIMS' existing ability to generate external funds, thereby making available significant new sources of funding over and above current Government appropriations. Government research organisations, including AIMS, are allowed to retain 100% of earnings so generated.
See also response to Recommendation 9 (page 2).
83. The Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1987 be amended to allow the Minister to request advice from the OSS about any mining operation in Australia. (paragraph 15.28)
84. Commonwealth and State Ministers discuss the best use of the expertise of the OSS in relation to Australian mining operations. (paragraph 15.28)

85. The Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1987 be amended to allow the OSS to undertake research in the general field of environmental monitoring and management, including contracting to carry out research or provide advice for other bodies. (paragraph 15.32).
86. All mining companies operating in the Alligator Rivers Region that benefit from the work of the Office of the Supervising Scientist be levied to help support that work. (paragraph 15.38)
87. Where substantial information is made available to other mining concerns, a charge should be made. (paragraph 15.38)
88. Funds be provided for the construction of permanent laboratory accommodation at Jabiru. (paragraph 15.43)

Already in hand The Ministers for Environment, Sport and Territories, and Primary Industries and Energy presented a joint submission assessing the adequacy of the Commonwealth's approach to uranium mining regulation in the Northern Territory. The submission took into account the recommendations of the JCPA, the Taylor Review of the OSS and the Industry Commission Report on Mining and Minerals Processing in Australia.

The OSS and its research arm, the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute (ARRRI) will be subsumed into the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. A number of changes relating to the roles, functions and administrative arrangements for the OSS will be introduced, including the decision that ARRRI will be able to undertake contract research of up to 30% of the Commonwealth contribution to ARRRI research.
