TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technology on Pay Television and Videotex Services. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator The Hon Bob Collins
Minister for Transport and Communications
25 November 1993

The third report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies was tabled in Parliament on 23 June 1992. The report fulfilled the Committee's initial terms of reference relating to pay television and the standards for content of videotex services.

Recommendations 1 and 2 were considered by the Senate during the debate on the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 and the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Act 1992. Many amendments were made to reach a final position.

Recommendation 1: That x-rated material should not be considered suitable for screening on pay television, whether provided as subscription television broadcasting services or as subscription television narrowcasting services, and regardless of the means of delivery being either telecommunications or radiocommunications technologies.

This recommendation has already been implemented through legislation for subscription television broadcasting services. Narrowcasters will need to address this matter when they develop their codes of practice.

Under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, subscription television broadcasting licensees will not broadcast a program that has been refused classification, or has been classified `X' by the Office of Film and Literature Classification (Schedule 2, 10(1)(f)).

A prohibition on X-rated material has not been placed on subscription television narrowcasting services. Subscription television narrowcasting services are to develop, in consultation with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) and taking account of any relevant research conducted by the ABA, codes of practice.
The codes of practice may relate to:
preventing the broadcasting of programs that, in accordance with community standards, are not suitable to be broadcast; and,
methods of classifying programs that reflect community standards.
In developing these codes of practice, community attitudes to the following matters are to be taken into account:
the portrayal in programs of physical and psychological violence;
the portrayal in programs of sexual conduct and nudity;
the use in programs of offensive language;
the portrayal in programs of the use of drugs, including alcohol and tobacco; and

the portrayal in programs of matter that is likely to incite or perpetuate hatred against, or vilifies, any person or group on the basis of ethnicity, nationality, race, gender, sexual preference, age, religion, or physical or mental disability.
The codes of practice may also relate to methods of ensuring that protection of children from exposure to program material which may be harmful to them is a high priority.

The ABA is to maintain a Register of the codes and this register is to be open for public inspection. If the codes of practice fail, the ABA has the power to determine program standards. The ABA will, before determining, varying or revoking a standard, seek public comment on the proposed standard, variation or revocation.

Recommendation 2: That the Australian Broadcasting Authority conduct extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television, on what levels of violence and depictions of sex should be allowed, and what other matters should be included for viewing by adults and children in the various classifications.
This recommendation has already been implemented through legislation.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 provides that subscription television broadcasting licensees are to ensure that access to programs classified as `R' by the Office of Film and Literature Classification is restricted by disabling devices acceptable to the ABA. It also provides that `R' classified programs will not be broadcast:
until the ABA has completed extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency; and
the ABA has recommended, and the Parliament has, by resolution of each House approved, the broadcast of such programs (Schedule 2, s.10(1)(g)).

PARA.TAB: This position was reached in the Senate after numerous amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: For programs such as news, sport and documentaries, under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 all broadcasting service providers must develop codes of practice that take account of matters including sexual conduct, nudity and psychological violence. The codes are to be developed in consultation with the ABA and take account of any relevant research conducted by the ABA.

The ABA is to maintain a Register of the codes and this register is to be open for public inspection. If the codes of practice fail, the ABA has the power to determine program standards. The ABA will, before determining, varying or revoking a standard, seek public comment on the proposed standard, variation or revocation.

Recommendation 3: That, in view of the inconclusive evidence received by the Committee during its inquiry, standards for programs on pay television should be the same as those currently set by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for free-to-air television, until the results of the research recommended by the Committee in Recommendation 2 become available.
Recommendation 3, has largely been put into effect through the ban on `R' material on Pay TV pending the results of ABA research.

Under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 codes of practice may relate to preventing the broadcasting of programs that in accordance with community standards, are not suitable to be broadcast; to methods of ensuring that the protection of children from exposure to program material which may be harmful to them is a high priority; and to methods of classifying programs that reflect community standards.

Under the Act, subscription television broadcasting licensees will not broadcast a program that has been classified as `X' by the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OLFC). The licensee is to ensure that access to programs classified as `R' by the OLFC is restricted by disabling devices acceptable to the ABA, broadcasting `R' material only after the ABA has completed extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency regarding violence and sex, and after the ABA has approved their broadcast.

Under the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Act 1992, the ABA may impose a licence condition on subscription television broadcasting licensees designed to ensure compliance with the film classification system administered by the OLFC.
Pay TV will be subject to the common classification system of `G', `PGR', `M', `MA and `R' which will be administered by the OLFC.
Recommendation 4: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for videotex services, including closed user access videotex services, the following:

PARA.TAB: The provider of any videotex service will not provide knowingly or negligently information which in any way may be interpreted as equivalent either to the X or R film/video classification, or to the Category 2 classification for literature.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was accepted in principle by Telstra. As previously advised to the Committee, Telstra does not now provide videotex services of the type which would cause this code of conduct to be taken into consideration.

Recommendation 5: That AOTC and other telecommunications service carriers enter into a contract with the Office of Film and Literature Classification for it to act as the monitoring and enforcing body for the code of conduct for videotex services.
This recommendation was accepted in principle by Telstra.
The Committee has made a valuable contribution and has thoroughly investigated a difficult area where there are many community views.
In conclusion I thank the Committee for a comprehensive report on a difficult subject.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1992-93 annual report of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission will be the second last report of this body set up in 1991 to take over the $2.7 billion debt of the AWC, the $4.6 million stockpile of the AWC and the warehouse and other properties held by that body. The main task of the AWRC was to discharge the debt in accordance with a specified seven-year repayment program.

PARA.TAB: During the next two years of the operation, the market conditions changed significantly. The AWRC operated within its legislative requirements and I commend the role of Bob Richardson in this regard. His job has not been easy. As a woolgrower, I admit that we all have the capacity to shoot the messenger, especially in circumstances that have been as depressing as they have been for the current wool market.

When the AWRC was set up, there was substantial agreement that the stockpile be transparently reduced. Bob Richardson was determined to re-establish the respectability of an industry that had been seriously wounded by government policy. It was not the stockpile that was breaking the industry; it was the debt. The AWRC had a set repayment requirement. These targets were initially met. But, as it is clearly known now, the repayments schedule became unsustainable.

The 1992-93 season, which this AWRC report comments on, saw a further major deterioration in the wool market. The annual target was again changed and the government responded further by setting up the Garnaut committee which laid down a regime for the future. Garnaut's proposals have passed through the parliament and have set down an entirely new infrastructure for the management and sale of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission's stockpile. After 1 July 1994, the stockpile and the debt will be inherited by the new statutory body that will ultimately be privatised. On the balance of probabilities, woolgrowers will have equity in that body.

The AWRC will soon cease to exist as it has outlived its reason for existence. Wool International will sell the stockpile by a fixed reduction regime, not a fixed debt repayment schedule as is presently the case. It will treat the stockpile as an asset and one which most reflects the circumstances that will apply when the stockpile no longer exists.

I hope that the AWRC shows great responsibility in its operations between now and 30 June next year. I urge it not to sell one bale of wool more than it is obliged to. The most important thing for the future of the industry is a recovery in price. This will happen earlier if a limited amount of wool comes out of the stockpile between now and 30 June 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to use the five minutes that I am allowed under Standing Orders to refer to some of the matters contained in this report. A couple of sitting weeks ago, I raised with the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins—the minister responsible for AMSA—the question of AMSA's purchase of a replacement ship for the Cape Moreton at a cost of nearly $20 million. Senator Collins did his usual bellowing, claiming that this was best offer available, that the authority had done the right thing and everything was beyond reproach and beyond question. He still maintains that view and did so at the estimates committee hearings.

PARA.TAB: Since then we have found a bit more information. I look to this report to see whether I can get any more information on how the authority went about purchasing a $20 million ship overseas without putting it out to tender in Australia. It is my understanding that in 1992 the cabinet issued guidelines for purchases by government business enterprises. AMSA was listed as one of those government business enterprises that ought to follow these guidelines on the manner in which such purchases should be handled. At this stage it is my view that the guidelines have not been appropriately followed.

This is a $20 million purchase that Australian industry was not effectively given the chance to compete for. In response to that allegation, AMSA says, `Look, we were never going to buy a ship; we were just looking for a charter. We were roaming the world looking for a ship to charter, and what do you know? A cheap bargain came up'. It is like going to the supermarket for chops and coming home with pea soup. AMSA spotted these bankrupt hulls—I think that is what they are called—and thought, `They are cheap, so we will buy them'. And they were cheap; there is no dispute about that. AMSA came back and asked the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services and it basically said, `They might be cheap but you should give Australian industry, and Australian workers, a chance to compete for this work'.

Instead of putting it out to tender, what happened? The chief executive officer hopped on a plane, whizzed around and in a matter of days had verbal consultations with four shipping companies—and, as I understand it, another company said that it could have made the ship—all of whom said that they could do it, although some said that they could not do it within the time required. One said that it could do it for $20 million to $25 million, slightly less than the average that Senator Collins referred to.

I then turn to the financial statements and see that $2.6 million was spent on redundancy payments because the authority has chosen to decommission the ship that it had. Presumably, that means the 100 or so crew—or at least a big portion of them for $2.6 million in redundancy payments—have gone off to do something else while we wait for this other ship to come from Spain. So, if the firm that said it could do it for $20 million to $25 million had been able to do it for $20 million, that could be compared with the cost of the Spanish option, which you could day has gone up to $22 million, because there might not have been redundancies.

But the real point to make is that this report does not detail adequately the manner in which that purchase was made. AMSA did not originally intend to buy a ship. It badly miscalculated what the purchase price of a ship would be in Australia. I can hardly believe that Senator West is asleep listening to this; I am not that boring. If, instead of doing a quick ring around at the last minute to say, `Listen guys, could you do this at this price by this time?', AMSA had started the ball rolling in September the year before and done what it should have and issued tenders and given Australian industry a chance to compete, a few more Australian workers in the shipbuilding industry might now have a job. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to draw attention to some aspects of the operations of the Federal Airports Corporation, not necessarily those aspects for which the Federal Airports Corporation is best known; namely, the provision of the facility at airports for aircraft to take off and land in safety and to get people on and off them in some degree of comfort, I presume. I would like to concentrate on the activities of the Federal Airports Corporation which have been arrived at through the priority that the government has given to changing its philosophy from one of providing a service to one of meeting its own costs and conducting itself in a corporate style.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this particular change in philosophy has resulted in an aggressive attitude in all aspects of the Federal Airports Corporation's activities. Some might say that it is an admirable thing for an organisation such as this to cover its costs, but I believe that it has led to some anomalies which have had an effect which was not intended. Under the heading `Commercial' on page 11, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A priority was the development of commercial strategies designed to capitalise on opportunities . . .

The capitalisation on opportunities to which I refer relates to the operation of off-airport car hire operators—people who conduct their business of renting cars to travellers in a town or a city located near the airport. This business is typically one whereby tourist based packages are offered to people and arrangements are entered into so that a person hires a car and, upon arrival at an airport, takes delivery of that car, under a contract which has been arrived at previously.

PARA.TAB: The FAC has decided that this is an opportunity for it to make a buck, because people are arriving at an airport looking for the enterprise that they have entered into an agreement with. We have all seen the usual thing that happens at an airport; we are either coming down the escalator or reaching the baggage area and we see an operator of a hire car business standing there with somebody's name on a piece of paper, or perhaps a personal identification. The client meets the operator and is directed to a car.

The FAC is seizing this opportunity to intervene to rake off a dollar. I suggest that, if some people think that is all right, the logical extension of such an attitude is that the FAC will see the opportunity to apply that philosophy to taxi and limousine drivers, tour buses—one can imagine pensioners on a Women's Weekly tour being asked to pay $2 to the FAC before they are allowed to get on the bus—or journalists. Why not take it to the full extent? Any journalist who wants to conduct an interview with a politician or a person arriving would have to pay the FAC a buck on the way through.

A number of business transactions take place at airports. A number of meetings of people who engage in business off-site also take place at airports. If every person who had business with another person and met that person at an airport was asked to pay a rake-off to the FAC, I suggest that we would label that as protection money or a mafia-style operation. That is the extent to which the legitimate operators of car hire businesses throughout Australia are being subjected to victimisation because it is their unfortunate position to have to meet their clients at an airport. I suggest that it is time we looked at it in a proper regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This annual report, which is actually two volumes, was only made available today and I have not had time to go through it completely. Of particular interest to me is the report on the managing of OGIA—the Office of Government Information and Advertising—which comes under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services. OGIA was associated with the marketing of the disability reform package. The marketing of this package took place under the auspices of the Office of Government Information and Advertising in conjunction with three other departments.

PARA.TAB: It took some time for me to extract the information about the letting of a contract to promote the disability reform package because the Office of Government Information and Advertising was chairing the meeting that was associated with the committee that was supervising the promotion of this program with the three other departments. When I extracted information from the committees that were looking into administrative services, social security, health, housing and local government and DEET, I was able to discover that some problems were associated with the letting of this contract.

A series of names of large advertising agencies were put forward as suggested possibilities to be approached to submit tenders on a selective tender basis. There was a request for more names of organisations or businesses that could look at a more innovative rather than a mass-advertising approach. Two names were put forward. One of those names came from a list that OGIA had of people who had put their names forward who may at some stage be approached to undertake government projects.

It transpired that no checks were undertaken of the financial capabilities of the company that finally got the contract. I am not talking about a small contract; I am talking about a contract of $4.95 million of taxpayers' money. If OGIA or the committee responsible for letting the contract had carefully checked the records—in fact, the last annual return to the Australian Securities Commission—of that company, it would have been revealed that the company was trading at a loss, that its liabilities exceeded its assets, and that it possibly, or probably, was balance sheet insolvent.

It was in the estimates committee that we discovered what had happened. Senator Loosley tells us that estimates committees are a waste of time. I think one of the things this demonstrates is that pursuing an issue puts departments on notice that they need to be much more accountable for the way in which they spend taxpayers' money. This contract was let to this company. We were told that two checks had been done. One check was to a department in New South Wales for which the company had undertaken a contract. The other check involved one other department. So there were two checks, but the proper checks were not undertaken.

One of the problems that has occurred is that the company went into liquidation in July of this year, which has resulted in a number of unspecified creditors. Some of those creditors are people with disabilities. It is sad and ironical that the program was designed to promote the employment of people with disabilities, and it appears that there are people with disabilities who are owed money.

It is also contended that the Commonwealth has no financial responsibility to the unsecured creditors, yet letterhead was being used by this company and by the Commonwealth that appeared the same—the same logo on the top, different addresses, obviously—and sometimes the employees of the company were working out of Commonwealth offices. So some people who undertook work for the company believed it was under the umbrella of the Commonwealth.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Australian Electoral Commission is very large and very detailed. It points out, generally, the very good work that the commission does. It particularly makes reference to the good work that the Australian Electoral Commission did in assisting with elections in countries where Australia had an obligation under United Nations arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I am, however, concerned at one aspect of the Australian Electoral Commission's work relating to its investigation into some irregularities which were reported concerning the election in the federal seat of Leichhardt, in Far North Queensland, at the last election. There were a number of allegations made on oath and supported by statutory declarations which were submitted to the returning officer at Cairns about irregularities in the seat of Leichhardt. Honourable senators will be aware of some of these allegations which I have mentioned previously.

There was an allegation that on 15 occasions the scrutineers reported that voters were placing blank ballot papers in the ballot boxes, yet when these were counted in Cairns later there were no blank ballots—suggesting that someone had interfered with them. It was alleged that ballot boxes were not sealed and were opened during the day to retrieve mistakenly placed absentee votes. There were reports of returning officers' assistants seen picking up blank ballot papers off the floor, filling them in and placing them in the ballot box. There were reports about Labor Party scrutineers and officials having undue influence. There were reports about ALP how-to-vote cards being left on officials' tables—not in the voting compartment—and referred to by officials.

These complaints were pointed out to the returning officer in Leichhardt and supported by declarations. The Australian electoral officer for Queensland said that he investigated these reports. He came to the conclusion that there was no substance in the complaints and he said he was not going to proceed further. In his letter to the people who had complained, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I should say that the allegations made against the polling officials have been rejected by them. Regrettably, when opposing statements are made in such circumstances as existed in this case and there is no independent evidence, it is difficult to reach absolute conclusions.

I was concerned at just what investigations were conducted by the Australian electoral officer. To my mind, the people who complained and swore statutory declarations were not consulted by any officer of the AEC. It seems that all the electoral officer did was ring the people about whom these complaints had been made and say to them, `Did you do that?'. Naturally enough, because criminal offences were involved, they said, `No, we didn't do it'. So he has found that there has been no substance in the allegation. In this letter reporting back, he also said:

On the question of objectivity or bias, I believe that your scrutineers have not taken sufficient account of cultural sensitivities which affect the manner in which some electors in these areas might request assistance in casting their vote.

I do not know quite what that means. Either we have rules on how to vote or we do not have rules. I cannot understand how cultural sensitivities—whatever that means—can be taken into account in determining one set of rules for some people and a different set of rules for other people.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, my time is brief so I cannot continue, except to say that I urge the Electoral Commission to take action, as suggested and recommended by the Liberal Party in its submission to the joint standing committee, in particular in relation to the recommendation that the AEC retain suitable supervisors not drawn from or associated with a particular local area. I urge the AEC to consider that recommendation and the other recommendations made by the Liberal Party. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Order! The time allocated for the consideration of government documents has expired. All those senators who sought and obtained leave to continue their remarks are reminded that that opportunity will be given at a later hour this day.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present letters from persons referred to in proceedings of Estimates Committee F in response to matters raised in the committee. With the concurrence of the Senate, the letters will be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: We act for Dr LEK Kim Sroun, a Cambodian boat person currently held in detention at Westbridge Detention Centre near Sydney. In accordance with resolution 5 of the Resolutions on Parliamentary Privilege agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988, we are instructed to write to you in respect of certain remarks made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs concerning our client in the course of the Minister's evidence before the Senate Estimates Committee on 12 November 1993.
Hansard records the following exchange between Senator Bolkus and Senator Short on that day (page F210):

PARA.TAB: "Senator Short: . . . I am referring to the Wilcox judgement that Dr Lek should pay two-thirds of the minister's legal costs.

Senator Bolkus: It is not Dr Lek; it is Sister Lek. Dr Lek is the title that has been given to this person by those who are helping him to try to fabricate a perception in the minds of people in the media and others.
Senator Short: So you do not think he is a doctor?
Senator Bolkus: No. He is a nurse.
Senator Short: I will call him what everyone else seems to have been calling him, which is Dr Lek.
Senator Bolkus: If you want to be conned as well, that is fair enough".

INTERJECT.PARA: The Minister's remarks cast a dark shadow over Dr Lek's reputation and credibility.

We are instructed that in fact Dr Lek is a qualified medical practitioner in Cambodia. We attach a copy of a certificate dated 2 January 1990 issued by the National Medical Academy of Cambodia, certifying that Dr Lek graduated with Honours as a Doctor of Medicine. The certificate omits Dr Lek's surname. We are instructed that this is because Dr Lek chose not to use his surname at the Academy because of his fears of persecution by the Vietnamese backed Hun Sen Government then in power.

Dr Lek graduated on 19 October 1989 and his graduation certificate was issued on 2 January 1990. Prior to commencing his full-time medical studies at the National Medical Academy in 1983, Dr Lek was an assistant nurse at the Rathgany Hospital in Cambodia. This information, together with a copy of his graduation certificate as a medical doctor, was provided to the Department shortly after his arrival in Australia in March 1990 in support of his refugee application.

Dr Lek, who has taken a leading and public role in the representative proceedings in the Federal Court, is puzzled by the Minister's motives in raising at this stage the authenticity of his medical qualifications. Since 10 May 1990, when Dr Lek lodged his claim for refugee status, he has consistently described his profession as doctor. The authenticity of his medical qualifications have, to our knowledge, never been disputed by officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, responsible for processing and determining Dr Lek's application for refugee status.

An appeal has been lodged on behalf of Dr Lek to the Full Court of the Federal Court against Justice Wilcox's decision dated 8 October 1993 holding that the refusal by the Minister's delegate to grant Dr Lek's application for refugee status was flawed in law. Should those appeal proceedings be successful, the likely outcome is that the Minister or his delegate would have to reconsider Dr Lek's application for refugee status. In those circumstances, the Minister's remarks as quoted above could reasonably be expected to be highly prejudicial to a future assessment of Dr Lek's claim for refugee status given that those remarks directly and unambiguously impugn the validity of his medical qualifications and his general credibility.

The Minister's remarks are also highly damaging to Dr Lek's reputation and prejudice attempts by him to persuade the Australian Government to allow him and other Cambodian boat people to remain in Australia on humanitarian grounds.
We request on behalf of Dr Lek that this matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges in accordance with resolution 5.

TAB.EMPHASIS: For technical reasons, the certificate could not be reproduced.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senate Estimates Committee F—Proceedings on 12 November 1993
I refer to Hansard for the proceedings of the Senate Estimates Committee F on 12 November 1993.

In that hearing I was referred to by name in circumstances which adversely affect my professional reputation. Senator Bolkus at Senate Hansard F211, 212 made the following statements, allegations and imputations relating to me:

PARA.TAB: Australian taxpayers are funding fruitless litigation on behalf of Dr Lek and other Cambodian refugees. This is not correct. Neither I personally nor the firm of which I am a partner have received any funding in respect of the litigation in which I am acting for Dr Lek and other Cambodian boat people. My firm is acting pro bono publico in the litigation, as are other law firms representing Cambodian boat people in separate litigation.

That I and other lawyers are pursuing fruitless court cases. This is also incorrect. In the very proceedings to which Senator Bolkus refers involving Dr Lek as the representative, the appellants were successful in establishing that, contrary to the previous Minister's position, the Minister had the power under the Migration Act to consider allowing the Cambodians to stay on humanitarian grounds. In addition, 3 of the 48 individuals in those representative proceedings were successful in establishing that the Minister's delegates had committed errors of law and the Court ordered that their claims for refugee status be reconsidered.

Furthermore, on the same day that Senator Bolkus made these remarks about lawyers pursuing "fruitless court cases", Justice Keely delivered judgment in Melbourne Federal Court proceedings involving a Cambodian boat person who arrived on the same boat as Dr Lek. His Honour set aside the decision of the Minister's delegate in that case, having found that the decision refusing refugee status was wrong in law on numerous grounds, some of which should apply to other Cambodian boat people. Justice Keely ordered that the refugee status application be reconsidered.

It would, of course, be wrong of the Minister to prejudge the possible outcome of any such reconsideration resulting from successful judicial review proceedings and I assume that he was not purporting to do so in suggesting that the court cases are "fruitless".

That I had failed to keep in mind the interests of my clients and the broader Australian community in "kicking off and pursuing fruitless court cases". For the reasons set out in relation to the preceding point, this is also incorrect. In addition, as an experienced and responsible legal practitioner, I am very conscious of the interests of my clients and always seek to further them in a reasonable and proper way.

That Cambodian refugees "are basically entrapped by the legal advice that is provided to them", with the imputation that this legal advice is inadequate, in that it induces Cambodian refugees to pursue litigation without full knowledge of the likely or possible outcomes. This is incorrect as I have taken care to ensure that my clients are fully aware of the likely consequences of particular courses of action, and they exercise their independent judgment in their instructions to me.

That Cambodian refugees have had a "bondage" imposed on them by "Dr Griffiths and others" and do not appreciate the alternatives available to them. This is also incorrect. The Cambodian refugees for whom I act have at all times been aware of the alternatives available to them. As mature adults they are well able to make their own considered decisions on matters affecting them and their dependents.

INTERJECT.PARA: In accordance with resolution 5 of the Resolutions on parliamentary Privilege agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988, could you please refer this submission to the Committee of Privileges for its consideration.
I refer to your letters of 17 and 18 November 1993 concerning remarks made about Dr Lek Kim Sroun and you in proceedings of Estimates Committee F.

The procedure for referring matters to the Privileges Committee under Resolution 5 of the Senate's Privilege Resolutions applies only to remarks made about persons in the Senate, and does not apply to proceedings in committees. There is another provision in the Privilege Resolutions requiring committees to provide an opportunity to respond for persons who have been adversely referred to in committee proceedings. This is the normal procedure by which persons adversely referred to in committee proceedings seek to respond.

Estimates committees, however, meet only during the consideration of the annual and additional appropriation bills, and they have concluded their deliberations for this year. I therefore propose to table your letters in the Senate and seek the concurrence of the Senate to their incorporation in the Senate Hansard. I trust that this will be satisfactory to Dr Lek and to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 14, 1993-94, Efficiency Audit, Growth, Change and Equity, Recurrent Funding of Higher Education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week in this place I spoke to the annual report of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and drew to the attention of the Senate a number of the shortcomings of DEET in relation to the way it is managing the higher education process in this country. I spoke about the deficiencies of the open learning system, deficiencies in quality assurance, deficiencies in how it is managing research in this country and deficiencies in the way it is managing its own financial affairs. The Auditor-General in the last three years has heavily qualified his report into DEET.

PARA.TAB: The report we have before us today reveals a number of other glaring anomalies in the way in which DEET manages the university sector. We have in this report particular mention of the profiles process which would have to be one of the greatest wastes of universities' time and money developed in this country. Under `Key Points' in the report it is stated that research and evaluation of higher education issues could be better focused and managed properly, that institutions should be encouraged to allocate resources to facilitate their best use, and that universities should be able to identify and pursue national priorities better. In addition, it is stated that the transfer of school leavers to higher education should be better targeted.

Basically, the report is being fairly polite about a process which DEET is managing fairly poorly. It is particularly bad news for the universities. With profiling, which is one of the main subjects targeted in this report, the universities are actually getting the worst of both worlds. They have to spend an enormous amount of time and effort in putting the material together for the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Yet, as this report reveals, when DEET gets hold of this material, it does not use it very effectively. As a matter of fact, it does not feed back to the universities vital information that is needed for their growth and development. Indeed, a number of the universities have stated to me that the whole process has wasted a considerable amount of the time of senior staff and a considerable amount of money. All the information that goes in could be useful if it is fed back to them in some form that they can use for guidance.

In many universities, this is not the case. The paperwork goes into this great bureaucratic bin, the department does not process it and the universities receive no feedback. So, as I say, they have the worst of both worlds. If profiling is going to be done, it should be done properly and information fed back. Otherwise, the universities should be left alone to get on with what they are supposed to do best, which is teaching and research. They say that it should be better focused.

It is amazing, given the amount of intrusion, that DEET is not more effective in directing and guiding the universities. One would have thought that one of the things that would come out of the profile process at an early stage would be the fact that there is an increasing emphasis on postgraduate enrolment to the detriment of undergraduate enrolment. This is a trend that has been going on for many years, yet DEET has suddenly discovered the problem and suddenly tried to pull the universities up with a halt by saying, `Well, we will cut down the number of postgraduate students by pushing up fees'—as a matter of fact it is proposing to double them in one year—` and we will put a sudden brake on the expansion that has been going on for several years and that will then free up places in undergraduate education'.

DEET has been undertaking this profile process for quite a number of years so why has it not identified the problem earlier and why has it not used it for guidance at an earlier point in time. I think the particular example I just used shows the failure of profiling. In the case of the University of Melbourne, 1.6 kilograms of profiled documents were sent in to DEET, yet the university was not given the guidance that it needed.

The Auditor-General's report has once again revealed the shortcomings of this department and I would urge it to stop being so intrusive in the university process, to give the universities back the freedom that they originally had and to leave the locus of decision making and the development of the universities in their teaching and research functions to the people who know best how to run these institutions—and that is not the bureaucrats in Canberra who sit there with these huge lumps of paper, effectively do not do anything with them, put up the costs of the university and slow down the whole process of development in higher education.

I would hope that this year the department does take notice of this report and does try to increase its effectiveness, as the Auditor-General indicates, but does it in a way that means the whole process is decentralised and not run from a central, remote bureaucracy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act, on behalf of the President I present the annual report of the Joint House Department for the year ended 1992-93.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint House Department has come under some scrutiny in the last couple of weeks in relation to the preferences of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that have been expressed as to how the Joint House Department should expend some of its money or, should I say, some of the taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: This report covers 1992-93 and therefore presumably, since we have only just been able to get a copy of it, will not make reference to this matter. What I would hope it does make reference to are some sorts of guidelines that Joint House could use as to when it can say to a prime minister, `Look, we do not care what your preference is. The matters relating to Joint House are matters for us to decide. We will decide them according to the guidelines we have got' and not come under some sort of executive pressure to purchase things, whatever they be—artworks, furniture or whatever—that suit a prime minister.

The particular case which I have some knowledge of, but not complete knowledge of, is the preference of the Prime Minister to have the cabinet room redecorated and an indication that he would prefer to have some Gould prints—and not just some Gould prints, but some particular ones. Taxpayers' money has purchased more than 3,000 artworks for this building's art bank—none of them were suitable, of course, except, I think, one. Such is the preference of this Prime Minister in this difficult economic climate that none of those artworks was good enough; he had an idea of what he wanted and he ended up getting it.

With the department's probably quite proper policy that artworks on paper need to be rested for a certain period, instead of needing only eight prints to decorate the cabinet room, the department needed 16, and through one of its own bungles it ended up purchasing one more than it needed. So now we have 17 Gould prints, only eight of which will be hung up at any particular time.

TALK.START.PARA: —To go with the galahs in the cabinet room.

—As my colleague Senator Patterson says, eight Gould bird prints to go with the galahs in the cabinet room—and she is not far wrong in making that remark. Preference was not just expressed for which prints ought to be purchased. This is why I am worried about the need for some guidelines that will help Joint House to be in a position to be able to say to a prime minister—any prime minister; sooner rather than later I hope a Liberal prime minister—`Look, we don't care what your taste in art is, whether you like these empire clocks, whether you know how to say "nouveau riche" or you have to say "novo reech" or whatever; we don't care what your preferences and tastes are or your false class-inverted snobbery, we're not going to buy anything unless we think it's appropriate'. Joint House should not be subject to prime ministerial preference.
—What a statement!

—I happen to think the statement is true. One of Senator Murphy's colleagues interjected the other day asking why I did not speak much in this place. I think if we all spoke a little bit less and only on the things that we had a particular interest in, instead of babbling on to just fill up the time we have, we might do a better job. This is a matter that I have a particular interest in. I do not waste the time of this place repeating speeches that other people have made all over the place.
—Except for quorums.

—There is the senator who did it. I intend to speak on this. If those opposite want to keep interjecting, that is fine, they can keep interjecting. It will simply mean I will take a bit longer to say what I want to say. I am quite happy to have repartee in debate across the chamber because I am not worried about the time—I am here until 5 o'clock anyway; I am on duty—but if those opposite want me to get through quicker, they might like to zip up.

PARA.TAB: Prime ministerial preference was expressed, and there we have it—17 Gould prints at a cost of about $66,000. I do not know whether we know this yet, but what I would like to know—and I think members of the public and members of the art world who are interested in the preservation of Gould's works, would be very interested to know—is whether, as a consequence of taxpayers' money being available, and it was readily available because the Prime Minister had indicated what he wanted, any Gould collections that were still in book form were, in effect, ripped up in order to provide one of the requested works.

These plates were not lying around individually; these prints were not done to be individual prints. They were originally done and produced as fabulous books on birds, in this case, and I think there are others on animals. They are intended to be kept together as a collection. What art lovers have done is disaggregate some of these things. There has been a reluctance by collectors to break up books of the so-called better works—those often identified as being the ones with more colour and strength.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a private sale they were disaggregated. As a matter of fact, they were disaggregated some time ago.

—I will come to that. If one were a collector and had one of these books, and knew that someone really wanted one of the plates in it and that government/taxpayers' money was behind it, one might be inclined to break up the book. I particularly would like to know whether prime ministerial preference with $66,000 worth of taxpayers' money on these prints has not only occasioned us to buy 17 of them, but also whether, as a consequence, any of the books have been disaggregated—whether one more of these whole collections has been busted up on the whim of the Prime Minister. That is what I would really like to know.

PARA.TAB: It went further than the $66,000. The Prime Minister expressed a preference for what sort of frames these prints ought to have. This guy is not just happy to have what it is that he wants on the walls; he wants a particular type of frame around those prints. So he is not happy with the artwork he wants; he wants the frame that he wants as well. As I recall, more than $13,000 was spent in purchasing handmade frames. Let us not be the working man's framer here; let us go for handmade gilt frames for the cabinet room—never mind the expense, it is only the taxpayers who are paying, not you and I out of our private money, this is taxpayers' money.

Then we come to the famous mount board around the outside. The Prime Minister apparently is not happy to have a plain cardboard mount—lots of people have these—oh no, he wants a French line and wash put on them. For those who do not understand what that means, it is an additional band of colour on the inside of the mount board primarily from water colours, but it does not matter which type of paint. There might be one or two additional bands of colour, bordered with specific lines to define where those extra bands of colour go—black might be used; frequently gold is used. It is called a French line and wash.

I happened to make a remark in the estimates committee with respect to having spent over three and a half thousand dollars on 17 bits of cardboard with a bit of paint on them. Some poor little personas opposite got a bit upset and tried to misrepresent that I was, in fact, talking about the Gould prints. They obviously did not realise that, before I came into this place, I had a print and framing business and I have some idea about this.

I am quite interested in the visual arts. I purchased for myself a Brian Westwood quite recently, and the only thing that nearly stopped me buying it was that he had done a portrait of this Prime Minister. Had I known that what this Prime Minister was going to do would perhaps result in some Australian Gould collections being disaggregated to suit his preferences, I might have said to the person who was offering me the Brian Westwood painting, `You can stick it, because he has got something to do with this Prime Minister who has a preference for treating himself—'

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the one you bought?
—The Brian Westwood?
—Was it the Prime Minister?
—No, I certainly would not have bought a Brian Westwood of the Prime Minister—most certainly not. No, it was one of the jockeys series with Bart Cummings's colours, a very nice painting.
—An original, Senator?
—This is a painting. Do you understand these things? This is a painting.
—Yes, I do understand.
—`Is it original?' You do not have non-original paintings.
—There is a difference between an original and a print of Gould.
—With respect, I think because I have—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I wonder if I could remind the chamber that we are referring to the Joint House annual report and get everybody back to the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and I am hoping to absolutely underscore the need for Joint House to have guidelines—I hope they have in this report and, if not, I hope they will have in the next one—as to how it can avoid being sucked into wasting all this money. I am using this as a example of a huge waste of money. I do not say that the Goulds are a waste in the sense that they are not worth it; I think we paid way over market price. Nonetheless, I believe that in these hard economic times Joint House should not have been pushed by this Prime Minister and that we should have some guidelines to save it being pushed into making this type of idiotic purchase. It should not be spending three and a half thousand dollars on 17 bits of cardboard with a bit of paint on them to decorate a cabinet room for the Prime Minister's preferences. This purchase is an absolute national disgrace.

PARA.TAB: What is more disgraceful to me, being a South Australian, is what came off the cabinet walls. Guess what came off the cabinet walls and what was not good enough for this Prime Minister?—a couple of John Olsen prints. Let me explain something for the edification of Senator Crowley. Senator Crowley obviously does not have a strong interest in the visual arts because she does not understand the difference between a painting and a print. She is confused about the terminology `print', which is commonly used to describe the reproduction of a painting, and the terminology used by those more informed who, when referring to a `print', are referring to a lithograph, etching, silk-screen, linocut or whatever. When I said that something is a painting, Senator Crowley interjected, `Is it an original?'. That clearly demonstrates her lack of understanding of what a painting is. I hope that I have elucidated some of the information for her in that respect.

One might say, `Well, so what? You are just a parochial South Australian. John Olsen is not that hot stuff. So why would you expect that to be on the cabinet wall?'. I would expect them to be on the cabinet walls because John Olsen received one of these Keatings; that is, one of the arts grants of $65,000 a year for five years that were originally intended to encourage artists. It was assumed that these grants would go to the younger and middle-aged artists. I have no doubt as to Olsen's capacity at all; I am making no criticism of him in that respect.

I would have thought that the Joint House Department, in the conduct of its duties in selecting John Olsen's works, would have selected artworks from an artist that this government has decided is of such importance that he is worth some $300,000-odd of taxpayers' money. Despite the fact that the government has decided he is worth that much, guess what? The prints do not suit the Prime Minister's taste. The works of a very good South Australian artist have been taken off the walls in the cabinet room. Let us not pretend, as Senator Crowley is trying to do, that it was simply because they had to be rested.

The situation is that this Prime Minister has a dislike of things royal and mimics those people who are monarchists—there is quite a degree of division in the community as to whether we ought to remain a constitutional monarchy or become a republic. He ridicules all these people. I am coming to the point, Mr Acting Deputy President, because I can see what you are going to say.

The Prime Minister treats himself as the king, the emperor and the royal family of this place. The king or the emperor says to the Joint House Department, `Don't worry about how you're meant to allocate your money; don't worry about parliamentary scrutiny. Listen: I want some Gould prints and I want to indicate the ones I want. I do not just want them framed but I want to indicate the frames I want. I do not just want them mounted but I want to indicate the mounts I want'. The cost will be $85,000 to $90,000—some people have said $100,000. There was a bit of fussiness about the lighting in the cabinet room for which the taxpayers had spent a lot of money. All of the lighting had to be taken out and a whole lot of new stuff put in over each of the spaces where these prints will go. Why? Because the Prime Minister expressed a preference that each print should be individually lit.

When those opposite go out and walk past a CES or a Department of Social Security office and see people looking for a job, and wonder whether this country has got enough money to fund the services it ought to, they should just reflect on spending $100,000 worth of these people's money—my money, your money, taxpayers' money—on a prime ministerial preference; on prints that could have been put somewhere where the public could see them. But, no, this is for the galahs in the cabinet. There is to be very limited access to this artwork at a cost of $100,000.

I want to make two points. First, the Joint House Department should not be subject to prime ministerial preference. It is a disgrace. We have to find a way to stop this. Whoever is Prime Minister should not be able to walk around here like the emperor of heaven knows where announcing what he would like all over the place and have the Joint House Department go along with it. That is a disgrace; it should be fixed.

Secondly, if John Olsen is good enough to get one of the Keatings—although there seems to be some doubt about how one does get these in at least one case—surely he should be good enough to grace the walls of the cabinet. He is a very good South Australian artist of which South Australia is very proud. I am very sad that those lithographs, or prints in any event—that is, original prints for the edification of Senator Crowley—have been taken off the cabinet walls. I look forward to the next annual report detailing this sorry saga and detailing a way that has been devised to stop it happening again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some interest to what Senator Vanstone had to say about the 1992-93 annual report of the Joint House Department. In fact, she spent all her time talking about an event that has happened in 1993-94. This obviously shows some tolerance on behalf of the chamber to listen to her speech, but we understand that flexibility.

PARA.TAB: I do have some sympathy for any person who stands in this place and talks about the usage of taxpayers' money, because generally the money is very hard earned. None of us enjoys paying taxes. After that hard earned money has been gathered by the Treasury, we do not like to see it being wasted. Assertions have been made about the purchase of certain prints. I have heard some of the arguments on that. I admit that art is not one of my strong points. I very rarely stand in this place and talk about artworks.
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Kemp became a member of this place, I stood in this chamber and made comments about the purchase of Blue Poles, which was mentioned earlier today by way of interjection. I suggested then that I was a philistine in this area and, despite recently becoming a grandfather, which does not help matters, I still am. I became a grandfather on Monday. Earlier this afternoon, I heard my granddaughter cry for the first time as my son was bathing her in hospital.

PARA.TAB: I thought Blue Poles ought to be sold because it was a waste of money. If people are willing to pay $10 million, $12 million or $15 million for prints like that, let us get the money from them and have the works taken out of the gallery. Let us put that money to the use of all Australians right around the country. I think far too much has been centralised here in the national capital. The people in the rest of Australia do not get to see these wonderful prints that taxpayers' money has been invested in. I am talking about taxpayers' money in the sense of Blue Poles, not in the current sense.

Let me refer to the recent purchase of Gould prints for the cabinet room. As I say, I do not profess to be an expert in this area of the art world. But I have heard in the debate and through interjections here today that the funds for the purchase of these works of art actually came from the profits of the bookshop. They did not come from the taxpayer; they did not come out of consolidated revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you think—

—We will have to wait until the annual report is tabled here next year to find out. When that report is tabled, I hope that Senator Vanstone will put the same scrutiny on it. I hope that she will rise in this place and admit her error. I hope that she will acknowledge that the money which purchased the Gould prints came from the bookshop. That is what I have been told.
—I agree with you. You are right. It is just taxpayers' money. That's all.

—I return to my opening comments about the usage of taxpayers' money. It is taxpayers' money that is being used by one of Senator Vanstone's colleagues belting around Australia, flying first-class all over the country, promoting herself and undermining her leader. If Senator Vanstone wants to be consistent on the usage of taxpayers' money, she should stand up immediately after I have finished and condemn her colleague in the same way as she has attempted to condemn the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and members of the cabinet. I challenge Senator Vanstone and also Senator Kemp to do that.

PARA.TAB: The good senator has gone on the public record as saying how much has been spent in a given period of time last year. But she is not doing it for the benefit of taxpayers. Senator Vanstone knows that; I know that. Our respective parties have suffered the problems of leadership challenges and the undermining of leaderships. But at least when it happened in our party—bitter though it was—there was no abuse of the taxpayers' money going on to the same degree and for the length of time that it has been going on now. For consistency in defending the usage and alleged abuse of taxpayers' money, Senator Vanstone should get up immediately when I finish my speech—or one of her colleagues should—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you condemn the Prime Minister?

—I have said that I will wait and hold my peace on that one until I see the report. I am talking about something that is happening at the moment, not only in the abuse of taxpayers' money but also in the undermining of the honourable senator's parliamentary leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on a preliminary examination of all aspects of the validation of care aggregated module and standard aggregated module funding of nursing homes.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This reference was referred to us on 30 September. We had a reporting date of 1 December, and we have come in before time. The reference of this matter arose from complaints that had been made to the department, the Ombudsman and to some members of parliament and senators. In looking at this reference, we received four submissions plus other correspondence and we have held six private meetings.

PARA.TAB: It is important to realise when looking at nursing home areas that several inquiries and studies in the early 1980s, including one by a Senate select committee, indicated that there were serious problems both with the care provided to some nursing home residents and with the costs involved with the program and the infrastructure. While costs varied between the states, there was little incentive to be efficient and there were opportunities for inflated expenditure and fraudulent practices. Reports also found that the standard of care in some instances was low, with consequent effects on the wellbeing of residents. Several changes have been introduced into the residential care program, including hostel care, since 1986, with the aim of improving the quality of care and lifestyle of residents and ensuring effective accountability.

As I say, we had four submissions and some other correspondence. It has come to our attention that a number of organisations and individuals are actually involved in following up these complaints. A number have gone to the Ombudsman and have been investigated there, and I understand that there more are going to him. I understand also—it is believed by us, anyway—that some of the problems identified may also be handled by the Australian Federal Police. It is possible that the Australian National Audit Office may wish to examine, as part of its work on the aged care program, the validation aspects of this as part of its report. That the committee would certainly welcome.

The committee reports that it will maintain a watching brief on all validation matters referred to it and will report again to the Senate during the last week of the first sittings in 1994. The committee accepts that the validation process is a crucial part of the restructuring of nursing home funding and is not prepared to recommend that the process itself be interrupted while these investigations, or those of other bodies, are carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report before the Senate is the preliminary report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs into the validation of what has come to be known as CAM and SAM funding of nursing homes. Honourable senators will recall that this reference resulted from the Senate agreeing to my motion on 30 September. During the Senate debate on this motion I pointed out that the coalition was not questioning the appropriateness of conducting validations of public funding of nursing homes. As I said at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: However, every nursing home proprietor must have an undeniable right to a timely validation that is prospectively applied in accordance with a consistently defined and interpreted set of guidelines by validation teams acting in a professional manner.

Although the terms of reference for the preliminary inquiry include five subparagraphs, this sentence neatly sums up the underlying objective of the Senate's reference. In its preliminary report, the committee concludes that the validation process is a crucial part of the restructuring of nursing home funding and that it is not prepared to recommend its interruption while investigations are being carried out. The coalition agrees with this conclusion. I contend that the interruption of the validation process would be more likely to exacerbate some of the problems that have been raised with me and the committee, particularly those relating to timeliness and the prospective application of funding criteria.

PARA.TAB: The committee concludes that it will, `maintain a watching brief on all validation matters referred to it and will report again to the Senate during the last week of the first sittings in 1994'. This means, I presume, that the committee intends to make a further report in April 1994. Given the relatively short time frame the committee has had to conduct the preliminary inquiry and the range of issues that are entailed in this reference, this is a sensible recommendation. My reading of it—and I would very much like to be corrected if it is an inaccurate reading—is that it allows those who wish to express concerns about the validation process to do so during the period up until the first period of sitting, or April of 1994. I hope Senator West or another committee member will be able to enlighten me.

As the committee indicates in its report, recent legislative amendments are closely related to the validation process. The mode of consideration outlined in the committee's report will allow it to take account of the impact of relevant legislation that is currently before the parliament. It is also worth pointing out that the Ombudsman is currently conducting an investigation as a result of receiving a number of complaints about nursing home validations. In addition, and as is indicated in the report, the Audit Office has also indicated that it may wish to consider validations in its audit of the aged care program.

In its preliminary report, the committee has made what it describes as preliminary comments about a number of issues relating to the specific terms of reference given to it. It is recognised in the preface to these preliminary comments that, `currently available evidence is often incomplete'. While the committee does not recommend a more detailed inquiry overall, it does, in relation to a number of issues that are referred to in its preliminary comments, state that it may wish to consider a number of matters in more detail. Rather than take the Senate's time with the detail of these preliminary comments, I urge those who are interested in this preliminary report to be become acquainted with them.

However, it does need to be pointed out that the committee has seen fit to make one specific recommendation in this report. It has recommended that the documentation required for the substantiation of CAM and SAM funding in respect of periods when the nursing home was owned by another person be made available. This is an important recommendation which demands a response from the government.

A number of nursing home proprietors and their industry representatives have expressed concerns to me about the impact of the National Health Act secrecy provisions on verifying the accuracy of decisions made by the department. To an extent this problem emanates from the department's tardiness in validating expenditure from 1986-87 onwards. However, it must also be recognised that the legislative amendments initiated in 1992 and in 1993 will do much to overcome this problem. In the meantime it is important that the rights to natural justice of proprietors are not unnecessarily fettered by the secrecy provisions.

In conclusion, I wish to take this opportunity to thank the members of the committee and the staff of the committee for their efforts in relation to this preliminary inquiry. I urge the industry to continue to express its concerns in relation to nursing home validation to the Senate committee during the five months until April 1994. Finally, I urge the committee to ensure that it communicates its preliminary conclusions to the aged care industry and, in particular, the fact that it will maintain a watching brief on the matters referred to it and report during the last week of the first sittings in 1994.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following three reports of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities: The Role of Audit Committees in Corporate Governance, a progress report; Trading of Shares in Jupiter's Limited; and Committee Exchange with the New Zealand Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: I was going to make a short statement, but in the interests of time—I would have loved to have got involved in that other debate on the lithographs to correct a few incorrect statements—I seek leave to incorporate three short statements in Hansard in relation to those reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Role of Audit Committees in Corporate Governance

PARA.TAB: The Committee's report to the Parliament on this matter arises from a Committee decision to inquire into the current role of audit committees in Australian corporate governance in late 1992.

The Committee initiated discussion on audit committees by publishing and circulating a discussion paper late in 1992 to organisations and individuals who the Committee considered would be interested in the subject; particularly the accounting and auditing professions.

As the Committee reports, its preliminary inquiries into the role of audit committees were greatly assisted—as is the case for the introduction of audit committees to all public companies—by the Arthur Anderson/Institute of Company Directors 1992 survey of all Australian listed companies. The Committee has annexed the executive summary of this excellent and important survey to its report; I recommend it to all interested in this important area.

The Committee notes that the Australian Stock Exchange's exposure draft on current listing rules which was circulated during late 1992 raised the question of making the existence of audit committees a condition of listing on the exchange. The ASX advised the Committee that this question is currently being pursued in discussions with the Attorney-General.
The Committee, as the report notes, will assess whether it will re-open its inquiry on audit committees in Australian public companies in 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: Trading of Shares in Jupiter's Limited

PARA.TAB: The Committee's report to the Parliament on this matter results from a reference to the Committee from the Senate in November 1992; a reference made on the motion of Senator Spindler.

The Committee's report notes that the Committee sought and obtained detailed advice from the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange, the bodies which are responsible for ensuring proper and honest trading of shares on the Australian securities market.

As the Committee reports, and having considered the submissions from both the ASC and the ASX, the Committee considers there is no grounds for it to make further inquiry into the matter; a conclusion unanimously agreed to by all members of the Committee.

A final point can be made about this matter. The Committee's inquiry demonstrates that market monitoring and surveillance systems set up by the ASX—and the ASC—can be used to ensure movements in the trading of securities which may be sensitive to extra-market considerations, are detected.

SPEECH.PARA: Committee Exchange with the New Zealand Parliament

This report deals with the visit of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities to New Zealand in July this year. The Committee was invited to travel to New Zealand by the New Zealand Parliament as a part of the program of regular committee exchanges between the two countries. The overall aim of the visit was to discuss the harmonisation of law between the countries, with a particular focus on corporations law.

The Committee was hosted by the New Zealand Parliament's Justice and Law Reform Select Committee and Commerce Select Committee. The Committee also took the opportunity to meet with government agencies business organisations.

The discussions we held in New Zealand were very valuable. New Zealand has taken a much different approach to Australia in reforming its company law and in some ways has made more progress than Australia. I was particularly impressed by the commitment to a simplified, principled, drafting style that New Zealand has adopted and their apparently well founded confidence in the ability of the courts to understand and act upon the principles set out in legislation. In developing its new legislation New Zealand has also review many of the basic, and outdated, concepts which entered company law in the last century and whose value has never been properly re-assessed. This is a matter which we in Australia are only now addressing.

The discussions the Committee held extended far beyond company law issues. The report briefly outlines those discussion and I draw the attention of honourable senators to the report for more detail on the range of issues examined. Of course the harmonisation of business laws between different countries should extend beyond the already significant progress that has been made by Australia and New Zealand. But the success of the visit and the progress that has already been made between these two countries indicates the potential benefits to Australia of extending this process to include our trading partners in Asia.

The success of a visit like this depends, to a great extent, on the organisation by the host country and the enthusiasm of the people the Committee meets. I must say that on this occasion the organisation by the Committee's hosts in New Zealand was excellent. We were able to meet with everyone we wished to and all of the arrangements went like clockwork. Everyone with whom we met extended the utmost courtesy to the Committee and the discussions we had were invariably wide ranging and interesting. I would therefore like to place on record the Committee's thanks to everyone we met in New Zealand.

I would particularly like to thank; the Honourable Robin Gray, Speaker of the House of Representatives; Mr Rob Munro and the other members and staff of the Justice and Law Reform Select Committee; Mr Wayne Kimber and the other members and staff of the Commerce Select Committee; Professor Richard Sutton of the New Zealand Law Commission; and Mr Max Simmons from the Distinguished Visitors Branch of the Department of Internal Affairs. There is insufficient time to acknowledge everyone here so I will draw the attention of honourable senators to acknowledgments contained in he report.
