SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Securities Commission has produced a marvellously glossy annual report. If honourable senators read this annual report they would think that there was nothing wrong with corporate regulation in this country. How mistaken they would be! In this annual report the ASC seeks to trumpet some of its great achievements—for example, the regulation of corporate matters and bringing people who have defrauded the public or acted improperly to heel. On page 30 of the annual report, for example, it lists as one of its successes the prosecution of one Mr David Howe, a director of a company called Farndale Ltd. It says that he was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . sentenced to two years imprisonment, minimum term of eight months, on charges relating to the improper use of his position to gain an advantage for Howe Corporation Pty Ltd. Solicitor, Nigel Smith, was sentenced to two years imprisonment, minimum term of nine months, for being knowingly concerned in the commission of an offence. John Campbell was fined $17,500 and ordered to perform 240 hours of community service after pleading guilty to improperly using his position as a director of the company.

What this annual report does not tell us is that Farndale and the Howe Corporation collapsed in 1987 and 1988 respectively; that these matters are over five years old; that the offences in question occurred before the collapse of the companies—and this is one of the great achievements of the Australian Securities Commission and, before it, the Corporate Affairs Commission!

PARA.TAB: What we have here is a joke. This is not proper corporate regulation. Anybody can take a charge that relates to a matter over five years old and say it is a success because they finally got it resolved this year. The real test of the success of the Australian Securities Commission is how well it is regulating corporate misconduct at the moment.

Unfortunately, six months ago the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was forced to come to this chamber and seek a reference to look into the manner in which the ASC exercises its investigative powers. We have received over 108 submissions on that inquiry and the submissions continue to come in to this day. Every week we get more submissions from people who have been aggrieved by the Australian Securities Commission. Most of those submissions are not from the crooks and the villains and the scoundrels trying to cover up what they have done; many of those submissions come from the victims of corporate misconduct whom the ASC has attacked when it should have been attacking the perpetrators of these offences in the first place. Many of those submissions come from people who had ASC officers knock on their door at 7.30 or 8 o'clock at night to deliver documents that related to their being required to appear in court the very next day to defend their own private assets from applications by the ASC to have those assets frozen. These were the victims of the rip-offs, not the perpetrators.

We were supposed to have our first hearing next week in Brisbane—because of the work load of the committee this was six months after the legal and constitutional affairs committee received this reference—but it was suggested that this hearing be cancelled while we go off and have a hearing on another matter which has been referred to us at short notice. That makes me angry enough as it is.

But what makes me really angry is the fact that the Australian Securities Commission recently approached the secretary and other staff of our committee and sought to have a private meeting with them, not with the committee. It was told, quite correctly, that if it wanted to meet with anybody it would meet with the committee, and it would do so in public. It declined that offer. The really sad thing is that those officers of the ASC who sought to do that made the approach after having just attended a conference on the privileges of the Senate committee system, which they were forced to go to because of their previous misconduct. What did they have to say to the committee secretariat that they cannot say to the members of the committee themselves? What do they want to say about us that they do not want to say in public? The ASC is rotten right the way through. Unless I see something to the contrary, I will have to believe that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a reference before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs relating to the Australian Securities Commission. As Senator O'Chee said, the committee is still receiving submissions relating to that inquiry. As a member of that committee, I still have an open mind on the reference that the parliament has directed to that committee. I am not so certain, after hearing Senator O'Chee's comments, that the same could be said for him. On reading the submissions, I do not think all of them have come from, as he said, victims of the ASC. Most definitely not all of them have. I have not read each and every submission yet as there are over 100.

PARA.TAB: We should be a little more careful when we rise in this place before we pre-empt the decisions of committees. If we are going to do that, why bother giving committees references of this nature in the first place? The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is one of the busiest committees in this parliament—not only in the Senate, but in the parliament itself. Senator O'Chee well knows that as a member of the committee.

Earlier this year the committee got involved in the budget debate which, on one particular occasion, involved four full days of hearings on matters that the Senate chose to refer to the committee. As I recall—and I may be corrected on this—the committee has six other specific references; they are not minor references. Off the top of my head, I recall the very large inquiry into the cost of justice; the inquiry into gender bias in the judiciary—another one which has evoked a lot of media and public attention; and the inquiry into the rights and obligations of the media. There are but three references, all of which are very extensive and all of which have attracted a great deal of attention and a great deal of submissions from the public generally and from interested organisations.

I heard Senator O'Chee say that the meeting the committee was to have next week in Brisbane has been put off because of other matters. I do not know as yet whether a decision has been made; I know that there is some speculation that the native title legislation may be referred to this committee. The native title bill has attracted some controversy, not only in my home state of Western Australia but also in other parts of Australia. It is right and proper that standing committees of the parliament look at legislation which is attracting some attention; certainly nobody can say that the native title bill is not attracting attention.

How many sitting days are left in the rest of the year? This chamber is having a week's break followed by two weeks of sitting. This Senate standing committee has to fit in references given to it by the parliament. If that means that next week—instead of being at home looking with admiration on my new granddaughter—I will be in Brisbane or Darwin or Perth or Melbourne or somewhere else, that is the obligation I have as a member of parliament, and every other member of that committee has that obligation. That is unfortunate, but we know those things when we apply for the jobs that we have.

I rose only out of concern about the manner in which Senator O'Chee spoke. He has reached conclusions on this inquiry when we have not—as he said from his own mouth—started the public investigation. We all have our biases and our prejudices, but we should contain those to some degree prior to formulating final conclusions in a public manner such as Senator O'Chee has done. If there is truth in what he alleges, I have great confidence that this committee, which has acted in a very bipartisan manner in the past, will reach the correct conclusions and will make the right and proper recommendations to the parliament in order to correct any wrongs that may be there. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having worked in the insolvency profession, I can say that most of the people who work in the profession—
—You certainly aren't now.

—Senator Carr's childish interjections sometimes really leave me flabbergasted. Today he has done it yet again. Having worked in the insolvency profession, I can say that most of the people who work in that profession have creditors' best interests at heart. That might be something Senator Carr has difficulty understanding, but that is a reflection on him rather than anything else. What surprises me, however, is that a very small number of liquidators seem to be bringing the profession into disrepute.

PARA.TAB: I recently referred a matter to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), which I hope has been actioned in the interim; I am yet to hear back, but I am trying to be patient about the matter. It was a partnership dispute in Brisbane in relation to a company which was put into liquidation. At the time at which the company was put into liquidation, it had very few assets other than cash in the bank and a few debtors; that was about it. The business itself had already been sold as a going concern. There was an estimated $80,000 surplus after paying out all of the creditors.

The provisional liquidators and liquidators ran rampant with the funds in this company; they acted in a very unsatisfactory fashion. For example, they spent in the vicinity of $11,000 chasing a $3,000 debt. Over 60 per cent of the money declared as debts owed to the company went in legal fees and expenses. Not only will the creditors not receive 100c in the dollar, but the provisional liquidators and liquidators together have taken $80,000 to $100,000 in fees, plus legal expenses.

When queried by a journalist in Brisbane, they said that the more the creditors fought the price of the liquidation, the less they would get. That seemed to indicate that they were going to use the funds still remaining in the administration to pay their costs in fighting the committee of inspection and the creditors of the company. That is something they are not entitled to do, but these gentlemen in question seem to have taken it upon themselves to do it.

I understand that two other insolvency professionals, both of them official liquidators, were on the committee of inspection for this company. They both thought that the costs that had been incurred in the administration were excessive and unwarranted.

When the good liquidators of this company were appointed, they immediately proceeded to carry out an investigation into whether there had been any voidable dispositions during the relating back period. The voidable dispositions or, rather, the undue preferences which they sought to find could not exist if the company paid 100c in the dollar to its creditors, which it was expected to do. The only way the company was not going to pay 100c in the dollar to its creditors was if the liquidators chewed up all the money themselves. It was a totally unnecessary investigation and a waste of the creditors' money.

As I said, most of the liquidators and insolvency professionals in this country are good people who work hard and who frequently write off many of their costs and fees in order to get a good result. I am concerned that a tiny number of people are not playing by the rules. Unfortunately, the firm in question—I have not named the firm and I have not named the company; I want to highlight the size of the problem—has been referred to me on other matters with similar allegations. In those cases, I did not think it was appropriate to contact the Attorney-General, per se, about the level of costs, but I hope that the Attorney-General's Department is going to read this Hansard or will be listening to this broadcast, so that it will be aware of the concerns that I am raising, and so that it will recognise that this is a serious issue. The creditors' money is at stake and this matter should not be allowed to continue in this fashion. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on treaty Nos. 14 and 15 together. They refer to exchange of notes constituting an implementing arrangement concerning plutonium transfers to the agreement with the European Atomic Energy Community—EURATOM; and, exchange of notes consisting an implementing arrangement concerning international obligation exchanges to the agreement with the European Atomic Energy Community.

PARA.TAB: The two agreements between Australia and the European Atomic Energy Community, or EURATOM, relate to safety and safeguard measures associated with Australian sourced radioactive material. The agreement associated with plutonium appears to tighten up deficiencies concerning arrangements associated with the retransfer of plutonium. This plutonium is recovered from spent fuel reprocessed at La Hague and Sellafield in England.

It would appear that the plutonium agreement changes the concept of advanced generic consent to advanced consent on the retransfer of consignments of plutonium from Europe to Japan. The agreement now makes it necessary for advance consent to be given for specific shipments of plutonium. Previous plutonium could be simply retransferred, based on arrangements contained within earlier agreements. The lack of consent over specific shipments technically prevented Australia from stepping in at any particular point and stopping the retransfer of plutonium to Japan unless it had good cause to suspect that the safeguard obligations were not being fulfilled.

Whilst the agreement tightens up certain aspects of plutonium transfers, it does nothing to stop this trade. I understand that the Japanese are currently storing the last shipment of plutonium that they took receipt of. It has not gone for immediate use in the Minju fast breeder reactor.

The fact that Japan has moved into the plutonium economy and that it is currently storing its plutonium creates alarming signals within the region. This is creating significant regional instability. The accumulation of plutonium by Japan is being used in part as an excuse by north Korea not to allow full safeguard inspections. North Korea appears to be saying that it is hypocritical to concentrate on its facilities whilst at the same time condoning Japan's plutonium accumulation.

It would appear that the plutonium agreement has been precipitated by the possibility that the next shipment to Japan will contain plutonium originated from the use of Australian uranium. Australia supplies 15 per cent of Japan's uranium. In essence, this means that Australian uranium may well end up as plutonium stockpiled in Japan. We are, in effect, contributing to the instability of northern Asia.

On top of the security risk, the movement of highly radioactive spent fuel from Japan to Europe and back again as plutonium puts a large percentage of the world at risk from a serious accident. No agreement will eliminate the enormous risk to regional security or eliminate the hazards associated with the shipment of highly radioactive material. The best way that Australia can contribute to reducing these risks is to stop selling uranium and to encourage other nations to develop a future based on renewable and environmentally benign sources of energy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak to treaties Nos 16 and 21. Firstly, I will deal with the convention for the conservation of southern bluefin tuna. The Western Australian Greens acknowledges the need to develop urgent measures to conserve viable populations of the southern bluefin tuna. Unfortunately, we do not believe that this convention will fulfil that need or that the current government has any intention of honouring it.

PARA.TAB: The current southern bluefin tuna stock is drastically depleted. Sadly, this reflects the state of all of Australia's major commercial fisheries. The recently tabled report of the Australian, Japanese and New Zealand scientists on southern bluefin tuna found:

SPEECH.PARA: The continued very low abundance of the parental biomass is cause for serious biological concern.
It continues:
The new biological information indicates that recruitment declined during the early 1980's to about 50% of the 1980 level by 1985, and this low level has continued for at least 2 more years to 1987.
We should take serious notice when scientists make this type of statement. Regrettably, we believe that this convention will do very little to protect this species from a further decline in numbers.

PARA.TAB: The language of the convention still contains the outmoded terminology found in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Clause 3 of this convention refers to the term `optimum utilisation'. Senators may remember that Senator Coulter and I drew attention to this outmoded term in our statements relating to the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill that was passed in the Senate last week. The term `optimum utilisation' has been used by countries throughout the world to justify the over-utilisation of fish stocks. Unless multi-species assessments are made and incorporated in management plans which are based upon an ecosystem approach, the southern bluefin tuna has a pretty grim future.

Further, the convention does very little to ensure that methods used to catch southern bluefin tuna do not adversely affect other species. A recent documentary on the ABC graphically depicted the tragic effects of long-line fishing on bird species, particularly rare species of the albatross.

Of course, these conventions are only as good as the government's will to implement them. Less than a month after this convention was signed by the Australian government, the Minister for Resources, Michael Lee, granted an additional 100 tonnes of tuna to the Australian fishing industry over and above the agreed quota established by the parties to this convention. This is an appalling act of hypocrisy by the Labor government as it totally contravenes the intent of this convention. It certainly does not auger well for the tuna.

I also wish to refer to treaty No. 21, which is the agreement establishing the south pacific regional environment program. The WA Greens welcome the signing of the agreement, which establishes the south pacific regional environment program as an organisation in its own right. During the 10-year period of its operation, SPREP has been a most effective regional organisation at working towards protecting the environment in the south pacific. Its newfound independence should give it greater scope to develop further measures to protect the environment.

As a member of SPREP, Australia has a key role to play in the region. It is the most industrialised nation in the region and, among other things, has a special role in developing strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Australia should work closely with the OECD members of SPREP, the US, UK and France to ensure that they develop strict measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

South pacific nations have the most to fear from sea level rise and increased weather disturbance caused by the greenhouse effect. The south pacific nations have made repeated calls for a timetable for reductions starting immediately.

At the most recent intergovernmental negotiating session on the climate convention, Australia's stance on reducing greenhouse gases appeared to slip behind the initiatives of other nations. The Auditor-General's report, tabled in parliament this year, highlighted the lack of action being undertaken by the Australian government on this issue. This must be extremely worrying for our pacific island neighbours.

Earlier this year, Papua New Guinea tabled a proposal to prohibit hazardous waste imports into the region. The Australian government has lobbied for a much weaker position. The WA Greens believe that this is totally unacceptable. Pacific nations should not become the dumping ground for the industrialised world. Already we have seen the pacific used for nuclear testing by the French and toxic waste incineration by the US. It is time that countries like Australia take a strong stand towards protecting this unique corner of the world. Hopefully, the signing of the south pacific regional environment program agreement signals a more responsible approach by the Australian government in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the last two treaties on the list, which deal with two of the three committees on human rights. As a result of a decision by the Keating government, these committees have the right to hear Australian domestic disputes. I am on the record on a number of occasions as pointing out that it was a bad decision to overturn the philosophy of the Australia Act and to allow Australian domestic disputes to go to UN committees. If we happen to not feel that the independence and sovereignty of our nation is a key issue and believe that it is appropriate for UN committees to involve themselves in Australian domestic activities, we have to make sure that those UN committees are appropriately structured to deal with Australian disputes. These two treaties mention two of the three committees to which Australians can now take domestic disputes after going through the various internal arrangements.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons for raising this point is that I do not believe these committees are appropriately structured to play any role in the Australian legal system. I am given some comfort for that view by another report which is currently on the agenda—World conference on human rights. This report was written after the Vienna conference which was held on 14 to 25 June this year. It is a very interesting report in which Senator Gareth Evans gives an extensive summary of his view of activities. There are also various reports filed by individual members of parliament, including Senator Harradine and Mr Ruddock.

One of the points to come out of that conference was the divergence of views in the world on human rights. There were differences of opinion on how particular rights should be interpreted and which rights were more important than others. That is a very important debate. In some countries some rights are considered to be more culturally determined. A lot of countries at that conference were said to be very unhappy with the sorts of views that western societies like Australia were putting forward.

These committees contain the nominees of a wide variety of countries, many of which, unfortunately, are either not free or only partly free. The human rights cases which emerge from Australia will be interpreted by people whose particular views of human rights are nowhere in line with the views of mainstream Australia or even the views of Senator Evans.
This report demonstrates that concern. For example, on page 5 of the report that Senator Evans tabled today, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . civil and political rights, and that at the national level governments have a responsibility to implement effective development policies.
The report goes on:

However, there are still wide differences, even among Western countries, on the relative importance, definition and implementation of economic, social and cultural rights, and it is clear that this area will be a major focus of the human rights debate in future years.

What the government has done is to throw open the Australian legal system in a significant area to committees which are bitterly divided on how we define human rights, how particular rights have preference over other rights and how we strike a balance between those rights. That is why I say it was a very bad decision by the Keating government to overturn the philosophy of the Australia Act. If members of the government believe that it is appropriate for UN committees to involve themselves in Australian activities, then they have to focus on how these particular committees are composed. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not necessarily agree with all that Senator Kemp has had to say about this matter. I believe it is good that Australia at times subjects itself to international scrutiny. If this scrutiny is from established international bodies, I think that would serve us well. The fact that there is a divergence of opinion about those bodies is probably a strength rather than a weakness because it means they are not all of like mind.

PARA.TAB: I want to speak in general terms about one matter in which I have a particular interest. A complaint has been made about Australia's performance in relation to an aspect of human rights. I am going to talk about this matter in general terms because it is the subject of scrutiny by a committee of the parliament; therefore I will not be too specific.

When the complaint was first made I made a public comment that I welcomed it. The complaint, which was that Australia was in breach of a number of international obligations in the human rights area, was made time and time again and then finally, in the middle of this year, a formal complaint was sent to the United Nations Committee on Human Rights. I look forward to hearing the result of that complaint, which has been made by many organisations, because it will be good to settle this matter once and for all. I am sorry to be vague on this matter. I want to follow my own standards from an earlier speech that I made in this chamber a short while ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not to do with an offshore island, is it?
—No, it is not. It is about a body of people who are currently in Australia. I can talk to Senator Kemp privately if he wants me to follow the matter through.
—Tasmania is not an offshore island.

—It is certainly not about Tasmania. Senator Kemp also raised the matter of the recent human rights conference held in Vienna. I have not had the opportunity to read that report fully but I have certainly glanced through it. I am aware of the participants of that conference, including the government advisers who were representative of the three major parties in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: When the criticism about the matter to which I have referred was made to my committee it was said that Australia was constantly being criticised by international forums because of the way we reacted and treated people in this area. When we followed this matter through with questioning we were not able to get evidence of which nations were criticising Australia. We were also unable to find out which conferences were criticising Australia. The recent human rights conference would have been the ideal forum at which to raise this matter but it did not make the agenda.

Through further investigation and questioning, we found that criticisms of this country had been made at international levels. Much to my horror—and we will talk about this in more detail at a later time—we found that that criticism was actually being made by Australian non-government organisations abroad. It saddens me somewhat to think that people, many of whom are being financed by the Australian taxpayer to participate in human rights forums, would go overseas and seek to make a name for themselves and elevate themselves in the community by criticising their own country.

I do not share all Senator Kemp's views about the treaties or the human rights conference. I will read the report from the human rights conference and I hope that Senator Bourne, who was an adviser to the conference, will give the Senate more information about what went on in Vienna earlier this year. I think they are very useful forums. As I said earlier, I think it is good that Australia from time to time subjects itself, within limitations, to international scrutiny so that we can have a better measurement of how we are performing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one of a number of people in this chamber—I know that my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald is another—who very much disagrees with the recommendations that have been made in relation to how we should handle the wool stockpile. I know that my view is a little controversial. I am definitely of the view that we should quarantine the stockpile, finance it at low interest rates over a long period and send a very clear message to the market that we will not release the wool unless the price reaches a certain trigger.
—You supported our legislation.
—With great reluctance. The more Senator Sherry tells me that it was his legislation the more reluctance I feel about it.
—You should have voted for my amendments.

—Senator Woodley's amendments were not consistent with my viewpoint at all and that is why I did not vote for them. The reluctance that I feel about it, whilst it is uncommon here, is not uncommon in the community, particularly in the wool industry itself. I think there are a lot of growers who look with great trepidation at what is about to happen to their industry. A lot of growers say, `Look, this is the return that we need just to break even. At the moment we are below what we need to break even. If prices remain low for a substantial period—' which is perfectly likely in this case—`we will be out of business'.

PARA.TAB: It is not as though we are just losing farmers, although that is bad enough in itself; we are losing some of our specialist woolgrowers—people who have not just one generation but two or three generations of expertise in the production of wool. If we are to maintain a world market leadership position in terms of wool production, it behoves us to do something to keep this industry stable; it behoves us not to destroy the returns that these growers will get by virtue of a particular policy. I know that this is a view that is not shared by the majority in this place or in the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —In your own party.

—There are differing viewpoints on this matter in our party, but the great advantage of being in the National Party as opposed to the Liberal Party is that I am still allowed to express my viewpoint, which is what I am doing right now. I will continue to express this viewpoint and my concern for the woolgrowers of this country because I came to this chamber with a definite mission to preserve the core of our primary production.

PARA.TAB: I came into this chamber with a belief that the battle is out there on the back blocks of Queensland, on the dry and dusty land around Charleville and all those other western towns, which need someone to battle for them in here. That is why I will keep on saying this. I hate to say it, but probably two years down the track there is every likelihood that people will be saying, `We did the wrong thing, and maybe we should have locked up the wool stockpile'. But by then I suspect that the damage will be done.

I think there are ways that we can still minimise the effects it will have. We should use certain provisions of the Bankruptcy Act to implement the farmers assistance scheme, which would at least give these people some sort of relief from immediate collection of debts and immediate action by some secured creditors, because that is where the threat is. I do not want to be one of those people who sit quietly by and have the blood of Australia's farming sector on their hands. I do not intend to do that at all. That is why I take this opportunity to speak on this document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I agree with a lot of what Senator O'Chee said. I have to put that on the record when it is true. I especially agree with what he said about members of the Liberal Party not being able to express their opinions freely—
—I didn't say that.
—That is what Senator O'Chee said.
—You did say `Liberal'.
—I have just come in to help him change it. He did not realise.

—Then perhaps I do not agree with Senator O'Chee on that particular matter. I was just trying to be very generous to him in the remarks that he made. However, I do agree with many of his other remarks, particularly about the debt which is faced by woolgrowers. My concern is that there is still a problem, even with the great hope that I have that, despite my apprehension and some of my fears, the present policy will work. Although I moved amendments and expressed some of those apprehensions in my speech when the legislation was before the Senate, I give my commitment, my energy and my hope that the policy will work. It must work because, if does not work, not only woolgrowers in this country but also the nation itself are in big trouble.

PARA.TAB: I want to underline the fact that, no matter how we rearrange the selling of the stockpile, because of high interest rates and some of the advice that woolgrowers were given by financial advisers, many woolgrowers face debts which, even if they are able to sell their wool at reasonable prices, will remain. I believe that we need to address this question of rural debt in a much more radical way than we are prepared to do at this moment.

On a future occasion I would like to propose some methods that I believe would make it possible to address those very deep concerns and problems which many woolgrowers and other members of the rural community face because of the debts hanging over their heads. I thank the Senate for this opportunity to make those few remarks. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a parliamentary adviser at the UN World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna this year. I found it an immensely valuable learning experience. We see the workings of this parliament as being complicated, intricate and convoluted, as indeed they are, but they are absolutely straightforward when compared with the United Nations. Sitting at the conference watching the way the United Nations works and the way different people reacted to other people at a personal and country level was absolutely fascinating. I must say that I would not have missed it for the world.

PARA.TAB: Before this conference started, the fear of many human rights organisations was that it could be hijacked by the least enlightened countries and that the basic tenets of human rights could be eroded. We all feared a diminution of the impact of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and of the associated covenants. That is only possible, of course, because at conferences such as this everything has to be done by consensus. If one single government in the world does not agree with any statement, that statement is not included in the final conference declaration. The pressure on governments—some governments—to at least look as though they believe human rights must be upheld has to be immense and it has to be constant.

There were four preparatory conferences in which officials of all the governments involved attempted to write a draft of what would become the final statement of this conference. By all accounts, these four preparatory conferences were extremely difficult, as would be expected with a subject such as this. The document which was argued over at the UN world conference itself was full of statements which had not yet been agreed on, and many of them were contradictory.

We ended up with a declaration which is not too bad. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights has been totally upheld, as have the associated covenants. The universality of human rights was acknowledged. The push by some countries to declare the rights of the community to be paramount over the rights of the individual was successfully averted. The rights of women and the rights of children were declared to be equal in every way to the rights of men. This may seem self-evident to us here in Australia, but it most certainly is not in much of the world.

The use of rape as a deliberate act of war has now been condemned in no uncertain terms by the international community. The rights of indigenous peoples have been acknowledged, even though only in a preliminary manner. The issue of peoples—with the `s' on the end—was the item at the conference which caused the most controversy. Australia, I am proud to say, was one of the countries which supported most strongly that it should be `peoples' with an `s'—taken by other countries to mean races—and not just individual indigenous people. We pushed that very hard. We lost it this time, but that is just one of the battles, not the war. I hope we will continue to be one of the countries in strongest support of that.

This document includes the three speeches that were given on behalf of Australia at the conference. The first was given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). I have to say that I do not think it is too exciting, but it is not too bad. I always tend to look at our foreign ministers' speeches in the way that I look at all other foreign ministers' speeches. I thought that in this one he came a bit closer to my point of view, and I was pleased to see that. To give him credit, he was the only one who actually offered a significant amount of money—$300,000—for strengthening the domestic infrastructures which support human rights in other countries. Nobody else, not one other government at that conference, offered any money to do anything.

The second speech included in the report is by our Ambassador to the UN in Geneva, Penny Wensley. It is very strong on women's rights and the rights of all vulnerable groups in the world. I recommend it. It is an excellent speech. Ms Wensley was an excellent leader of the delegation when the foreign minister left. He was a very energetic leader and a very good leader while he was there. Penny was also very good. The third speech is by Mrs Lois O'Donoghue of ATSIC. It is a very strong statement of what we have got wrong and what we have got right in indigenous people's rights. It is balanced and it is fair. I certainly recommend that one to everyone.

Finally, I congratulate all the members of the Australian delegation for their very hard work in achieving the result we did. The hours were long, the pressure on everyone was strong and constant, and the whole thing was very difficult, but they did a magnificent job. They are all listed in the report.

This conference was not the disaster many of us feared it could be. We did not solve the very substantial human rights problems of the world, but the conference declaration did not create any more and it did advance the cause of human rights, even if just a little. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this report for two reasons—to commend the report and also to draw to honourable senators' notice some of the material in regard to the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee, which I have spoken on in previous debates. In terms of new developments in genetic research and its application, there are significant advances in research in Australia and some early experimentation overseas which indicate that proposals for gene therapy on humans—that is, the introduction of genetic material into humans after birth which does not affect the germline—may come in the very near future.

PARA.TAB: This committee will be looking at the challenges of the coming year, which will see continuing changes in technology and an increasing interest in human gene therapy proposals. I commend the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee, which is composed of a large number of people. Besides scientists, the committee includes members from the wider non-scientific community with backgrounds in fields such as law, philosophy and environmental issues.

I commend to honourable senators a book which was published earlier this year called Predicting the Future because, in the part dealing with medicine, it mentions that the big challenges that lie ahead of us really are in relation to the ethics of genetic manipulation. The deliberate insertion of DNA—deoxyribonucleic acid—into human germline cells whence it could be passed on into children is banned in Australia. One compelling reason for this is that there is no logical use for such an approach in the treatment of human diseases.

The primary issue with the insertion of foreign DNA into a human subject is the effect upon the patient. Other applications include the insertion of DNA as a marker of the fate of certain classes of cells in the bodies of patients with cancer, the insertion of cloned genes into white blood cells to increase the vigour of their attack upon cancer cells, and the insertion of RNA—ribonucleic acid—into cells to break down genes causing cancer or to attack viruses causing diseases such as AIDS. The ethics of this is, properly, a part of the considerations of the Australian Health Ethics Committee, which takes into account these additional applications of nucleic acid insertion.

I rise tonight to bring that to the attention of honourable senators. Part of that is also part of the human genome project, where all the genes on the human cell are being documented around the world. It is a huge effort, primarily on behalf of the Americans, the British and the French. Something like $15,000 million is being spent on this. It will affect everybody in this chamber and every Australian. It is approaching us with a rapidity that is not appreciated by the community at large.

I wish to record these comments within the Hansard of the Senate, at least to draw this situation to the attention of people outside the scientific community, so that some thought can be given to the actual ethical aspects of these things that are going on around us. I think that science is outstripping the community at large in its consideration of the issues as they will affect the average person. I commend the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee—both its chairman, Emeritus Professor Millis, and the members of the committee itself—for the great work it is doing in this regard. I am sure that the government will continue its funding in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee annual report. I do not want to repeat what Senator Herron has said because I agree with him very strongly, having spent five and a half years on the Queensland University of Technology ethics committee with a growing apprehension about the use of genetic material, particularly that obtained, for instance, through procedures such as in-vitro fertilisation, embryo transplants and spare embryos. I attended some conferences whilst I was on that ethics committee and saw the technology which is now so far ahead not only of the ethical debate but also of the legal debate. For those reasons, I would like an opportunity at a later date to speak further on this issue.

—I wish also to speak on the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee annual report. (Extension of time granted) I thank the Senate because I think it is good to keep this debate all in the one time frame.

PARA.TAB: In March 1992, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology tabled a report entitled Genetic manipulation: the threat or the glory. It recommended the creation of a legislative framework to clearly define and give legal force to controls on the use of genetic manipulation. To this date no legislation has surfaced. The Greens WA are deeply concerned by this. The potential harm to humans and Australia's biological diversity from an unregulated release of a genetically modified organism is too great a risk to be bound by voluntary guidelines. We call on the government to immediately set in train actions to develop appropriate legislation as a matter of urgency. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to deal with both my motion and that of Senator Calvert together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Government's announcement in the 1993-94 Budget that it intends to close three naval bases: HMAS Huon in Hobart, HMAS Encounter in Adelaide and HMAS Moreton in Brisbane, and

(ii)that the Government has admitted in Estimates Committee B on 10 November 1993 that it has still not determined the financial savings to Defence which would flow from the closure of the three bases or how naval functions in each State will be maintained; and

PARA.TAB: (b)resolves that the closure of each of the three bases should not proceed unless and until the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)establishes that there are significant savings to be made by the closure of each of the three bases,

(ii)demonstrates how defence interests will be furthered by the closure of each base, particularly representation functions, support for naval reserve and naval reserve cadet forces, the provision of naval personnel services and the administration of ship visits for each State,
(iii)make adequate provision for the protection and preservation of the heritage value of each base, and
(iv)provides for the protection and preservation of memorials which may exist on each base; and

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that, several months after announcing the decision to close the HMAS Huon naval base in Hobart, the Government is yet to provide either a substantive economic argument to justify the decision or an acceptable alternative to house Tasmania's naval defence personnel, naval reserve or naval cadets;

(b)recognises that HMAS Huon is a unique heritage building, endorsed by the National Trust, which houses naval memorials and artefacts of crucial importance to our nation's naval history which must be retained in their present environment;
(c)acknowledges that the decision to close HMAS Huon has caused considerable concern amongst all those associated with the naval service in Tasmania and within the wider Tasmanian community; and
(d)resolves that, in recognition of the special role which HMAS Huon fulfils in Tasmania, the decision to close the base be reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: My motion concerns the rather silly decision of the government to close HMAS Huon, HMAS Encounter and HMAS Moreton, whilst Senator Calvert's deals specifically with HMAS Huon and raises the same protest. Apart from general comments on the three bases, my comments will particularly relate to the base in South Australia, HMAS Encounter, and also the base in Tasmania, HMAS Huon, and I think my colleague Senator MacGibbon, from Queensland, will make some specific comments in relation to HMAS Moreton in Brisbane, with which he is very familiar.

PARA.TAB: This decision was announced by the government some little time ago and came as something of a surprise to us because the navy in each of the three states—South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland—has had a long and proud history. These bases have served Australia's interests well and they seem to still be serving worthwhile functions. Just to mention a few, those with which we are very familiar: to conduct the representational functions of the navy; to support naval reserves and naval cadet reserve forces; to provide personnel and family services; and to administer the RAN and allied ship visits.

There is also an aspect that I think is very much underestimated by this government, and that relates to the place of these bases in terms of naval traditions and culture, something which is very meaningful to naval people. Certainly I know it from the many dozens of South Australian ex-servicemen and women who have spoken to me in relation to HMAS Encounter.

I suppose in some ways I should declare an interest in that it was at that base, in the old drill hall that this government is planning to sell off, that my father signed up in the Second World War, as did so many of his mates, many of whom did not return. It is just an example of how that particular base in South Australia means a great deal not only to the ex-service personnel but also their families.

I witnessed it personally in attending a memorial service there a couple of months ago. I was surprised by the literally hundreds of ex-service personnel who were present representing many different naval groupings. They demonstrated by their presence and what they said to me how important it is to them, particularly in terms of the memories of lost mates.

So important was it in fact that some years ago they set up a memorial garden in HMAS Encounter and there are plaques there representing each of the ships from which they served out of Adelaide, and from time to time people go back there for services to remember the dead. So it really does have a place in the hearts and minds of people who have been associated with the navy in South Australia. The thought of demolition of the old drill hall, or even removal of their memorial garden, is something that distresses them greatly.

I do not think the government, as I said, has properly appreciated that fact and our bringing this motion on tonight gives the minister an opportunity, I hope, to give it further consideration. I witnessed it when I went down to Huon in Tasmania a few weeks ago and again talked to former naval personnel about that particular rather beautiful site and facility. I received expressions of the same sentiment of how it is associated with the naval tradition that has been so much a part of Hobart and how disappointed people would be if in fact that tradition disappeared. That spirit becomes relevant to the issue of the naval reserves and the naval cadet reserve forces because if these functions are transferred to what will simply be regarded as a central military establishment away from the sea or the rivers, it simply does not seem to attract the same interest for those who want to serve in a naval function.

I believe that the government's decision to transfer these reserve and cadet facilities to what it refers to as `defence centrals' in each of the states will have the effect of providing a disincentive to young and older people who want to contribute service in this voluntary way. I have little doubt that that will be the case.

Having seen these bases operating and noting that they seem to be making a worthwhile contribution, let me turn to the reasons given by the government for the decision to close them. The primary reason given seemed to be a financial one. There also were some vague reasons and the minister might attempt to respond to them tonight. We are told that, out of this process of moving the navy into a non-naval base, greater efficiencies will result.

But, Mr Deputy President, I put to you that both those arguments simply do not seem to stand analysis. Firstly, in relation to costs, it was suggested in the first instance before the estimates hearings that the gross costs in relation to the bases would in fact be savings. I specifically refer to the evidence of Commodore Ritchie, given before Estimates Committee B on 3 September. On page B67, he is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to the annual cost for Moreton as approximately $1.3 million, $700,000 for Huon and roughly the same for Encounter. Those costs do not include the salaries of personnel located at those bases. The savings we hope to accrue are those costs because they are the operating costs of the bases. We will not accrue savings from the salaries . . .

When one started to do an analysis of this, the position was found to be quite blurred. The government, in relation to each base, was abandoning certain functions—and that is admitted; particularly the use of a patrol boat for reserve training. But those functions were to go whether the bases were retained or not. So any savings associated with that change of function are not savings that can be attributed to the closure of the bases.

PARA.TAB: When we looked at what other functions might be included within the savings figure, we found that the other principal functions in relation to the bases were to be transferred to amorphous bodies known as `defence central'. So, if a recruiting officer is transferred from one of the naval bases to defence central, again there is no saving being made. It was said again that, with real effort, it was found there was some duplication and that perhaps some of the positions could be dispensed with. But they could be dispensed with in any event without closing the base. So that is not really a valid saving either.

Then we were told that there are savings that would be associated with the cost of keeping the bases. But that is now in a state of some confusion also because Huon, as we understand from the subsequent estimates committee, is now not to be sold by the government. So, at Commonwealth expense, it still has to be maintained. I think it was suggested that it might be put out for DEET to occupy. Whether it is Defence Force or another government administration, there will not be a saving in costs associated with maintenance.

So where are the savings? As I have said, when we start to analyse the figures that were blandly put in the first estimates committee, the savings quickly become illusory. In fact, when we got to the subsequent estimates committee hearing on 10 November, the supplementary hearings, on page B197 Commodore Ritchie is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot tell you what the dollar savings would be.

So we started off some months before when it was suggested that something like $2.7 million might be saved—and let us put that in the context of a Defence budget of about $10 billion; but, anyway, $2.7 million is nevertheless a significant sum of money. But, by the time we got to the supplementary estimates, that seemed to have disappeared. We have the astonishing situation that neither the navy nor the government could tell the committee what savings would be achieved at all. As I said, when we start to look at the functions that are being transferred, what the government is intending to do with the specific bases, it is hard to find the answer anywhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the resolution of the Senate relating to the return to order, I table an index of and documents in relation to the resolution of the Senate concerning the Australian Artists' Creative Fellowships. They are pretty self-explanatory. We have had a substantial debate about it; I do not want to have another.

PARA.TAB: I will speak briefly to this matter. Firstly, with regard to the question of the applications, honourable senators would know that I had some concern about that resolution. Nevertheless, I acknowledge that it was carried over my opposition and I have sought to act in accordance with the spirit of it. I do not pretend to be the world's expert on all the details of information privacy principle 11 but I understand, on advice, that it does have this aspect concerning what can be disclosed with the agreement of the individual concerned. I will seek the leave of the Senate to respond in accordance with that letter later, but I table the letter. It seems to me to comply with the information privacy principle and the spirit of the Senate's request, and probably enables the concerns which I have to be met. We will see what the answer is, but I think it will.

I table all the other documents that are listed there. For the sake of completeness, I advise the Senate that there are two cabinet minutes which, in accordance with the normal procedures, are not tabled. But I assure the Senate that there are no additional facts or information in those. There are merely reiterations of information in the documents which I have tabled. I have decided, on examination of the particular circumstances of this case, to table the addresses of the people concerned given the nature of that information. I do not think it causes any privacy problems or any problems to those individuals. That is not an indication that in the normal course I would wish to do that for the reasons I have previously outlined.

There are some additional documents relating to the appointments. They do not add any new information but they are reiterations of and an outline of the process. I confirm what I said in the debate about the resolution itself that there are no minutes. The report of the meeting is in the form of a report by the meeting to the Australia Council, but it has all the information necessary for the Senate to be able to assess the decisions of that panel. So I cannot literally comply with that resolution because it relates to a document that does not exist. It provides the information that was sought but in a different form.

The only thing is for me—and this is probably the easiest way to do it but I am open to advice about process—to seek the leave of the Senate to respond further to part 1 of the resolution relating to the applications by Mr Tozer on the next sitting day, when I will have had the chance to have a response from Mr Tozer to the letter which I have written to him seeking his agreement to table such documents. If there is another process for me to do that in a way that does not literally comply but is consistent with the Senate's wishes, I will be happy to go through it, but if I could have the leave of the Senate to comply on the next sitting day, I would greatly appreciate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: It was on Monday of this week that I gave notice of a motion in this place which asked for the same documents mentioned in the motion that we are discussing now. In that motion I asked for information that Mr Tozer had given in his application for his first fellowship and the second fellowship. Subsequently, I think I am correct in saying that we amended that motion to address the privacy concerns that Senator McMullan had expressed. When he found himself unable to or unwilling to table the documents we had asked for, we had an order of the Senate for this afternoon. That is because I would like to see this cleared up. I think it ought to be cleared up for everyone concerned, including all those people who served on the committee.

PARA.TAB: I reiterate, and I will keep reiterating, that I am not in any way casting aspersions on Mr Tozer's ability as a pianist or his qualifications to earn or to be awarded a scholarship. Nor am I casting aspersions on the people who accepted the invitation from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What I am saying is that it is a little odd that the then Treasurer nominated seven people and recommended them to the minister for the arts, and then the minister for the arts recommended them to the Prime Minister. It seems to me that it would have been more appropriate for the minister for the arts, in discussion with the arts community, to have nominated people.

It may well have been that we came up with the same list. I am not casting aspersions on those people. I have had letters from those people. I want to put on the public record that there was concern in the arts community that there were personal associations between one awardee in particular and some of the people on the committee. Whenever a group of people from the arts community gets together, it is highly likely that some of the people on the committee will know some of the applicants. It is almost unavoidable. We would expect that those people would declare their association—whether it be personal, professional or whatever else—to the committee. The committee would make a judgment about whether that level of association causes it to question whether that person should participate in the awarding of the particular scholarship associated with the person that the committee member knows.

One of the people who has written to me said that they actually did that, but we do not know that because there are no minutes. I take on good faith that that was done. But, as Senator McMullan told us earlier today, there were no minutes of that first meeting where $1.4 million was expended. I do not understand why there are no minutes. I do not know whether it was because of the timing, and the Australia Council had not taken over the full responsibility of that committee or whether it had not come fully under the umbrella and therefore it did not have a secretariat. It is of great concern to the arts community and to the rest of the community when $1.4 million of taxpayers' money is expended and we do not have any minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the meeting at which it was made, the Australia Council meeting, it was minuted, and you have got that. That is where the money was spent. You are talking about when the recommendatory body met. They reported to the Australia Council. The decision is made by the Australia Council.

—The concerns that I have expressed need to be resolved. Recommendations were made at a meeting and yet there are no minutes of that meeting where recommendations are made. We ought to be able to see the process whereby those recommendations were made to the Australia Council. But minutes were not made; I do not know why, but they were not.

PARA.TAB: Had the minister come in here when I asked the question and said to me, `I do not have the details', as some ministers do, `I will go away and find out', had he come in here and said, `This is how the committee was appointed'—which would have stunned and surprised me, but anyway—had he said, `This is what happened; I have checked with the people who are involved and they have indicated to me that any possible conflict of interest had been expressed', this matter would have been resolved. But as it drags on because the minister does not seem to be able to comply with the order of the Senate, it makes it difficult for me, it makes it difficult for the artists concerned—all of whom had grants—and it makes it difficult for the people on the committee, and I know they are voluntary people who have given up enormous amounts of time and who have expertise in their particular areas.

Mr Tozer got a second fellowship of a considerable amount of money. Irrespective of what Senator McMullan said, it is a significant amount of money—for many artists a large amount of money. Many artists would like $65,000 a year. Mr Tozer got a second award. The terms and conditions and guidelines of the fellowships indicate that the awards will be given under exceptional circumstances. Given the prestige of these awards and given the nature of the awards and the amount of money involved, we ought to know what those exceptional circumstances were. If the minister can tell us what those exceptional circumstances were, that might put our concerns to rest.

I cannot see any reason why the minister cannot comply; it is an order of the Senate. To write to Mr Tozer and say to him, `To assist me in this matter I would appreciate your advice as to any objections you may have to the disclosure of any information contained in your applications of 1989 and 1993 for the grant of the creative fellowships' does not indicate to Mr Tozer that I have asked for all personal information to be eliminated from that application. What I have asked for is the purpose for which he applied for the two grants. That is the detail I wanted. Instead of complying with the order of the Senate, the minister seeks advice from Mr Tozer.

Citizens have a right not to have their personal business exposed publicly, but I am not asking to expose anything in public; I am asking for the reasons Mr Tozer gave. One of the reasons he gave is that he was going to start up a music school in the long run, he said, or `in the distant future' it tells us in the report of the decision to give the first award. The music school has not eventuated. He may have achieved the first part, doing recordings of little known composers, which was one of the aims, if I remember correctly, and the other aims he set out, but he did not achieve the aims of the first fellowship. One would query the giving of a second one.

But, short of suspending standing orders and short of pursuing this and appearing unreasonable—I do not think it is unreasonable to ask for it—I guess one would say that we will wait until 6 December. I would like to have had it over and done with tonight, cleared up, so I could actually talk to the people involved and this issue would be finished, possibly. But Senator McMullan obviously does not feel that is the appropriate way to go. I think it is—for us to see the documents and to get it over and done with. I ask Senator McMullan to reconsider the request that the documents be presented, in order for him to comply. I will not force that issue, but I think it would be appropriate to get it cleared up and over and done with and not have it hanging around for another week until we sit again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are prepared to wait until the sixth. As Senator Patterson says, we want to be reasonable about this and we would like to see what Mr Tozer has to say about it. The Democrats would like to see those applications with all the personal details taken out. We are quite happy for them to be shown just to senators. I believe that Senator Gareth Evans would be quite happy to tell people that I do not tell other people what is in documents which are shown to me confidentially; I would never do that. I believe that Senator Patterson can be trusted in the same way. Indeed, all senators can. I would like to see what is in those documents on that confidential basis, but we are all quite happy to wait until the sixth of December to see what Mr Tozer has to say in answer to Senator McMullan's letter.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner, we were debating the government's decision to close three naval bases.
—One in the motion.

—Huon, Encounter and Moreton. Notice of motion No. 429, which was mine, refers to the closure of three bases; 440, which was Senator Calvert's, deals specifically with HMAS Huon. I was saying that the case had to be made out by the government and that the case was going to be cost savings and/or improvement in the efficiency of the defence force. I was dealing specifically with the issue of what savings would result from the closures. I had said that not even the Navy in the estimates hearings was able to indicate that savings would actually flow; it was certainly not able to indicate the quantum of savings that would flow. I had just gone through the fact that by the time one transfers functions to another base—and in some instances the Commonwealth continues to hold the property, in any event—the savings are largely illusory.

PARA.TAB: So if the case is not going to be made out on the basis of cost savings, then presumably the government is going to say that the efficiencies that occur out of the closure, that the improvement in some way of the Australian Defence Force as a result of the closure, other than cost savings, is the basis for its decision. I would be interested to hear the minister's argument, but I have not heard an argument to date that I find at all convincing.

The issue of the wharves demonstrates the fallacy of this argument that if one removes the Navy to a central defence centre then in some ways it operates more effectively or more efficiently. To do that one takes the Navy away from its wharves. It was interesting in relation to Encounter in Adelaide that the view of the Navy in Adelaide was that the decision of the government was that, although the administration part of the base would be sold, the wharf would not be sold because it was essential to Navy's operations. The Navy understood that from it was to be based HMAS Protector, which was going to be used in the working up trials of the new Collins class submarine used by the reserves and by the cadets. So the Navy informed us that the decision was that the wharf would be kept as essential for its purposes.

Then when we get to the estimates committee we find from the minister that the decision of the government was that the wharf would be sold as well. One of the advantages of an estimates committee is that one can then move from the minister to the senior naval officer present. When an explanation was sought from him as to the contradictory advice that we were now receiving from the minister and from Navy, we got the somewhat unusual answer, `The Navy is actually making a submission to the minister that we keep the wharf because we, the Navy, see it as'—I am paraphrasing—`basically of great value'. When I went down to Huon in Tasmania I got the distinct impression that the Navy again sees the wharf facility as of particular value. It should not come as a surprise to hear that the Navy regards its access to the sea as important to its operations.

I think there may well be submissions from the Navy to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in relation to the wharf at Huon in Hobart. Where is the advantage in efficiency or effectiveness of the Defence Force that flows from this change? There is certainly no advantage or efficiency to the Navy. So far, with respect, the government has failed to make out grounds for such an advantage or efficiency in terms of the Defence Force as a whole.

I will conclude my remarks as I know my colleagues also wish to speak on this issue, namely, Senator MacGibbon in relation to Moreton and Senator Calvert in relation to Huon. I wanted to conclude by mentioning my concern about the memorial garden at Encounter in Adelaide. I put to the minister at the estimates committee that the local federal Labor member, Mr Sawford, had given certain undertakings to the naval community in Adelaide that if it was not able to secure another place for its memorial, the government had made a decision that it would be protected in its current location. Specifically, in a press release, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If agreement cannot be reached on a suitable location to secure the garden future, the Navy is committed to ensuring that appropriate provisions are incorporated into the conditions of sale of the property.
He said that he had the minister's authority to say that.

PARA.TAB: When we questioned the minister in the estimates committee on that—I am paraphrasing the minister, but I think correctly—he basically said that no such undertaking had been given. The local naval community—I hesitate to use the word `heavy'—has been almost heavy to accept relocation of the site. It is certainly against its wishes, but it has been told that it has no other choice and it has to accept it. Now there is further distress in that it was told from the start that if it had to be relocated, the Commonwealth government, through Navy, would be prepared to bear the total cost of that relocation. It is now told that it has to be moved but it has to share the cost of the relocation. Again, it feels let down.

That is not the way to build the morale of a defence community in any city. It is typical of what seems to have been the muddle of this whole decision making process. Announcements were made on the basis of savings. The savings proved to be illusory—the work had not been done to calculate and demonstrate such savings. Now it looks as though they do not exist at all. There has been confusion over how the functions of Navy would operate if the base functions were moved to the administrative centres, so much so that we have disputes between Navy and the minister as to what will happen to the wharves. The whole thing appears to have been an almighty shambles.

The bottom line is that the government can do what it likes. If it announces that it will close the bases, it can close the bases. Nevertheless, the Australian people and the parliament are entitled to hear a convincing case from the government for the course of action it has chosen to adopt. So far we have heard no such convincing case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the vagaries of the timing of when these debates come on, it would have been my preference to speak after having heard the contributions of Senator MacGibbon, Senator Calvert, Senator Harradine, Senator Woodley and, I believe, Senator Bell. A normal expectation is that this debate in general business would have come up at about 5 o'clock. I have had to intervene in the debate at this stage simply because of timings of meetings.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pleasure to be on my feet discussing a defence issue in general business. This is my first time. Since becoming Minister for Defence in March 1990, this is the first time the opposition has decided to raise a defence matter in general business. I find it interesting, having searched over those three and a half years, with many important issues to be discussed—including the force structure review, the Gulf War and many other topics—that it has chosen to discuss the closure of three minor naval bases.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a big debate over the Gulf War.

—I am only talking about general business; I am not saying that we have had no defence debates in this chamber. I would be very foolish if I said that. Instead of picking one of the bigger issues about the important destiny of defence, the opposition has picked an issue in which it believes an unpopular decision of government can milk out a fair deal of electoral mileage. There is no running away from that; there is good electoral mileage in this for the opposition and for other minor parties.

PARA.TAB: It is not unusual that one would receive representations when it involves a base closure. It would not surprise anyone to learn that the honourable member for Denison, Mr Duncan Kerr, has on several occasions made representations about this issue to me, as one of the bases is in his electorate. When people accuse us of political bias, I think—I stand to be corrected by honourable senators here—that all three base closures are in Labor electorates. People accuse us of in some ways skewing defence priorities for political purposes. This is hardly a stand out example of that.

I must say at the beginning that I agree with one aspect of Senator Hill's contribution—when he said that the traditions of the Navy and the defence forces are important. The decision to close these bases is not a reflection by this government on those serving servicemen and women who have served in these bases in the past. I do not think it has been asserted in a direct sense that it is, but for the record's sake, let me say that I believe many who served in these particular bases served their country well.

I recall receiving a letter recently from the Premier of Tasmania wondering whether a Tasmanian town could adopt Anzac, the first Anzac ship. Whilst that matter has yet to be progressed, I did not remember his pointing out that of the six Collins class submarines, three are named after Tasmanians, which does honour in one way the traditions of the contribution that Tasmania has made in a naval sense.

This decision is essentially about what I regard as the effective use of the defence dollar. In all of Senator Hill's contribution tonight, in which he nitpicked around the edges, he did not put forward to my satisfaction any reason why these bases should continue, what vital purpose they serve or what vital contribution they make to the modern Navy. That is not in any way seeking to derogate from what they may have done in the past. That aspect was notably absent from Senator Hill's speech. He talked about traditions, he questioned savings and made all these other points, but he did not say what massive useful purpose or real purpose the three bases that are to close will have for the future effectiveness of the Navy.

Why was the decision made to chose HMAS Huon, Encounter and Moreton? Essentially, no defence force remains static. We are investing in new bases and new facilities around Australia. The implication of that, given the strategic priorities in the north and west, does not mean that we retain every existing defence facility that we have had for decades. I wonder what the local members would think if I had to ring them up and say, `We weren't going to invest some money in Stirling, Scherger, Tindal or in redoing the barracks at Townsville, et cetera. I am sorry, we can't do that because bases in other electorates are saying they have to be funded or continue to be funded at a current level and we can't redirect resources at all'.

I am certain that if the other solution is simply to do that but spend some extra money out of government revenue, the Democrats would not take such a benign attitude to this issue. They have often said that they want defence expenditure reduced by $1 billion to $2 billion, which is very much in line with what the Greens would like. I will come back to that later.

The real rub of this matter and the real hypocrisy in this chamber is with the Liberal-National party coalition. It says time and again in the budget debate, `We don't want you to put up any revenue measures. We believe that the debt reduction strategy that this government has undertaken is a question of reducing expenditure. We really believe that you should be reducing government outlays by $8 billion a year'.

This may seem passing strange, especially to my colleague Senator Carr who has heard Senator Tierney get up here on many occasions saying that he wants more money for university libraries and more money for university places; the other day it was more money for Aboriginal things. Those sorts of statements are replicated across the board by most of those who sit opposite. They want extra funding in individual cases, but they want some massive macro cut. Here is the rub: where should the cut occur? The Liberals are very much in favour of macro reduction of expenditure. Every time we put forward a micro suggestion as to where it should occur, they say that it is not in the public interest; or that it is against the states' interests; and, that we really should not be cutting that particular area.

When we really press them, the only squawk I have heard out of those opposite is that we should not build the new foreign affairs building at Barton. They are not taking into account the cost of refurbishment of existing buildings and the cost of building other new buildings if something is not done about it. That is the one white elephant they can point at. They pointed out that it was going to cost $190 million; it has come down $40 million in the meantime, but let that go through to the keeper. That is basically the opposition's position. It does not believe in any of the micro cuts one has to make to reach a macro target.

The fact is that from 1987 to 1993 the defence budget has been kept in real terms. As a result of this year's budget, which I regard as somewhat regrettable, defence expenditure will be reduced by two per cent over the next four years.
