Therefore, and anticipating in 1991 that we could not expect a real increase in defence expenditure, the Department of Defence has undertaken some of the most radical reforms of any government department in this country: the force structure review, the logistic review, the regional review, and the ready reserves. We have put these efficiencies in so that we can generate sufficient savings to keep our capital equipment program going and not only to maintain capability but to enhance capability overall.

Some people will say, as Senator Hill said today, `What is $2 1/2 million in $10 billion?' Not much. Even over 20 years, $25 million does not sound much in a budget of $70 billion. But every time one applies that $2 1/2 million across the board and starts multiplying it, it then becomes an almost life and death issue for the defence forces. That is what we are involved in and this is part of that process.

It was announced prior to the decision to close Huon, for instance, that the Ardent would be retired, as most fast attack boats are, and that there would be a different approach to training reserves which would involve them in a much higher level of activity on capital ships. What we are really arguing in this case is to keep a naval base that does not have a boat, for a start. This also argues in the face—Senator Hill argued this way today and I do not agree with him—of moving against tri-service locations. That is something we have done right around Australia. It is something that air force has done in Tasmania already, with no objection from those opposite. The air force is not located at an aerodrome at the moment, yet Senator Hill says that any navy administration should be by the sea because the navy goes to sea; what absolute nonsense.

Let me go back to the attitude of navy to this. If navy had a money tree, an unlimited expenditure, there is no doubt it would like to keep these three bases open. But, during the expenditure review committee process, it is required, like every other unit in the defence force, to put up a priority list, a hurt list, so that in the case of defence expenditure being lessened it will know which will be the first to go. Not for the first time, these three bases were put up. This is not the first year they were put up, nor will it be the last. It was not as though accurate costings had been done at that stage; estimated costings had been made.

I am under a misapprehension here, and Senator Hill quite rightly corrected me. I was given a message that we were debating Huon tonight, not two motions together, so I may skew my remarks a little more towards Huon; but that is my fault, no-one else's. I got a letter from the premier of Tasmania saying that this decision indicates that this government is not interested in defence in Tasmania. I have written back to him. I am not going to release that letter—not that there is any problem with it, but I think it is probably his privilege rather than mine to release it.

I pointed out—we will open them in January—that we have spent $1.3 million refurbishing Anglesea barracks. We have spent a further million dollars on refurbishment for the recruiting centre. We have spent a further million dollars on other refurbishments in Tasmania. There was no opposition to that expenditure from those opposite. This is a strong indicator that we in defence do not regard Tasmania as irrelevant or as somewhere that should be ignored.

It is true that, coming out of the force structure review, there was a decision to look at closing Scottsdale in Tasmania. My colleague Mr Bilney put that in place. People in Tasmania raised objections to that. I intervened and looked at the matter. Because I regarded the case as being sufficient, we intervened and changed that decision. So far, I have had no reason—no reason whatsoever—to intervene in the Huon decision. No case has been made out by Senator Hill. Regrettably, I will have to read in Hansard tomorrow the speeches of the three Tasmanians to see whether they can put forward views that can convince me.

It is true—I think Senator Calvert will refer to this—that 12,000 people in Tasmania signed a petition saying that they would like us to reverse our decision on Huon. The person who led that particular campaign was one Mr Michael Hodgman MLA. Mr Hodgman has been extremely active on this issue. I thank him for his service in the navy which he has just terminated. He was a reservist for many years. I did speak to him on the phone on one or two occasions. As a result of that, he wrote me a letter setting out 10 great reasons why we should not close Huon.

His first reason has already been alluded to: that the savings will amount to a miserly $250,000 a year. That is his figure, no-one else's. Yet he had that confirmed when Commodore Ritchie wrote back to him indicating that the savings would be more than $250,000—referring to the amount which Mr Hodgman took as being the actual amount. Let us clear up that particular area right away.

Senator Hill is right when he says that he could not get an accurate answer in the estimates committee on the actual savings as the navy was still working on it. The indicative figure that was given there—and this is still stood by as more research is done—is $700,000 a year and there is a figure of between $2.7 million and $3 million per year for the closure of the three bases.

The second reason given by Mr Hodgman is that if HMAS Huon is closed, visiting personnel will be disembarked into a situation which could be embarrassing and physically threatening. In other words, if the US fleet comes to Hobart, we need to sneak the personnel in through the back door of Huon, otherwise a few of the green demonstrators will upset them. We do not have to do that in any other city in Australia. Having had our last three national conferences—and, I am pleased to say, our next national conference—in Hobart, I have always found it to be one of the most hospitable towns I have ever visited.

His third argument is that if HMAS Huon is closed down and the integrated reserves are transferred to the defence centre at Anglesea barracks, the reserves will drop by 30 or 40 within a couple of years. There is no evidence at all to support this assertion. Integration of reserves into overall naval activity would result in greater job satisfaction and sense of belonging to the reserves, which is precisely why we have taken that action with the reserves. It also encourages those reservists who have seen the organisation as too much of a social event to resign.

His next argument says that we cannot fit the 20 permanent naval force and defence personnel, 80 reservists and six reserve cadet headquarter staff into the defence centre at Anglesea barracks. There is no need to provide permanent accommodation for all those groups mentioned by Mr Hodgman. The majority of reservists are assigned to operational activities that occur outside the defence area.

Mr Hodgman's next assertion is that it has been strongly suggested that the Tasmanian naval band—comprising 20 members—will be disbanded. We have no current plans to dissolve the band, but I notice—even with the great facilities at Huon—that we have only 11 of the 21 billets filled. This is another nonsense argument.

Mr Hodgman's next point is that the navy will not therefore be represented by a commander in Tasmania if we move out of Huon. Again, that is a nonsense and it will almost certainly be retained at that rank. He goes on to say that it would be devastating to the morale of the navy in Tasmania. I have seen no such evidence of that.

Mr Hodgman also states that Huon has national trust status. It does at a state level, not at a federal level. But we will try to respect Tasmania's laws in that way. He asserts that Tasmania will be the only state in Australia without a designated naval base. Senator Hill has corrected the record very strongly on that today by mentioning Encounter and Moreton, although a base at Cairns in Queensland will remain.

The final argument given is that defence assistance is being sought to make HMAS Huon the base for the eradication of the North Pacific Sea Star. Mr Hodgman seeks the posting of a naval diving unit to Hobart to combat the problem. Other arguments are mounted, such as our not being able to have a proper military funeral without Huon, et cetera. There is a string of fairly wild claims about it.

The most important thing to discount in this matter is Mr Hodgman's well-asserted claims over the costs. We all know that he cannot count. After all, he was the individual who bought the speaker's regalia not so long ago. He got the TV cameras in and got filmed in the speaker's regalia. Unfortunately, he anticipated a majority vote in the state parliament. Two of his colleagues ratted, and the regalia has now become a collector's piece. So I do not think I will take his opinion about adding up figures.

However, I still have a very great soft spot for Michael Hodgman. I was one of those senators in a committee room in the old parliament house who saw Michael Hodgman, along with Mrs Kelly, confront someone who had a bomb strapped to him and talk him out of that situation. Whilst I am certainly combative about this issue with Mr Hodgman, I do not doubt his courage and the courage that he showed that day.

But I think he is innumerate—except for one aspect. He was very numerate the other day when arguing for a 40 per cent pay rise for a state politician who will represent an electorate the same as a federal member for the same pay, even though there are seven of them. If the Tasmanian government is looking at micro-economic reform, it might consider looking at that decision again and changing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fewer parliamentarians.

—Fewer parliamentarians is always a good idea if that is the motive to save money. If it is simply to rig the electoral system because it takes 14.3 per cent of the vote to win three out of six rather than seven seats, one would have to have some doubts about that. But I am not going to lecture Senator Harradine on Tasmanian political history, because there would be only one certain result. I like winning, and I would not in that case.

PARA.TAB: Having discussed the attitude of the Liberal Party in general, which I find quite hypocritical, and having looked at Mr Hodgman's articles, which I find quite shallow, let me turn to the Australian Democrats' interest in this. From time to time, especially in election campaigns, we are lectured by the Democrats on defence policy. They say that we should scrap the submarines, put in fast patrol boats that have popguns on them, cut the defence expenditure by $2 billion and put everyone at AMECON and ASC out of work. In other words, they want us to set up a glorified boy scouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —$1.2 billion.
—I am not talking about Senator Woodley. I have yet to hear his views on this. I am talking about Senator Spindler's expressed views before the last election.
—I was just correcting your figures. It was $1.2 billion.

—It is $1.2 billion as calculated by the Democrats. That is the figure they put in their policy speech. When we added up the effect of the cuts, the total came to well beyond $2 billion off the defence budget.

PARA.TAB: What is in it for the Democrats to make them stir this up? Well, 12,000 people signed a petition in Tasmania. They thought that they had better jump on the bandwagon because one or two people might be roped in. They saw the politics of the matter. They took a little political opportunistic jump-in to find what they could milk out of it, even though they basically have too much contempt for the Defence Force. They do not have a universal contempt, because I know of some individual areas where Senator Woodley and his colleagues take a real interest. But on the whole, in the macro sense, they have no conception of what is required for the defence forces of this country.

I will now deal with a more confusing attitude in Senator Calvert's motion. He talks about memorials. I hope that he explains which memorial he is talking about at Huon because I do not know of one. If he is talking about memorabilia, which is a quite separate thing, he can have my assurance that the memorabilia that are associated with Huon will remain within Tasmania and would almost certainly be relocated to Anglesea Barracks. But if it is thought appropriate by the navy that some of the memorabilia should be left in the existing Huon for whatever future purposes, I will certainly listen to those arguments.

In summary, Huon will have no reserve patrol boat after January 1994. Reserves will be trained with fleet units. The naval reserve cadets do not reside at Huon. They are only dependent on it for administrative support. Large naval vessels are unable to berth at Huon. The duplication of administrative and support activities at smaller single service establishments does not represent the efficient use of resources or personnel. Naval staff can be accommodated in the Anglesea Barracks and, contrary to some claims, reservists by the nature of their activities do not require dedicated facilities.

I do not think one needs to be a QC to understand that HMAS Huon no longer has a future as a defence base. In my view, it has another future which will be an ongoing benefit to the community, particularly for young Australians. In conjunction with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Hon. Kim Beazley, it has been proposed to establish a youth training and hospitality centre at Huon. This may include some state agencies where that is practicable. The proposal will be further developed by the state director of DEET over the next few months. I think that there is a lot of potential in this proposal. This type of facility, along with its location, lends itself to on-the-job training for the building trades and hospitality apprentices.

The Hon. Ray Groom, the Premier of Tasmania, wrote to me recently outlining his proposition for Huon and the future of the property. In my response, I made it clear to him that, while I do not intend to change the decision to close Huon, I recognise that any commercial use of the site is unlikely. This point was taken into account, considering future use options.

A decision has been made to close Huon. At this stage the government has no intention of changing that decision. I can appreciate that some see this as a separate issue, but it is not. It must be viewed in the context of what we in defence are achieving overall in the maintenance of a viable Australian Defence Force.

Some of the press articles referring to this issue—Senator Hill was very studious not to refer to them, so I congratulate him for that—implied that, if the Senate carried a motion here today, I would have to reverse the decision. That is not the case, never will be the case and is not a desirable thing to do. If our judgment is wrong on this and other matters, we will be judged by the electorate. That is exactly what we are here for. That is when we will face our jury.

I wish to assert here tonight that the last thing we wish to do, in the interests of the Australian Defence Force, is set up a similar system that exists in the US Congress. Any US administration wanting to close a base, alter a base or do anything else, must first get congressional approval. Therefore, trade-offs and second-best choices are made to achieve a result.

I do not think anything that I have said tonight will convince any of the senators who contribute to the debate to rethink their position, because they have their mind made up. I hope I am not so narrow-minded that I cannot listen or later read their comments and mull over them. But so far in this debate, in the discussions at estimates committee, the correspondence that I have received, the conversations with Mr Michael Hodgman and others and the letters from the premier, a convincing case for the retention of Huon and, in turn, Encounter and Moreton has not been established, other than that we need a naval presence because that is important or that we are in some way ignoring the traditions of the defence forces. In these times, considering the configuration of our defence forces, sometimes we have to make hard decisions. I really think that the opposition is trying to work both sides of the street.

I will conclude with an anecdote about making cuts, even though it is not directly relevant to this issue. When Mr Downer was the shadow minister for defence he put out a press release in which he said `Coalition slams $19m army music bill'. That was a nice opportunistic press release saying that basically the government was spending too much money on bands. Mr Downer drew all sorts of illogical conclusions from that. He already knew that the matter was under review. The government then announced the decision to cut back army bands. We cut them back in specific locations, moved them to reservists and amalgamated them.

Senator Hill, as his successor, put out some advice to all coalition senators and members on army bands. He did not actually send a copy of this advice to us. I am happy to table this document or have it incorporated in Hansard. This is a good example of weasel words because his predecessor had already attacked expenditure on army bands. When the government did something about it, the opposition tried to work both sides of the street. Senator Hill's document said, `We believe Senator Ray is out of step with community attitudes and has gone too far.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have sent you that.

—Senator Hill did not send that advice to me but, nevertheless, I got a copy of it. The document went on to say that cost savings could be `more effectively achieved by streamlining where possible.' Senator Hill used all the usual weasel words. The facts are: the government did something hard a few months after the opposition said that it should do it. After the government had done it, the opposition jumped in like a big brown dog of political opportunism. It said, `Let's get in there and stir it up; let's stir up parochial thinking. We'll pick off Western Australia because the permanent band has gone there; then we will pick off South Australia and so on.' The opposition agrees with the policy in principle and in the macro, but it never agrees with it in the micro. If it can work both sides of the street and not get caught doing it, that is what it will do.

PARA.TAB: This debate tonight is a microcosm of the general political debate in this country. The opposition says `Government expenditure is out of control; it is too high. The deficit reduction program should not be affected by tax rises or revenue rises anywhere, even if they are neutral. The government cannot do that. We, as a tough, efficient and united opposition, demand cuts to government expenditure.'

When we put the acid on the opposition and ask it where it is going to cut expenditure, it says, `I am sorry we have jumped Fightback. We are in a holding pattern until we establish who is going to lead us in the next election. We will announce our policy when we are good and ready. Maybe then we will announce where we will cut expenditure.' But the opposition will not do that because it has adopted the Petro Georgio tactic of hit and not be hit.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are feeling a bit sensitive there, Robert, aren't you.
—It is true. I have quite an admiration for him.
—Well, he creamed you; you have to say that.
—He beat us in last Victorian election.
—No, creamed you.
—I think even Tony Eggleton could have organised a campaign to beat us in the last election in Victoria. I think even he could have got a successor.

PARA.TAB: This is a microcosm of political debate in which this opposition will make demands that we cut expenditure and thump the table with the right-wing views of Senator Kemp and the Institute of Public Affairs. The opposition will say, `We love Margaret Thatcher. We love Reagan economics. We love all those things. Get in there, get the knife out. Slash and burn.'

The moment the government makes the first cuts, all the local Liberals, including Senator Newman—I hope she gets well, by the way; I would send her a cheerio if I could, because she will follow this debate eventually—are handing out leaflets and telling everyone they will lose their jobs under the Labor government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will clarify the part of the motion that Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, had a problem with. In saying `memorials' I meant memorials of battles fought and the memorabilia in that place. Whilst they may be memorabilia, they certainly are memorials to the local navy.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting to see that Senator Ray gave 20 minutes of his very important time to come in here and debate this matter which, in Tasmania's case, involves a very small amount of money. The Minister for Defence spent 20 minutes pouring scorn on this side of politics and the Democrats over our concerns about HMAS Huon in Hobart. As Senator Hill pointed out, he does not even know the amount of money that will be saved. It could be anything between $200,000 and $700,000 a year. No doubt we will find out at some future date. Senator Ray accused both the coalition and the Democrats of trying to make cheap electoral mileage out of this particular matter.

It is very interesting to note that there was no mention made of this proposed closure in Tasmania before the last election. Not one word was said about this. We talk about being cautious about what we say to voters, but I can assure Senator Ray that he does not live in Hobart so he does not know the impact that the proposed closure—and he confirmed tonight that it is definitely on—has had on the community. It is not just the closure of HMAS Huon or the money that is saved, it is the attitude of the government towards Tasmania and particularly Hobart.

I note that Mr Kerr holds the seat of Denison by a large majority. I wonder what that majority would have been if the government had told the people of Tasmania before the election—when it lied to the Tasmanians, just as it did to all Australians—that Senator Schacht was going to come to Tasmania and attempt to scrap CSIRO or change it so much that it was unworkable. The government did not tell the Tasmanian electorate that it was going to come down and cut $1 million off the Antarctic division budget this year and more next year and cut the number of ships from two to one. The government certainly did not mention the closure of HMAS Huon. Those three matters would have made things rather difficult for Mr Kerr.

Senator Ray ought to think again when he comes into this chamber and accuses us of cheap political mileage and hypocrisy. He also needs to understand that the announcement in the budget that the government was going to close HMAS Huon has caused tremendous outrage in the community. He mentioned that there were 12,000 signatures on a petition. That might not sound a lot if one lives in Sydney or Melbourne, but I can assure him that if one lives in Hobart it is a pretty good effort to get 12,000 signatures on a petition. These people are outraged at the decision.

What he did not mention is that HMAS Huon is home for 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy staff, 108 active reservists and 40 inactive reservists. In terms of the overall defence budget it is a very small item. But as far as Hobart is concerned it is rather important. I am pleased that my colleagues from Tasmania Senator Bell and Senator Harradine, who also know how the people in Hobart feel, are supporting my motion tonight.

The committee that was set up to save HMAS Huon has been successful in gaining a tremendous amount of support, both from the community and also from the RSL. The new RSL national President, Major General William `Digger' James, announced that the RSL will oppose the closure of the base. He has been supported by the Tasmanian RSL President. Those people know the feeling that is generated in the community. They know that naval ex-servicemen in Tasmania are outraged by this decision.

The history of HMAS Huon goes back to 1 July 1911 when it was drafted into service. It was originally known as Cerberus VI. There are quite a few other Cerberus bases around the world. I suppose the most action that Huon saw in those days was deciding what to call the base.

The beautiful site where the base is situated is part of the Queens Domain that was given to the people of Tasmania in the last century by Queen Victoria. As anybody who has visited Tasmanian knows, Tasmanians are very proud of their heritage and very proud of their old buildings and important sites. HMAS Huon is one of those sites.

As Senator Robert Ray said, it is listed under the state National Trust. It is not listed under the National Trust of Australia—so what? We see it as a very important building. It contains a number of priceless naval memorabilia and artefacts that have been collected over the years. At one stage it was named HMAS Derwent after the river. It was renamed HMAS Huon in only 1942.

The naval history of Tasmania goes way back. In fact, if I remember correctly, the Lady Nelson, a replica of which has been built in Tasmania, served in Tasmania; it was an exploring ship in Tasmanian waters and later went around Australia; I think it was recognised as probably the first Australian navy ship; and it was based in Hobart in its early days.

We all know that Admiral Collins, a Tasmanian and one of our naval war heroes, was one of the many Tasmanians who had been recruited over the years. I believe that it was no accident. Money is just not everything. Because of our tradition of being an island state, our maritime history and partly because of HMAS Huon, it is no accident that Tasmania has the highest per capita enlistment in the Royal Australian Navy and has very strong historical associations with the proud record of our navy in battle. Admiral Collins was one of those naval people who was proudly a Tasmanian.

What price can one put on recruitment? As Senator Hill pointed out, I would have thought a naval establishment would have to be near the water. It seems now that the navy will be moved to Anglesea Barracks along with the air force and the army. Senator Robert Ray made light of the air force at the barracks. The air force has a very minor role in Tasmania. It never was situated at the airport. It has always had its own premises elsewhere in Hobart. But comparing the navy with the air force is quite a furphy.

The last time this particular matter came up and it was floated that the base was going to be closed the federal member for Denison, Mr Duncan Kerr, at the time lobbied the then Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley. He was successful. It seems that Senator Robert Ray is taking a much more hard-nosed approach. I would like to know why the government has decided to pick on Tasmania first. As I said earlier, Senator Schacht decided to try to disband CSIRO and then the Antarctic division. In 1989 Mr Beazley gave a commitment that the base would remain open. This decision certainly was not made known to the Tasmanian people before the last election.

It is interesting to note that the Labor members and senators in Tasmania have been very quiet about this matter; we have not heard a peep out of them, not one word. Not one of them has come forward to support the committee that has been set up to try to save HMAS Huon; not one has been prepared to support the wishes of the Tasmanian community. I think this will be remembered by the Tasmanian electors.

I wonder how practical this move to Anglesea Barracks will be. Anglesea Barracks itself is not a large area. I think it is highly unlikely that Anglesea Barracks has the room, and without a vessel or a naval base on the water Tasmania's association with the Royal Australian Navy will become a laughing stock. Therefore, the once proud record of recruitment in Tasmania will drop off. What price can we put on recruitment?

A nephew of mine was recruited in the navy in Hobart. He studied in the UK and is now a Lieutenant-Surgeon in the navy. There are many more like him who come out of Hobart. If the young people know that they will have to spend their time at Anglesea Barracks, that they will have no training, or very little, on the water and that they will be jumbled in with the other two forces, I would be very surprised if they will be all that interested in coming forward.

I know that there has been a lot of speculation, but this will leave Tasmania worse off than the other states because at least the other states will have some naval bases left. The closure of the other two bases will not mean that those two states affected will not have a naval base on the water. I note a particular letter that was written to the Hobart Mercury by a mother of a young sailor, who unfortunately is no longer with us. It is rather a long letter. I do not wish to read it all out tonight, but I feel that she expressed the feeling of people in Hobart. She said:
I am disappointed that I find the need to write about the closure of HMAS Huon.

To give you a brief background of my involvement with HMAS Huon, my son at 12 years of age wanted to join the reserve cadets but being too young was told to come back when he turned 14, however he was told he could attend every Tuesday night until a petty-officer at HMAS Huon said he was sick of seeing him and issued him with a uniform 12 months before his official age. He joined the RAN as a junior recruit at 15 1/2 years and trained at HMAS Leeuwin, completed his term and was accepted to HMAS Nirimba where he graduated at the top of his class. He was further honoured with the position of right hand marker at his graduation ceremony.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, he died later. But, as his mother pointed out:

PARA.TAB: For a saving of $250,000 I am surprised that the Federal Government would remove the only permanent naval presence in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Tasmania receives only about $20 million of the total $9 billion defence budget. I presume that with the intended closure of Huon that will be even less. I know that the powers that be have their eyes on the north, but I think it is most important that the defence forces have a significant presence in each state, if for no other reason than to encourage young people to become part of the service.

PARA.TAB: As I said, Tasmania has always played its part, particularly through the navy. But after all the heat had gone out of this and we found that it may go ahead—with the reason expounded being to save money—I found it most unusual to find that the Huon will now not be disposed of; it will be kept and, as Senator Robert Ray said tonight, may be picked up by DEET to be used as a place for training in catering and the like.

But we already have a very successful catering establishment in Hobart. We have plenty of space for training young people. In fact, the Commonwealth centre in Hobart has about six or seven floors that have nobody in them; they are vacant—very valuable space doing nothing. If we are going to keep this building, why would we turn around and use Huon for training purposes, which will probably cost about as much money as it would cost to keep it open and be run by naval personnel? It just does not make sense.

The government will be up for an expense, whichever department it is. Just because Senator Ray wants to make some microcuts at the edge of the defence budget of a few hundred thousand dollars, the morale and the association with the navy in Hobart will be severed.

I believe that the federal government has an obligation to the state of Tasmania, which, after all, is part of the Commonwealth—although sometimes I wonder whether it is or not. The people in the state pay taxes and I think it is important that the government ensure that the state has an active naval presence and a base which is applicable to the needs of such a presence.

The government talks about money. I took a bit of time this afternoon to look back through some of my public works reports. I note that this year, just on the navy—and these are the bigger projects—the government spent $9.9 million at Nowra on stage two of the HMAS Albatross; it relocated the Naval Support Command Headquarters in New South Wales at a cost of another $13.4 million; then, again in New South Wales, it spent $73 million on HMAS Waterhen.

Last, but not least, of course, it relocated the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong at a cost of $12 1/2 million. That hydrographic office was up for grabs by every politician in the Labor Party. It could have gone anywhere. In fact, it could have gone to Hobart. If the government is talking about saving money, I remind it that it already had a facility in Hobart that perhaps was underutilised. The Australian Hydrographic Office could have gone to Hobart. But no, it went into a very good area—an area that was politically favourable to the government. It is the same old story of playing favourites, just like Mrs Kelly has with the sports grants. Again the $12.5 million was spent in New South Wales. It seems that unless people live in New South Wales or Victoria they will not have any money spent for defence or for any other reason because it is not politically expedient.

Senator Ray said tonight that he has not heard any good reason why HMAS Huon should be kept. All I am saying is that it has been established there since 1911; it has been proved to be the most productive recruiting area for naval personnel in Australia—that in itself must have some value; it is something that Tasmanians are very proud of; and at present it is catering for almost 200 naval personnel. If it is going to be kept and money is going to be spent on it from another government department, what is the difference? Why get the Tasmanian people offside and run the risk of reducing the intake of naval recruits just to save a few hundred thousand dollars?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little disappointed that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) did not stay to hear the debate tonight. I certainly do understand the pressure that is on him. It is not necessarily a criticism, but it is said because, if he had stayed, perhaps I would have been disposed to take him a little more seriously. He did assume that he knew what the Democrat position—and, I assume, the position of the rest of the speakers in the debate—would be, and then answered what he believed to be the position taken, which is rather a risky position to take in any debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like to say to him that, in fact, the Democrat position is based on a policy formulation which is both dynamic and realistic. I would even have been prepared to agree with the minister, to a certain extent. I place on the record, in case he reads it, that I do agree with the government's deficit reduction strategy; I do agree with the minister about the budget constraints which he faces; and I certainly agree with him that the Democrats have projected budget cuts, particularly in the area of defence, in previous years. But I would like to say to him that we have carefully costed those cuts and that the cuts are made very specifically and certainly not necessarily in the areas in which the present minister would make those cuts.

I was interested that he spoke about Mr Hodgman as not being able to add up. I am sorry that the minister did not accept my interjection, because by continuing—and he has done it at least twice in this place since I have been here—to speak of the Democrat policy as cutting $2 billion off the defence budget, he is simply inaccurate. I am sorry but I do not accept his explanation that somewhere or other he has added up what we were going to do and has come to the figure of $2 billion. In fact, our figure, which was nearer to $1 billion, was very carefully worked out. I do not think the minister ought to talk about the ability of other people to add up. Perhaps he might be prepared in another debate to admit his mistake in that regard.

The question I have to ask the minister is why it is that we continue to concentrate our naval forces in Sydney. I do acknowledge, of course, the development of Stirling in Western Australia. It seems to me that, whenever cuts are to be made, it is always to the peripheral bases. Certainly, in terms of regional development, the Democrats would place the emphasis on spreading our defence forces into regional areas rather than concentrating on places such as Sydney.

The minister talked about making hard decisions. He knows as well as I do that the really hard decision that some government will have to make in the future is to remove the fleet base from Sydney, along with ECAC, the East Coast Armaments Complex, and the dockyard. This is the hard decision that he will not take. So, in fact, his accusation that the opposition or the Democrats will not make hard decisions is really a furphy. I challenge the minister, with regard to the strategic review that is being done from which Australia's defence white paper is being prepared, to allow that process to happen before he begins to make the kinds of cuts that we are dealing with here tonight.

I support the coalition's amendment because it asks the right questions and gives the minister an opportunity to come up with answers which will satisfy the Australian community. After all, it is not the Royal Labor Navy or the Royal Ray Navy, it is the Royal Australian Navy. So let him give the answers which will satisfy the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two elements to this debate: firstly, the decision itself, and, secondly, the justification for it. The decision clearly was driven by a misperception of costs involved.

PARA.TAB: I agree very much with Senator Ray's contention that defence is a dynamic thing and things change. In a sense, defence facilities around Australia are very much a prisoner of history—of what has developed in the past. There is need for change, and there is change that has to be made. I think the army is probably the worst in this, with its drill halls around the place; particularly in relation to the reserve, there is a real need to relocate a number of those.

Senator Ray made a great deal about the fact that Senator Hill did not have time in his speech to develop the reason for the retention of these bases. The retention is really quite simple and self-evident. Navy has to be represented in all the Australian states, and it does need a shop window in the capital cities. It does recruit in all states. We simply cannot have a defence force that is based on Queensland recruitment alone, even though it might provide the majority of enlistees in all three services, we have to have a national effort. There are naval administration matters within the Commonwealth that have to be administered through the state and, of course, there is the matter of ship visits to capitals.

What we had at the estimates committee which led to this situation was a total lack of any justification for the decision. We had some very unfortunate naval people having to defend the indefensible. To be very kind to them, they had a really romantic view on the savings. What they did was pure Keatingesque economics. They came up with a figure for the cost of the three bases and said, `Well, if we close the bases we can pull all that money into our hip pocket and we're going to be that much better off'. Then they went ahead and admitted that they were going to keep pretty well all the personnel—they would get rid of some of the civilian ones, but the rest of the naval uniformed personnel would be redeployed around the navy.

It was really as silly a decision as the decision of a former CNS when he was in the position of being told by this government that he had to cut $X million from the RAN budget. He closed the amphibious squadron in Brisbane when it consisted of HMAS Tobruk and all the LCHs and when 6th Brigade in Brisbane was tasked with training in amphibious warfare. We had a very good facility set up at HMAS Moreton with the roll-on, roll-off facilities. They had all been developed under the brilliance of Captain Bill Owen, who was then the senior naval officer in Queensland. But it went without any thought or any analysis, purely to satisfy a requirement in the budget preparation at the last minute. It is crystal clear from the evidence given to the Senate estimates committees that history has repeated itself at the last minute in the preparation of this budget.

I want to talk about Moreton. We have heard a bit about Huon and we have heard a bit about Encounter. I accept that HMAS Moreton is a facility that is run down. I deplore the speed with which the government ran it down. It has done nothing to encourage the RAN reserve in Queensland—a body that had about 180 operationally efficient reservists for many years. The figure today would be something like nine or 10. There may be considerably more than that on the books as reservists, but operationally efficient numbers are minuscule. We once had, when that amphibious squadron was going, probably 1,000 regulars at the place. But the decision was taken in the budget and almost overnight the equipment and furniture and a lot of things were auctioned off. The government moved with remarkable speed to get out of it.

The point I want to develop is the need for a naval basing facility within southern Queensland. One of the great requirements for the RAN is not the Indian Ocean and the shift to HMAS Stirling in the west, which has been driven by parochial considerations of the Labor Party to hold seats in Western Australia. The navy has a great requirement to be active amongst the Pacific island states. It is more logical that that be supported out of Queensland than out of Sydney.

Ultimately, of course, the east coast base of the navy must be Gladstone, as I have said for many years, where there will be very considerable cost savings, in ship steaming time and the rest of it, getting into exercise and deployment areas. Having a facility on the east coast able to operate with the army, particularly if the government goes ahead with what has been in the papers recently of buying two of the Newport class landing ships to replace Tobruk and Jervis Bay, becomes paramount. That cannot be done in the south; it has to be done in Queensland, and preferably in Brisbane with 6th Brigade.

The evidence that was given to the estimates committee was that the navy would move to Bulimba. I put a plea in to the minister to get some people to think about this and think about it in some depth. Bulimba could be developed to provide a very efficient base for an amphibious squadron to service the requirements in the southern Pacific area. There is plenty of land there for vehicles and stores, even for a helicopter landing pad; there is wharfage at the present time which would accommodate these new ships if they are bought; and there are ramp facilities available.

We have to look at the requirements not only from a military point of view but also from a civilian point of view, for example, cyclone relief and probably earthquake problems. An earthquake erupting in Rabaul might require very considerable aid to the civilian population in that part of New Guinea and the ability to support and replenish and store ships to provide that aid becomes very important.

I am saying to the minister that he should put a bit more thought into what is being done rather than maintain the adhockery that we have clearly and demonstrably had up to the present. We are dealing with something here that really was an impromptu, last-minute decision—something to save, I understood him to say in his speech tonight, between $2.7 million to $3 million. Since Encounter was about $700,000, Huon was again about $700,000 and HMAS Moreton was $1.3 million, I do not think his mathematics are any better than the numeracy skills that he ascribed to the Hon. Michael Hodgman. I think his figures were a bit rocky on that.

We are dealing with an impromptu decision. I agree that there is a case for reviewing facilities—by all means, let us run the Defence Force so that we maximise the return for the taxpayer's dollar—but we have to take the view that the defence industry is not a corporation. It does not live or die by its balance sheet. It is involved with issues that have many intangibles and unforeseeable factors. The Defence Force is here to serve the interest and the national security of this country on a basis measured in centuries, not in days or balance sheets, for a government that gets into great trouble and runs up such an appalling overseas debt as this government has.

Let us put a little more thought and care into what we are doing with a body that is as important to Australia as the Australian Defence Force. It is not something that can be subjected to heavy funding one year when there is a good wool clip and cut back the next year when there is a drought. The national interest demands some degree of stability and, above all, it demands a degree of planning and thought. We certainly have not seen that in relation to the closure of these three facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support this motion with pleasure. We have not been convinced by what has been contributed to this debate by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray. I find it quite easy to agree with Senator MacGibbon on this occasion about the description of the romantic view of savings that was held by the officers at the estimates committee. This should be considered with a great degree of cynicism. If the motivation is to cut defence spending, then I really think that other areas could have been considered a lot more closely.

PARA.TAB: Without attempting to address the debate in the sort of detail that was brought to it by either Senator Calvert or Senator MacGibbon, it would seem obvious to even the only barely interested observer that instead of spending billions on submarines—a relic of the cold war and something of little practical application in terms of defending Australia from its real threats of illegal immigrants, smuggling, drug trade and even of pirates in the South China Sea—the priorities in that area could have been reassessed. Perhaps they could be replaced with a fleet of 30 Tasmanian-built seacats which are devastatingly fast ships.

I can see the potential for initial training in Tasmania based at HMAS Huon and perhaps providing a real defence against the threats that we face in the north of Australia. I do not think it was at all a sensible excuse to give that the government was considering cuts in defence spending and that this was the primary motivation here.

I hope that Senator Ray's contribution has not revealed that there is a slight chance that motivation was governed by personal feelings regarding the Hodgman family. If there was any suggestion of that I would be horrified, but to listen to his speech one might be justified in thinking that. Nevertheless, with that aside, I think it is a misguided attempt to save money in that area and we support the motion of the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for this debate has almost concluded. In fact, if the motion is not put within the next two minutes, there will be no vote in this chamber. So that prevents me, unfortunately, from outlining the reasons that I wanted to advance in support of Senator Calvert's motion, which I strongly endorse.

PARA.TAB: However, as I have the permission of the various whips and also that of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter, written today by Alderman Doone Kennedy, urging that the Minister for Defence reconsider his decision to close the navy establishment in Tasmania.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: LORD MAYOR'S OFFICE
Town Hall
Hobart
Tasmania

I am writing to request that you reconsider your decision to close the Navy's establishment in Tasmania, HMAS HUON. I am aware that many others have written to you on this matter and I am also aware of the broad thrust of the responses which your office has made to their letters

Much of the argument against closure of HMAS HUON has been founded on issues of tradition and heritage. Tasmania's contribution to the Navy has been significant—far greater than might have been expected from such a small state. I believe that tradition and heritage are important factors in the need to retain a dedicated naval presence in Tasmania, not just because of their meaning for the past but, even more importantly, because of what they mean for the future.

The simple fact is that Tasmanians have a very great deal to offer the Navy. The fact that our Defence policy is focused around operations to the North and West of Australia must, of course, be balanced by the need to draw support and people—particularly reservists—from around the nation.

Your own Defence policy seeks to bring about an increased reliance on Reserves. In those areas of activity for which they are capable of being trained, such as Patrol Boat operations, the Naval Reserves represent a particularly cost-effective source of manpower and there is every indication that the Navy's need for them will grow.

It is the nature of Naval Reserve employment that the people involved must to a large degree be trained, led and nurtured where they live. I know that your response to others who have written has been that ". . . sea-going reservists will train and serve. . . in Fleet units operating from. . . Sydney, Perth, Darwin and Cairns" What that response misses though, is that there is more to recruiting, training and retaining skills currency than the annual continuous training periods spent away from home each year. The proposed naval staff in Hobart will be a part of delivering that training and support, but in significantly less suitable accommodation.

The Defence Forces make a considerable investment in the training, leadership, teambuilding and corporate ethos of their permanent personnel. A sense of identity and ownership are an important outcome of that investment. The decision to close HMAS HUON makes it clear that, despite a growing need for their services, you are not prepared to make a minimal investment in the Naval Reserve for the same outcomes. Their needs for corporate identity are not any less than those of their permanent counterparts by virtue of the part-time nature of their service.

Elsewhere in Australia, the process of integration of Reserves and Permanent Naval Forces means that the Naval Reserve will share this kind of support with their permanent counterparts. The disappearance of a dedicated naval facility in the state of Tasmania, however, will have a devastating impact on Naval Reservists here.

While I don't predict an immediate mass walkout of Tasmanian Naval Reservists, it is clear that the closure of HMAS HUON will lead to a steady decline in this increasingly needed manpower resource and a consequent abandonment of your policy of increased reliance on the Reserve. There are clear messages for Naval Reservists around the nation in such a development.

Implicit in your responses to other correspondents is the suggestion that the only function of HMAS HUON was to support the attached training vessel, HMAS ARDENT. This certainly was one of the functions which necessitated a waterfront location. It was also only one of a considerably wider range of functions which more than justify a dedicated Naval establishment. The benefits of HUON in terms of identity and location will not be replaced by various cramped quarters dispersed around Anglesea Barracks.

Had your office, or any of those involved in the decision to close HUON looked more closely at those functions, perhaps it might have been recognised that they justified the minimal investment directly attributable to continued use of the establishment. As I noted above, the Navy in Tasmania has a great deal to offer the Navy nationally and can make a cost effective contribution.

Returning to withdrawal of the attached training vessel, this decision in no means justifies closure of HUON and, indeed, it is not particularly relevant to closure. The other functions being performed there justify retention of the establishment. Moreover, I am advised that studies undertaken by the Naval Reserve in Hobart well before the budget decision, led to the identification of 13 of the 25 naval positions in HUON for reallocation elsewhere within Navy once HMAS ARDENT was withdrawn. In other words, the real manpower savings were already achieved and closure of HUON makes very little further difference. Its retention as a facility ideally suited to training and support of Reserves is thus at minimal cost.

The claim that the decision to close HMAS HUON was made to save money has already failed scrutiny. The fact, admitted at the recent Senate Estimates Committee hearing, that nobody knew what would be saved is relevant, although I would have thought anyone could have identified the direct salary and maintenance costs attributable to the establishment itself, rather than the functions it supports. It seems inescapable that savings, if any, will be minimal and they will be at least partly replaced by new costs in respect of whatever new premises are occupied.

Given the paltry sum of money involved, it seems to me that, far from being about savings, the decision was an attempt to `cry poor' at the budget table. Indeed the comments, reported in the local media, of the Chief of Naval Staff during his visit to Tasmania, that the decision demonstrated that Defence was being `cut to the bone' reinforce this assessment.

Similarly, the recent decision to retain HUON in Commonwealth hands for use as a "Youth Training and Hospitality Centre" is open to question. Duplicating existing State facilities and expenditure, this decision, too, appears to have been made without the benefit of advice from anyone who knows what is happening in Tasmania.

Along with media coverage of the training centre proposal was a report that the memorabilia presently held in HUON would be retained there after closure. This proposal is gratuitously offensive to those who have been evicted and are now faced with deprivation of their `family heirlooms'. Many of the items involved are not Commonwealth property, but belong to the various messes.

This issue will not `go away'. As Lord Mayor of Hobart, I have given my full support to the campaign to save HMAS HUON. I have also given my full support to those Tasmanian Senators who will vote on the matter in the Senate this week.
In summary. I ask you to reverse a decision which:

PARA.TAB: saves virtually no money,

SPEECH.PARA: flies in the face of a policy of increased reliance on the Naval Reserve,
will significantly diminish support to, motivation of and, ultimately, availability of Naval Reservists,
has every appearance of being motivated by political posturing rather than savings,
is being followed by further politically inept decision making (the Youth Training Centre proposal); and
will be a continuing and escalating political problem for your government and for its elected representatives in Tasmania.

Minister, the state of Tasmania and its naval personnel are worth considerably more than to be treated as a political football. I strongly doubt that the point has really been reached where it is beyond the Navy's management to find real savings which would allow it to operate within budgetary guidance—rather than close down support for those who take a growing part in keeping `the sharp end' operating.

The decision to close HUON makes no meaningful contribution to the achievement of savings. Rather it diminishes the Navy's ability to make the best use of a cost effective manpower resource, in return for minimal investment. I can assure you that more and more people here are coming to see this fact, and increasingly, to resent this easily reversible decision
Yours sincerely.
(Alderman Doone Kennedy)
LORD MAYOR
Wednesday. 24th November. 1993

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—The Joint Standing Committee on Migration, in a letter of today's date signed by the chairman, has raised with the President a matter of privilege under standing order 81. The committee states that an article contained in today's Canberra Times indicates that there has been an unauthorised disclosure of a draft report of the committee.

The President is required to consider whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to the criteria set out in privilege resolution No. 4. The President has explained to the Senate in previous cases how he applies these criteria. He gives precedence to a motion if a matter is capable of being regarded by the Senate as meeting the criterion relating to reasonable protection for the Senate and for committees against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them, and if there is no other readily available remedy.

Paragraph (16) of the Senate's privilege resolution No. 6 declares that the disclosure of a document confidential to a committee or proceedings in private session of a committee, without the authorisation of the committee or the Senate, may be held to be a contempt.
Past decisions by the Senate indicate that the unauthorised disclosure of committee documents is regarded as potentially obstructive to committee operations and as a matter of some seriousness.
The President therefore determines that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence in accordance with standing order 81.

On behalf of the President, I table the letter received from the joint committee. Senator McKiernan may now give a notice of motion. As the Senate is not sitting next week, standing order 81 allows Senator McKiernan to move a motion now, without notice, if he chooses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 81, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

SPEECH.PARA: Having regard to the article in the Canberra Times of 25 November 1993, headed `MPs to press for softer detention rules for refugees', whether there was a disclosure of a document that is confidential to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, or of proceedings in private session of that Committee, without the authorisation of the Committee, and, if so, whether a contempt was committed by that disclosure.

The committee viewed this matter very seriously when it came to its attention this morning. The article in question appeared on the front page of the Canberra Times which, of course, is readily available in this building. An urgent meeting of the committee was organised after the deputy chair of the committee, Senator Short, and I conferred in the chamber at 12.45 p.m. today, that being the earliest possible opportunity. At that meeting there was a large attendance of committee members, all of whom treated the matter very seriously. As a result of the committee's decision at that meeting, I wrote a letter to the President drawing the attention of the Senate to the matter.

PARA.TAB: Because it is a joint committee, a similar letter was also written to the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The committee was somewhat uncertain what to do, and the matter has been raised in the House of Representatives. That means that perhaps the matter could be referred to two privileges committees of the parliament. In relation to that I would suggest that either the presiding officers confer and make recommendations or suggestions or give a direction as to which committee ought to look at it or, alternatively, that the two privileges committees themselves might give a consideration as to which of them should consider the matter and further examine it.

On the seriousness of the matter, there is just one further explanation I would care to make at this point in time. This is serious because the confidentiality of committee proceedings has been intruded upon and interfered with. The committee is far from making final decisions on this matter. The members of the committee have given this inquiry a great deal of attention, and we hope to report to the parliament when we have finally completed our deliberations in a matter of three weeks or so.

There is concern about the seriousness of intrusion and interference in parliamentary processes. I would suggest that many committees of the parliament would not be able to continue to operate were their initial draft documents freely and openly available through the pages of the national media of this country.

A second and perhaps much more serious matter is how the material that appeared in the newspaper today could be treated by some people who have a big interest in the matter. You would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are a number of people, who are not the subject matter of the committee's inquiry, who are detained in immigration detention centres in different parts of Australia—quite a substantial number of people. We know that in the past incorrect advice has been given and distortions made of public statements to those people. I have a great concern, which, indeed, is shared by some of the committee members, about how this matter might be reported to those individuals who are held in detention centres, perhaps creating for them a further air of false hope that they might be allowed to remain in Australia.

Of course, that is not the case and cannot be the case because the committee is not examining the applications made by those people who are currently in detention—omitting those 53 people who arrived on our shores by boat last evening. But there are over 200 other people in detention. I personally have some knowledge that in the past newspaper articles, television reports and radio commentary have been distorted and given those people false hopes that they might be allowed to remain in Australia.

The committee is aware that, despite the fact that we have tried to allay their expectations, many of those people are waiting with some expectation that there might be some outcome for them in the joint standing committee's deliberations. That is not the case—and I have to say that with some vigour here tonight. The committee is examining and making recommendations on future detention policies and practices of the Australian government. I hope that my short statement here tonight will help in stopping or ceasing to commence any form of propaganda that may be used with those people who are currently in detention and who are awaiting legal decisions on whether or not they will be allowed to remain in Australia.
I thank the Senate for the opportunity to bring this matter before the chamber tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Having to bring these matters forward certainly is not something we, as committee chairs and members, particularly enjoy. It is very irresponsible of the journalist and certainly irresponsible of the newspaper to publish this material.

PARA.TAB: I have one other important matter to mention before I sit down. All available members of the committee who were present at our lunchtime meeting today were questioned as to whether they had, or had knowledge of anybody from within their offices having, in any way passed this material on to the journalist concerned. All of the members available answered in the negative—and I make that statement for the record.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Employment, Education and Training Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 November on motion by Senator Zakharov:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on aspects of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. I would like to reiterate Senator Zakharov's thanks to the committee secretariat for the effort that they put in to ensure that this report was brought into the chamber within the time set down. The report contains a dissenting report, which I can do no other than condemn as an inaccurate and factually wrong statement. The inquiry was conducted within a limited time frame. Therefore, the report is not definitive in respect of the technical detail of the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993. Rather, as has been said by Senator Zakharov, the chair of the committee, the report addresses the key themes of the proposed legislation.

PARA.TAB: The committee received 32 submissions from various parties. We had three public hearings and received evidence from all key organisations. There were three terms of reference for the committee to analyse. Those terms of reference were:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Whether the proposals in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill would promote a more co-operative relationship between employers and employees and a more dynamic workplace culture in:

PARA.TAB: (a)unionised workplaces; and
(b) non-unionised workplaces; and

SPEECH.PARA: 2The implications for the States of the proposals in the Bill with respect to the States' rights and responsibilities; and
3Other related implications arising from the Bill.

In summary, the report supports the general thrust of the government's proposed legislation. We heard evidence from a number of employer organisations that the bill was a negative rather than a positive approach to enhancing industrial relations, but no evidence was really presented to support these claims.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the outset, there is also a dissenting report. It is appropriate that I redress some of the spurious claims contained within that. Firstly, I would like to go to the question of consultation. The opposition members on the committee made great play about the consultation process, specifically as it related to employers and Liberal state governments. They have promoted a view in their dissenting report that there was little or no consultation with these parties. The facts simply do not support their claim.

With regard to the states, the process began back in December 1992. The issues likely to form the legislation were discussed at a meeting of state premiers in Perth in December of that year. The then Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, convened a special meeting of Labor ministers on 16 December 1992, where the states were provided with further information. The legislation was again discussed with the states in Brisbane in April of this year. State officials were fully briefed in September of this year.

The new minister, Minister Brereton, wrote to state ministers in early October 1993, providing a copy of the draft legislation as it stood at that time to ensure that the states had sufficient time to examine the legislation before the next meeting which was held at the end of October. The minister also advised the states in writing of progressive changes that occurred before that date. In addition to all of these meetings, the minister had individual meetings with all state ministers, plus further exchanges of correspondence during the development of the government's legislation.

As for consultation with other major players in the game, this also commenced in a comprehensive way from April of this year. By way of comparison—opposition members would have us believe otherwise—the minister met with the ACTU some 25 times, and at least 32 times with employer groups around the country. I do not need to name them all, but over 100 meetings took place with the various interest groups. So on the matter of consultation, the government's record speaks for itself; unlike, I must say, that of the Victorian and Western Australian governments when they were bringing in their own industrial relations legislation. To my knowledge, in Victoria there was no consultation with the federal government. As for Western Australia—it seemed to be the one that wanted to whinge most about this—it sent a copy of its legislation to Minister Brereton after it had been introduced into state parliament.

In going to the terms of reference of the committee and looking at the issue of whether or not the government bill improves relationships between employers and employees and enhances the enterprise bargaining process, as can be seen from the evidence, there are varying views about this. If we look at the proposed bill objectively and the current legislation that is in place, we can really draw no other conclusion than that the proposed legislation can achieve both of these objectives.

The bill does not, as is claimed, put in place more restrictions. What it does do is provide flexibility and an opportunity to enhance the enterprise bargaining process. What it also does, and what the three states under Liberal governments have not done, is provide protection for workers against unscrupulous employers. If we compare state and federal legislation as they currently stand and take note of reports that have been conducted by both the Department of Industrial Relations at a federal level and independent analysts, it is quite evident that the current federal legislation has been far more successful than that of any of the states in areas of flexibility and workplace change.

As at 10 November this year, over 1,320 enterprise agreements were registered under the federal system, which came into effect in October 1991. Those agreements cover some 800,000 workers or about 12 per cent of the nation's work force. By comparison, in the states of New South Wales and Victoria where legislation has been in place for similar periods of time, there are only some 386 agreements registered in New South Wales and about only 155 in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not tell you anyway. They weren't listed.

—That is right. Again, by way of comparison, the studies found that agreements under federal legislation adopted a broader agenda concerning enterprise performance, whereas agreements in the state jurisdictions focused on a narrow range of issues such as wages and conditions.

PARA.TAB: By way of example, I would like to refer to the Victorian approach. It is quite evident from work contracts that have been either drawn up collectively or individually, which the Victorian government would certainly deny—it certainly did in answer to questions from Senator Carr from Victoria about protections it provides—that if one was employed and working under a state award prior to March this year, one would not lose any of the conditions contained within those awards. Workers at Fancy Fingers, Alexanders, Nandos Chicken Land, Bed Bath n'Table, Australian Pacific Supermarkets, Westco Jeans, Copperart, Speeds Shoes, et cetera would certainly contradict that. The copies of the contracts of employment that I have show that those employees lost substantial conditions that they had working under awards prior to March 1993.

The second term of reference relates to the implications for the states and how the federal legislation might impact on states rights. It should be noted that the legislation proposed will have no impact over state legislation where the states are meeting the obligations of international conventions, such as those of the ILO, to which we are a signatory. There is a claim by Western Australia that it is meeting the obligations of ILO conventions.

I would like to point out that as far as setting minimum rates of pay and minimum conditions are concerned, it is a ministerial decision in Western Australia. Although it has a mechanism whereby the minister can make that decision arising out of a recommendation from the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission, there is no requirement for that commission to use any basis for making that recommendation—that is, they do not have to assess the wages and conditions of workers around that state. There is no obligation. So it is not meeting the requirements of a number of the conventions. Therefore, the legislation may have an impact in some of those areas but for others, such as Queensland and South Australia, the legislation will have no impact whatsoever.
With respect to one of the other issues that was raised—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to contribute to the discussion on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I endorse the recommendations of the committee, as contained in the report. Obviously I do so because I signed it. I want to address the way in which the report was compiled and the process that was engaged in. In particular, I want to spend a short period addressing and continuing my little campaign in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The public hearing which was conducted last Friday was conducted while the Senate was sitting. It provided particular embarrassment for me because at that time in this chamber we were considering two bills on industrial relations and education on which I was required to speak on behalf of the Democrats. I was therefore unable to attend and participate in the public inquiry, except for very short periods. I had a set of questions which I was unable to address. The chair of the committee, Senator Zakharov, was kind enough to ask some of those questions on my behalf but it was far from a satisfactory position. Perhaps if I had approached Senator Murphy, he would have been keen to ask questions on that occasion. Shuffling backwards and forwards from this chamber to the committee hearing was not a satisfactory situation to be in.

Luckily, the facility to review the proceedings of the committee was available to me and I was able to participate in the final compilation of the report. That process is certainly not conducive to either the proper conduct of the business of this chamber or the proper conduct of the committee acting on behalf of this chamber. I want to register that protest loud and strong. I was not satisfied with it and it was less than satisfactory to the committee.

However, that does not mean that the criticism which was addressed first by Senator Murphy is a criticism which holds. Senator Murphy dismissed the criticism that the committee did not have time to do its work properly, and I wish to address it as well. Although I have criticised the holding of the hearing on that day, it did not detract from the opportunity that the rest of the committee had to pursue the matters they wished to, nor did it detract from the opportunity that the witnesses had to present their case. I said earlier in debate in this place on another matter that the debate which was rehearsed was one which had been heard previously, perhaps even ad nauseam. The subject matter which was brought to the committee was little different to the subject matter which was brought to the committee over the previous year in the inquiry into sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

Apart from addressing that criticism and agreeing with Senator Murphy in the way in which it was dismissed, I would also like to say that I agree with much of what Senator Murphy has just said. The report of the committee adequately and properly addressed the terms of reference and produced a set of recommendations which should be endorsed by this chamber.
