TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs entitled, A National Drought Policy—Appropriate Government Responses to the Recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force. It has been a little slow in coming, as has the end of the drought in a lot of places. For example, in southern Queensland at the moment we have a horrific drought which has been going on for a couple of years or more. In the eastern and northern parts of the New England region of New South Wales drought is still occurring. Drought is also occurring on the north coast and in other isolated pockets.The history of an appropriate drought strategy for Australia is very long and protracted. In 1990 the drought review task force published a report but by 1992 most of the recommendations in that report had not been acted upon. It was for that reason that the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs embarked upon an inquiry. It took us to many and varied places, as evidenced by the pictorial records in the report. I remember saying at the time, after we published our report in July 1992—that is quite a long time ago when one thinks about it—that we thought it was almost too late to be of any use for the current drought. Fifteen months later, we have a government response.

PARA.TAB: At that time I said in a press release:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has to be responsible for providing comprehensive assistance for drought-stricken farmers, even though farmers want to become self-sufficient to survive drought.
I went on to say:
. . . they can't do this without the support of Government—including the provision of appropriate financial incentives to store funds, fodder and water.
Expenditure relating specifically to preparations for drought need to be fully tax-deductible in the year of expenditure, and a more attractive and effective IED scheme needs to be implemented.

We suggested the implementation of tax credits, et cetera. I said in my press release that the federal government could not abandon primary producers and that becoming responsible for drought survival is a process that will take many years and we could not expect farmers to achieve self-sufficiency overnight. I went on to say that within the national disaster relief arrangements, the federal government had to realise its obligation when drought becomes severe. I suggested that the trigger mechanisms to activate Commonwealth involvement in severe drought could include an application from the shire concerned, the use of objective measuring of soil moisture readings, and an overriding subjective assessment by a tripartite drought committee involving the cooperation of federal and state governments. That would have taken the matter out of politics.

PARA.TAB: I am very concerned that the reply from the government to some of our areas of concern is that we should encourage a self-reliant approach to drought. The government has said that the national drought policy does encourage self-reliant approaches to drought by treating it as one of the risks for which managers of farm business must prepare. It says that the policy seeks to address the past approach of reliance on government assistance during drought periods by removing the emphasis on transaction based subsidies and drought declarations. I wish to take up that point.

In the case of the transaction based subsidy, stock can get out of a drought affected area on to better pastures that are available around Australia. That is good for numerous reasons. It is good for animal welfare as it is getting the stock on to better pastures. It is good for maintaining the breeding herd or the breeding flock, which is most important in times of a severe drought in Australia. That has really been forgotten about by removing the emphasis on transaction based subsidies and drought declarations.

Severe droughts will continue to occur in Australia into any century we like to think about. The fact that we said we would take drought out of the natural disaster arena still did not mean there was not an obligation on the federal government to take it into account when it got beyond the ability of somebody to handle it. Our suggestion was that the one in 20 drought be determined by an objective measurement and there should be a trigger for the government to immediately come in and help out. A fair bit of export income is produced by the rural communities and they deserve some help. We should make sure that we keep the flock and the herd surviving for future years.
The government response mentioned a number of problems with the rural adjustment scheme. A comprehensive review of the rural adjustment scheme has been undertaken. The government response states:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular its recommendations focused on the mechanisms for achieving structural adjustment in the rural sector.

On 29 July the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand met and discussed, amongst other things, the uncertainty in application of the RAS guidelines for triggering exceptional circumstances; and the application of income support provisions in circumstances where a reasonable valuation of farm assets is difficult because few sales occur. Lots of problems occur with the rural adjustment scheme. I still do not think that is the real answer that we require in Australia to handle drought.

PARA.TAB: The response also addressed income equalisation deposits. The committee suggested that an effective IED scheme should be introduced. We used to have a very effective income equalisation deposit scheme. In a good year, people could put money away—not at a high rate of interest—and they could get a total deduction from their income in that particular year. They could bring it back in a year of drought at the ruling rate of tax they were paying in that particular year. That was a good scheme. When the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair from the other place was the minister, he was one of the instigators of that scheme. The money that went into the primary industries bank was of great help and assistance to the rural communities.

Sadly, the income equalisation deposit scheme has been emasculated. Even though it has come back into being with the government now, a lot of questions can be asked about it. What interests rates are going to be charged? Is it going to be the bond rate? Are there going to be severe penalties if incorrect self-assessment is done? The scheme could be a lot more flexible than what the government is proposing, without fear of any rorting.

One of the things that disturb me about this government is that, if one person rorts something—maybe some people have rorted that scheme—the government cancels it for all the people it could help. That is a sad thing for us. Just look at the paper today. People have had wonderful wheat crops in the Walgett area. It is the first time they have had decent wheat crops and a decent income for a long time. Surely, they could have a really good income equalisation deposit scheme whereby they could put money away that they have got from their crop which they have grown this year, and when they get their bad seasons in the future—they get a lot of not so good seasons in the Walgett area—they could bring back that money. That would allow those people to put away money for self-sufficiency, to look after themselves in times of a drought. Self-reliance is very important and it is one area of recommendation in the committee's report.

In reply to our report, the government said that there has to be more education. I can assure people who have—and those who have not—had anything to do with the land that it does not matter how well one is educated; it is very hard to educate and to train people to know when a drought starts. It is all very well for the government to say that people should destock for drought—they know that it is going to come the next week, they have to destock for it. That is all very well. Without transaction based subsidies and assistance in that respect, it will be very difficult for people to say, `I will get my stock away to better pastures and prepare myself for the drought that may be coming up'.

The new arrangements for drought will definitely be tested over time. In future, the federal government should show more flexibility in response to calls for help. The long drawn out process for each of the present arrangements should not be repeated. I welcome the response but I do not think it has really gone all the way to making sure that we retain our herds and our flocks and to making sure that we keep our people on the land for the future benefit of Australia.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 18 November, on monion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have been urged to respond to the SIS bills by amending them. We have received a large number of complaints from disaffected public servants in Victoria who allege that the Kennett government is meddling in their super fund arrangements with a view to reducing benefits substantially. The number of complaints is very large and should not go without notice. In fact, the number of these complaints has been exceeded only by the correspondence which has been received by us on the introduction of the super guarantee charge.

PARA.TAB: This level of concern is not surprising. Victorian public servants, like their New South Wales counterparts earlier this year, have had their superannuation scheme gutted by mean-fisted state governments. What is concerning us is that they have been able to thwart the basic employment contract law by ready access to legislation.

Under the transfer arrangements between the old and the new Victorian superannuation schemes, I understand that existing members stand to lose up to 20 per cent of their accrued entitlements. The `voluntary' transfer to the new scheme is made compulsory by possible punitive increases in contributions of up to 160 per cent. This will have a serious impact on particular age groups. New employees, like those in New South Wales, will be entitled to only the minimum superannuation provided by the superannuation guarantee levy system. We are told that this has been done as part of an effort to reduce state indebtedness and unfunded liabilities.

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has taken an active interest in the goings on in public sector superannuation. The third report of the committee, entitled Super and the financial system, resulted in the production of a seminal report on public sector superannuation across Australia highlighting two key areas: firstly, that the level of unfunded liabilities for public sector superannuation was increasing and in the near future would present government with severe funding problems; and, secondly, that there are differences in the level of employer contributions from one state to the next.

I will give an example. The Rolls Royce of the scheme was the Defence Force retirement and death benefits scheme, which had a level of employer support of about 26 per cent. The FJ Holden of the scheme was found to be the new Victorian scheme, which is funded at 11.3 per cent. The report showed that the reorganisation of the Victorian scheme has already resulted in the reduction of the level of employer support from 21.5 per cent to 11.3 per cent. The New South Wales scheme was also reduced from 21.5 per cent to 14 per cent under the Wran government.

Having regard to the seemingly low level of employer support in the Victorian scheme, we were somewhat surprised to hear that attempts were being made to further whittle away these benefits. I understand that the government is reducing benefits to rein in its public sector debt. The letters which I have received call on my party to legislate by way of amendments to the SIS bills to prevent a state government from reducing benefits by fiat.

I can understand the concerns of those whose benefits have been, or will be, reduced. However, this parliament and the Commonwealth are not well placed to become involved in that dispute, in a legislative sense at least.

Until the High Court decides otherwise, states are recognised as having a constitutional right to legislate on industrial relations matters affecting their employees. Whether they could reduce the level of benefits below the SGC minimum, however, is another matter. Our advice is that, as the SGC is a tax on employers who do not meet their minimum superannuation contributions, the Commonwealth could insist that states meet their obligations.

The High Court decision last year in South Australia v. the Commonwealth provides some guidance as to the degree of protection that the states have over their employee superannuation fund arrangements. In that case, the Commonwealth was prohibited from imposing a tax on that state's superannuation funds as, under section 114 of the constitution, the tax was seen as a tax on state property.

Commonwealth intervention to dictate to states that certain conditions above and beyond the SGC be maintained would be likely to suffer a similar fate. That is not to say that the Commonwealth should stand idly by while two of the country's largest employers restructure their superannuation arrangements to the detriment of hundreds of thousands of workers. The issue of Australia's $34.4 billion worth of unfunded public sector superannuation liabilities is a national problem, if only because more than half of that amount is, at present, part of the Commonwealth schemes.

When the Senate superannuation committee looked at the issue, it recognised that a great deal more information was needed. It unanimously recommended that the Minister for Finance convene a national meeting of state finance ministers or treasurers to develop a plan of action for addressing the problem of unfunded liabilities. Unfortunately, since then, the Commonwealth has done nothing while two states have now reduced the superannuation entitlements of their employees, particularly their new employees.

A coordinated approach to the problem of unfunded liabilities could at least ensure that unfortunate employees who find themselves subject to a capricious state government are not picked off and made to experience the unilateral withdrawal of hard-earned benefits. The problem of unfunded superannuation is also a part of a bigger state debt problem, which my colleague Senator Coulter has been investigating in the Australian Loans Council committee.

That recommendation of the superannuation committee was made in October 1992—over a year ago! It is my understanding that government responses to Senate committee reports should be tabled within three months of the tabling of the committee report. It seems strange that the government response is now 10 months overdue. Perhaps the government could respond to the fourth, fifth, and sixth reports, which were also tabled over three months ago.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying some hours ago, what the government is seeking to do by amending the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is extend police powers so that on certain occasions they would be able to tap a telephone line without a warrant. Those circumstances are limited. They have been even more limited by the amendments moved by the coalition. For example, there was one instance where it did not need to be an emergency and as a result of amendments suggested by Darryl Williams QC that situation was remedied. These amendments provide a check on the circumstances when warrants are not required in that the relevant agency needs to seek a warrant `as soon as practicable'. If the circumstances for the tap do not comply with the requirements outlined in the act then obviously the warrant will not be granted and therefore the tap will have to come off. But that does not alter the legality of the tap until that time.

PARA.TAB: There is another amendment that the government is seeking and with which the coalition agrees. That amendment deals with how the judicial officer should categorise the circumstances when the agency seeks a warrant. The amendment basically says that irrespective of whether or not those circumstances fit into a class under which the judicial officer can now issue a warrant—that is, a class one or two offence—those circumstances will be treated as though they are within that category for the purposes of that warrant. We agree with that extension.

I indicated earlier that the opposition is concerned about extending the capacity of police forces to intercept telephone lines. However, I also outlined earlier that these powers are suitably limited. One might say that this amendment extends the powers of police further, and to an extent it does. As I understand the situation, if one went to seek a warrant to tap a phone today under the circumstances which exist under this bill, one would not get it. The circumstances would not be considered to come under class one or two offences.

Nevertheless, the opposition says that that is fair enough. The circumstances outlined in the bill under which the government imagines one ought to be able to put a tap on without warrant are so limited that we do not believe it is worth not allowing the amendment.

I understand that my colleague Senator Spindler wants to move a few amendments. I hope I will not be misrepresenting the gist of them when I say they are as follows. Firstly, Senator Spindler is saying that if we are so worried about the difficulty police might have in getting hold of a Federal Court judge to issue the warrant and we want to allow these taps to go ahead in emergency situations, why not solve the problem another way and allow other judges to issue warrants, particularly Supreme Court judges. The opposition does not agree with that amendment. We are quite happy with the circumstances as they exist at the moment.

Federal Court judges are available. There may have been occasions when there has been a huge difficulty in getting hold of a judge. We believe the purpose of this amendment is to solve that problem. We prefer the solution the government is offering to the one that the Democrats are offering.

The Democrats go further. They ask us to accept some fall back positions. They have asked us to consider whether we will accept a further amendment to the amendments already proposed. The Democrats are suggesting that where a warrant is required within the time defined as being `as soon as practicable', we should accept the addition of the words `but not later than 24 hours or as soon as practicable whichever comes sooner.'

The opposition says no to that amendment as well, the reason being that we believe that `as soon as practicable' is understood by the courts and it is terminology that they can easily use. The Democrats' proposal to allow an option of 24 hours does not help the situation much. It may encourage a situation in which the warrant is not sought as soon as it should be. This is not because the police forces are relying on any ambiguity but because the `as soon as practicable or not later than 24 hours' may be an incentive to go a bit slower. The opposition believes that `as soon as practicable' means just that and does not need any further definition.

The Democrats want to move a further amendment which requires that when a warrant is sought under these circumstances the police must report it to the ombudsman within seven days. At this stage, the opposition is not inclined to accept that proposal either. These matters have to be reported in any event, so we do not necessarily see that there is much to be gained by changing the time for reporting. The upshot of the Democrats' proposals are that we do not like, and I do not imagine the government necessarily likes, an extension of the powers to tap telephones. We acknowledge that this extension is limited to where either a party or private citizen agrees or one party to the communication is a police officer.

It is further limited in the sense that where one party to the communication is a police officer there is a whole list of things that need to happen. As a consequence of one of our amendments, it has to be an emergency situation or there has to be a serious threat of injury to a party involved or a serious threat to property. In any event, as soon as practicable after the tap is put on a warrant needs to be sought. If the tap is not in accordance with the legislation it will not be able to be continued because the warrant will not be granted.

We are talking about a very limited circumstance. It covers what is potentially a serious gap in the powers of the police at the moment. The opposition believes that by adding the requirement that a warrant be sought as soon as practicable, the civil liberties concerns are catered for. We do not believe that the Democrats' proposed amendments, while being in line with the general sentiment of concern about extra tapping, necessarily add anything to the legislation on a day-to-day basis. We support their sentiments, but we think that in practice the amendments at the coalface will not add up to much. So we are not inclined to support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1993. At present the principal act regulates the interceptions of telecommunications—in other words, telephone tapping. Interceptions are currently permitted only under warrant in the following circumstances: firstly, by ASIO for national security purposes; secondly, in the case of narcotics offences such as drug importations under the Customs Act—

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interceptions are currently permitted only under warrant in the following circumstances: firstly, by ASIO for national security purposes; secondly, in the case of narcotics offences such as drug importations under the Customs Act; and, thirdly, for law enforcement purposes for serious offences such as murder, kidnapping and serious fraud. It should be noted that state agencies can only obtain warrants to intercept telecommunication services in their own state.

PARA.TAB: As the act stands, the responsibility for executing warrants lies with the Telecommunications Interception Division of the Federal Police. All intercepted signals are routed from the exchange identified in the warrant to the TID's facility in Canberra where the signal is recorded. This signal is then rerouted to the law enforcement agency which applied for the warrant. This arrangement has been criticised as being impractical and costly. This brings me to the first change that this bill seeks to make.

The bill proposes to replace the present system of routing interceptions through TID in Canberra with a new system which allows the intercepted signal to be received directly by the agency, but the TID maintains control of interceptions by a switch computer link. The claimed advantages of the system include increased signal quality and reliability and come with a greatly reduced cost of approximately $2 million for all agencies. We consider that first amendment uncontroversial and the Australian Democrats will certainly support it.

The second group of amendments, which we also consider to be uncontroversial, relate to the removal of the territorial limitation in the phone tapping process. A loophole appears to have arisen in the provisions of the act as a result of the restriction on state law enforcement agencies when they use warrants for interception. The restriction has apparently been exploited by those involved in criminal activities by simply moving from state to state. The bill therefore proposes to remove this territorial limitation provided that the agency can show a nexus between the investigation of an offence for which it has responsibility and the outside service it wishes to intercept. The Democrats will also support this amendment.

There are a number of other relatively minor amendments. The bill also proposes to extend interceptions to include computer related offences under part VIA of the Crimes Act and the addition of the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission in the list of state agencies which are entitled to apply for warrants. The bill requires under section 99 the minister's annual report to parliament to include details of the use of the new powers to intercept calls without a warrant and details of the total costs of interception for law enforcement purposes. The Democrats see nothing controversial in those.

However, a range of amendments in the bill causes us considerable concern from a civil liberties point of view. It is proposed to enable Federal Police or state police to intercept telecommunications without a warrant in two circumstances: firstly, to monitor or record telephone conversations to which the agencies are party, involving actual or threatened loss of life or threat of serious injury or of serious damage to property where there is urgency which does not permit application for a warrant to be made; and, secondly, to monitor or record telephone conversations of a likely recipient of kidnapping or extortion demands where they have that recipient's consent.

Some amendments to these provisions were moved in the House of Representatives by the coalition and they have certainly improved these provisions. However, we still have considerable concern about the way in which the government seeks to overcome what could well be a shortcoming in the procedure. The first amendment which I will deal with is not likely to be accepted by either the coalition, as we have heard, or the government, as I have been advised. However, I have not been conclusively advised by the government whether it will accept my fall back amendments as foreshadowed, which I have discussed with the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) in the Senate. I look forward to the minister advising me. I trust that the government will see fit to mitigate some of the dangers to the rights of individuals that these measures entail.

The amendments moved by the coalition in the House of Representatives resulted in the insertion of subclauses (6) and (7). These amendments make the emergency provisions less open ended in that they require, firstly, a warrant to be sought `as soon as practicable' after an interception occurs in an emergency situation without a warrant and, secondly, an interception to cease should the judge refuse the application for the warrant.

The Democrats do not believe that these amendments go far enough in addressing the civil liberties concerns associated with the use of interceptions without a warrant. We have received representations from numerous law societies and civil liberty organisations including the Law Council of Australia, the New South Wales Council of Civil Liberties, the Law Institute of Victoria, the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties, the New South Wales Law Society and the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties, all of whom are totally opposed to granting police the power to intercept without a warrant even in such emergency situations.

As far as those organisations are concerned, all the coalition amendments do is shut the gate after the horse has bolted. The coalition amendments leave it open for the police to buy time to continue with an illegal interception because they need only bring an application for a warrant before a judge `as soon as practicable'. If there is an illegal interception, there is no recourse. The judge will simply direct that the interception shall cease. A further concern is that the police can use illegally obtained evidence in court. Under the rule in Bunning v. Cross, illegally obtained evidence is not prima facie inadmissible. Rather, the court has a discretion to exclude it on public policy grounds.

The Australian Democrats believe that the provisions under the principal act are sufficient—that is before these amendments are introduced—to deal with emergency situations because, firstly, section 30 of the act already provides for interceptions by the carrier for tracing calls in an emergency situation without a warrant and, secondly, it is already possible under section 40 to apply for a warrant by making a telephone application.

The police have apparently expressed concerns about the difficulty of locating an `eligible judge', currently defined under the legislation as Federal Court judges only, to grant a telephone application in circumstances of emergency. It would seem that these amendments are a response to this concern. However, we think that these amendments are an overkill. Hence, the Australian Democrats will be voting against clause 10—that is my first amendment—and will be moving alternative amendments to address this concern of delay in emergency situations.

The main amendment that we suggest, after rejecting section 10, is to increase the number of judges defined under the legislation as eligible to receive telephone applications. We do not believe that it is necessary to solve the problem that is obviously there—namely, to find a sufficient number of judges to make telephone applications quickly—simply by giving the power to the police. This was the burden of the complaints and submissions that we received from the various organisations, including the law councils and civil liberties councils, which I have enumerated. Rather than give this power to the police, they would like to see more judges appointed. There is really no reason why we cannot extend the power to receive telephone applications beyond Federal Court judges to include state and territory supreme court judges. To us this appears to be a much more sensible way to address this problem, which we do not deny.

In addition—and in particular—if, as seems likely, the amendment to remove clause 10 and to add the judges of state and territory supreme courts to the definition is not accepted, I will foreshadow two additional amendments. One of them would be to ensure that, if the police have moved to intercept telephone communications without a warrant in emergency situations, they should seek a warrant, certainly as soon as practicable—which was one of the amendments of the coalition—but no later than 24 hours after the interception has occurred.

I cannot agree with the argument that was put forward by Senator Vanstone that `as soon as practicable' is adequately defined in usage in our courts. It seems to me to be an extremely rubbery concept. I have come across the use of this term, for instance, in the anti-dumping legislation, under the customs legislation, where `as soon as practicable', in terms of making public a report submitted to the minister, extended not only beyond 24 hours but beyond two days, beyond four days and, in some cases, up to a week or more.

I do not accept, therefore, that there is a generally accepted time span which is defined by the term `as soon as practicable'. I would have thought that it was very worth while to introduce a safeguard by saying, `Certainly do it as soon as practicable, but no later than 24 hours', because every additional hour, every additional day, means that people are having their private telephone conversations intercepted without warrant. I would suggest that this is a practice that we should not condone. While we realise that there could be pressing circumstances in which this must be done, or should be done, if the additional judges are not appointed, then at least we should try to limit that period as much as we can.

The second amendment that I am foreshadowing requires notification within seven days to the Ombudsman's office when interceptions have been commenced by police without a warrant. That is not as revolutionary a provision as one might think. At the moment, a report of interceptions must be provided to the Ombudsman twice a year. We are now dealing with a circumstance in which the interception is being carried out without a warrant—in other words, without judicial protection of a citizen. It seems very reasonable that this should be reported to the Ombudsman, not only to keep a record of it, but to investigate if the circumstances of the incident justify it.

We believe that the amendments that have been proposed by the government are of great concern. We believe that, to some extent at least, the dangers could be minimised by more regular and thorough reporting to the Ombudsman in situations in which interceptions will be carried out without warrants and in which the civil liberties of citizens are at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1993 is a very important piece of legislation. It is important because it relates to the privacy which we all enjoy as Australian citizens. The coalition recognises that we need to have a balance between that privacy and the powers which our law enforcement agencies require in order to ensure that they are able to control criminal activities. It is a difficult subject. In many ways, whatever action is taken is likely to offend one group or another, as Senator Spindler could attest to from the number of representations he has had. The coalition's position has always been consistent. We have repeatedly taken the view, in this chamber and in the other place, that crime cannot be tolerated and that we must make every endeavour to assure, by any means, that it is removed from our society. We would all be aware that there have been many recent technological advances. In fact, as senators, we have benefited greatly from those technological advances in the operation of our offices. However, any new advances create new opportunities for the criminal element and, therefore, may require amendments to the powers afforded to our law enforcement officers.

PARA.TAB: The bill before us today amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 by introducing a new range of powers under the act. It will make available a new procedure by which warrants issued to state police forces and agencies may be executed.

In line with the new technological advances which I outlined previously, there will be a new computer-controlled system known as the TIRAC which will allow state agencies to receive the intercepted signal without its being routed through Canberra. In the past, the procedure was extremely time consuming and there was a loss of signal quality. It is important to understand that the Federal Police will still be the responsible authority in this matter.

The bill will also introduce a central register of warrants, showing the particulars of all warrants under the act, and it will allow emergency interception by state and federal police authorities in a range of emergency situations. In the past, criminal elements have sought to evade aspects of the act by moving around the country. These amendments will also allow warrants of interception to be issued outside the state boundaries where necessary. As I have said before, the coalition has supported the general thrust of this bill, and I believe it will be supported by the Australian community in the main.

I am also pleased that the government, and in particular my Tasmanian colleague the Minister for Justice, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), saw fit to incorporate into the bill the amendments proposed by the opposition in the other place. I add my congratulations to those of Senator Spindler and others to the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) on his success in having those amendments adopted by the government.

A number of concerns have been expressed by the Privacy Law Committee and the criminal law section of the Law Council of Australia, amongst others, in relation to the introduction of interceptions without a warrant in crisis situations. Many legal and civil libertarian groups contacted the coalition to express the view that such new powers went beyond an acceptable limit of checks and balances. It seems that they also spent a fair amount of time talking to Senator Spindler about this. The coalition supports those concerns, but at the same time we need to accept that law enforcement agencies must be able to respond immediately to a crisis such as a kidnapping, an extortion attempt or a siege.

Under the government's original proposal, in the situation of exceptional circumstances such as a siege where it is impossible to apply for a warrant, it is possible for an interception to be initiated without a warrant. We believe that under those circumstances it should be a requirement that a warrant for interception be sought as soon as is possible and should that warrant be refused the interception must cease immediately. I am sure that most people would consider these to have been reasonable safeguards.

The other case in which the government was prepared to allow an interception to occur without a warrant was in relation to a kidnapping or an attempted extortion. Again, whilst the coalition accepted that in such cases an interception should be allowed without a warrant, we nevertheless maintained that it should be a requirement that a warrant be applied for as soon as possible.

I believe that one of the most important amendments contained in this bill is the provision for warrants of interception to be issued outside the boundaries of a state. Under subsection 39(3) of the old act, it was impossible to obtain such a warrant and it was widely recognised that this defect acted as an advantage in encouraging those involved in criminal activities to move from state to state. Such a restriction was unacceptable and the new provision will allow state authorities to exercise greater control over those who have sought to abuse the system.

Many Australians would be concerned, I believe, about the interception of telecommunications without added safeguards. As I mentioned before, it is essentially a privacy issue and a matter of obtaining a balance between privacy and law enforcement. I believe it is important to place on record the comments of the Australian Law Reform Commission 1993 report on privacy which sought to provide a theoretical basis for a definition of privacy. That report claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an individual's claim to personal autonomy involves a claim to have some control over the way in which he interacts with others. This implies the ability to exclude others from conversations or communications into which he enters and the ability to prevent . . . other people spying on his activities.

Last week in this place I brought to the attention of the Senate the case of Mr Geoffrey Marr. Honourable senators who were here at the time and took notice of what I had to say—I suppose there are one or two—would probably be familiar by now with the fact that Mr Marr is a former Telstra employee who had been the subject of a most unacceptable investigation by Telstra. The activities of Telstra in intercepting telecommunications are also covered by this act. I am concerned, and I believe the Marr case highlights this fact, that we need to place greater controls over the interception capacities of Telstra. I have already stated that the bill before us today requires law enforcement authorities to obtain an interception warrant, but currently no such provision applies to Telstra.

PARA.TAB: In Mr Marr's case, both his private telephone and his work telephone were connected to Telstra's CCAE recording equipment for up to two months without obtaining a warrant. I consider this to be a gross invasion of his privacy. Telstra has claimed that such action was necessary because of concerns it had regarding the activities of Mr Marr, but, as it turned out, such concerns were unsubstantiated and were later rejected. I believe that if Telstra is to be empowered to monitor telecommunications then it needs to have a much better case than just a gut feeling, which it appears was all that was required in the Marr case.

The other issue which the Marr case raised was the failure of Telstra to retain records relating to its interception. It is a requirement for Telstra to maintain its records for three years, but in the Marr case the tape appears to have been mysteriously corrupted and the records destroyed. This was in direct contravention of Telstra's own guidelines and, in addition, creates great uncertainty about the ability of Telstra to adequately manage such wide-ranging powers.

As I mentioned initially, this is a very difficult issue. No-one would deny the right of law enforcement officers to take whatever means are necessary to adequately investigate criminal matters. At the same time, the Marr case indicates that under some sections of this act there are not adequate requirements in relation to the activities of Telstra and I believe it is a matter which we should examine in the near future.

I have spoken to Mr Marr and I know that he feels very disturbed that his privacy should be encroached on in this manner and I believe anyone here in this chamber would share that view. I would also argue that, as elected representatives, when the balance tips too far we have a moral obligation to act to ensure that the right of privacy for the individual is adequately safeguarded.

As a postscript to what I have just said, I would like to share an experience my office was involved in only last week. I will let honourable senators draw their own conclusions, but it certainly disturbed me. I do not know whether other senators have had similar sorts of experiences. My office was endeavouring to send a fax to a solicitor in Sydney who was acting, coincidentally, on behalf of a former Telecom employee who had raised doubts about certain management practices. My staff tried several times without success. They checked the number and found that it was the correct number.

Finally, they thought it may have been a telephone number so they dialled it. The phone was answered and the voice at the other end said, `Australian Federal Police, major crime investigation'. My staff were very concerned; they immediately hung up. After they had calmed down a bit, they tried the fax again and—surprise, surprise—it was transmitted successfully. I do not know whether it was just a crossed line or a coincidence, but it seems very much of a coincidence to me. I just wonder whether any other senators in this place have had those sorts of experiences from time to time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks about the amendments that have been proposed by the Australian Democrats but, first of all, I will explain why the amendments that were moved by the opposition in the House of Representatives were accepted by the government.

PARA.TAB: The opposition amendments that were moved in the House were accepted by the government because they improved the measures already in the bill to ensure accountability for police action in emergency situations. The amendments proposed by the government are intended to fix a technical defect in the opposition amendments. The problem is that the requirement to seek a part VI warrant can only be met if the conduct which has given rise to the emergency constitutes a class 1 or class 2 offence as defined in the act.

As suicide is no longer an offence in any jurisdiction, and as threats to kill do not in at least some jurisdictions meet the test of a seven-year gaol term provided for in the definition of a class 2 offence, it would not be possible to obtain a warrant in respect of these acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean they don't hang you for suicide any more?

—Senator Crichton-Browne really tempts me to make remarks about the suicide efforts of the opposition in the last election, but never mind. I think the former President of the Liberal Party in Victoria described the Liberal Party Fightback GST proposals as the longest suicide note in history.
—How can you prosecute somebody for suicide? You can prosecute them for attempted suicide, not for suicide.
—I think that is the point, is it not?
—That's not what you said.

—I said `as suicide is no longer an offence in any jurisdiction'. I will see what my advisers have to say about it. Yes, I have to agree with Senator Crichton-Browne. His semantics are correct. It used to be an offence to attempt suicide. I suppose Senator Crichton-Browne would want capital punishment for people found guilty of attempting suicide and have them executed anyway!

PARA.TAB: To deal with this problem, the government amendment provides that where an act does not constitute a class 1 or class 2 offence, it is to be taken to constitute a class 2 offence for the purpose of attracting the warranting provisions. The effect is that the accountability mechanisms which are associated with the issue of warrants, such as regular inspections by the Ombudsman, will be incorporated. The amendment will also remove any uncertainty where the act which has given rise to the emergency is a generalised threat to kill someone, as in some siege situation, or a threat to kill oneself.

Speaking to the number of amendments which were moved by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Australian Democrats, my first advice here deals with three of them. Those three amendments would do three things: firstly, broaden the pool of eligible judges to include state supreme court judges; secondly, remove the Attorney-General's discretion to nominate judges; and, thirdly, omit the provisions that will enable police to engage in participant monitoring in emergencies. They are in clauses 1 and 2 of the bill.

In relation to the first point, at present only judges of a court created by parliament may be nominated as eligible judges. While the inclusion of state supreme court judges within the category of judges who may be nominated to issue warrants may have some practical advantages, the government is not convinced that those advantages would outweigh the disadvantages of the proposal. In particular, the proposal could be seen as placing at risk the current Commonwealth control arrangements which contribute to the maintenance of an appropriate system of accountability.

In relation to the second point, the removal of the Attorney-General's discretion to nominate judges for the purpose of dealing with warrant applications would mean that a warrant application could be made to any judge of the High Court, the Federal Court, the Family Court or of a state supreme court who had consented to being nominated. This amendment would considerably increase the number of judges vested with this power. As a matter of practice, nominations to date have been restricted to judges of the Federal Court. The removal of the discretion to nominate particular judges may also place at risk the constitutional validity of the scheme for judicial supervision of telecommunications interception.

In the case of Hilton v. Wells 1985, 157 CLR, page 57, the High Court rejected a challenge to the power to issue warrants which was based on the characterisation of the power as non-judicial. The court held that the power was not conferred on the Federal Court but on the judges individually as designated persons. These provisions were strengthened in 1987 following the court's decision. But the proposed amendment may give rise to an argument that the parliament was conferring a warrant issuing power on all federal courts.

In relation to the third point, which is clause 2, removal of the provisions relating to emergencies would mean that unacceptable delays in dealing with emergencies would continue to occur. Increasing the number of judges who may issue warrants might alleviate the problem of finding a judge at short notice. But, even if more judges were to become available, it would still take time to prepare warrant applications, affidavits and the like, and to meet the carrier's requirements for the connection of intercepts.

Sieges, hostage taking and kidnapping, thankfully, are not common in Australia, but when they occur it is imperative that they be dealt with effectively and as quickly as possible. The longer any delay, the greater the likelihood of lives being lost. The government believes that the scheme embodied in the bill represents an appropriate balance between the needs of law enforcement in such situations and privacy concerns.
So, for those reasons, the government opposes those three amendments proposed by the Democrats.

There are a further two amendments which I understand the Democrats have put up as a fall back position. One requires police to seek a warrant within 24 hours of commencing their participant monitoring, and the other requires police to report certain matters to the ombudsman within seven days of the emergency. The first amendment is unexceptionable but unnecessary. The proposed provision already requires police to seek a warrant as soon as practicable after the event. Their diligence in doing so is subject to inspection by the ombudsman.

The second amendment is, in some ways, redundant and is open to a number of objections. It would suggest that the ombudsman would have power to comment on the exercise of the judge's discretion in issuing a warrant. This would be unacceptable to judges. It would need to be redrafted to take account of the scheme of the act, which provides for actions of the Australian Federal Police to be inspected by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and actions of state police to be inspected by state agencies, usually the state ombudsman under state legislation.

The amendment would be superimposed on the accountability scheme which already exists in the act. It appears to be based on a misconception that the ombudsman has a power to report on the propriety of individual warrants. All that he could do with the information would be to include it in his regular report to the Attorney-General.

It may be useful to argue for a greater role for the ombudsman generally under the act than was considered appropriate by the joint select committee which considered telecommunications interception in 1986. As a result, the government will also oppose the Democrats' two fall back amendments.
