SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President
Today is a milestone.
A response to another milestone: the High Court's decision in the Mabo case.

The High Court has determined that Australian law should not, as Justice Brennan said, be "frozen in an era of racial discrimination". Its decision in the Mabo case ended the pernicious legal deceit of terra nullius for all of Australia—and for all time.

The Court described the situation faced by Aboriginal people after European settlement. The Court saw a "conflagration of oppression and conflict which was, over the following century, to spread across the continent to dispossess, degrade and devastate the Aboriginal people". They faced "deprivation of the religious, cultural and economic sustenance which the land provides" and were left as "intruders in their own homes".
To deny these basic facts would be to deny history—and no self-respecting democracy can deny its history. To deny these facts would be to deny part of ourselves as Australians.

This is not guilt: it is recognising the truth. The truth about the past and, equally, the truth about our contemporary reality. It is not a symptom of guilt to look reality in the eye—it is a symptom of guilt to look away, to deny what is there.
But what is worse than guilt, surely, is irresponsibility. To see what is there and not act upon it—that is a symptom of weakness. That is failure.
Mr President, some seem to see the High Court as having just handed Australia a problem. The fact is that the High Court has handed this nation an opportunity.

When the Prime Minister spoke last December in Redfern at the Australian launch of the International Year for the World's Indigenous People, he said we could make the Mabo decision an historic turning point: the basis of a new relationship between indigenous and other Australians.
For the seventeen months since the High Court handed down its decision, the Government has worked to meet this challenge.
The Prime Minister has made our response to the Mabo decision a personal priority. The Mabo Committee of Ministers has worked tirelessly. A team of officials has provided continuous support.

Right from the start, the Government recognised the national and historic importance of a proper response to the Mabo decision, and put in place a year-long process of consultation and detailed policy development.
Also right from the start, we made our twin goals clear: to do justice to the Mabo decision in protecting native title and to ensure workable, certain, land management.

We held extensive talks with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, State and Territory Governments and the mining and pastoral industries. Our processes were open. We kept on talking—always on the basis of accepting the Mabo decision and wanting to make it work.

One year after the decision, as part of our community consultations, we released a public Discussion Paper setting out the complex legal and other issues frankly and clearly, as well as examining possible ways to respond to them.

Continuing this deliberate and open approach, on 2 September we released a detailed draft Outline of possible Commonwealth native title legislation as a focus for public comment and for discussions with Aboriginal and industry representatives and with the States and Territories.
These were positive, detailed talks. They raised many important matters which have been taken up in the legislation I am presenting here today.
I won't say it was easy. Good policy rarely is. And the result will not—and could never—satisfy everyone. If it is to be good legislation it shouldn't even try.
This legislation is principled and workable, the product of a sustained and thorough policy process.

Mr President, this has been a huge undertaking on a subject of immense complexity. The rewards for the nation of getting it right are also immense. To retreat from this challenge, to say that this opportunity is beyond our reach as a nation, beyond the limits of our collective intellect and goodwill, would be to betray not just the indigenous people of Australia but ourselves, our traditions and our future.

It is to be hoped, Mr President, that those who have so far confined their role in Mabo to spoiling and over-simplification will now bring a constructive approach to their examination of this proposal.
The process has already seen much goodwill in the community, not least from people and groups whose interests and points of view are very different. Let us carry that goodwill into this Parliament.
The Bill has four key aspects:
ungrudging and unambiguous recognition and protection of native title;
provision for clear and certain validation of past acts—including grants and laws—if they have been invalidated because of the existence of native title;
a just and practical regime governing future grants and acts affecting native title; and
rigorous, specialised and accessible tribunal and court processes for determining claims to native title and for negotiation and decisions on proposed grants over native title land.
Mr President, this is a comprehensive and detailed Bill—as it has to be. Honourable Senators will find that Part A of the Explanatory Memorandum provides a useful overview.
Let me now address a number of key points.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The International Convention and the RDA

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation complies with Australia's international obligations, in particular under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

As indicated in the preamble, the legislation constitutes a special measure under the Racial Discrimination Act for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—providing as it does significant benefits such as special processes for determining native title; protection of native title rights; just terms compensation for any extinguishment of native title; a special right of negotiation on grants affecting native title land; designation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to assist claimants; and establishment of a national Land Fund.

Mr President, the Bill recognises that the bulk of dealings in land are done by the States and Territories. The Bill does not seek to change this situation—on the contrary it is properly sensitive to the prerogatives of the States. The Commonwealth is, however, playing its proper role in setting national standards and establishing a national framework for dealing with native title.
The Bill will enable State and Territory governments to validate their past grants with certainty provided they adhere to the standards set out in the Bill.

The Bill specifically provides for States and Territories to propose their own tribunals and arrangements for, firstly, determining native title claims and, secondly, deciding whether proposed grants affecting native title may be made. Provision is made for Commonwealth recognition of these State arrangements, and the criteria for this are set out clearly in the Bill.
Determination of native title claims may be in the Federal Court or a recognised State or Territory body. Appeals must, however, be in the same stream in which the case was initiated.

In regard to decisions on land use, where we have recognised State and Territory processes the Commonwealth will step back. State bodies, not the Commonwealth tribunal, will decide whether grants should proceed.
Such States and Territories will also be able to over-ride tribunal decisions in the State interest.

States and Territories who wish to see a national system with proper recognition of their land management responsibilities, and with fairness for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, will find it in this Bill. We will be happy to cooperate with them.
But we cannot accept West Australian style legislation involving:
compulsory, wholesale extinguishment of native title—a title embodied in the common law, and the inherent right of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who meet the criteria
the mandatory replacement of this by a statutory title—a title only conferred at the pleasure of government, and which can be extinguished in particular cases virtually at a Minister's whim
a land management regime which provides only the flimsiest protections for Aboriginal people—protections far less than other land holders enjoy.

If a government wishes to introduce a Bill permitting the voluntary conversion of native title to a statutory title it may do so under clause 20 of our Bill. But let Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people choose for themselves whether they want the native title affirmed by the High Court or some statutory alternative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Commonwealth's Approach to Native Title

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, native title is derived from the traditional laws and customs of indigenous people. These may vary considerably across Australia. This Bill does not codify native title rights. Rather it provides that, in determining native title claims, the Federal or State bodies involved will ascertain the rights in each particular case.
Because the foundation of our position is acceptance of the High Court's decision, the Bill protects native title to the maximum extent practicable.

Under the Bill, native title, once determined, will be held by a body corporate representing the native title holders' concerned. This will facilitate dealings in relation to the land and will endure over time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Validation and Security for Existing Grants

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, it is essential to safeguard the rights of those who hold existing grants of interests in land.

This Bill sets out a regime for the States to validate grants with certainty. It does not prevent States and Territories from attempting to validate on their own terms. But they would do so at their own legal risk. And the Commonwealth would obviously not, in that case, help meet any resulting costs.

Validation covers not only past invalid grants—made before 31 December 1993—but renewals and extensions as defined in the Bill. It also covers invalid actions of government. And it covers laws made before 30 June 1993.

Validation by the Commonwealth, or in line with the Commonwealth regime, limits the extinguishment of native title. Only validated freehold grants, residential, commercial and pastoral or agricultural leases, and validated Crown actions basically involving permanent public works, will extinguish native title.
Naturally, existing reservations for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will be preserved.
I draw attention also to the recording in the preamble of the Bill of the Government's view that under the common law past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title.
There is therefore no obstacle or hindrance to renewal of pastoral leases in the future, whether validated or already valid.
Validation of mining leases will not extinguish native title rights, which can again be exercised in full after the grant, and any legitimate renewals, have expired.

This is not discrimination against the mining industry, or some radical departure from existing practice. Let me quote, for example, section 113 of the Western Australian Mining Act: "When a mining tenement expires or is surrendered or forfeited, the owner of the land to which the mining tenement related may take possession of the land forthwith . . . ". Mr President, how can we offer native title holders any less?

Mr President, as well as clearing up the uncertainties of the past, this Bill provides for the future—it delivers justice and certainty for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, industry, and the whole community. It provides for the determination of native title and for dealings over native title land.
Generally, governments may make grants over native title land only if those grants could be made over freehold title.

This test is founded directly on a principle of non-discrimination. A government may not make a freehold or leasehold grant to somebody else over your or my freehold. If our title is to be extinguished, a government must acquire it and only for the purposes set down in compulsory acquisition legislation, and you or I must be given the protections involved. By contrast, a mining grant can generally be made over your or my freehold.

It will be exactly the same for native title. This is a clear, fair test which land managers in all jurisdictions can use. It does not mean that native title will amount to the equivalent of freehold in all cases.

Where native title has been established, or where there is a registered claimant in the Federal or State systems, the Bill provides a process of negotiation and, if necessary, determination by the tribunal on whether a proposed grant should proceed. The relevant Minister will be able to override tribunal decisions in the State or national interest.

This emphasis on Aboriginal people having a right to be asked about actions affecting their land accords with their deeply felt attachment to land. But it is also squarely in line with any principle of fair play. It is not a veto.

The time frames set for notification, negotiation and arbitration are tight but fair. Provision is made for expedited processes where a particular grant would not involve major disturbance to land or interference with the life of Aboriginal communities. Moreover, classes of grant can be excluded from the negotiation process altogether where they would have minimal effect on any native title. Certain prospecting and exploration permits would be likely to fall within this category.
Where native title has not yet been determined, Governments will be able to ascertain whether there is a credible native title interest in land over which they wish to make a grant.
Also, for example, a mining company operating on what has been assumed to be vacant Crown land will be able to seek a determination whether native title exists.

Normal compulsory acquisition procedures, including a right to compensation, will apply to native title land. This means that Governments can acquire land from native title holders, just as they can from other land holders, for public purposes such as infrastructure development.

The integrity of the land management system will thus be maintained. But we insist this be achieved in a way which respects the profound Aboriginal connection to the land and provides appropriate protections.

The Bill explicitly recognises that native title holders may choose to surrender inalienable native title on terms acceptable to them, for example to exchange it for a statutory title. For example, native title holders may wish to lease their land for a tourism or other commercial venture.

The Bill recognises further, that there may be cases where regional negotiation is the most efficient way to avoid or resolve conflicts over land use for large areas. Where we judge this to be a promising approach, the Commonwealth is prepared to facilitate such negotiation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Access to Tribunal and Court Processes

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the Bill concerns detailed arrangements to establish a National Native Title Tribunal and to develop a capacity in the Federal Court to determine native title and compensation claims. The Tribunal will conciliate and determine proposed uses of native title land where there are no recognised State or Territory bodies. The Bill sets out criteria for Commonwealth recognition of State bodies.

However, beyond this, the Government takes the view that a right cannot be said fully to exist unless people are empowered to pursue it. This is especially true for Aboriginal people, who are, as a group, the most disadvantaged Australians. Claimants for native title will need assistance to pursue their claims.

We will therefore, under the Bill, determine representative Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to assist claimants. They will not have a monopoly on representing native title claimants: individual claimants or groups of claimants can go elsewhere if they wish.

Representative organisations will also assist in coordinating claims: it is important that claims come forward in a sensible, organised way. They will also be a channel for notification of proposed actions affecting native title as provided for in the Bill.
The organisations will, of course, be fully accountable for any funds provided.

Where third parties are engaged in litigation involving native title, the Attorney-General will have a capacity to provide funding for legal assistance, should he consider it appropriate. The Government will be consulting key stakeholders—such as Aboriginal representatives and the NFF in establishing the guidelines that the Attorney-General will rely on in taking decisions.
Mr President, industry gains a very great deal from this Bill because it imposes clear, statutory rules for land use where the Mabo decision left uncertainty.

The Bill does not lock land away. On the contrary, as I have explained we are not setting up complicated barriers to mining exploration or operations. Where State processes, for example Mining Warden's courts, are suitably supplemented to take sensitive account of native title interests and are recognised by the Commonwealth, they—not the Commonwealth tribunal—will make decisions on mining applications. In our negotiations with the States, some constructive proposals have already been made in this regard, which are acceptable in principle to the Government.

Moreover, there is specific provision for matters decided at the exploration stage not to be re-opened when mining is being considered. Protections in State and Territory laws against over-bidding by another company remain. And existing mining operations will not face additional conditions or costs, for example for land rehabilitation, because of native title.

The Bill will ensure the validity of legislative regimes governing economic activities offshore—those relating to commercial fisheries and petroleum extraction operations being of particular note. However, recognising the different circumstances applying offshore, while any future grants or interests will have to be issued in a non-discriminatory manner, they will not be subject to the freehold test or to the associated negotiation and arbitration procedures.

In general the Bill provides that governments can confirm any existing ownership of natural resources, including forests and minerals. But any future acquisition of natural resources from native title holders must—properly—be on a non-discriminatory basis.

The Bill provides that Aboriginal people who own or acquire a pastoral lease, and who also would satisfy native title criteria but for the prior extinguishment of their rights, may choose to claim native title.

This is no back door: to get native title, the same criterion of continuing connection with the land will need to be satisfied. And the Bill provides that the pastoral lease may be maintained, so that the land need not be lost to pastoral use. The Government remains totally committed to a strong, viable pastoral industry: and to Aboriginal people's participation in it.
This Bill therefore offers clear provisions for dealings in native title land and certainty to our great resource-based industries.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Application of Laws to Native Title

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides that laws and regulations applying generally in the community also apply to native title land provided they are consistent with this Bill. This covers such matters as heritage protection, environmental and health controls and fishery regulation. Native title land is thus kept fully within the reach of Australian law.
The Bill allows existing access to beaches, waterways and other recreation areas to be confirmed.

Many specific laws affecting use and management of land are likely to need review to take account of native title. For example, the Commonwealth will, over the next two years, review our laws to better recognise native title hunting, fishing and gathering rights. We will be asking the States and Territories to do the same. I note too that the Bill does not affect rights under Commonwealth land rights legislation. We will be looking at a range of Commonwealth legislation, including Commonwealth land rights laws in light of the native title regime.

Mr President, in the interests of fairness for existing grant holders, where compensation is owed to native title holders for validation of past grants, it will be government, not the grant holder, who pays.

We recognise that the Commonwealth should make a proper contribution towards compensation costs. We will have further discussions with the States and Territories who are willing to join with us in this national approach, as well as on cost sharing for the legal and administrative regime.

Just terms will be payable for extinguishment of native title. We take the view that any special attachment to the land will be taken into account in determining just terms. Compensation for impairment, for instance for surface disturbance caused by mining, will be on the basis of existing State and Territory regimes.

Importantly, the Bill makes provision that compensation may be non-monetary, for example, the granting to native title holders of alternative land. It permits such issues to be raised in compensation negotiations, including where existing grants have been validated.

The Government has always recognised that despite its historic significance, the Mabo decision gives little more than a sense of justice to those Aboriginal communities whose native title has been extinguished or lost without consultation, negotiation or compensation. Their dispossession has been total, their loss has been complete.

The Government shares the view of ATSIC, Aboriginal organisations and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, that justice, equality and fairness demand that the social and economic needs of these communities must be addressed as an essential step towards reconciliation.
While these communities remain dispossessed of land, their economic marginalisation and their sense of injury continues.

As a first step, we are establishing a land fund. It will enable indigenous people to acquire land and to manage and maintain it in a sustainable way in order to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations.
Addressing dispossession is essential but will not be enough to overcome the legacy of the past and achieve reconciliation.

In a further stage, we will, in consultation and negotiation with ATSIC and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, look at ways to increase the participation of Aboriginal people in Australian economic life and to safeguard and develop Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture.

We will invite ATSIC and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, to develop proposals and to provide formal advice following the important National Reconciliation Convention to be held in October 1994.
What we will be looking for is constructive, realistic proposals, which will develop a positive community consensus and contribute to a lasting reconciliation.

Mr President, the Government will establish a Task Force of officials within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to oversee the practical implementation of this legislation. We are also providing the necessary funding this financial year for the Task Force to carry out its work.
No one should doubt our willingness to commit the effort and resources to make the scheme work, and work efficiently.

If the Bill is approved by Parliament, by 1 January 1994 most major aspects of the future regime will come into force. Aspects which depend on the establishment of new institutions will come into effect as soon as possible on a date to be prescribed.

Mr President, the land management challenges posed by Mabo are hugely important and they are comprehensively dealt with in the Bill. But let me conclude, as I started, on the wider significance of the Mabo case.

For today, as a nation, we take a major step towards a new and better relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. We give the indigenous people of Australia, at last, the standing they are owed as the original occupants of this continent. The standing they are owed as seminal contributors to our national life and culture: as workers, soldiers, explorers, artists, sportsmen and women—as a defining element in the character of this nation. The standing they are owed as victims of grave injustices, as people who have survived the loss of their land and the shattering of their culture.

Mr President, who can say that we would have survived these experiences as well as they have? Today we offer a modicum of justice to indigenous Australians because we have reached an understanding of their experience—and our responsibility.
Today we move that much closer to a united Australia which respects this land of ours, values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and provides justice and equity for all.
For already in the process of developing the Bill we have learned a great deal about each other and how to work together. We have extended the frontier of our mutual understanding.

Perhaps the most outstanding, but by no means the only, example of this has been the participation of representatives of the combined Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Organisation Working Party in the unprecedented negotiations leading to this legislation.

In hailing what she termed "a remarkable settlement and historic agreement", Lois O'Donoghue, the Chairperson of ATSIC—said, and I quote, "indigenous affairs will never be the same again in our nation".
It is for that reason above all, Mr President, that I commend this Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate just agreed to, the Native Title Bill 1993 stands referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and report by 9 December 1993.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993INCOME TAX (FRANKING DEFICIT) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 November and 27 October, on motions by Senators Collins and Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it two bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 and the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill 1993. The latter bill, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Amendment Bill, formally imposes what is known as a franking deficit tax. The majority of the changes introduced by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), including the amendments to be introduced during the committee stage, are indeed welcomed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: However, much to my dismay, there are two major changes in this bill which will cause some perhaps unintended consequences and some difficulties for the respective industries, namely, the petroleum mining industry and the life assurance industry. I refer in particular to the amendments concerned with the calculation of apportionment of tax deductions for life assurance companies and also the proposed abhorrent retrospective amendment disallowing deductions involved in certain overseas petroleum operations.

Apart from these two issues, the amendment bill (No. 3) contains amendments which are largely of a technical nature and involve minor changes introducing a degree of flexibility to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987 as a result of the report to parliament on the operations of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act at the end of 1992. These amendments enable exploration expenditure to be offset against receipts from other projects. There are minor changes to sales tax and also to insolvency legislation.

Arising from the budget 1993-94 announcements, there are provisions for relief for small businesses by deferring the initial payment of company tax in respect of the 1993-94 year, a move also welcomed by the opposition, and the exempting from income tax of income derived by non-profit organisations established for the purpose of promoting the development of tourism. There is also provision for sales tax exemption for goods used in various activities of the RSPCA.

The bill also makes changes to the imputation system as a result of the reduction in company tax for the year 1993-94 and later years of income, whereby the corporate tax rate is dropped from 39 to 33 per cent. A single franking account currently in existence will be replaced by dual franking accounts. This will allow companies to frank dividends with either the 39 per cent or the 33 per cent imputation credits tax, depending on the rate of tax which gave rise to the imputation for which credit was paid.

This new dual franking regime is indeed welcome because it avoids the loss of a franking credit which may otherwise have arisen from the drop in the corporate tax rate from 39 to 33 per cent. Previously, corporations did suffer a loss of a franking credit, particularly the last time that the rate dropped from 39 to 33 per cent. So this new dual approach is indeed welcome.

I call upon the tax authorities and professional bodies to make all corporations aware of the need to establish these new structures because, whether or not the mistake is intentional, these severe penalties are attached when errors are made. So I think it is incumbent upon government as well as the professional bodies to make well known throughout the corporate community the need for the establishment of these new structures.

Two accounts will be required—to be known as class A and class B franking accounts. The franking debits and credits arising in relation to the tax paid for 1992-93 and earlier years of income, including a credit that arises because of a franking surplus at the end of the 1993-94 year, will be posted as a class A franking account, and franking debits and credits arising in relation to the tax paid for 1993-94 in latter years on income will be posted to the class B franking account. The company rate for these years is the new lower rate of 33 per cent. The 39 per cent rate is for franking accounts A and the 33 per cent rate is for franking accounts B.

The substantial percentage drop in the corporate rate has caused other consequential changes which have been debated in this place previously, giving rise particularly to many legislative changes to the fringe benefits tax legislation because of the substantial gap that is in place between the corporate rate and the maximum personal rate plus the Medicare levy. This substantial gap gives rise to certain ingenious tax planning involving tax minimisation schemes which the government has yet to pick up.

The bill also proposes amendments to capital gains provisions so that they do not apply to capital gains and losses realised on the disposal of policies of life assurance or rights under policies of life assurance by complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation funds or trusts.

In addition, once again, the provisional tax provisions of the tax law have been amended to maintain the current uplift factor. It is now eight per cent for the calculation of provisional tax for the 1993-94 income year. In fact, the Senate would be well aware of my concerns about the operations of the provisional tax. Firstly, the eight per cent uplift factor is unrealistic, unjust and unduly harsh, considering that we are in a recession, considering the low rates of interest and considering the low inflation factor. The bill makes changes to fringe benefits tax and the superannuation guarantee. These are largely of a technical nature and I will not address them in my speech.

I now turn to the proposed retrospective tax measures. The Income Tax Assessment Act will be retrospectively amended from 20 August 1990 to ensure that deductions are not available in Australia for expenditures incurred in carrying out mining, quarrying or exploration activities associated with petroleum which do not generate assessable income in Australia. These changes refer particularly to the petroleum industry.

I draw to the attention of the Senate, in particular that of the Australian Democrats who can have a significant say in this outcome, that the professional bodies—the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Law Council of Australia—have all expressed grave concerns about the amendments as the government has decided to overcome an apparently defective drafting passed into law by amending the existing law retrospectively. The law was quite clear in terms of the statute passed by this parliament. This is the worry. It will be back-dated to 1990.

The joint submission of these bodies to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) refers to a press release issued by him which indicates that under a technical defect in the law a mining company could claim a deduction in Australia for expenditure incurred offshore, notwithstanding that the income from the offshore operation was not taxable in Australia. I was rather disturbed at the role that some of my colleagues on the scrutiny of bills committee played in relation to this very important issue. They did not inquire as to the other side of the picture; they just took advice from one side. They put so much emphasis on a technical defect that they were led to a wrong conclusion.

The submission that I have referred to states that unfortunately amendments made by the 1991 measures actually deleted the words `in Australia' from the relevant provisions. That is black letter law. It resulted in a change to the Income Tax Assessment Act permitting taxpayers to claim a deduction whether or not the expenditure incurred outside Australia was carried out for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income. The submission points out that the explanatory memorandum at the time did not make clear what the full intention of the change was to be. The law clearly needs to be amended. We and this community at large know that the government has the right to amend the law. That is not in dispute. However, the law should not be retrospectively changed where it will adversely affect taxpayers who acted on the law as it stood at the relevant time. The general principle as to retrospective taxation legislation cannot be swept aside by a government merely because of a technical defect so as to significantly disadvantage those taxpayers who have relied on the law as its stands.

My other concern is the length of time that it took the tax office and the government to bring about this change—two years. The apparent effect of the 1991 amendments was raised on two separate occasions by the professional bodies during regular consultations with the tax office. The first occasion was through the foreign income measures subcommittee of the National Taxation Liaison Group on 26 September 1991 when the industry and its agents brought it to the attention of the tax office. The second occasion was at a subsequent meeting in February 1992. The tax office merely noted at the first meeting that the matter would be examined and at the latter meeting that it was still being examined. There was no concern, no indication and no signal of change. It has all the hallmarks of a delay and an indifference similar to that which was adopted by the office during the horrendous days of the bottom of the harbour schemes.

There has to be some sort of sanction by this parliament for inaction by the government, particularly in circumstances when it is going to take away a black letter law entitlement that was previously in place. Where the law is clear, people do not have to go back and read what is said in the budget, the second reading speeches and all of those sorts of things, because businesses do not have access to the sort of information that we assume that they have. The tax office and the government assume—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they would know what was in the budget that affected them.

—We just assume that they have. We live in this ivory tower and we assume that everybody has this collection of records whereby they can have access to the inner feelings, emotions and meanings of the tax office. That just is not so in the real world. They are out there to earn a bob and arrange their affairs according to the law as it is made from time to time. They should be entitled to apply that until the law is prospectively—and not retrospectively—changed.

PARA.TAB: Given the period of time that has elapsed since those meetings, it is not unreasonable for tax advisers to take the view that the tax office perhaps has accepted that the relevant provisions operate according to its black letter tenor, particularly given the absence of any timely response. Why not a press release? Why not a note in the subsequent minutes? The silence is really deafening and worrying in relation to this issue, or a decision to amend. A crucial point that we have to note—I think this is just as serious as the retrospective law—is that the proper administration of law depends on the cooperation and goodwill of the professional bodies. They get invited to these meetings to make these submissions. They put the case to the tax office, not the other way around.

In good faith, they put the cards on the table and they got no response, apart from its being looked at—it was under examination, et cetera. This goodwill will surely break down if the tax office and the government act retrospectively to the detriment of the professional bodies and their clients as a result of issues which they raise. This is the serious part.

A further complication arises because we understand that at least one private ruling—and maybe others—to particular persons acknowledges these expenses were properly deductible. However, I am aware of one circumstance where a claim was denied. These circumstances raise a very difficult situation. How can a party, having received a private ruling, get on in terms of a retrospective law? All taxpayers have to be treated in the same way on the same issues.

It needs to be stated that retrospective legislation has really been used as an instrument freely to deprive citizens of their right, but usually only by repressive and non-representative or non-democratic governments. Once we see it used in this way in a democratic and free society, as the Law Council and others say, it undermines the confidence of the community in the fairness and certainty of our laws. This change has caused queries from other major companies in this country about other possible retrospective legislation. I give notice that the opposition will be moving an amendment.

It is regrettable that this amendment will lack support from the Democrats and the Greens. Where are their democratic principles? Earlier, we heard Senator Spindler praising the Law Council for its various pronouncements and recommendations. On this occasion, it has issued a pronouncement. It has written a letter to the government expressing its concern, but it thumbs its nose when it suits. There needs to be a degree of consistency in terms of justice. That is what we were looking at in the previous issue where the Democrats were at pains to point out the position as put forward by the Law Council. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter from the professional bodies to the Assistant Treasurer in relation to this problem of retrospectivity.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Law Council of Australia
The National Council of Lawyers
6 October 1993
The Honourable George Gear MP
Assistant Treasurer
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Assistant Treasurer

PARA.TAB: JOINT SUBMISSION BY THE LAW COUNCIL OF AUSTRALIA, THE TAXATION INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALIA, THE AUSTRALIAN SOCIETY OF CERTIFIED PRACTISING ACCOUNTANTS AND THE INSTITUTE OF CHARTERED ACCOUNTANTS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.PARA: COMMENTS ON PROPOSED RETROSPECTIVE AMENDMENT DISALLOWING DEDUCTIONS FOR OVERSEAS MINING, QUARRYING OR EXPLORATION EXPENDITURE—TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1993

We are writing on behalf of the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, and the Law Council of Australia (the professional bodies), to express our grave concern about your announcement of 4 August 1993 to the effect that the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will be retrospectively amended from 21 August 1990 to ensure that deductions are not available in Australia for expenditure incurred in carrying out mining, quarrying or exploration activities overseas which do not generate assessable income in Australia. This has now been incorporated into the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993.

Your Press Release indicated that under a "technical" defect in the tax law, a mining company could claim a deduction in Australia for expenditure incurred offshore notwithstanding that the income from the offshore operation is not taxable in Australia. You say this was never intended to be the case and it is a basic principle of tax law that deductions are not available for expenditure incurred in deriving exempt income.

The Explanatory Memorandum describing the changes to the relevant sections indicated that the effect of the amendments, for example, s.25 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Act 1991, amending s.124AH, was to extend the exploration and prospecting provisions by allowing a deduction in respect of operations carried on both in and out of Australia as long as those operations were carried out for the purposes of gaining or producing assessable income.

Unfortunately, the amendments made by the 1991 measure by deleting the words "in Australia" from the relevant provisions resulted in a change to the Income Tax Assessment Act permitting taxpayers to claim a deduction whether or not the expenditure incurred outside Australia was carried out for the purposes of gaining or producing assessable income. Whilst an explanatory memorandum may be of assistance in resolving ambiguity in a legislative provision or confirming its ordinary meaning, (see Acts Interpretation Act 1901, s.15AB) it is the Acts of Parliament that taxpayers must ultimately rely upon when determining their legal rights and obligations. This is clearly acknowledged by the decision to amend the law. If the Explanatory Memorandum could determine the meaning of the section, no amendment would be necessary.

The professional bodies are, therefore, most concerned that you have decided to amend the existing law retrospectively to seek to overcome the apparently defective drafting passed into law by the Parliament. The professional bodies clearly recognise the right of the Government to amend the law from time to time. However, amendments should not be given retrospective effect where they will adversely affect taxpayers who have acted on the law as it stood at the relevant time. There is, of course, a general principle against retrospective taxing legislation. This cannot be swept aside merely to deal with a "technical" amendment if the effect of the retrospective change is to significantly disadvantage those taxpayers who have relied on the law as it stands.

There are two further major aspects of concern here. First, the professional bodies in the course of their regular consultative processes with the Australian Taxation Office twice raised the question as to the apparent effect of the 1991 amendments. The first occasion was at the National Taxation Liaison Group, Foreign Income Measures Sub-Committee meeting held on 26 September 1991. It was indicated at that meeting by ATO representatives that the issue would be examined. At a subsequent NTLG Foreign Income Measures Sub-Committee meeting held on 2 February 1992, the ATO representatives advised that the matter was still being examined. Minutes of these meetings, issued by the ATO, are widely published, and tax advisers are well aware that in the absence of a timely response to an issue having been raised with the ATO, it may reasonably be taken that ATO accepts that the relevant provisions operate according to their tenor.

It is fundamental to the consultative process with the ATO that where issues of concern are raised with the ATO, clients of members of the professional bodies should not be retrospectively disadvantaged as a result of issues of concern being raised.

If the ATO or the Government were to act retrospectively to the detriment of the professional bodies and/or their clients in relation to matters raised by the professional bodies with the ATO, not only would matters of substance not be drawn to the ATO's and the Government's attention but ultimately the consultative processes would break down. Ultimately, the proper administration of tax law depends upon the co-operation and goodwill of the professional bodies.

The professional bodies understand that in this particular case the proposal to retrospectively amend the relevant provisions was raised with you by the ATO without informing you (through oversight) that representations by the professional bodies made to the ATO seeking clarification of the provisions had not been acted upon by the ATO previously. In these circumstances, we consider it is imperative that you review the decision to retrospectively amend the relevant provisions and reverse it.

Secondly, it may be possible, though we do not know whether it is so, that the ATO may have issued private rulings to particular taxpayers acknowledging that these expenses were properly deductible. How you would propose to identify whether this has occurred and to deal with that situation with retrospective legislation we do not know. Clearly, we consider that all taxpayers have to be treated in the same way on this issue.

Retrospective legislation has generally been an instrument used only by repressive and non-democratic governments to deprive citizens of their rights. Once it is used in a democratic and free society such as ours, it undermines the confidence of the community in the fairness and certainty of our laws. Since your announcement we have already had queries from major companies in this country about other possible retrospective legislation.
Such a destabilising result can not, in our view, be justified, particularly where it arises from an attempt to overcome a technical deficiency of the nature of that involved here.
The professional bodies look forward to your early decision on this matter.
Yours sincerely,
B.S. Virtue
Deputy Secretary-General

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to the problems being faced by the insurance industry in relation to the calculation and apportionment of tax deductions for life insurance companies. The proposed amendments were first announced by the Treasurer in a press release dated 31 May 1993. The first of the government's amendments, which aim to ensure that the formulas do not treat as assessable income the taxable superannuation components transferred by superannuation funds to life companies, was designed to correct a longstanding anomaly with transferred superannuation contributions. We and the industry are in complete agreement with this amendment.

PARA.TAB: As a result of recent discussions, the minister will introduce an amendment that will remove the difficulty whereby essentially annuities operated through life assurance companies were in a negative position. It provided a discrimination against life company offered annuities compared with other providers of such products. The reason for this amendment is that the CSRA, a class of assessable income, is a combination of both life insurance policies which are vested in the trustee of a complying superannuation fund and life insurance policies in relation to rollover annuities—`RA' relates to the rollover annuities—which do not vest in the trustee of the complying superannuation fund. As initially submitted, the amendment dealt only with the CS policies which needed to include the rollover elements as well.

The coalition was concerned that if the bill passed into law in its original form, the rollover annuities would be at a considerable commercial disadvantage. It is essential that there is a level playing field for the various providers of superannuation products. I regret that it took so long to get what was apparently a very simple amendment introduced into this place. A further problem is that the industry believes it contains a very fundamental flaw. We had an amendment which we were prepared to put on behalf of the industry to remove a distortion, because the amendment the government puts in will create a further distortion in excess of the one it seeks to rectify. Again, this is related to the calculation and apportioning of tax deductions of life insurance companies, which treats as assessable income super premiums and the investment component of life policies.

The problem is that the amendments go well beyond what was originally discussed with Treasury. The original discussions centred on the correcting of deficiencies in subsection 116CF(2), the expense apportionment formula, caused by the inclusion of taxable contributions transferred from superannuation to life insurance funds under section 275. The industry believes that it would be preferable for life insurance companies to use the existing basis for apportioning deductions until agreement is reached on the use of accepted—(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the result of an agreement between the government and the opposition for once—I would like to get that on the record—we are debating this taxation legislation at 25 minutes to midnight. The bill before us is a mixed bag of measures. On the one hand, it contains a range of long awaited exemptions from tax liabilities. I would like to tell Senator McMullan that I am looking forward to getting up to the RSPCA in my notes. I remember that debate last year very well. Child-care providers and non-profit tourism operators are also included. These measures have been much delayed and are welcomed.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the bill contains a range of other amendments to fix various drafting faults that have emerged in the tax laws. It is not much fun having a mopping up arrangement. In one case the government is wanting us to fix an unclear tax law on overseas petroleum development deductions going back to August 1990. I think it is incredible that the Australian Taxation Office has taken three years to sort this out. I give praise where praise is due, but this is not one of those occasions.

Then we have to consider the quality of the drafting. Following representations from professional bodies such as the life industry and the taxation institute, a number of technical amendments have been needed because the bill, as passed in the other place, will create more problems than it solves in some areas, particularly in relation to life assurance companies.

The Joint Committee on Public Accounts report on the tax office issued last week—not the dissenting report, but the body of the report—was extremely critical of the state of taxation legislation in Australia and urged a comprehensive rewrite of the legislation. The committee noted that the tax office recognised the need to do something fundamental and that the snowball has been rolling down the hill for a long time now, threatening to bury us.

The committee went on to note that the tax office's thinking on how to fix the problems was not very advanced. It also criticised the process the tax office uses for amending its legislation, commenting that the process has resulted in a body of unintelligible law. It also recommended better arrangements to provide more certainty and prompt law in legislation by press release. I endorse these recommendations. I do not think governments make it easy for the tax office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor does the Senate.
—I accept that; but Senator McMullan accepted one of my amendments last year, so he can take his share of the blame as well.

PARA.TAB: It is argued that, if the Taxation Office were able to take more seriously its consultative arrangements with industry and the taxpayer, messy pieces of omnibus legislation like this would perhaps no longer be necessary. The bill has a number of main purposes. These include amending the imputation arrangements of company tax and dividend franking deficit tax to take into account the reduction in the tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent.

Secondly, the bill amends various tax laws governing the deductibility of petroleum mining companies' overseas exploration expenses and corrects a drafting flaw in Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 6) 1990. Thirdly, it modifies tax arrangements for life assurance companies and policies held by complying superannuation funds, approved deposit funds or pooled superannuation trusts. Fourthly, it reduces the provisional tax uplift factor from 10 per cent to eight per cent for 1993-94.

Fifthly, it implements a 1993 budget decision to again defer by two months the initial payment of company tax instalments by small business. Sixthly, it allows the deductibility of the capital cost of establishing grapevines in Australia to be evenly deductible over four years. Seventhly, it amends the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 and the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act 1993, which we have just passed, to allow complying approved deposit funds to accept superannuation guarantee shortfall components.

The legislation also makes technical changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, the deductible donation provisions and the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987. I wish to speak on only a few of these matters.

The Democrats cautiously support the introduction of tax deductibility on the capital costs of developing vineyards. This measure, introduced as part of the budget discussions on the wine tax, is probably the most controversial part of the budget package of industry support measures.

My colleague Senator Meg Lees has been closely involved in these three-way discussions with government and industry. It is a very generous deduction. It has left grape growers concerned about speculators coming into the industry simply to gain the benefits of tax deductibility. They believe that this, combined with possible new planting by existing producers, could cause a major increase in grape production and a fall in prices in an industry which is already struggling.

It is vital that the effect of this tax measure and the assurance of the Winemakers Federation on new plantings be closely monitored in the development of the wine industry plan. Should wine production explode in an unsustainable way, this provision may need to be revisited.

I want to turn now to the extension of the sales tax exemption to child-care providers and the RSPCA. The Democrats are pleased to support these measures; they are measures which we have been advocating for a long time.

The sales tax exemption for various child-care providers, including for long day care, outside school hours care, vacation care, occasional care and family day care coordination, reflects the needs of those using child care in the 1990s. The proposal was included in the Democrats 1993 child care action plan, which we launched in the lead-up to the federal election. The provision of this exemption will result in the containment of child-care costs for many Australian families. We commend the federal government for taking this move which, as we say, is also reflected in the Democrats' policy.

The long-awaited decision to grant sales tax exemption for the RSPCA is another amendment that has finally come about. This amendment seeks to exempt the RSPCA, an Australian institution, from paying sales tax. Sales tax law has always recognised that public benevolent institutions should be exempt.

The need for this provision, as we visited last year in this debate, dates back to a 1931 High Court decision which held that the term `public benevolent institution' in the tax act is limited to those bodies which promote the relief of poverty, suffering, distress or misfortune. That extremely narrow test excludes the RSPCA, because the decision does not include bodies that promote the relief of suffering and distress of animals or the environment, only humans. We heard about the history of this last year.

The RSPCA has a branch in every state and territory in Australia. Its work is well known and supported. In October 1992, I moved an amendment to the sales tax law to establish an exemption for the activities of the RSPCA. On that occasion the government and the opposition combined to defeat that amendment. Senator McMullan gave a stirring speech about the bowerbird tendencies of the Australian Democrats and the way in which we were very prone—it is etched indelibly in my memory—to fly over and see glinting objects and dart down and pick them up. He was very disparaging. I notice that in this bill the bowerbird has come home to roost, only this time it is called the Labor bowerbird.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a deal.

—I did no deal. This is all the Labor party's initiative in picking up a Democrat idea. What has changed in a year, Senator McMullan? I am really curious to know. Last year Senator McMullan trotted out the lost dogs home and the cat protection society and he said, `No, I cannot give it to the RSPCA because what then do we do about these people?'. What do we do about the cat protection society and the lost dogs home this year? What has happened in one year? What has the RSPCA done to Senator McMullan in one year to make him drop his objection to this bower bird theory mentality and embrace the RSPCA's arguments?

PARA.TAB: The bill also amends the treatment of deductions for exploration and development expenses incurred in petroleum mining activities. This amendment will seek to correct a drafting error with the legislation introduced as part of the 1990 budget which modified the foreign income legislation to extend the deductions on certain capital expenditure on particular activities in Australia to similar offshore activities that generate income to be taxed here. The difficulty for the government arises because the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 6) 1990, which implemented the budget initiative, did not expressly make clear that deductions allowable for offshore exploration and development expenditure incurred in petroleum mining should only be allowed if it produced assessable income; that is, income generated in Australia.

The result is that the current legislation allows the expenditure used to generate tax exempt income to be offset against assessable income for petroleum companies. I have listened carefully to Senator Watson's case, and I will hear from Senator McMullan on this. I do not like retrospective tax legislation, and I know, Senator Watson, that the professional bodies—the law council, the tax institute and both accounting bodies—are appalled that it has taken three years for the tax office and the government to clarify this provision. Yes, we do have evidence that the industry, through the taxation liaison group foreign income measures sub-committee, asked the tax office twice—on 25 February 1992 and again on 21 May 1992—to clarify the issue. The tax office promised to look into it and, as I understand it, only finally determined its position in a press release from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr George Gear, on 4 August 1993.

I understand that between May 1992 and August 1993 one claim was lodged by one of the smaller companies and rejected by the tax office. But I do not think we can support Senator Watson's amendment because we think that, prior to 1990, companies were not allowed a deduction for expenditure incurred offshore. The 1990 budget decision lifted this restriction as part of a package of measures covering foreign income and allowed a deduction, but only where the expenditure was used to produce assessable income. If the income was exempt—that is, tax was paid in other comparable countries—then the restriction would remain in place. I guess it all comes down to this: because the vast majority of taxpayers affected have not applied, it appears this restriction was understood by the industry, despite the worst efforts of the tax office. We are not talking about taking something away by this retrospective provision, but clarifying a concession granted. Reluctantly, unless I hear something to the contrary, I will have to oppose Senator Watson's amendment.

I want to make it very clear to the government that it will face a heavy onus to persuade us in relation to future retrospectivity. We have already had this argument in relation to long service leave and recreation leave. The Democrats will also be supporting the amendment moved by the government on the treatment of deductions for life assurance companies. The legislation, as it was originally drafted, created—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that simply because one is a petroleum company?

—No, it has got nothing to do with whether one is a petroleum company. I told Senator Watson that it appears that the restriction was understood and they were just testing the limits. The legislation as it was originally drafted created a bigger problem for life offices than it solved in its treatment of the apportionment formulas between various classes of income. The government amendment brings the situation back to normal. Again, it is a matter of consultation with industry and not rushing the legislation.
—You assume everybody is guilty.

—Senator Watson, I do not assume everybody is guilty. That is not my view of the world at all. If this legislation had not been rushed, the provision would not have been needed. With those qualifying comments, the Democrats support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bills in this package are not of themselves earth shattering but are collectively significant. I do not wish to make a long speech at the second reading stage because I would like to get as much of the bill dealt with as I can, even though the time for the sitting today is drawing to a close. I will make only a most formal summing up. Senator Watson, Senator Kernot and I have essentially done this tax debate routine so often before that it is getting to be a tired act.
—Justify your position on the RSPCA.

—I do need to respond briefly to Senator Kernot. I have only two responses to Senator Kernot's comments about the RSPCA. There really are only two alternative interpretations. One is that we should stop Hansard recording what we say because then our words will not come back to haunt us. That is a problem that we all face from time to time, and it is not exclusive to the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: My second explanation is that the area of tax policy that I have left has been taken over by those with a kinder heart. I am sure that Mr Gear and Co. will be basking in the reflected glory of the decision that I was not prepared to support but that they have. I welcome the social benefit of it. I will bury my concern about the tax policy implications of it and hope that the benefits outweigh the costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you will never use that bowerbird theory again.

—I will never use it when it is not appropriate. The disposition seems to be fading somewhat in that corner of the parliament, so I hope that it might be a lasting change. I will not indulge myself any more with the Senate's valuable time so late in the evening. I thank honourable senators for their support. The important issue of retrospectivity needs to be debated, but I will do that at the committee stage.

TAB.TAB: (a)superannuation premiums to which subsection 111A(1) applies, being premiums in respect of CS policies;

(4)Clause 136, page 60, lines 34 to 36, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "136.(1) The amendments made by sections 134A, 134B and 135A apply in relation to eligible repair goods where tax was borne on a dealing with the goods on or after 1 January 1993.
"(2) The amendment made by section 135 applies in relation to sales tax amending Acts that receive the Royal Assent after 26 October 1993.".

SPEECH.PARA: (5)Clause 143, page 63, line 7, omit "CR22", substitute "CR23".

I acknowledge that the committee stage of the debate will not be finished this evening but I welcome the opportunity to put the government's amendments on the record. The amendments involve changes to deductions allowable to life assurance companies and credits for sales tax paid in respect of parts used in certain repair activities.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment is required to ensure that the formula in section 116CF, which allocates current year non-exclusive deductions between classes of income of a life assurance company, operates to allocate all of the relevant deductions. The bill as presently drafted includes certain amounts in the denominator of the section 116CF formula. However, it does not include all of these amounts in the numerators used to apportion non-exclusive deductions to the various classes of taxable income.

The rollover annuity—RA—factor has not been included. The result may well be that in some cases not all of the allowable deductions relevant to the complying superannuation rollover annuity class can be allocated to that class of income. The CS/RA component is taxed at 15 per cent. The position is to be remedied by this amendment to the bill.

Amendments (2), (3), (4) and (5) will provide a sales tax credit for tax paid on parts used in the repair of goods that are, at a later date, sold or transferred by the repairer to another person for use as business inputs in the primary production, mining and manufacturing industries. Under the current sales tax law, goods producers—such as farmers, miners and manufacturers—are entitled to exemption on parts purchased by them for use in the repair of their goods producing machinery. Similarly, if a goods producer contracts for such repairs to be carried out by another person and parts are supplied in the course of the repair, exemption applies to those parts. However, there is no exemption for parts used in the repair of machinery owned by a machinery dealer or repairer if the machinery is later for sale or transfer by the repairer or dealer to a goods producer.

The credit will apply from 1 January 1993—the commencement date of the streamlined sales tax legislation—and will cost approximately $25 million per annum. Full details are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum that I now present to the Senate. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The federal Liberal-National party coalition welcomes the amendments. They are in two parts. With regard to the deductions allowable to life assurance companies—the first heading—we will not proceed with two amendments that have been circulated which would have corrected the deficiency in the original bill, giving some degree of justice, particularly in the area of rollover annuities.

PARA.TAB: However, there is one further issue that has not been addressed, and that concerns the basis of apportioning deductible items. It is my understanding that there is a continuing dialogue between the industry and the tax office in the hope that an agreement on apportionment on a factual basis can be arrived at. I seek, therefore, a confirmation of this from the government because I regard this continuing dialogue to move to a more factual basis of apportionment as particularly important, particularly as what we have just enacted really exacerbates a situation that disadvantages the industry in relation to a disproportionate weighting to the 15 per cent superannuation class. As we all know, the policies being issued at present are weighted more heavily in terms of superannuation type products, of which the life companies have something like 30 per cent. That side of their life business, of course, has been affected quite considerably.

The other amendment is to provide a tax credit for parts used in the repair of business inputs. I must remind the chamber that this was an unfortunate omission from the streamlined sales tax, which commenced on 1 January 1993, despite assurances given in response to the questioning by the Liberal-National party. I ask: how will companies be able to recoup the lost sales tax in terms of its being applied as from 1 January? The amendment, of course, will be of considerable benefit to farmers, miners and manufacturers, especially in circumstances where the repairs are carried out by other people on their behalf. But a question which I am particularly concerned about is: will there be a lost credit in respect of past transactions, or will people be able to claim that credit, because the amendments ostensibly relate back to 1 January?

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
