SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to address the present situation in the sugar industry, a major industry in Queensland. The Queensland raw sugar industry has just had a most productive year. It is a very important industry for Australian employment and export earnings. The industry is on the verge of entering a new export phase in refined white sugar. It will provide a whole new dimension to the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: It has just been announced that a joint venture between CSR, Mackay Sugar Co-operative and the British based trading company E.D. and F. Mann is under threat by the refusal of the Trade Practices Commission to give the refinery the go-ahead. Australia has an opportunity to become a major player in the growing international white sugar market through a new refinery being built in Mackay. The joint venture refinery is a $200 million project. For the first time Australia will be in the position of having a refining capacity surplus to domestic requirements and will have the chance to become a major exporter of refined sugar. The joint venture is set to yield 160,000 tonnes of refined sugar for export a year compared with 20,000 tonnes currently exported.

The new Mackay refinery would be a world ranking, low cost refinery with associated storage facilities. It would also run a high-tech bulk carrier that can bag sugar en route to overseas markets. It would be a state-of-the-art refinery and would allow Australia to enter the white sugar market with the advantage of a highly efficient and world competitive refinery.

The sugar industry is the economic lifeblood of many communities along the 2,100 kilometres of coastline of Queensland and northern New South Wales. The industry employs 19,000 people in growing, milling, storage and marketing and benefits another 26,000 indirectly. Sugar contributes about $3.3 billion to the Queensland economy each year. Every dollar earned by the industry creates a further $1.55 in other sectors of the economy. Ninety-five per cent of all cane farms are owned by 6,700 cane farmers.

The Australian raw sugar industry is a world leader with a reputation for technical innovation, product quality, reliability and customer service. Over the last five years the industry has made an enormous investment in its continued future. Growers have expanded the area under cultivation by 33 per cent; mills have rationalised and expanded; and a new refinery has entered the market increasing competitiveness in the refining industry. Despite massive subsidies provided to sugar producers in the US, EC and Thailand, which lower the world price and compete unfairly in the world markets, Australia remains internationally competitive. This year, Australia was the world's largest exporter. Domestic sales represent the industry's largest single outlet—800,000 tonnes—and Australian consumers pay the lowest sugar prices in all OECD countries and lower than in many developing countries.

All in all, the industry forms an important mainstay to many regional economies. It is a growing industry and a major export earner. It is also an industry in which growers have traditionally been involved in downstream and value adding processing of their product through involvement in the milling process. The sugar industry has been a model industry for this government's policy of Australian farmers investing and becoming involved in downstream processing and value adding. It is why it makes sense for growers to be involved in the next step of processing of their raw sugar—that of refining.

The Australian raw sugar industry is a leading exporter, being the world's largest exporter this year. Last year, exports of raw sugar increased by 14 per cent to Japan with Japan taking 50 per cent of all imports from Queensland. There were record sales to Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and New Zealand. Unfortunately, the US reduced its quota by approximately 16,000 tonnes, and the NAFTA agreement will have long-term effects on Australia's imports into the US with Mexico eventually receiving tariff free access to the lucrative US market.

The raw sugar export market is a stagnant market. In contrast, the white or refined sugar market is an expanding market. The government's own agricultural research organisation, ABARE, has just released a paper on the effect of Australia entering the refined sugar export market. ABARE has concluded that Australian farmers will gain from such a move, with increased revenue of around $2,500 a year for each grower. ABARE has predicted that, as a result of Australia entering the refined sugar export market—a market currently worth about $5 billion a year—the Australian raw sugar industry will receive increased returns of $23 million a year. Yet, despite the many acknowledged benefits from involvement in the white sugar export market, the Trade Practices Commission has indicated that it intends to block the joint venture establishing the new refinery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—If the honourable senator would allow me to develop my argument, I will come to that. I think that Professor Fels and the commission should reassess the decision to stop the merger because it will prevent Australia's entry into a new export market—the refined sugar market. Such a decision will be a great blow to development of the sugar industry—a future successful, guaranteed export earner.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, there are three refiners—CSR, Bundaberg Sugar and Manildra. Manildra, in New South Wales, only became operational a few years ago. Before that, Australia had only two refineries. After the entry of the joint venture there will still be three refineries—but three refineries that would produce sufficient surplus for Australia to enter the more stable white sugar market.

I have always been a supporter of more competition in the marketplace. I was a most forceful proponent of the change to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to allow more competition through changes to the mergers provisions. I have continually campaigned over the last three years to raise this issue—in parliament, within my own party and in the press—to point out the problems that Australia's competition policy was causing the business community. In a speech in parliament last December, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: It must be recognised that with a small population of 17 million people, with most competing countries using world class technology, there must be room to buy or amalgamate, but there must be balance.

I have always argued that balance must be maintained, and balance is what I am calling for now. I am calling for Professor Fels and the Trade Practices Commission to acknowledge that we must have balance. Australia is down to two breweries, and that is excessive market power. When we get to three refineries, that will be all that Australia can adequately handle.

PARA.TAB: Yet, on a long-term view, with the establishment of the new joint venture refinery in Mackay, there will be no loss of competition in the market. Instead, as an added bonus, there will be development of a new export industry and grower involvement in value adding and downstream processing. When one considers the current plight of many rural industries and producers—negative incomes and the struggle to hold on to properties—involvement in processing beyond the farm gate provides a sensible course for farmers by which to increase their returns and maintain their independence.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, and the government have been telling farmers continually that they must become involved in downstream processing. No-one on this side of politics—and I include the Democrats—would disagree, but we should not put hurdles in the way when the opportunity arises. The refinery at Mackay would have given canegrowers a 25 per cent share in CSR's sugar refining business in Australia and New Zealand through its equity in Mackay Refined Sugars. It would be a very positive way for Queensland's sugar industry to maximise the downstream effect of value adding, as has been strongly advocated by state and federal Labor governments.

If the Trade Practices Commission refuses to give the go-ahead for the joint venture, as it has indicated, there may be a short period when a price war reduces the domestic price for sugar. But there are many uncertainties about any permanent price reduction. It is certain that there would be a destructive price war which could not be sustained for long before one refiner would have to go out of business.

It may just be that the new refinery, owned by the farmers, would fail as it would not have a well-developed domestic market. Most sugar sold in Australia—in fact, 80 per cent of domestic sugar—is used by a few large food processors. There are certainly no guarantees or means within the Australian system that ensure that any savings in costs to processors will be passed on to the consumer. Consumers in the past have certainly not benefited from any reductions in sugar prices when they have occurred.

The domestic price of sugar in Australia is one of the lowest in the OECD, and it is lower than in many developing countries. There is also a scheme whereby exporting food manufacturers receive assistance on their exports. It is a rebate scheme paid for by the industry and is currently around 10 per cent ad valorem.

There is a very important restraint on the domestic price of sugar. I have often spoken in this place about the massive subsidies given to our competitors in the US, the EC and Thailand, which in turn reduce the world price of sugar. This very same artificially lowered world price acts as a price restraint on the domestic price. It is the import parity price that sets the Australian domestic price, not the number of refineries in Australia.

The Trade Practices Commission seems to think that if it refuses the new refinery permission to set up, we will end up with a permanent situation of four refineries. A domestic market of 17 million people is not large enough for four refineries. After much pain and damage to the industry, the market will demand that there be only three refineries, but the process gone through to arrive at this stage will be at a huge and unnecessary cost to the industry. It will involve a tremendous waste of resources to the industry.

The government has seen a similar situation and a similar tussle with the motor vehicle industry. Eventually a government plan was needed to bring the industry back to the three local manufacturers that the Australian population could support. Let us not go through all the pain, suffering and bankruptcies to reach this decision which can be made now: Australia can maintain only three refineries.

I am concerned that the refusal of the Trade Practices Commission will result in the loss of a new export market in refined sugar and that an excellent opportunity will be lost for farmers to involve themselves in further downstream processing of their industries.

Stabilising benefits would be returned to the industry from an involvement in both the raw sugar and refined sugar export markets. It would help the industry to be involved in the more stable and expanding white sugar market. ABARE has confirmed this, and the only way it will achieve this is by the development of the Mackay refinery by the joint venture, combining the marketing skills and personnel of CSR and the state-of-the-art facility in the new Mackay refinery.

It would be a great shame to lose this opportunity to develop a new export industry when the economy is crying out for increased export earnings to lower our deficit and create jobs. A successful and secure new refinery in Mackay would not only provide new jobs and investment to the Mackay region but also give growers and the Australian economy a boost. The sugar industry would be on a secure path to a new venture in the white sugar export market.

I call on the government to consider the wider benefits that would flow to both the sugar industry and the whole Australian economy from the new joint venture. The government cannot turn its back on a new project and ensuing export industry that will lead the sugar industry into a new era; replace old technology with the latest technology; create jobs and investment in regional Australia; involve farmers in value adding beyond the farm gate in line with their own policy; and create new opportunities in the growing white sugar market beyond the present stagnant raw sugar market, particularly in view of certain market losses from the new NAFTA agreement.

Australian rural producers are internationally competitive and world leaders in their field. This new refinery represents an opportunity that must not be lost for Australian sugar producers to extend their export markets and increase their returns through investment in their own industry.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Cultural, Recreational and Sporting Facilities Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly during the adjournment debate to raise a very serious matter concerning what has become known as the sports rort affair. I want particularly to emphasise its impact on my own area in the Hunter Valley. The Senate is aware that the Auditor-General has found very serious problems with the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program and its administration by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Ros Kelly.

PARA.TAB: Today in the House of Representatives the minister was questioned about the program, and one grant in particular to the Eastern Suburbs Maitland Cricket Club. Maitland is my home area in the Hunter and, therefore, the questions asked of the minister are of great concern to me. I believe they were of great concern also to the people in the electorate of Patterson which, before the last federal election, was the most marginal seat in Australia.

Today in the House of Representatives the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories was questioned by the shadow minister for youth sport and recreation, Mr Ronaldson, on the disgraceful sports rort affair and the granting of $49,000 to the Eastern Suburbs Maitland Cricket Club. Mr Ronaldson asked the minister whether she knew or approved of a grant to a club that had no ground, for which no development or building application had been lodged, and whose paddock that was being used by the club as a practice ground was near an old gasworks and is now being checked out by the Environment Protection Authority for possible contamination.

The minister was also asked about the role of a member of the club, Mr Tony Keating, the endorsed state Labor candidate for Maitland and now a staff member of Mr Bob Horne, the member for Patterson. The minister totally failed to answer the very important questions Mr Ronaldson was raising. The sum of $49,000 is a lot of money to be promised to an organisation without proper controls to ensure that the money is well spent. There are many other genuine community projects in our area that could have done with that money as well.

The disgrace is that the whole community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program is worth $30 million and the Labor government has used it in the most outrageous pork-barrelling exercise in marginal seats that we have ever seen in this country. The money was meant to last until at least 1994 and Mrs Kelly gave almost all of it away to marginal Labor seats in the few months leading up to the last federal election. The average grant given to a marginal Labor seat was exactly double the average given to a marginal coalition seat before the election.
In a condemning report the Auditor-General has stated that the minister kept inadequate documentation on the reasons for her decisions to award the grants. The Auditor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . claims that decisions on the allocation of grants were politically motivated could not be put to rest.

That is the key point on page vii. Some very serious questions have been raised about the propriety of the ALP, including pork-barrelling in Patterson and the involvement of local ALP members. Mrs Kelly has said that she will check the details of the questions raised. I hope she does exactly that and accepts the responsibility for her actions and those of her co-conspirators in the ALP.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Kelly's continued refusal to date to answer these serious questions can only lead to the conclusion that the allocations of the grants were politically motivated. The Auditor-General has raised many criticisms of the program and has been forced to leave many questions unanswered because of the lack of accountability and the lack of documentation by the minister. The minister should produce the evidence that she has not been involved in this outrageous pork-barrelling exercise or she should accept the consequences of her actions and resign.

The question of ministerial responsibility was one that came up recently before the Senate Select Committee on Pay Television Tendering, of which I was deputy chair. We looked at this whole question of ministerial responsibility. After considering Senator Collins' case, I am sure that what we found out about ministerial responsibility and why ministers should resign is certainly very much applicable to Mrs Kelly.

Often a minister is required to resign because the department does something wrong and the minister remains ignorant of these actions. Kellygate is much worse because the minister has done something wrong and the department seems not to have known about it. This is a far worse offence and she should do the proper thing and resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret getting up at this late hour, but the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Crowley) is in the chamber and I want to take advantage of that fact. Today Senator Crowley was offended by my calling her a liar—a remark which I withdrew. While Senator Crowley may have privilege within this chamber about the use of such language, she does not hold privilege outside the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I know that her office has been disseminating lies about me. I have had constituents call my office to say that her staff are calling me a liar. I warn Senator Crowley about the blackguards in her office who have become very nervous and shaky about the massive public outrage over the accreditation handbook. I warn Senator Crowley that there is no parliamentary privilege outside this chamber. I also alert Senator Crowley to her own comments on radio. I will be obtaining transcripts of the comments she has made in attempting to refute my accusations.

I wish to take the opportunity before the Senate rises to appeal to the Green senators. As the issue of the accreditation handbook has caused such massive outcry and outrage by the public, the matter is now in the hands of the Greens, who hold the balance of power in this chamber. I appeal to the Greens, on behalf of the greater majority of the Australian public, to take the time between now and when the Senate returns in seven days to read and fully understand the accreditation handbook; to fully understand the massive weight of public support against this handbook; and, moreover, to understand that this handbook has not been put together by the industry, as the minister would have them believe, but rather by a clique of people appointed by the minister calling themselves the Child Care Accreditation Council. It is nothing more than a clique under the minister's control.

I say to the Greens that there is unprecedented outrage against this handbook. All the signals show that the Greens at this stage are not supporting the coalition in its stance against the handbook, but I believe they should, in the next seven days, take the time to talk to the people, understand their points of view and place themselves, just for once perhaps, in the mainstream thinking of Australia. If they do not, they will always be on the fringe, representing fringe people.

On 8 December they will have an opportunity, when these accreditation regulations come before the Senate, to place themselves in the mainstream thinking of Australia. If they do not, they will never be forgiven for letting the Australian people down.

I do have some faith in the two Green senators because they have shown a great deal of independence from and resistance to the government during the budget sittings, over the Mabo bill, and on many other issues. Here is another chance for them to show that they really are not just a fringe group but that they can from time to time connect with mainstream Australian values.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Boswell, I ask Senator Crowley when she will provide Senator Boswell with the document that she promised him at question time today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to wind up today by thanking honourable senators for their contribution to this adjournment debate, but Senator McGauran came in and I do not thank him at all. I categorically refute Senator McGauran's revolting charge against my staff. If he had any idea of what my staff have been doing in the last few days, he would know that what he said about them is disgraceful.

PARA.TAB: Under parliamentary privilege, Senator McGauran has abused those people who are not here to speak for themselves but who have been refuting his outrageous claims. Under parliamentary procedure, I am not allowed to describe those claims as lies. Senator McGauran is an absolute disgrace.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I ask Senator Crowley to withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Disgrace' is unparliamentary.
—Very latterly it is unparliamentary.
—Withdraw the unparliamentary remark.
—I am meditating on that, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—She can't meditate.
—I can meditate. I can take my time to do this and I do. I withdraw that. What one would say about Senator McGauran would probably be unparliamentary in any parliament.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Crowley well knows that she cannot impugn the integrity of any honourable senator or member of parliament. Senator Crowley is obviously upset. I ask her to calm down before she says something that she will regret.
—That was not a point of order.

—I am not sure what is worse—Senator Boswell's pathetic patronising or Senator McGauran's deliberate misleading misrepresentation of the truth. If Senator McGauran wants to come in here and say the things he said about my staff and take the high moral ground, he should go for it. But he should not dare expect me to accept one word of that. Let me say to anybody who is daft enough to be listening at this time of night that I find it appalling that Senator McGauran should smear the good name of my staff in that way. It is despicable but not unexpected behaviour.

PARA.TAB: I sincerely hope that, when Senator McGauran goes to bed at night, he finds it possible to lie straight because he has created the most awful misrepresentation of the truth out there. Tonight he actually wanted to say that I appointed the accreditation council.

TALK.START.PARA: —You controlled it.
—I controlled it!
—They are all your friends.

—My friends! I controlled it and I appointed its members! Senator McGauran ought to chase a few facts. The discussions on the accreditation process started in the early 1990s. Those discussions were running in 1991 and the interim National Accreditation Council was formed in 1992. The appointment of its members had nothing to do with me.
—You are the government.

—Senator McGauran wants to say that the government appointed the representatives. That is a pathetic long bow. He is now drawing that bow over his pathetic mistake—his misrepresentation of the truth—not knowing what he is talking about. Senator McGauran really ought to do some work instead of taking the stuff that somebody is feeding him because they have got it wrong or they have got it right but he has not got it right. He is getting the message very wrong. He does not know what he is talking about. That is pretty obvious, which is a shame because a whole lot of people in this community are now very distressed by the appalling, despicable campaign that Senator McGauran has run.
—Of course they are distressed.

—I am not distressed; but I said today that I do not support a campaign where anybody anonymously rings up women in this country saying, `I know where your child goes to child care'. I find that absolutely abhorrent and totally despicable. Anonymous phone calls are disgusting at the best of times—and these are people who claim to have the care of our children at heart! If I knew who those people were, I would certainly be prepared to make that information public. I cannot think of anything lower or more despicable than to threaten people like that.
—What has that got to do with us?
—Senator Boswell is whipping up the campaign.
—We are telling the truth.

—No, those opposite are not telling the truth. They insist on not hearing a word I say and having their own views. The night is but young, I feel. I know about child care. I am here to talk to those opposite. Good evening, gentlemen. I am happy for those opposite to stay and listen to all I have to say about child care. I think it is time that Senator McGauran actually heard the whole story and got it absolutely right.
—This will be real punishment!
—Yes. I might do that or I might change my mind; it just depends. Of course, I realise that I cannot possibly ask Senator McGauran to believe the truth about anything—which is a great shame.

PARA.TAB: I can tell Senator McGauran one thing: he has made so many mistakes tonight that it is quite clear that he does not know a single thing about this subject. No, I did not appoint the people to that council; no, I did not nominate those people; no, they are not my `mates'; and no, they were neither under my instruction nor anybody else's. In fact, Senator McGauran should know that some of them were actually chosen as representatives from the private child-care industry itself. A position was declared for the confederation and the federation, and those organisations themselves nominated people.

Senator McGauran shakes his head and indicates that that is not true. I think that is very interesting. It is quite clear that he does not want to hear the facts; he does not want to know what the facts are. The facts are that Senator McGauran has misrepresented the truth again—and `misrepresented' is hardly the word to use. I would much rather leave the chamber and call him what he is. He has given a disgraceful, dishonourable and deliberate misrepresentation of the facts. He does not know that categories of people from the private industry were indicated and they nominated people. That is not the government or me and my mates manipulating people.

The next thing Senator McGauran should know is that all that happened before I became minister. I had no say in any of that at all. He is drawing a very long bow. Senator McGauran needs to know the difference between the Interim National Accreditation Council and the National Accreditation Council. I suspect that, until now, he has not even thought about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the people.

—I think the people of Australia need to know the assurance I have given over and over: if ever a Christmas carol is banned, I want to be the first to know of it; if any children are denied trains or dolls, whether they be girls or boys, I want to hear about it.

PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran has run amok; he will continue to run amok—and that is not an inappropriate description of his actions. There is nothing I can really do to contribute further to the discussion. It is becoming obvious to me that Senator McGauran is hell-bent on deliberately misunderstanding and misrepresenting. Just tonight on this adjournment debate, he has made that patently clear. Either he did not know what he was talking about or he was very happy to misrepresent the facts.

It is a pretty stupid way of going about things. Indeed, Senator McGauran may have his moment in the sun in the short term, but in the long term there is no place for that kind of misrepresentation; no place for that kind of campaign; and no place for deliberately obfuscating, confusing and misrepresenting the truth to people—none at all. One of these days, it will all come back to haunt him.

People out there are beginning to understand what it all means. The campaign has been whipped up by a small section of the private child-care industry which contributed to designing the guidelines and which is now backing away from them for reasons I do not know—I suspect that Senator McGauran does because he is obviously talking to that small section and running with that campaign by that small percentage of the private industry.

The section which is running with this campaign is trying to feed Senator McGauran his lines—but he is getting them wrong. He will have to listen a whole lot more, because it does not do his reputation any good to be so obviously wrong. I think people will be shocked when they discover how often Senator McGauran has been so wrong. We will have to say, `Well, there goes Senator McGauran again'. We can call him `Wrong McGauran'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are Calamity Jane.
—I think that what is sadly lacking in that corner of the chamber is the civilising presence of Senator Bjelke-Petersen.
—She would be horrified.

—I am sure she would be, Senator Boswell. She would be absolutely horrified by what those opposite have been doing. I could speak to Senator Bjelke-Petersen and I know what she would say about the terrible business that those opposite are going on with—`I think it is a terrible pity'.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I think that the minister has made aspersions on a part of this chamber which I think she should withdraw. She has made the aspersion on me and my colleagues that this part of the chamber is not as good as it should be. I think that is an aspersion on everyone, and I think it is quite incorrect.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not believe that is a point of order, but I ask Senator Crowley to address her remarks through the chair and not react to interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, you are quite right on that point, Mr Acting Deputy President, but Senator Brownhill is quite right too when he acknowledges that there is something very disappointing about that quarter of the chamber.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have another point of order. I think the minister is now having trouble hearing because I did not say that, and I think the Hansard will prove it.

—Speaking to the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I like Senator Crowley's attitude of deference to you in the chair. She now squats on the side arm of the chair and she stood through all of Senator Brownhill's points of order deliberately juggling as if she were a juggler in a circus rather than taking a proper respect for this chamber and, in particular, yourself.

—I was watching Senator Brownhill, but I think it is very late and there is perhaps a tendency for us to be getting strained at this time of night. I think Senator Crowley might be rounding off her remarks.

—I think it would be a good idea, too, but I suspect that it is hard to round off my remarks. As Senator McGauran said, he was terribly chuffed to find me in here because he had come in to put on the record again his clear statement of not knowing what he is talking about on child care. It seemed to me perfectly proper to remind him that he does not know what he is talking about. But when he is talking, he is responsible for creating a lot of very unhappy and anxious people. Unfortunately, that seems to be the price of democracy.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit like parliamentary privilege, which was designed in the first place to protect people who wanted to make truthful statements and had to have the protection of the parliament to ensure that they were not in any way in jeopardy for telling the truth. But what we find now is that, in the name of democracy and parliamentary privilege, senators tell untruths and get the same protection. I think it is worthy of the greatest consideration by this chamber that parliamentary privilege is now being abused in the name of protecting people, and that allowing the protection it offers them is support for people misrepresenting the truth. I would like to close my comments there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great shame in this place when name-calling becomes a substitute for intelligent, reasoned argument. What we have seen tonight is a tirade from Senator Crowley which masquerades as intelligent debate but which is, in fact, nothing but name-calling. I was reminded, as I was sitting here listening to this barrage of abuse which has been directed at my colleague Senator McGauran, of the bad days in Australia when racism really did exist in this country, when people would be teased, taunted and jeered at and we got the sort of nastiness that we have just seen this evening. It was very sad because I do not think there is a place in this society for the bitter vindictiveness which was behind some of the name-calling to which Senator McGauran was subjected this evening.

PARA.TAB: Many of the comments were clearly unparliamentary. I listened to Senator Crowley's speech from start to finish. I saw the first bit of it on the closed-circuit television and the rest in this chamber. When an honourable senator is accused of deliberately misleading people, that is an unparliamentary comment. It has been ruled unparliamentary in the past; it has been ruled unparliamentary recently; and nothing which has happened tonight will change the fact that that comment is unparliamentary. In being applied to Senator McGauran it is also wrong.

Senator McGauran was smeared with all sorts of dreadful allegations. Senator Crowley said tonight—as she has said in the past and, I think, today—that people were phoning up parents and saying, `I know where your child goes to child care'. I am quite simply at a loss to find the relevance of that matter to the issue of child care, or to Senator McGauran for that matter. Unless, of course, Senator Crowley is suggesting to this chamber—and, if she is, here is her chance to affirm it—that Senator McGauran would be behind that sort of conduct. Is silence consent?

Does the minister perhaps realise that it is unsatisfactory to say those sorts of things and imply that any honourable senator in this chamber would indulge in that sort of behaviour? It is either irrelevant or the grossest slur that can be cast across this chamber. Yet that is what we have seen. I do not believe that Senator Crowley tomorrow will want to read the Hansard of what she has said tonight. I do not believe that Senator Crowley next week will feel that what she has said tonight has raised her in the estimation of honourable senators. I do not believe that Senator Crowley, if she remains a minister, will look on this speech tonight as one of her most learned and balanced contributions.

Most importantly, I do not think Senator Crowley, by her conduct in this matter, has indicated herself to be a person who is willing to accept the responsibilities of high office. After all, Senator Crowley is the minister who brought these guidelines before this parliament, tabled them in this place and put her seal of approval on them. Does Senator Crowley mean to say that she tables guidelines in this place of which she does not approve? If she does not approve, then she should say so. But she does not do that. Senator Crowley approved of those guidelines and yet, when criticism was made of those guidelines, she tried to blame it on somebody else. But what she has to understand is what we on this side of the chamber understand and what many of her colleagues on the other side of the chamber understand and that is, that in matters such as this, the principle of Westminster democracy and ministerial responsibility applies.

It does not do a minister any good to attempt to say that somebody else wrote the guidelines when that minister came before this place, tabled those guidelines in this chamber and sought the approval of this Senate for the implementation of those guidelines. That is the problem that Senator Crowley has. She cannot deny that she approved of those guidelines. She cannot deny that she bears responsibility for them, even though other people were the authors. That is why we have been treated to this tirade of name calling tonight.

I am reminded that during question time today Senator Crowley promised to give Senator Boswell some documents. I understand that Senator Boswell has rung Senator Crowley's office several times and not received those documents. The documents remain unforthcoming. That is the minister's responsibility. That is where the minister fails. That is why the minister is at fault in coming here and doing as she has done tonight: slurring the name of a good man, a man with integrity, a man with honesty and a man who has some passion and conviction about what he does.

I can say here and now that I could not consider the people I sit with to be anything other than the finest colleagues that a person could want in this chamber. Whilst the things that Senator Crowley said were totally unparliamentary, we did not interrupt her because she was clearly upset and we did not wish to prolong this debate any further. I could not let those slurs, those aspersions, on my colleague go without rebuttal because there is a place for honour and dignity in this chamber and I will work to preserve them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

(2) During the 1992-93 financial year, for week days and for weekends, what was the average: (a) number of calls to DAS which were disconnected prematurely by (i) the operator, and (ii) the caller; (b) number of calls to each DAS, between the hours of: (i) 12.01 a.m and 2.00 a.m., (ii) 2.01 a.m. and 4.00 a.m., (iii) 4.01 a.m. and 6.00 a.m., (iv) 6.01 a.m and 8.00 a.m., (v) 8.01 a.m. and 10.00 a.m, (vi) 10.01 a.m. and 12.00 noon, (vii) 12.01 p.m. and 2.00 p.m., (viii) 2.01 p.m. and 4.00 p.m, (ix) 4.01 p.m. and 6.00 p.m., (x) 6.01 p.m. and 8.00 p.m, (xi) 8.01 p.m. and 10.00 p.m., (xii) 10.01 p.m. and 12 midnight; and (c) number of calls requesting household and business numbers for each of: (i) 013 services, (ii) 0175 services, and (iii) any other and what DAS.

(3) (a) Are directory assistance operators required to provide a name to the caller on every occasion; if so, are there any, and what, exceptions to this rule; (b) what steps does Telecom take to ensure that operators provide a name to callers; (c) is it possible for Telecom to trace operators who did not provide a name to callers; and (d) what are the sanctions for operators who do not provide a name to callers.
(4) Has Telecom considered requiring operators to provide to the caller an identification number.

(5) Are there any, and what, limits placed on the nature and/or extent of information which will be provided in response to a single call to: (a) 013 services; (b) 0175 services; and (c) any other and what DAS.

(b) 0175—Telephone numbers for areas outside the local White Pages area from which the call is generated.
(c) 1139—Changed Number Information. If a customer's number has changed, there is a recorded voice announcement instructing the caller to ring 1139 for information on the number they are calling.
(2) (a), (b) & (c) This information is regarded as Commercial-in-Confidence
(3) (a) Operators are encouraged to provide a name to callers and most are doing so. However, the Communications Workers Union does not support the mandatory provision of operators' names to callers.

(c) No.
(d) None. See answer to 3(a).

(4) Yes. However, customer surveys indicated that customers prefer a name to be supplied rather than an identity number. Furthermore, the possible use of incorrect identity numbers by operators would be difficult to police.
Yes. Up to four listings are provided per call.
Note that no silent line numbers are released by operators.
(c) 1139—one listing per call.
0103—one listing per call.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell asked me without notice on 23 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many people actually work in the Minister's Department?
(2) What is the reason for the difference between the numbers of staff occupying office space advised in the answers to Questions on Notice 148 and 653?
(3) How many people are classified as longer term temporary staff, as mentioned in the answer to Question on Notice 653?
In the course of my answer to Senator Campbell, I undertook to confirm the precise numbers relating to the staffing of my Department. Accordingly, I provide the following information;

(1) At the end of June 1993, the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services employed 9,792 personnel being 9,689 full-time personnel and 103 part-time equivalents. At the end of June 1992, DAS employed 11,129 personnel being 10,996 full-time personnel and 133 part-time equivalents. This

ANSWER.PARA: is a reduction over the twelve month period of 1,337 employees. There is a difference between these figures and those contained in the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1992-93 owing to differing data sources and definitions. This has been discussed with the authors of the Bulletin (the Department of Finance) in order to reconcile the differing sources and definitions used.

PARA.TAB: (2) The difference between the staffing numbers identified in answers to Questions on Notice 148 and 653 arise from the inclusion in the answer to Question No. 653 of longer term temporary employees and corrections to earlier data, as well as the exclusion of certain employees not actually occupying office space. These changes were explained in the answer to Question No. 653 and in my answer to Senator Campbell's question without notice.

(3) At June 1993 there were 2,773 temporary employees in my Department. `Longer term temporary employees' are defined as personnel engaged under temporary arrangements, such as term contracts or consultancies, for periods exceeding several months. For the purposes of responding to Question No. 653, 222 such personnel were identified.
